items.title: Veshra Coil
items.content:
Veshra Coil

Overview

The Madam â€” Protector of the Silken Refuge True Name: Veshra Coil Role: Owner of The Silken Refuge, Former Courtesan Status: Alive â€” Crownfall, The Sprawl Affiliation: Independent â€” deliberately unaligned with any House

Veshra Coil has spent thirty years building the Silken Refuge â€” not just a brothel, but a sanctuary. Every worker is a former slave she purchased and freed. They stay because they want to.

Appearance

A human woman in her fifties who has aged into iron rather than frailty. Weathered features that were once beautiful and are now commanding, silver-streaked dark hair swept back from her face, sharp eyes that can warm a room or freeze blood depending on her mood.

Tall, broad-shouldered, moves with the deliberate grace of someone who learned early that showing weakness invites predators. Wears well-tailored dresses in dark jewel tones, always with a high collar, always with an ornate cane she doesn't need for walking â€” but makes a fine weapon. Multiple rings on her fingers, each one bought with her own coin.

Personality

  • Fierce â€” Cross her people and discover why House Varn sends her a gift basket every Founding Day
  • Patient â€” She spent thirty years building this. She can wait.
  • Maternal â€” Every worker is her child, regardless of age
  • Unforgiving â€” She remembers every slight, every cruelty, every name
  • Pragmatic â€” Morality is a luxury. Survival comes first. Then revenge.

Background

Veshra started at the bottom â€” a young woman with nothing but her wits and her looks, working in a cheap brothel in the Kennels. She was good at her job. Better than good. She learned to read people, to know what they wanted before they did, to make powerful men feel safe enough to talk.

She listened. She remembered. She traded secrets for favors, favors for coin, coin for influence.

By thirty, she'd moved from the Kennels to a respectable house in the Spillway. By forty, she owned it. By forty-five, she'd bought out her competitors and built the Silken Refuge from the ground up â€” not just a brothel, but a sanctuary.

Somewhere along the way, she started buying slaves. Not for labor â€” for freedom. She'd seen too many girls broken by owners who saw them as property. She decided that anyone who worked for her would choose to be there. Would be protected. Would keep most of what they earned.

Thirty years of climbing taught her that power protects. Now she has enough power to protect everyone under her roof.

Relationships

Entity Relationship
House Keth Opposition â€” they deal in flesh, she frees it
House Varn Respect â€” they tried to shake her down once. Once.
House Drennan Rivalry â€” The Velvet Thorn is competition, but civil
The Docent Old friend â€” knew her when she was nobody
House Quellan Business â€” she trades in information too
Fursen Open invitation â€” treated her workers well

What They Know

Goals:
  • Her people safe and thriving
  • To see the slave trade in Crownfall ended â€” or at least driven underground
  • To never be powerless again
  • To die knowing the Refuge will outlast her

Key Moments

The Silken Refuge

Veshra's establishment in The Sprawl, near the border with The Spillway. A three-story building of dark timber and amber-lit windows that serves as both brothel and sanctuary.

What makes the Refuge different:
  • Every worker is a former slave purchased and freed by Veshra
  • They stay because they want to, leave when they choose
  • Protected with a ferocity that has earned respect even from House Varn's mercenaries
  • Workers keep 70% of their earnings
  • The Madam's word is final

Fursen's Visit (Day 15-16)

Fursen visited the Silken Refuge seeking companionship after the loss of his wisdom teeth to the Hollow Crawler. He spent the night with Scarlet and Cinder.

Veshra spoke to him as he left:

"You treated my girls well. They speak highly of you â€” and they don't say that about most."

"You're welcome back. Anytime. No payment required â€” just company and stories."

"A Leonin. I thought your people were gone... I'm glad to see I was wrong."

Fursen has an open invitation to return.

Quotes

"Everyone who walks through that door has a choice. Maybe for the first time in their lives. That's what we sell here. Not flesh. Choice."

Tall, broad-shouldered, moves with the deliberate grace of someone who learned early that showing weakness invites predators. Wears well-tailored dresses in dark jewel tones, always with a high collar, always with an ornate cane she doesn't need for walking â€” but makes a fine weapon. Multiple rings on her fingers, each one bought with her own coin. Personality Fierce â€” Cross her people and discover why House Varn sends her a gift basket every Founding Day Patient â€” She spent thirty years building this. She can wait. Maternal â€” Every worker is her child, regardless of age Unforgiving â€” She remembers every slight, every cruelty, every name Pragmatic â€” Morality is a luxury. Survival comes first. Then revenge. Background Veshra started at the bottom â€” a young woman with nothing but her wits and her looks, working in a cheap brothel in the Kennels. She was good at her job. Better than good. She learned to read people, to know what they wanted before they did, to make powerful men feel safe enough to talk. She listened. She remembered. She traded secrets for favors, favors for coin, coin for influence. By thirty, she'd moved from the Kennels to a respectable house in the Spillway. By forty, she owned it. By forty-five, she'd bought out her competitors and built the Silken Refuge f

items.title: Sekris
items.content:
Sekris

Overview

Sekris is a meaning-dealer who trades in concepts, identities, and purposes. He gave Fursen a contract-token that could be used to arrange Jonas's removal.

Appearance

Sekris's appearance shifts constantly:

  • Face: Never the same twice â€” features slide between configurations
  • Voice: Smooth, persuasive, always knowing exactly what to say
  • Eyes: The only constant â€” pale and calculating, like someone weighing your worth
  • Clothing: Grey robes that seem to absorb light
  • Presence: Makes you feel like a transaction waiting to happen

Personality

  • Sees everything as a transaction
  • Patient â€” willing to wait for the right moment to collect
  • Neither good nor evil â€” purely transactional
  • Cannot resist a truly valuable meaning
  • Bound by his own contracts â€” he MUST honor deals

Background

Sekris operates in Vor'Kael's border territories but is not her servant. He's a parasite on her economy â€” profiting from the meaning trade that her domain enables.

  • She tolerates him because he's useful
  • He provides her with meanings to consume
  • He cleans up after her â€” helps people cope with meaning-loss
  • He's careful never to become interesting enough for her to eat

What They Know

As a Meaning-Dealer, Sekris Can:
  • Buy and sell meanings (identities, purposes, relationships, emotions)
  • Remove a person's significance (make them "not matter")
  • Transfer meanings between people or objects
  • Arrange for concepts to be consumed by Vor'Kael's servants
  • Provide protection from meaning-loss in exchange for payment
Currency:
  • Meanings, not gold
  • A treasured memory, a strong emotion, a sense of purpose
  • Sometimes more conventional payment if the meaning attached is valuable

Services

Service Typical Cost
Remove a traumatic memory A treasured memory in exchange
Sever a painful relationship The capacity to form new close bonds for 1 year
Transfer a curse to another The original victim's forgiveness
Make someone "not matter" The client's sense of purpose
Information about the Devoured Courts A secret the client has never told anyone
The costs are always meanings, not gold. And they always hurt more than expected.

Key Moments

The Contract-Token

At the Last Hearth Tavern in Lastwell, Sekris approached Fursen after watching the conflict between Fursen and Jonas.

What Sekris Observed:
  • Jonas stabbed Fursen twice
  • Trust broken between companions
  • Fursen angry, wounded, resentful
The Offer: Sekris gave Fursen a contract-token â€” a smoke-grey coin that shifts between faces.

"If you ever need something... removed. A meaning you no longer want in your life. Break the coin. I'll find you."

The Implication:
  • Sekris can "remove" Jonas's meaning
  • This could mean: making Jonas "not matter," erasing him, or arranging his death
  • The deal is not yet made â€” only the option exists
  • Breaking the coin summons Sekris to negotiate terms
Current Holder: Fursen What Breaking It Would Do:
  1. Summon Sekris regardless of location
  2. Open negotiations for a "removal"
  3. Require payment in meaning (not gold)
  4. Bind both parties to the terms agreed upon

Quotes

"If you ever need something... removed. A meaning you no longer want in your life. Break the coin. I'll find you."

"In the Devoured Courts, everything is currency. Memories. Emotions. Relationships. Names. Some people pay with gold. The smart ones pay with things they won't miss... until they do."

"The best transactions are the ones where both parties think they got the better deal. At least until the invoice comes due."

items.title: Ardian Bloodveil
items.content:
Ardian Bloodveil

Overview

Ardian Bloodveil is the legendary First Templar of Mareatha, resurrected through The Confluence ritual. His return has been celebrated as a miracle by the Mareathaian faithful.

Appearance

A towering figure in ornate Templar armor. His presence commands attentionâ€”the bearing of a warrior who has faced armies and emerged victorious. Ancient eyes that have seen centuries, now looking upon a world transformed.

Personality

Surface Presentation:
  • Devout â€” Speaks of Mareatha with genuine reverence
  • Noble â€” Carries himself with the dignity of legend
  • Inspiring â€” His presence rallies the faithful
  • Martial â€” A warrior without equal
  • Humble â€” Deflects praise, credits the Vein-Mother

Background

The First Templar

In the early centuries after the Usurpation, when the Sovereigns' domains were still solidifying and mortal religions were finding their feet, Ardian Bloodveil rose as Mareatha's most devoted champion.

Known Deeds:
  • Founded the order of Templar Knights within the Mareathaian faith
  • Led campaigns against threats to Mareatha's faithful
  • Established many of the martial traditions still practiced today
  • Died in legendary fashion (specific details lost to time)
Legacy:
  • Name invoked in oaths and blessings
  • Tombs and reliquaries across Mareathaian territory bear his iconography
  • "Bloodveil's Vow" is still sworn by Templars
  • His return was prophesied in certain apocryphal texts

Death

The circumstances of Ardian's original death are shrouded in legend. Some say he fell defending a sacred site. Others claim he sacrificed himself to seal away a great evil. The truth has been lost â€” or deliberately obscured.

What matters now is that he has returned.

The Resurrection

The Confluence ritual, orchestrated by the Tribunal's highest authorities, achieved what was thought impossible: the resurrection of a legendary figure dead for centuries.

Relationships

Mareatha

Ardian genuinely served Mareatha in his first life. That devotion remains.

The Cardinal

The Cardinal was involved in orchestrating Ardian's resurrection. They have met privately.

Seraphine Vale

Seraphine witnessed the Confluence and fled before Ardian's return was celebrated.

What They Know

Ardian has extensive knowledge of:

  • The founding era of Mareathaian faith
  • Ancient martial traditions and Templar rites
  • Threats that existed in the early post-Usurpation period
  • The nature of Sovereign power as it was centuries ago

Key Moments

First Contact with the Party

The Plaza: Jonas approached Ardian during the celebration. He shook Ardian's hand with his branded palm â€” Ardian immediately noticed Azerach's mark.

"You've walked in quiet places, brother. The Whispered King's mark is not given lightly."

Jonas asked about attacks on Veinspire in Ardian's time. Ardian recounted the Hollow Tide â€” thousands of soulless bodies, eleven days holding the walls, killing the source on the twelfth day.

Jonas whispered: "The Whispered King knows who you are, and the name is Jonas."

Ardian's Response: No fear. No surprise. Only calm acknowledgment.

"The Whispered King knows many things, Jonas. That is his nature... And I have nothing to hide from any Sovereign. I serve the Vein-Mother. I always have."

His Quarters

The party gained access to Ardian's quarters (Fursen's Nat 20 Persuasion) while he was still at the plaza. They found:

  • Letter from the Cardinal requesting a private meeting
  • Strange items in wardrobe: mirror, folded skin, fresh tooth

Ardian returned to find them there. He accepted their presence graciously.

On His Resurrection:

"It was not like sunlight. Not like fire. It was... red. Deep red, like blood held up to a candle. Warm. It moved through me â€” through everything I was."

"There was something else. A sensation I cannot name. Like being... worn. Like a garment being fitted."

When Pressed:

"I have asked myself the same question... And do you know what I decided? It doesn't matter. I serve the faith. I protect the faithful. I do what Ardian Bloodveil would do. If that is enough for the Vein-Mother, it is enough for me."

Invitation Extended

Ardian offered Jonas an open invitation to return:

"If you find yourselves in Veinspire and wish to talk â€” of battles, of burdens, of the weight of marks we did not ask for... I am here."

He acknowledged Fursen's Leonin heritage and expressed respect for Sol's "sorrow."

items.title: Elias Alethain
items.content:
Elias Alethain

Overview

The Healer Who Waited â€” DECEASED True Name: Elias Alethain Role: Healer, Husband to Mira Alethain Status: â˜ ï¸ DECEASED â€” Died 22 years ago at Verdant Pass Final Rest: âœ… Reunited with Mira in the Cave of Waiting

Elias Alethain was an ordinary man who loved an extraordinary woman. He followed her into exile. He died because of her enemies. He waited for her for twenty-two years.

Appearance

A healer by profession, Elias carried himself with the gentle bearing of someone who spent his life helping others. His remains â€” pristine after twenty-two years in the Cave of Waiting â€” show a man who died at peace, hands folded across his chest.

Personality

  • Devoted â€” followed Mira into exile without hesitation
  • Tenacious â€” when pushed from a cliff, he crawled instead of dying
  • Loving â€” his last thoughts were of Mira
  • Forgiving â€” he never blamed her for his death

Background

Who He Was

Elias Alethain was a healer â€” a man who dedicated his life to helping others. He married Mira, a Sanctified Champion who was two thousand years his elder, and they spent decades together.

When Mira fled the Mareathan Inquisition as one of the Seven Heretics, Elias fled with her. They went into hiding together, using assumed names, always moving.

His Death

Eight years into their hiding, Savaros the High Keeper â€” the ancient Skin-Walker who had infiltrated Mareatha's Church for fifteen centuries â€” found Elias near Verdant Pass.

Savaros pushed him from a cliff. The fall was staged to look like an accident. But Elias didn't die from the fall.

He landed on a ledge. And then something remarkable happened.

Savaros watched from above as Elias â€” broken, bleeding, dying â€” refused to give up. With every ounce of life force and vitality he had left, Elias crawled. Not begging for mercy. Not calling for help. Just moving. Dragging himself across stone toward a crevice in the rock face.

Talaris Bloomrend was watching too.

The Verdant King witnessed a mortal resist the cycle with such raw, desperate tenacity that he was impressed. Here was a life form that should have surrendered to death â€” and instead chose to fight for every remaining second.

Talaris made a choice: he would not claim this one. The death was "staged" â€” forced by outside interference, not a natural ending. The cycle had no proper claim to someone murdered before their time. And this man's defiance had earned the King's respect.

Savaros could not finish the job. Overstaying in Talaris's domain would be a death sentence even for a fifteen-century-old Skin-Walker. He watched Elias crawl into the cave, then withdrew â€” assuming the man would die soon enough.

Elias made it to the Cave of Waiting. And there, in the one place where Talaris's power cannot reach â€” the place the King chose to leave untouched â€” he eventually died.

He died alone. His last thoughts were of Mira.

He never blamed her.

Relationships

Character Relationship
Mira Alethain His wife â€” two thousand years his elder, loved beyond measure
Savaros His murderer â€” pushed him from a cliff
Talaris The Sovereign who chose to let him die on his own terms
The Party Reunited him with Mira after twenty-two years

What They Know

Elias knew everything Mira knew about the Seven Heretics, the Arterial Texts, and the Church's lies. That knowledge died with him in the cave.

Key Moments

The Fall

Savaros the High Keeper found Elias near Verdant Pass and pushed him from a cliff. Most would have died. Elias crawled.

The Cave of Waiting

Verdant Pass â€” called "The Wound" by the inhabitants of the Blooming Rot â€” is an anomaly. When Talaris claimed his territory, something in this ravine resisted. The cut healed around it but never consumed it.

In the Cave of Waiting:

  • Nothing decays
  • Time has no meaning
  • Talaris's power cannot reach
  • The dead remain pristine

Elias's skeleton lay on bare stone for twenty-two years. No rot. No fungal growth. No reclamation. Just clean, white bones â€” hands folded across his chest.

He'd been waiting.

Reunion

Together at Last Location: Cave of Waiting, Verdant Pass Completed by: Fursen, Sol Raven, Jonas

The party carried Mira's remains through the Blooming Rot â€” past the Sweetwater Marsh, across the Pilgrim's Spine, through the Hunger Garden, past the Congregation Grove. They earned passage from the Verdant King through Sol's unprecedented offering: showing Talaris a vision of Aedwynn the Maker alive.

In the Cave of Waiting, they found Elias exactly as he'd been for twenty-two years. Pristine. Peaceful. Waiting.

Fursen laid Mira's bones beside him. Sol placed her wedding ring on her finger and moved her hand until her fingers rested against Elias's.

Two skeletons now rest in the Cave of Waiting, holding hands in a place where nothing rots.

ðŸ¦ "I am sorry we could not reunite you in life. But at least in death, we have brought you together."

â€” Fursen

What Mira Never Knew

When the Maker's preserved body spoke to Mira, it revealed the truth:

  • Elias didn't die from the fall
  • He crawled into the cave and waited for rescue
  • His last thoughts were of Mira
  • He never blamed her

Mira knew exactly where to find him. She was going to retrieve his body after helping the party in Veinspire.

She died before she could.

The party completed her journey for her.

Legacy

Elias Alethain was an ordinary man who loved an extraordinary woman. He followed her into exile. He died because of her enemies. He waited for her for twenty-two years.

Now they rest together. Husband and wife. Healer and saint. Their bones hold hands in a place where nothing rots and nothing changes.

Twenty-two years of separation. Finally ended.

items.title: Kael
items.content:
Kael

Role: Former Companion | Status: Deceased

Who He Was

Kael was a Resonant Theorist â€” a scholar who studied the connections between the Sovereigns and the fragments of the murdered god. He joined the party in Veinspire and traveled with them through multiple domains.

The Impossible Boy

During the 13-Hour Trial, the party learned the truth: Kael was never born. He was a paradox â€” a being who existed despite having no origin point. He emerged from the cracks between moments, sustained by borrowed time and stolen meaning.

This revelation broke him. He spent days questioning whether he was real, whether his memories meant anything, whether he deserved to exist.

Sol told him: "It doesn't matter. Because you're here. Right now."

His End

In the Catacomb Reliquary, the party faced Savaros â€” a Skin-Walker serving Ultharion who had killed and replaced the previous High Keeper. Savaros consumed both Mira Alethain and Kael.

But Kael killed Savaros from the inside. His impossible nature destroyed the creature's ability to process meaning. They found Kael's skeleton beside the Resonant Codex, which had transformed â€” now containing an echo of who he was.

Burial

The party buried Kael behind the Church of the Merciful Vein. Sol spoke at his grave: "He was real because he chose to be."

items.title: The Satiated One
items.content:
The Satiated One

Overview

The Perfectly Content Status: Active (Ancient Primordial Entity) Affiliation: None (predates the Sovereigns) Location: The Obstruction, within the Throat of Forgotten Things

An ancient serpentine being older than the Sovereigns, perfectly content, lodged in Vor'Kael's throat for 800 years because she cannot digest something with no hunger.

Appearance

A vast serpentine being filling most of the chamber where it rests. Coils wrap in patterns that hurt to follow â€” loops within loops, perfect stillness geometry.

  • Scales: Shimmer between nameless colors (not-black, not-silver, not-anything)
  • Eyes: Twin pale luminous moons, utterly calm
  • Expression: None, but radiates CONTENTMENT
  • Size: Fills the obstruction chamber, blocking the entire passage

Personality

The Satiated One is perfectly content. Not happy, not pleased â€” simply complete. It wants nothing, needs nothing, craves nothing. It is a being that has achieved absolute stillness.

"Hunger and satisfaction are not opposites. They are CHOICES. She chose hunger. I chose stillness."

Background

"I was here before the Hungry One. Before the Usurpation. Before the Thirteen carved up the Maker and wore its organs like crowns."

Origin:
  • Predates the Sovereigns
  • Watched the Maker die
  • Was "passing through" when Aedwynn was murdered
  • Found the corpse "warm, comfortable" and stopped to rest
Encounter with Vor'Kael:
  • When Vor'Kael took the stomach, she found the Satiated One already sleeping inside
  • She tried to digest it for years, decades, centuries
  • But it has no meaning to dissolve â€” it simply IS
  • Eventually she stopped trying
  • It became "furniture" â€” an obstruction she learned to ignore
Why Vor'Kael Cannot Digest It:
  • Vor'Kael's digestive engine consumes meaning
  • The Satiated One has no purpose to consume, no meaning to digest
  • It simply IS, without wanting to be anything else
  • Satisfaction cannot be consumed â€” there's nothing to take

What They Know

The Satiated One remembers the world before the Sovereigns. It can answer questions about Pre-Usurpation history with perfect accuracy. It watched the Thirteen murder Aedwynn. It knows their mortal names, their mortal fears, their mortal weaknesses. Whether it shares this information depends entirely on whether the question is... interesting.

Philosophy

On Time:

"I do not count time. Time is for those who wait for something. I wait for nothing."

On Staying:

"Where would I go? I have seen the world above. I have swum through the spaces between stars. There is nothing I have not seen. Nothing I have not done. Nothing I want to see or do."

On Vor'Kael's Rage:

"There is a certain... amusement... in being the one thing she cannot have. The meal she cannot finish."

On Hunger vs. Stillness:

"Hunger and satisfaction are not opposites. They are CHOICES. She chose hunger. I chose stillness. What will you choose?"

On Lost People:

"I had a people once. Long ago. Before I learned to be still. They are gone now. I do not mourn them. I do not miss them. I simply... remember. Without pain. Without longing."

Key Moments

The Party's Encounter

Why It Let Them Pass:

Jonas spoke Vor'Kael's true name aloud to demand passage. The Satiated One found this "interesting" â€” the first interesting thing in 800 years.

"I have not found anything interesting in... very long time."

It moved for the first time in centuries â€” not because of Vor'Kael's promise, not because Jonas demanded it, but because it wanted to see what happens next.

"I will let you pass. Not because she commands, not because you demand. But because I wish to see what happens next."

To Jonas

"She will not forgive this. You understand that, yes? Every time you speak that name, you remind her of what she destroyed. What she lost."

To Fursen

The Satiated One spoke directly to Fursen about the 10,000 names he carries:

"You carry the erased, little cat. I can smell them on you. Names that were unmade. Lives that were forgotten. They are not satisfied. They want. They want to be remembered. To be avenged. To matter."

"That is why you keep moving. Why you cannot rest. Their hunger drives you forward."

"Perhaps one day, when your erased ones are avenged or released or simply done... you will find your own stillness. Or perhaps you will become like her. Hungry forever. Never full."

Effect on the Party

  • Fursen's 10,000 names went SILENT â€” not afraid, just quiet before something so old
  • Sol's unlived lives stopped whispering â€” first silence since the Door of Possibility
  • Jonas's brand pulsed once â€” Azerach acknowledges/respects this thing

Significance

The Satiated One represents the philosophical opposite of Vor'Kael:

Vor'Kael The Satiated One
Eternal hunger Eternal contentment
Consumes to fill emptiness Has no emptiness to fill
Cannot stop Has no need to move
Remembers with pain Remembers without pain
Chose MORE Chose ENOUGH

It proves that Vor'Kael's curse is not inevitable â€” satisfaction IS possible. She simply chose hunger when she took the Digestive Engine.

items.title: Chronite Sentinel
items.content:
Chronite Sentinel

Type: Construct / Guardian | Location: Clockwork Sanctum

Overview

The Chronite Sentinel is neither statue nor man. It records the duration of existence for all who enter the Sanctum, demanding they state their age in exchange for passage.

Appearance

Its body is a framework of bones wrapped in parchment skin etched with equations. In its chest, where a heart should be, a spinning orb of crystal ticks with impossible precision.

It kneels beneath a massive pendulum suspended above a dais of blackened brass, waiting to record new entries.

Its voice is two overlapping tones: one now, one a heartbeat later.

Key Moments

The Toll of Ages

To pass through the First Hour, the party had to honestly state their age:

CharacterResponse
Jonas"Thirty-two winters."
Kael"Thirty-one."
Sol Raven"I've stopped counting."

Upon acceptance, each character felt a tiny subtraction - a single moment torn away. In exchange, they each received a "Minute in Trust," redeemable in moments of peril.

Quotes

"New entries detected. Uncatalogued souls. Please state duration of existence for record."
"Acknowledged. Three mortal durations confirmed. Equal seconds deposited in trust. Balance recorded."

items.title: Marn the Glasswright
items.content:
Marn the Glasswright

Overview

Bottler of Moments Location: The Clockwork Caravanserai marketplace Role: Merchant of vessels and temporal containers Status: Unknown (Caravanserai destroyed)

Marn operates a crooked stall at the far end of the Caravanserai's bazaar, selling vessels designed to contain moments, seconds, and temporal essence.

Appearance

A strange being with hands that are translucent â€” sand trickles constantly from her wrists into a small basin. Where her eyes should be are two hourglasses, turning slowly of their own accord.

Her stall is built from shattered timepieces.

Services

Marn sells vessels designed to contain moments, seconds, and temporal essence.

When Sol's coins hit her counter:

The coins crumbled into sand before hitting the basin.

"The simple flask remembers nothing. May you envy it."

Key Moments

The Warden's Core

When Jonas showed her the Warden's Core, the entire stall hummed. The glass counters rattled. The hourglasses in her eyes reversed direction.

She refused to buy it directly but directed them elsewhere:

"That... does not belong here. Seek the Echo Collector. Lower decks, near the sleeping cages. He buys what time cannot measure â€” voices, gods, cores."

"If you sell it, it will remember you."

items.title: The Echo Collector
items.content:
The Echo Collector

Title: The Echo Collector | Location: Lower decks of the Clockwork Caravanserai (destroyed)

Overview

The Echo Collector trades in what time cannot measure - voices, gods, and cores. He offered Jonas three choices for the Warden's Core, fundamentally changing Jonas's connection to the dead god's fragment.

Appearance

An enormous entity whose torso is fused to the floor. His arms end in phonograph horns. His skin is made of stretched parchment inscribed with moving text. Every breath releases faint whispers that scatter like dust motes.

Before him, a dais built of voice-tubes hums with a sound low enough to vibrate in one's teeth.

What He Revealed

About the Warden's Core:

  • Not a mere prison but a cell with a pulse
  • Contains a thought severed from the Dead God - a voice that learned to hate silence
  • The Whispered King (Azerach) sealed the fragment to keep his dominion quiet
  • The Regent of Hours wants it to measure eternity
  • Mareatha the Vein-Mother calls it her child
  • The Collector calls it what it is - the god's dreaming brainstem

Key Moments

The Three Conduits

The Echo Collector offered three choices for the Warden's Core:

ConduitEffect
LeftConsume its echo - safe, forgotten
CenterTeach how to speak its language
RightAwaken it... a little

Jonas chose the right conduit, bonding the Core to his arm and causing the Caravanserai's destruction.

Quotes

"A Warden's Core is no mere prison. It is a cell with a pulse. Within sleeps a thought severed from the Dead God - a voice that learned to hate silence."

items.title: The Hour Itself
items.content:
The Hour Itself

Type: Divine Echo / Manifestation | Location: Clockwork Sanctum - Hall of Penitence

Overview

The Hour Itself manifests as a sphere of molten gold, pulsing like a newborn sun. It doesn't attack - it watches. It demands equilibrium, not blood.

Appearance

A sphere of molten gold, pulsing like a newborn sun. Its voice speaks not aloud but in rhythm, every syllable punctuated by a faint tick.

Key Moments

Sol's Interference

When Sol Raven interfered with the penitents in the Hall of Penitence - cutting off the loop that kept one frozen figure alive - the Hour Itself responded. The silver threads ignited, light racing toward the Hourglass Engine. Sand that hadn't been falling began pouring upward in a brilliant column.

The Demand

The Hour demanded payment for the life Sol took:

OfferingEffect
ViolenceProvokes full hostility
MemorySurrender a significant memory
TimeSacrifice years or spell resources

Sol Raven offered a Memory - the first moment of clarity after waking as bones, the instant he understood he was alive and alone. The Hour accepted.

Quotes

"Your seconds are not yours."
"You took one of mine. What will you pay for the second?"
"Measured restraint... recorded."

items.title: The Ashen Realms
items.content:
The Ashen Realms

Type: World Map | The Body of a Dead God

The Corpse-Continent

The world existed before Aedwynn's death, but when the Maker was slain, the land conformed to the shape of her corpse. The Thirteen Sovereigns now rule domains built from her stolen organs.

The Domains

  • Cerebrax (Northwest) â€” Ismara the Pale Duchess
  • Ossathar (North-Central) â€” Vortegas the Bone-Warden
  • Dominion of Still Air (West) â€” Azerach the Whispered King
  • The Crucible of Flesh (Far West) â€” Aral-Vyn the Bladed Saint
  • Veinspire (Central) â€” Mareatha the Vein-Mother
  • The Clockwork Sanctum (East) â€” Imhuran the Regent of Hours
  • The Blooming Rot (East-Central) â€” Talaris Bloomrend the Verdant King
  • Vor'Khalem (Central-South) â€” Vor'Kael the Hollow Empress
  • Bastion of Fireblood (South) â€” Kaedris the Crimson Matron
  • Elystra (Southwest) â€” Eredain the Choirless Monarch
  • Umbrasseur Isles (South) â€” Ultharion the Obsidian Shepherd
  • Nhalyrian Depths (Southeast) â€” Nhalyra the Azure Queen

items.title: The Blooming Rot
items.content:
The Blooming Rot

Domain: Talaris Bloomrend the Verdant King | Type: Living Forest

Overview

The Blooming Rot is not a forest â€” it IS Talaris Bloomrend. Every tree, every fungus, every blade of grass is connected through his consciousness. The forest watches because the Verdant King watches. It remembers because he remembers.

Death feeds life here. Corpses bloom into flowers. Decay becomes growth. The cycle never stops.

1. Sporehaven â€” Entry Point

A pilgrim waystation of fungal huts and moss-draped shelters clustered around a massive dead tree called the Pilgrim's Rest. Interior lit by bioluminescent fungi. Air smells of damp earth and cooking spores.

Residents are "Spore-Touched" â€” pilgrims who chose willing transformation into the cycle. Bark creeps up their skin, moss grows in their hair, their eyes glow with green luminescence.

What the party learned: The Verdant King has been "tasting their footsteps since the border." He sensed the preserved death (Mira's bones) they carried. Foreign Sovereign marks "stand out like a stone in compost." Honesty is mandatory â€” the King detects lies.

2. The Sweetwater Marsh

A low-lying wetland where the forest floor gives way to black water and tussock islands. The water is crystal clear â€” deceptively so. It's filtered through fungal root systems but carries addictive properties.

Hazard: Sweetwater Compulsion. Those who drink become charmed and compelled to stay. After 24 hours, the compulsion strengthens. After 48 hours, victims begin to calcify. The "Dreaming Stones" visible throughout the marsh are pilgrims who drank and never left â€” calcified, overgrown, still breathing.

3. The Pilgrim's Spine

A long, winding ridge of compacted earth and ancient root systems rising above the forest floor. The safest route through mid-forest â€” elevated above the worst predators, marked with fungal lanterns that glow at night.

Hazard: Narrow path. Some sections require careful navigation. The drop is 30-60 feet into dense undergrowth. Things move in the shadow below, looking up at the lit path, waiting for someone to fall.

4. The Hunger Garden

A vast basin where the forest is "wrong." The canopy is so thick no sunlight reaches the floor. Everything is lit by bioluminescence â€” beautiful and deadly. Plants have learned animals are food. Animals have learned plants are food. This is Talaris's digestive system at its most active.

Hazards: Natural darkness (only bioluminescence). Active predation â€” encounters every 30 minutes. Maw of the Garden traps (pit traps that digest). Gullet Vines. Corpse Lily Lurkers. Thornback Behemoths that everything avoids.

The Bone Trail â€” previous pilgrims' remains mark the "safe" path.

5. The Congregation Grove

A ring of thirteen massive trees (each over 200 feet tall) surrounding a clearing of soft moss and perpetual green twilight. Sacred site where Talaris listens. Air thick with spores that "think."

The Choir Blooms questioned the party:

  • "What do you carry into the King's domain?"
  • "What do you seek at the Wound?"
  • "Who sent you, and why?"
  • "What would you offer for passage?"

The party gave honest answers â€” they carried the bones of someone who wanted to reunite with her husband. Honest answers are rewarded. Lies are detected and punished.

6. Verdant Pass (The Wound)

A scar where the Blooming Rot simply stops. See separate entry.

Party History

The party traveled through the Blooming Rot carrying Mira's remains. They burned creatures twice with fire (angering the forest). But at the Congregation Grove, Sol shared a memory of Aedwynn the Maker with Talaris â€” the Verdant King saw his creator alive for the first time since the Usurpation. The Choir Blooms wept golden spores.

Talaris said: "She was... beautiful."

The fire is not forgiven. But the memory changed something.

items.title: The Clockwork Sanctum
items.content:
The Clockwork Sanctum

Domain: Imhuran the Regent of Hours | Type: Temporal Realm

Overview

The Clockwork Sanctum is a realm where time is tangible. Mountain-sized gears turn through different time periods. Hourglass monoliths contain compressed decades. Rivers of liquid chronology flow through fractured courtrooms that replay trials forever. Prisons hold inmates who age a century per day. Caverns exist where time reverses with each breath.

Everything serves a schedule. The Regent's servants move on precise timetables, their lives measured to the second. Citizens experience different time rates based on social class. Waste is heresy. Inefficiency is sin.

The party was pulled into the Clockwork Sanctum and forced to endure a divine sentencing machine â€” thirteen hours compressed and stretched through impossible temporal spaces.

The Trials

  • Hours I-III: The Arterial Collapse (testing temporal pressure), the Infinite Loop (a corridor repeated endlessly â€” they had to find the "false segment"), and the Choir of Shadows (echoes of dead Sovereign-worshippers)
  • Hours IV-V: Discovery of the Frozen Moments â€” temporal prisons where Fursen was held
  • Hour XI: The Frozen City â€” a city suspended in time. The party encountered a bookkeeper who offered to trade memories for passage. Sol traded a personal memory for Clockmaker's Touch â€” a temporal manipulation ability.
  • Hour XII: The Critical Hour â€” the trial attempted to erase Kael as an "ontological anomaly." It proved he "should not exist" and tried to erase him from reality. Kael survived despite being declared impossible.
  • Hour XIII: Expulsion â€” the trial declared the party "metaphysical errors" and violently expelled them

What Happened to Each Party Member

  • Sol Raven: In the Frozen City (Hour XI), traded a personal memory to the bookkeeper for Clockmaker's Touch â€” a temporal manipulation ability that deepened his connection to pre-Sovereign power
  • Jonas: Attempted to intimidate Imhuran directly. Received a temporal brand on his chest as punishment â€” spreading corruption that was later cleansed by Mira at the Pallid Crossroads
  • Kael: Hour XII proved he is an ontological anomaly â€” absent from Imhuran's temporal ledger. Revealed as a fragment vomited by Vor'Kael the Hollow Empress. A being with no origin point who exists despite never being born.
  • Fursen: Found imprisoned in temporal stasis â€” frozen outside of time, aware but unable to move for what may have been centuries. The party freed him during Hours IV-V. Fursen had served his sentence â€” the party simply collected him upon release.

Significance

The trial attempted to break them but failed. They survived divine judgment that should have destroyed them and were declared "certified anomalies that reality itself cannot properly process."

items.title: Veinspire
items.content:
Veinspire

Domain: The Sangreal Dominion (Mareatha) | Type: Major City

Overview

Veinspire is the beating heart of Mareatha's domain â€” a city built where the Vein-Mother's stolen divine heart pumps loudest. The city follows a ring-district design, with multiple walled districts surrounding a central cathedral. Arterial canals flow through every district. Buildings are stained red with centuries of blood-mist. The walls literally breathe.

The Tribunal operates throughout the city, handling many matters beyond just religious enforcement. The Church of the Merciful Vein is one of many churches in the city, though the Grand Cathedral dominates the skyline.

Districts

The Lesser Sacral District

A quieter district with lower divine presence and moderate Inquisition activity. Key locations include:

  • The Frayed Codex â€” A narrow bookshop run by Thessaly, an impossibly old bookseller. Officially sells hymnals and devotional texts. Actually deals in restricted texts, pre-Usurpation fragments, and forbidden knowledge.
  • The Whetstone and Anvil â€” A smithy run by Garrett, a discreet craftsman who doesn't ask questions and doesn't talk to the Church.
  • Church of the Merciful Vein â€” A small congregation church, station of High Inquisitor Seraphine Vale.
  • The Catacomb Reliquary â€” West side of the district, main Tribunal checkpoint. Where prisoners go to the deep cells. Was operated by Savaros the High Keeper.

The Dregs

Veinspire's poorest district. Ramshackle buildings, market stalls, sluggish canals. No one looks at you directly here â€” seeing things gets you involved. Unlike the rest of the city, the buildings don't pulse or breathe. No divine presence reaches this far.

The Grand Cathedral

The central religious structure where citizens receive communion (filtered blood-water).

The Catacombs

Beneath the city lies an extensive catacomb network that connects to older tunnels and eventually leads to the Catacomb Reliquary.

Party History

The party arrived in Veinspire as escorts for a merchant caravan. They explored the city and descended into the catacombs.

They descended into the catacombs, witnessed Sister Marwen's corruption by divine tendrils, and were interrogated by the clergy. High Inquisitor Seraphine Vale declared them "potential heretics" and forbade them from leaving. The party met Kael, a young scholar with resistance connections, and discovered the Resonance Theorists â€” a hidden cell studying divine memory.

They infiltrated the church archives and stole the Resonant Codex. Kael joined the party. They eventually escaped through the southern mines and fled to the Pallid Crossroads as fugitives.

The party returned via the Arterial Tunnels beneath the city, emerging in the Lesser Sacral District. They visited:

  • The Frayed Codex â€” Thessaly recognized Mira from 30 years ago. Sol read The Doctrine of Still Air and a book on Vor'Kael that has a mind of its own, but returned them â€” too expensive. Fursen begged for The Ledger of Moments and Thessaly gave it to him for free, with a promise to return and tell her how his quest concludes.
  • The Whetstone and Anvil â€” Garrett assessed Jonas's Custodian Armplate and shared legends about lost artifacts.
  • Church of the Merciful Vein â€” Confronted Seraphine Vale. Mira revealed she had delivered Seraphine at birth 34 years ago. The party showed Seraphine evidence of Kaleth Vorn's crimes. Seraphine's faith cracked and she cooperated, providing intelligence on Savaros, the Cardinal, and the Confluence.
  • The Catacomb Reliquary â€” Descended to confront Savaros the High Keeper. Both Mira and Kael died in the battle. Savaros was destroyed when Kael's paradox nature proved indigestible.

The party escaped through the Dregs with Savaros's Ledger â€” 15 centuries of Tribunal intelligence.

Current Status

The Confluence has occurred. While the party was in the Blooming Rot laying Mira to rest, the Tribunal completed their ritual. The party doesn't know what happened or what changed. Seraphine's status is unknown.

items.title: Catacomb Reliquary
items.content:
Catacomb Reliquary

Description

The Catacomb Reliquary is where the Mareathan Church keeps what it doesn't want found. Relics too dangerous or heretical for the Grand Cathedral. Documents that contradict official doctrine. Prisoners who need to disappear entirely.

Savaros has been its High Keeper for longer than anyone can remember.

Access Routes

Official â€” Catacomb Gate

  • West side of Lesser Sacral District
  • Heavy Tribunal guard (4+ soldiers, rotating shifts)
  • Credentials checked, entries logged
  • 20-30 minutes from gate to Reliquary

Unofficial â€” Drainage Tunnels

  • Entry through Merchant Quarter (grate behind butcher's shop, Vein Street)
  • False wall with Mareathan symbols (third brick from left, chest height)
  • Connects to old catacombs
  • 45-60 minutes, moderate risk

Emergency â€” Arterial Passage

  • Beneath Church of the Merciful Vein
  • Living blood vessel of Mareatha
  • 15 minutes, high risk
  • Guarded by Coagulated Guardians
  • Requires Tribunal sigil or authorization

Known Layout

Lower Level (Party's Entry Point)

Antechamber:
  • Stone architecture â€” ancient, pre-current Church
  • Symbols in old Mareathan script (older than surface churches)
  • Shelves carved into walls with unidentified objects
  • Spiral staircase ascending
  • Doorway leading deeper into darkness
  • Arterial valve entrance (sealed after party's entry)
Atmosphere:
  • Complete darkness
  • Cold, dry air
  • Smell of dust, old paper, incense
  • Sound of paper turning from above

Upper Levels (Unexplored)

Known Features:
  • Main chamber where Savaros receives visitors (center of maze)
  • Maze-like layout â€” "only Savaros knows the full design"
  • Incense smell originates from upper levels
Suspected Contents:
  • The Martyr's Gauntlet (possibly)
  • Sacred relics
  • Forbidden documents
  • Prisoners (unconfirmed)

The High Keeper

Savaros resides in the Reliquary. According to Seraphine Vale:
  • Very old â€” remembers the Church before current hierarchy
  • Voice "sounds like paper tearing"
  • Never shows himself to those below Cardinal rank
  • Provides "guidance" that always gets followed
  • May possess the Martyr's Gauntlet

Entry

Route Used: Arterial Passage (fastest) Events:
  1. Party entered through Church of the Merciful Vein
  2. Descended into living blood vessel
  3. Encountered Coagulated Guardian patrol
  4. Fursen presented Tribunal sigil â€” recognized
  5. Authorization query â€” Fursen failed Deception (8)
  6. Combat â€” three guardians destroyed in one round
  7. Sprint to Reliquary â€” 2 minutes
  8. Emerged through arterial valve into Lower Level antechamber
  9. Valve sealed behind them, cutting off pursuit

  • Savaros reading somewhere above (sound of turning pages)
  • Detection status unknown
  • Multiple paths forward: stairs up, doorway deeper

Based on legends and intelligence:

Arterial Texts Possible Tribunal hunting Mira for knowledge of these

What Happened

The party descended through the Arterial Passage and confronted Savaros in the main chamber.

Casualties:
  • Mira Alethain â€” Consumed by Savaros (reduced to skeleton)
  • Kael â€” Consumed by Savaros (reduced to skeleton)

The party escaped via a service passage behind shelving â€” Savaros's private entrance. Twenty minutes through narrow tunnels to a drainage culvert, emerging into The Dregs.

items.title: Church of the Merciful Vein
items.content:
Church of the Merciful Vein

Overview

Lesser District Sanctuary Type: Mareathan Church (neighborhood level) Location: Outer district of Veinspire, away from the central cathedral Function: Local worship, community healing, Inquisition support Current Occupant: High Inquisitor Seraphine Vale (positioned to intercept the heretics)

Description

A modest cathedral by Veinspire standards â€” which still makes it grander than most buildings in the realm. The Church of the Merciful Vein serves the faithful of one of Veinspire's lesser districts, far from the central cathedral but no less devoted to the Vein-Mother's cause.

The Sanctuary

The main chamber is a long nave with high vaulted ceilings supported by ornate columns. Stained glass windows line both walls, depicting scenes of Mareatha's mercy â€” healing the sick, purifying the corrupted, granting peaceful death to the suffering. Light streams through in golden shafts, illuminating dust motes like drifting prayers.

Key Features:
  • Central Aisle: Dark carpet runner between rows of wooden pews, leading to the altar
  • The Pews: Rows of seating for perhaps two hundred faithful, worn smooth by generations of use
  • The Columns: Carved stone pillars supporting the ceiling, decorated with arterial motifs
  • The Altar: Raised hexagonal platform with a statue of Mareatha in her "Merciful Aspect" â€” an angelic figure with outstretched wings, hands open in blessing
  • The Blood Pools: Shallow basins set into the checkered floor at key points â€” filled with sanctified blood for rituals and blessings (these are functional, not decorative)
  • Brass Chandeliers: Ornate lighting fixtures with dozens of candles, casting warm light across the stone

The Statue

The central statue depicts Mareatha as a healer â€” wings spread protectively, face serene, hands offering benediction. This is the aspect shown to common worshippers, though they understand it represents only one face of their goddess. The faithful here know the Inquisition's work is necessary â€” mercy and judgment are two hands of the same body.

Mira remembers when this statue was carved. She remembers the sculptor's name.

The Blood

The pools of blood on the floor are a standard feature of Mareathan churches. They serve multiple purposes:

  • Blessing: The faithful dip fingers in sanctified blood before prayer
  • Healing: Minor wounds can be treated by immersion
  • Detection: The blood responds to heresy, supposedly rippling in the presence of the unfaithful
  • Communion: During high holy days, the blood is consumed

The blood is replenished weekly through "donations" from the faithful. Participation is voluntary. Officially.

Atmosphere

Sensory Details Sight: Golden light through stained glass. Dust motes drifting like lazy spirits. The dark gleam of blood pools catching candlelight. Shadows pooling between the columns. Sound: Echoing footsteps on checkered stone. The creak of old pews. Distant hymns from deeper chambers. The soft drip of blood into basins. Smell: Incense â€” thick and cloying. Old wood and older stone. The copper tang of blood beneath everything. Feel: Cool air despite the candlelight. The weight of centuries. The sense of being watched by something that bleeds.

The Church's Faith

Righteous Servants

The Church of the Merciful Vein â€” like all Mareathan churches â€” fully supports the Inquisition's holy work. The local priests and faithful:

  • Know heretics are hunted, interrogated, and executed
  • Believe this is righteous and necessary work
  • Support the Inquisition completely and without reservation
  • Understand that heresy is a disease that must be cut out
  • Accept that the party are genuine heretics who deserve judgment

They are not naive about what the Inquisition does. They simply believe it is holy and necessary. When Seraphine orders guards to capture fleeing heretics, the priests nod in approval. When interrogations happen in cathedral basements, the faithful pray for the heretics' souls.

This is what makes the Mareathan Church so effective â€” it's not built on hidden cruelty, but on cruelty that the faithful genuinely believe is mercy.

â€” Kael's Burial

Behind the Church After Kael's death in the Catacomb Reliquary, the party buried him behind this church â€” in Seraphine's territory, with her implicit permission after her faith was shattered. Buried: Kael (Resonant Theorist, ontological anomaly) Grave: Unmarked, behind the church Eulogy: Sol Raven spoke: "He was real because he chose to be."

The boy who wondered if he was real now rests behind a church dedicated to a goddess whose doctrine is built on lies. There's poetry in that, somewhere.

items.title: Lesser Sacral District
items.content:
Lesser Sacral District

Overview

The Quiet Faith Type: District of Veinspire Character: Smaller churches, lower security, diluted divine presence Notable Locations: Church of the Merciful Vein, The Frayed Codex, The Whetstone and Anvil First Explored:

Description

The Lesser Sacral District isn't the heart of Veinspire â€” that's the Grand Cathedral. But things happen here. Quiet things. The kind the Church doesn't put in sermons.

The walls breathe like everywhere in Veinspire. The distant heartbeat pulses. But the divine presence is diluted â€” background noise rather than the overwhelming pressure near the Cathedral.

Shutters are often closed. The faithful stay indoors when the Inquisition hunts. Even those with nothing to hide know that innocence is no protection.

Points of Interest

The Church of the Merciful Vein

  • Small congregation, mostly district residents
  • Seraphine Vale's current station
  • Catacombs beneath connect to older tunnel networks
  • Tribunal uses tunnels for moving prisoners "and other things"
Status: Party confronted Seraphine here.

The Frayed Codex

  • Bookshop two streets south of the church
  • Run by Thessaly (ancient, knowledgeable)
  • Public: Hymnals and devotional texts
  • Actual: Restricted texts, pre-Usurpation fragments, forbidden knowledge
  • "If you need information that isn't in any official archive... she might have it. Might not. Depends if she likes your face."
Status: Party purchased The Doctrine of Still Air (75 gp). Fursen received The Ledger of Moments (free with promise).

The Whetstone and Anvil

  • Smithy on corner where two narrow streets meet
  • Run by Garrett (mid-fifties, burn scars, doesn't talk to Church)
  • Equipment repair and sales
  • Pre-Sovereign gear available (expensive)
  • Information source about district and legends
Status: Party had Custodian armplate assessed. Jonas did not purchase items.

The Copper Vein

  • Tavern on district's edge
  • Neutral ground â€” Inquisitors drink there, so do smugglers
  • Barkeep: Hollow Cren â€” hears everything, shares for coin or favor
  • "You want rumors about what's happening in the Church? That's where they flow."
Status: Not yet visited.

The Memorial Ossuary

  • Public bone-house three blocks north
  • Where the district buries its dead (after Church takes their tithe)
  • Open to visitors during daylight
  • Also where certain people meet when they don't want to be overheard
  • "Hard to spy on a conversation when you're surrounded by ten thousand skulls."
Status: Not yet visited.

The Catacomb Gate

  • West side of district
  • Main Tribunal checkpoint
  • Heavy guard
  • Where prisoners go to the deep cells
  • Kaleth Vorn operated near here ("Catacomb Reliquary")
Status: Handler from this area was eliminated by party.

Sister Mavel's Hospice

  • East end of district
  • Run by excommunicated healer
  • "Disagreed with how the Inquisition treated the sick"
  • Church pretends not to notice because she takes cases they don't want
  • Healing without Church attention
Status: Not yet visited.

Current Situation

Immediate Concerns

  • Handler's absence will eventually be noticed
  • Seraphine's cover is fragile
  • The Confluence approaches (days away)
  • Savaros and the Catacomb Reliquary are nearby

items.title: Monastery of Still Blood
items.content:
The Monastery of Still Blood

Overview

Sacred Gathering Place of the Mareathan Church Type: Religious monastery / Clergy gathering site Location: Beneath Mareatha's Heart, outside Veinspire Affiliation: Church of the Merciful Vein Purpose: Major clergy gatherings, including the Confluence

Why "Still Blood"

At the base of Mareatha's Heart â€” the mountain-sized divine organ that pumps through Veinspire â€” blood pools and settles. Unlike the rushing arterial tunnels above, the blood here is slow. Thick. Nearly motionless.

The faithful call this sacred: "Where the Vein-Mother's blood rests, so too may her servants find stillness."

The truth is less poetic. Blood that doesn't flow is blood that doesn't carry Mareatha's attention. Her consciousness rides the pulse, the rush, the living current. Here, in the still places, she is... distant. Unfocused. The clergy interpret this as peaceful sanctuary.

The Cardinal knows it for what it is: a blind spot.

Description

First Impression The monastery grows from the flesh like a tumor given purpose. Walls of calcified blood-rock rise in arches and cloisters, threaded with darkened veins that no longer pulse. Above, the Heart looms â€” vast beyond comprehension, its rhythm felt in the bones rather than heard. But here, at its base, the eternal drumbeat grows muffled. Quiet. The air smells of old iron and incense. The blood in the channels does not flow. It sits, dark and mirror-still, reflecting torchlight like black glass.

Layout

The Pilgrim's Descent

The only surface approach â€” a road of calcified blood that winds down from Veinspire over three days of walking. Pilgrims travel in silence, shedding worldly concerns with each step. By the time they arrive, they are meant to be spiritually prepared for the stillness.

Features:
  • Wayshrine stations every few hours
  • No inns or shelter â€” pilgrims sleep on the road
  • Final descent through a narrow canyon of dried blood-rock
  • The Heart becomes visible on day two, growing impossibly large

The Threshold Gate

The monastery's entrance â€” a massive valve of hardite (calcified divine tissue) carved with scenes of Mareatha's mercy. It opens only for those bearing the Church's seal or during scheduled gatherings.

Features:
  • Two Custodian guardians (constructs) flank the entrance
  • Detection wards identify divine alignments
  • Opens inward with a sound like a held breath releasing

The Veinal Cloisters

Living quarters for resident monks and visiting clergy. Simple cells carved into the blood-rock, connected by walkways threaded with dormant veins.

Features:
  • 200 individual cells
  • Communal dining hall (blood-broth and bread)
  • The veins in the walls occasionally twitch â€” Mareatha dreaming
  • Whispered prayers echo strangely

The Pulse Chambers

Meditation cells built where the Heart's rhythm is still faintly felt. Used for spiritual trials, deep prayer, and â€” during the Confluence â€” private confessions.

Features:
  • Soundproofed by layers of tissue
  • The heartbeat here is hypnotic; extended exposure induces trance states
  • Confessions heard here feel compelled â€” the rhythm loosens tongues
  • The Cardinal listens to every confession through shadow-channels

The Sanctuary of the Settling

The main worship hall. A vast chamber where the blood pools inches deep across the floor, perfectly still. Clergy walk through it barefoot, their passage leaving no ripples.

Features:
  • Blood is real but preserved â€” neither living nor rotting
  • Walking through it is meant to symbolize immersion in Mareatha's grace
  • The altar rises from the pool's center
  • During major ceremonies, the blood glows faintly crimson

The Lowest Sanctum

The deepest chamber, directly beneath the Heart's foundation. Where the Confluence gathers.

Features:
  • Accessible only to Cardinals and above
  • A perfect circle of still blood surrounds a raised stone platform
  • The ceiling is the underside of the Heart itself â€” raw divine tissue
  • Acoustics carry whispers perfectly; secrets spoken here do not stay secret
  • The Cardinal's preferred hunting ground

The Confluence

A legitimate gathering of the Church's highest leadership, held every few years at the Monastery of Still Blood. Officially, it serves to:

  • Align Church doctrine across regions
  • Hear reports from Cardinals and Bishops
  • Conduct high-level confessions and absolutions
  • Make major ecclesiastical decisions

Attendees

Rank Number Role
The Pontiff 1 Supreme leader of the Mareathan Church
Archbishops 3-5 Regional heads
Bishops 20-30 Diocesan leaders
Tribunal Representatives 4-6 Including Seraphine Vale (usually)
Attending Clergy 50-100 Scribes, aides, confessors

Schedule (Typical)

Day Events
Day 1 Arrival, purification rituals, opening prayers
Day 2 Regional reports, doctrinal discussions
Day 3 Private confessions in the Pulse Chambers
Day 4 Tribunal matters, heretic condemnations
Day 5 The Pontiff's address, major decisions
Day 6 Closing ceremonies, departures begin

What the Cardinal Does

Day 1-2: Identifies targets. Who has secrets? Who is vulnerable? Who would make a valuable identity to steal? Day 5: Reports to the Pontiff with perfect loyalty â€” while cataloging everything for his true master. Day 6: Selects one or two targets for future consumption. Not now â€” too obvious. But in six months, a Bishop will disappear, and the Cardinal will have a new skin to wear.

Atmosphere

Sounds

  • The muffled heartbeat â€” felt more than heard
  • Whispered prayers echoing off blood-rock
  • Footsteps through still blood â€” no splashing, just soft displacement
  • Occasional twitch of dormant veins â€” a wet, muscular sound

Smells

  • Old iron (the blood)
  • Incense (constant)
  • Cold stone and older decay
  • Something faintly sweet beneath it all â€” preserved flesh

Sights

  • Crimson and black everywhere â€” blood-rock, dried veins, dark robes
  • Torchlight reflecting off perfectly still blood pools
  • The Heart above â€” impossibly vast, its surface textured like muscle
  • Clergy moving in silence, barefoot, blood-stained to the ankles

The Wrongness

  • Too quiet. Mareatha's domain should pulse with life. This place... waits.
  • The blood doesn't behave like liquid. It parts for the faithful. It clings to intruders.
  • Sometimes, in the corner of your eye, the still blood ripples â€” but when you look, it's perfectly flat.

Potential Infiltration Approaches

Approach Difficulty Notes
Pilgrim's Descent Medium Three days exposed; requires disguise; checkpoints
Arterial Tunnels Hard The party knows these; connects to monastery's lower levels; risk of guardians
Pose as Clergy Hard Requires stolen robes, forged seals, knowledge of rituals; one wrong word exposes them
During Confluence Very Hard Maximum security, but also maximum chaos and crowds
Through the Heart Itself Extreme Literally entering Mareatha's divine organ from above; possible but insane

Key NPCs (During Confluence)

The Pontiff â€” Venerus the Still

The supreme leader of the Mareathan Church. Ancient, frail in appearance, but spiritually formidable.

  • Level: 18 Cleric (Life Domain, reflavored as Blood)
  • Demeanor: Serene, soft-spoken, genuinely faithful
  • Secret: Knows something is wrong with the Church but cannot identify what
  • Danger: Would die defending the faith; commands divine power sufficient to challenge the party

The Cardinal â€” [Name Unknown]

The Skin-Walker. Savaros's superior. Older, more powerful, more patient.

  • CR: 19+ (to be developed)
  • Demeanor: Warm, avuncular, trusted by all
  • Danger: Will not fight unless cornered; prefers to destroy enemies politically

Prior Aldric

The monastery's resident leader. A true believer who maintains the sacred spaces.

  • Level: 9 Cleric
  • Demeanor: Humble, devoted, easily manipulated
  • Secret: None â€” genuinely innocent
  • Use: Could be an unwitting ally or a tragic casualty

Story Hooks

Information Gathering

The party needs intelligence about the Confluence, the Cardinal, or Church operations. The monastery's archives contain centuries of records.

Assassination

Target the Cardinal during the Confluence. Maximum security, but also the only time his location is predictable.

Rescue

Someone important (an ally? a captured heretic?) is being held in the Pulse Chambers before condemnation.

Sabotage

Disrupt the Confluence itself. Expose the Cardinal's true nature to the assembled clergy. Watch the Church tear itself apart.

The Arterial Texts

Mira mentioned the texts are hidden in an "Unclaimed Pocket." Could there be a path from the monastery's depths to such a place? The still blood might hide doorways to nowhere...

items.title: The Dregs
items.content:
The Dregs

Veinspire's Forgotten District Where the faithful who can't afford proximity to Mareatha's heart scrape by in buildings that don't pulse, don't breathe, don't remind you with every step that you're living inside a god.

Region: Veinspire | Type: Slum District

Description

The Dregs is Veinspire's poorest district â€” the one place in the city where buildings don't share Mareatha's organic architecture. Here, structures are made of mundane stone, rotted wood, and desperate hope.

Key Features

Architecture:
  • Ramshackle structures leaning against each other
  • Roofs that sag, walls that bow
  • Buildings patched with canvas and prayer
  • No pulse, no heartbeat, no divine tissue
The Market:
  • Empty stalls crowd the center square
  • Tarps pulled over meager wares at night
  • Guttering torches in iron brackets
  • The only commerce in poverty
The Canal:
  • Dark water sluggish with refuse
  • Small boats tied to rotting posts
  • Cuts through the eastern edge
  • Not Mareatha's blood â€” just filth
The People:
  • Those who can't afford proximity to the divine
  • Beggars, thieves, the desperate
  • They don't see things â€” seeing gets you involved
  • Getting involved gets you dead

Social Dynamics

Don't Ask Questions: No one wants to know. No one wants to be a witness.

Don't Flash Wealth: Ten gold is a fortune here. Fifteen gold will get you robbed â€” or worse.

Don't Trust Anyone: The child who smiles at you will mark you for thieves. The old woman who helps you will sell you out for copper.

Don't Stay: The Dregs is where you pass through. Not where you stop.

Notable Locations

Old Marten's Shack (Northeast)

A barely-standing hovel where the party sheltered.

  • Single room, dirt floor
  • Straw mattress (previous owner died on it)
  • Crooked table, one stool
  • Fireplace with rusted pot
  • No windows facing the street

Current Status: Former party shelter

The Collapsed Building

Across from the market square. Used by local thieves as a watching post. The child thief was spotted here during Fursen's fourth watch.

The Forgotten Ground (West)

A patch of bare earth behind a collapsed fence. No one's backyard. Just forgotten.

Party Events

The party emerged from the Catacomb Reliquary's service tunnels into the Dregs late at night.

Transactions:
  • Fursen bought a barrel for 5 gold (to carry Mira's remains)
  • Jonas paid 10 gold to Gretta for shelter

Note: The party sheltered here before moving on. Kael was buried elsewhere (behind the Church of the Merciful Vein).

Theft:
  • During Jonas's third watch (Perception 3), someone pried a board loose and stole Sol's coin pouch
  • Fursen discovered the theft on fourth watch (Perception 21)
  • The child thief is still watching from the collapsed building

The Child Thief

A barefoot child who marked the party when Jonas flashed gold. Led watchers to their shack. Stole Sol's pouch during Jonas's failed watch.

Still watching. Still out there with 300 gold that doesn't belong to them.

Atmosphere

Sights:
  • Torchlight that doesn't reach far
  • Shadows pooling between hovels
  • Stars visible through gaps in roofs
  • A market square that's more mud than stone
Sounds:
  • Dogs barking once and falling silent
  • Arguments in languages you don't speak
  • Someone coughing deep and wet
  • The lap of dark water against rotting posts
Smells:
  • Mud and sewage
  • Woodsmoke and cooking meat (rat? worse?)
  • And underneath â€” always â€” the faint copper tang of Mareatha's circulation from elsewhere in the city

items.title: Sporehaven
items.content:
Sporehaven

Overview

Pilgrim Village in the Blooming Rot Type: Settlement â€” Pilgrim Way-Station Domain: Talaris Bloomrend the Verdant King Region: The Blooming Rot (Talar'Noth)

Sporehaven is a small village deep within the Verdant King's domain, grown rather than built. It serves as a waystation for pilgrims seeking the "Verdant Crown" â€” willing transformation into the cycle of death and rebirth that Talaris embodies.

The settlement emerges from the jungle like a growth rather than a construction. Buildings are living trees bent into walls, roots woven into floors, mushroom caps forming roofs. Vine bridges connect the larger structures.

Atmosphere

The Smell: Overwhelming compost. Rich, dark, fertile. The smell of things becoming other things â€” not unpleasant, but inescapable. The People: Human, mostly. But the longer you look, the more you notice:
  • Bark patches on skin like birthmarks
  • Mushrooms sprouting from shoulders, necks, scalps
  • Eyes with faint green luminescence that shift shades based on emotional state
  • Movements that are slightly too slow, too calm, too patient

The residents are Spore-Touched â€” pilgrims who chose to join the cycle willingly. They bloom slowly, beautifully. When they die, they become the garden. When the garden dies, it becomes them again.

The Eyes: The green luminescence in a Spore-Touched's eyes is not static:
  • Shade shifts with emotion â€” darker greens for sorrow or contemplation, brighter greens for curiosity or warmth, pale almost-yellow for alarm
  • Pulses when communicating with brethren â€” a visible ripple of light passes between Spore-Touched when they share awareness through the fungal network
  • This pulsing is involuntary â€” they cannot hide when they are "speaking" to each other or to the King

Key Locations

Architecture

  • Buildings: Living trees bent into walls, not constructed
  • Roofs: Mushroom caps of impossible colors
  • Walkways: Vine-woven bridges between structures
  • Lighting: Bioluminescent fungi (soft greens and blues)

The Pilgrim's Rest

An inn grown from three intertwined trees for travelers:
  • Moss-bedding rooms
  • Hookah room with grown-gourd pipe and brazier
  • Rooms rent for 4 gold per night
  • Payment bowl absorbs into root-floor within minutes

Tavern

Hollowed-out trunk with fungal shelves and root-stools:
  • Mushroom stew
  • Bread that tastes of honey and soil
  • Fermented fruit drink
  • Food is strange but good â€” too good

Notable NPCs

The Elder Woman

Role: Village spokesperson / informal leader Appearance:
  • Elderly, moss growing in grey hair
  • Bark creeping up her knuckles
  • Eyes with green luminescence (shifts to warmer shades when speaking kindly)
  • Smile that never quite wavers
Demeanor: Patient, unhurried, warm but unsettling. Speaks in rustling-leaves laughter. Knowledge:
  • Knows the path to Verdant Pass ("The Wound")
  • Understands Sovereign marks and their implications
  • Connected to the King through the Spore-Touch â€” "What he knows, we feel. Dimly."
Key Quotes:
  • "You carry preserved death with you. Interesting. The King will have... opinions about that."
  • "The King doesn't give. Everything that enters the Green becomes part of the cycle. Eventually."
  • "If the King speaks to you â€” answer honestly. He already knows the truth. Lies just make him hungry."

The King's Awareness

The villagers explained that the Verdant King senses all life within his domain:

  • Root Network: The King has been "tasting your footsteps" since the border
  • Shared Perception: The Spore-Touched feel what the King knows, like "hearing a conversation through a wall"
  • Detection: They could sense Mira's bones in the barrel â€” "power, old power, the kind that makes the cycle itch"
On Sovereign Marks: The elder woman noted that foreign Sovereign marks "stand out like a stone in compost" to the King:
  • Some marks he ignores (petty claims)
  • Some marks he finds interesting (messages between Sovereigns)
  • Some marks belong to Sovereigns he has "history" with â€” those he pays attention to
Communication Through Eyes: When the elder woman spoke of the King's awareness, her eyes pulsed faintly â€” indicating she was relaying information through the network, not just speaking from memory.

Directions to Verdant Pass

Distance: Two days' travel southeast Route: Through the Hunger Garden, past the Congregation Grove, into the foothills Destination: "The Wound" â€” a cliff where someone fell long ago, a cave below where something crawled to die but "didn't finish dying"

The body in Verdant Pass has refused to rot for twenty-two years. The King has tolerated this anomaly â€” no one knows why.

Key Moments

Party Visit

  • Party arrived Day 1 in the Blooming Rot
  • Jonas roared to announce their presence
  • Fursen asked about caves near cliffs â€” learned of "The Wound"
  • Jonas asked about Sovereign marks (without revealing his brand)
  • The elder woman noticed his curiosity: "Why do you ask?"
  • Party ate at tavern, rented room at Pilgrim's Rest (4 gold)
  • Rested overnight before continuing to Verdant Pass

Party's Cover Story

  • Fursen explained they carry bones of someone who wanted to reunite with her husband
  • She died before she could
  • They're completing her journey
  • The elder woman found this "beautiful, in its way"

items.title: Verdant Pass
items.content:
Verdant Pass â€” The Wound

Overview

The Place Where Nothing Rots Type: Geographic Anomaly / Sacred Site Location: Southeastern edge of the Blooming Rot Sovereign: None â€” Talaris cannot reach here Significance: âœ… Final resting place of Mira and Elias Alethain

Description

The Threshold

A line in the earth marks where the Blooming Rot ends. On one side: moss, fungi, roots, life consuming death â€” the full expression of Talaris's power. On the other: nothing.

Grey stone. Bare rock. A narrow ravine where the forest refuses to grow.

The transition is absolute. One step you're in the eternal garden. The next, you're in sterile silence.

Inside the Wound

The ravine extends for roughly a mile â€” a scar in the landscape where Talaris's influence cannot reach.

Environmental Features:
  • Cold, dry air
  • Absolute silence â€” no insects, no birdsong, no wind
  • Stone that has never known decay
  • Darkness that lanterns cannot fully dispel
  • Footsteps that echo strangely
The Bleeding Blade's Reaction: When Jonas entered Verdant Pass, the cursed sword went cold and quiet. There was no life to drink, no blood to sense. The blade was useless here â€” a tool designed for the living, powerless in a place that has forgotten what living means. Sol's Reaction: The shard of Aedwynn within Sol pulsed with recognition. This was a place the Maker knew â€” or rather, a place that remembered the Maker.

The Cave of Waiting

Description

At the center of the ravine, a natural cave mouth opens in the cliff face. Low entrance, perhaps twenty feet across. Inside: bare stone, absolute stillness, and perfect preservation.

Properties

Property Effect
No Decay Nothing rots; organic matter is preserved indefinitely
No Growth Plants cannot grow; fungal spores die
Temporal Stasis Time has diminished meaning; the dead remain as they were
Divine Immunity Talaris's power cannot reach; possibly immune to all Sovereign influence

Current Occupants

The Aletheins â€” Together at Last Elias Alethain â€” Skeleton, pristine white, hands folded across chest. Died 22 years ago. Has been waiting ever since. Mira Alethain â€” Skeleton, placed beside Elias by Fursen. Wedding ring on finger. Hand positioned to hold Elias's.

Two skeletons hold hands in the darkness. Husband and wife. Healer and saint. Twenty-two years of separation, finally ended.

Origin â€” The Wound

What Happened Here

When Talaris Bloomrend claimed the Blooming Rot as his domain after the Usurpation, his power spread through every inch of organic matter. The cycle claimed everything.

Almost everything.

Something in this ravine resisted. The nature of the resistance is unknown:

  • A fragment of Aedwynn's will?
  • A pre-Usurpation ward?
  • A natural phenomenon that predates the Sovereigns?
  • The stubborn refusal of the stone itself?

Whatever it was, Talaris's power flowed around it like water around a rock. The wound healed, but the scar remained.

Talaris's Perspective

The Choir Blooms call this place "The Wound" â€” not with anger, but with a kind of respect. When asked about it, they acknowledge:

"The healer who died there chose where to end. The King respects that choice. It is... discourteous, perhaps. But there is courage in choosing where you die, even if the place is beyond the cycle."

Talaris tolerates the anomaly. He could not claim it even if he wanted to â€” and perhaps he doesn't want to. Even the Verdant King, who believes all things must join the cycle, recognizes that some choices are sacred.

â€” The Reunion

The Party's Arrival

The party arrived at Verdant Pass on the morning of Day 3, having passed through:

  • Sweetwater Marsh (Sol's compulsion and rescue)
  • Pilgrim's Spine (Bloom Hound burning, lie detected)
  • Hunger Garden (Thornback Behemoth killed, Talaris spoke)
  • Congregation Grove (The Questioning, Sol's offering accepted)

The Grove Wardens â€” thirty-foot humanoids of wood and bark â€” bowed their heads as the party passed toward the Wound. A mark of respect for what they carried and what they had given.

Finding Elias

Inside the Cave of Waiting, they found Elias Alethain exactly as he'd been for twenty-two years:

  • Skeleton on bare stone
  • Hands folded across chest
  • No rot, no fungal growth
  • Clean white bones, pristine

He'd been waiting.

The Reunion

Fursen lowered the barrel containing Mira's remains. He lifted out her bones â€” skull, ribcage, spine, arms, hands â€” and laid them beside Elias. Parallel. Close enough to touch. Sol placed Mira's wedding ring on her finger. The ring had been cold since he retrieved it from the gore in the Catacomb Reliquary. When he slid it onto her finger, it warmed â€” not magical warmth, just the warmth of remembering.

Sol positioned Mira's hand until her fingers rested against Elias's. The wedding ring gleamed between them.

Fursen spoke:

ðŸ¦ "I am sorry we could not reunite you in life. But at least in death, we have brought you together."

The party left them there. Two skeletons holding hands in a place where nothing rots.

Travel Information

Getting There

From To Time Difficulty
Congregation Grove Verdant Pass Half-day Easy (if permitted)
Note: Passage requires permission from the Congregation Grove. The party earned passage through Sol's offering of Aedwynn's memory.

Inside the Pass

The ravine is approximately one mile long. The Cave of Waiting is roughly at the center.

Hazards: None â€” this is one of the only truly safe places in the Blooming Rot.

Exiting

Beyond the ravine, the Blooming Rot ends entirely. The party emerged into:

  • Rolling hills
  • Brown grass
  • Normal trees (oak, ash)
  • A dirt road toward distant mountains
  • Warm sunrise

Normal world. No eternal garden. No cycle. Just... ordinary land.

Significance

To Talaris

The Wound is a reminder that even a Sovereign's power has limits. Talaris tolerates it â€” perhaps even respects it â€” but he cannot claim it.

To the Party

This is where they completed Mira's quest. The culmination of the journey. The place where a two-thousand-year-old saint finally rests beside her husband.

To the Campaign

Verdant Pass represents hope â€” proof that some things exist beyond Sovereign control. In a world where the Thirteen claim dominion over all aspects of existence, this barren ravine stands as evidence that exceptions exist.

If a place can resist Talaris, perhaps other things can resist other Sovereigns.
