items.title: Dusthollow
items.content:
Dusthollow

Type: Settlement | Status: Neutral Territory

Overview

A small waystation located half a day west of the Pallid Crossroads. Contains the Dry Cup tavern, stables, and a handful of residences. Perhaps a dozen permanent residents. Neutral ground used as a staging point for travelers.

The Vorath Encounter

The party learned that Vorath â€” a Tribunal agent hunting Mira â€” was camped at Dusthollow. They investigated his room at the Dry Cup and found:

  • Evidence connecting him to the Tribunal and Seraphine Vale
  • A sealed letter from "K" (Kaleth Vorn) with orders to capture Mira alive
  • Instructions to interrogate her about the Arterial Texts

The Kill

The party rode back through the night to catch Vorath before he could flee. They arrived before dawn to find him at the stables, preparing to escape on horseback.

Jonas threw his hammer (missed, hit the horse instead). Vorath was thrown from the saddle and surrendered, offering information for his life.

Mira bashed his head in with her fist. No hesitation.

Intelligence from Speak with Dead

The party interrogated Vorath's corpse:

  • "Who is K?" â€” "Kaleth Vorn. Tribunal Hand. Veinspire Catacomb. Seraphine's superior â€” gives her orders."
  • "The Arterial Texts?" â€” "The Vein-Mother's mortal writings. Her doubts. Her failures. Words before divinity. The Tribunal must destroy them. Alethain knows where they are hidden."
  • "State of Veinspire?" â€” "Theorists scattered. Three cells discovered. Executions public. The Church fears what stirs beneath. The Mother's heart beats... irregular."

Significance

This was the moment Mira permanently left her old life behind. After killing Vorath, she could never return to the Pallid Crossroads without endangering the settlement. From here, there was only forward â€” toward Veinspire, toward vengeance, toward death.

items.title: The Pallid Crossroads
items.content:
The Pallid Crossroads

Overview

A Place That Shouldn't Be The Pallid Crossroads exists because people remember it exists. If they ever forgot, it would simply... stop. Type: Settlement Region: The Pallid Waste (Unclaimed territory) Population: Small (exact number unknown â€” people come and go)

Description

A settlement in the gaps between Sovereign territories. Wooden buildings with smoke rising from chimneys. The distant sound of voices. It emerges from the white landscape like a mirage refusing to dissolve, gaining solidity with each step until suddenly it's there.

A makeshift wooden wall surrounds roughly seventy percent of the town, gaps filled with nothing but intention. Guard towers stand at irregular intervals, manned by people who watch the pale horizon with the practiced vigilance of those who know what comes out of it.

The Nature of the Place

The Pallid Crossroads exists in Unclaimed territory â€” the gaps between Sovereign domains where reality was never shaped by divine theft. The Pallid Waste is a land of nothing: featureless white dunes, ivory sky indistinguishable from the horizon, silence so complete it feels like weight.

Navigation: You cannot navigate the Waste traditionally. Direction doesn't work here. Instead:
  • Know where you want to go
  • Walk with certainty
  • The Waste listens â€” if you're certain enough, it takes you there
Existence: The Crossroads persists because its inhabitants refuse to let it be forgotten. Every conversation, every meal shared, every story told is an act of defiance against the nothing. The settlement exists because people insist on it.

If the population drops too low, if too many people forget, the Crossroads will simply vanish.

Key Locations

Mira's Clinic

A converted house near the center of town. Wooden sign above the door: MIRA HEMM â€” HEALER.

Inside, it smells of herbs and something older. The healer who runs it â€” Mira Hemm â€” is a woman who appears to be in her fifties with grey-streaked dark hair and sharp eyes. She moves with the efficiency of someone who has healed more wounds than she can count.

Services:
  • Healing (mundane and magical)
  • Curse removal (some types)
  • Herb supplies
Notable Herbs:
  • Pallid Mint â€” pale leaves with faint blue tinge; one leaf silences for 24 hours, three leaves cause unconsciousness

The Ivory Inn

A building of pale wood and bleached stone. Interior lit by candles that burn with steady, colorless flames. The innkeeper is a tired woman with kind eyes who asks no questions.

Services:
  • Lodging: 3 silver/night (breakfast included)
  • Food and drink
  • Common room with fireplace
Warning from the Innkeeper:

"Don't go outside after dark unless you have to. Things move in the Waste when the light fades."

The Forge

Blacksmith's workshop. Usually manned, though the smith travels often. When the party visited, the door was unlocked, the building cold, the smith nowhere to be found.

Status: Unavailable (smith traveling)

The Market

If "market" means three stalls selling whatever people have found. Supplies are scarce in the Unclaimed â€” traders sell salvage from abandoned outposts and whatever can be scavenged from the old world's remnants.

Inhabitants

The people of the Pallid Crossroads came here to hide from the world. Most are not fighters. They're refugees, hermits, outcasts â€” people who found their way to the gaps between territories and decided to stay.

Known Residents:
Name Role Notes
Mira Hemm Healer Actually Mira Alethain in hiding
Innkeeper Ivory Inn proprietor Tired, kind, asks no questions
Hunter Woman Resident Lost friends to the White Marcher
Young Man Resident Nervous energy; helped with caravan quest
Middle-Aged Man Resident Seen too much to be surprised

Threats

The White Marcher

A creature of absence that hunted in the Waste east of the Crossroads. It erased things from existence rather than destroying them â€” wounds it inflicted were literally missing pieces of reality.

Status: Killed by the party

The Marcher destroyed a caravan of six people, partially erasing their bodies and supplies. The party tracked it, fought it, and killed it â€” but not before suffering wounds that couldn't heal and losses that were permanent.

The Waste Itself

The Pallid Waste wants to forget everything. Blood fades. Footprints vanish. Stay too long, and it might forget you too.

The Caravan Incident

A caravan of six people went missing while scavenging from abandoned outposts east of town. Signs found:

  • Blood on the eastern path
  • Boxes half-vanished â€” not broken, just absent
  • Clean edges where reality had been edited

The party investigated, encountered the White Marcher, killed it, and found the caravan's remains:

  • Three wagons (one half-vanished)
  • Four corpses, each partially erased
  • No survivors
  • Recovered: 47 gold, 3 days rations, half-erased letter

The Crossroads lost six irreplaceable people. In a settlement that exists through memory, every loss is existentially dangerous.

Visitors

The Father and Son

An old man with a walking stick and a young man carrying firewood. Travelers who guided the party to the Crossroads and explained how navigation works in the Waste.

The young man gave Fursen his rope freely when asked â€” no payment, no questions. Just one traveler helping another.

Old Man: "The Waste takes everything eventually. Might as well give things away while you still can."

Atmosphere

The Pallid Crossroads feels like a place that shouldn't exist. Step outside the wall and the white nothing stretches in every direction. The sky is indistinguishable from the ground. Sound dies. Color fades.

But inside the wall, there's smoke and voices and the stubborn insistence of people who refuse to be forgotten.

"The Waste doesn't hate you. The Waste doesn't feel anything. It just forgets â€” and if you stay too long, it forgets you too. The Crossroads survives because we refuse to be forgotten. Every conversation, every meal shared, every story told â€” it's all an act of defiance. We exist because we insist on it. And so far, that's been enough."

â€” Ivory Inn keeper

items.title: Lastwell
items.content:
Lastwell

Overview

Lastwell is the final settlement before the Devoured Courts. Here, at the threshold of Vor'Kael's domain, meaning itself begins to thin. Colors are muted. Words come harder. Purpose feels distant.

The town exists because someone has to warn travelers. Someone has to be the last voice that speaks clearly before the grey takes over.

Atmosphere

  • Colors: Muted, washed out, trending toward grey
  • Sound: Conversations feel like they take effort
  • Air: Smells faintly of nothing â€” absence of scent
  • Feeling: A gnawing emptiness in the chest

The closer you get to the Devoured Courts, the harder it becomes to remember why anything matters.

Key Locations

The Husk Pen

A pen containing husks â€” people who have lost their meanings. They exist, but they are nothing. They had names once, purposes, identities. Vor'Kael's border effect stripped them away.

What Husks Are:
  • Former people who ventured too close to the Devoured Courts
  • They exist but don't know why
  • They reach for meanings that aren't theirs
  • They can taste identity when it's offered
The Throat of Forgotten Things:
  • Fursen whispered "Sir Jonas" to the husks
  • The husks tried to claim Jonas's name, pulling at his identity
  • Jonas threw the Bleeding Blade at Fursen, wounding his thigh
  • Leonin blood (carrying 10,000 ancestors) spilled
  • Vor'Kael was alerted to something interesting at her border

The Last Hearth Tavern

The only establishment still functioning in Lastwell. Run by Marra, a woman who wants nothing more than for dangerous people to leave.

What's There:
  • Tasteless food (meaning fading from the ingredients)
  • Watered-down ale
  • A fire that doesn't feel warm
  • Locals who've learned not to care about anything
The Throat of Forgotten Things:
  • Jonas struck Fursen with Booming Blade after catching him stealing
  • Fursen met Sekris, a meaning-dealer
  • Fursen took Sekris's contract-token
  • Jonas purchased the Closed Locket from the smith

The Smith

A craftsman who works in metal but whose creations often lose their function. He sold Jonas the Closed Locket â€” a silver container that wouldn't open, containing whispers.

The locket held Vor'Kael's true name, preserved by Azerach for 800 years.

The Greeter

An old man who has lost his own name. He only remembers his function â€” to greet travelers.

He doesn't acknowledge everyone equally. When the party arrived, he looked past Fursen entirely â€” the Leonin might as well have not existed. His empty gaze settled only on Jonas.

His Warnings:
  1. Don't speak your name beyond this town
  2. Don't accept food from strangers
  3. Don't answer Questioners
  4. If something asks who you are, don't tell it
  5. If you start forgetting why you're traveling, turn back

He can't remember his own advice sometimes. He just knows it's important.

NPCs

NPC Role Status
The Greeter Warns travelers Fading â€” lost his name
Marra Tavern keeper Wants outsiders gone
Sekris Meaning-dealer Active â€” gave Fursen a contract-token
The Smith Craftsman Sold Jonas the Closed Locket

Dangers

Danger Description
Meaning Drain Extended time in Lastwell causes memories/emotions to fade
Husks Will try to claim your identity if you offer it
Questioners Vor'Kael's faceless scouts; answering them gives her information
Sekris Predatory meaning-dealer; trades in desperation

Key Events

The party stopped in Lastwell before entering the Devoured Courts.

  1. The Greeter warned them about the dangers ahead
  2. Fursen betrayed Jonas at the husk pen (gave his name to the husks)
  3. Jonas stabbed Fursen twice (Bleeding Blade throw, Booming Blade strike)
  4. Fursen met Sekris and took his contract-token
  5. Jonas bought the Closed Locket (containing Vor'Kael's true name)
  6. Party dynamics fractured

Why "Lastwell"

The town is named for being:

  • The last well of clean water before the Devoured Courts
  • The last place where words flow easily
  • The last settlement where people still remember why they settled
  • The last chance to turn back

Beyond Lastwell, there is only grey.

"We're the last people who still know why we're here. Past us, even that starts to fade. Turn back while you still remember what you're turning back to." â€” The Greeter

Someone has to be the last voice that speaks clearly before the grey takes over. Atmosphere Colors: Muted, washed out, trending toward grey Sound: Conversations feel like they take effort Air: Smells faintly of nothing â€” absence of scent Feeling: A gnawing emptiness in the chest The closer you get to the Devoured Courts, the harder it becomes to remember why anything matters. Key Locations The Husk Pen A pen containing husks â€” people who have lost their meanings. They exist, but they are nothing. They had names once, purposes, identities. Vor'Kael's border effect stripped them away. What Husks Are: Former people who ventured too close to the Devoured Courts They exist but don't know why They reach for meanings that aren't theirs They can taste identity when it's offered The Throat of Forgotten Things: Fursen whispered "Sir Jonas" to the husks The husks tried to claim Jonas's name, pulling at his identity Jonas threw the Bleeding Blade at Fursen, wounding his thigh Leonin blood (carrying 10,000 ancestors) spilled Vor'Kael was alerted to something interesting at her border The Last Hearth Tavern The only establishment still functioning in Lastwell. Run by Marra, a woman who wants nothing more than for dangerous people to leave. items.title: The Devoured Courts
items.content:
The Devoured Courts

Sovereign: Vor'Kael the Hollow Empress Location: Vor'Khalem region, southwestern Stolen Aspect: Hunger and Meaning Concept: Hunger, Consumption, Dissolution of Meaning Size: ~470,000 square miles

Overview

The Devoured Courts is where meaning goes to die. This region has been warped by Vor'Kael's stolen power over hunger and meaningâ€”the divine aspect of consumption she ripped from Aedwynn. The territory exists in perpetual consumption. Here, everything is eaten: food, objects, ideas, identities, purpose itself.

It is a realm where meaning itself is digestible, where purpose dissolves, and where hunger is the only truthful emotion.

Law of Hunger

Vor'Kael enforces the Law of Hunger throughout her realm:

  • Meaning is digestible â€” All concepts can be consumed
  • Emptiness seeks filling â€” The void must be satisfied
  • All things return to nothing â€” Everything dissolves eventually
  • Hunger is the only truthful emotion â€” All other feelings are illusions
  • Understanding is consumption â€” To know is to devour

Her priests speak in metaphors because literal truth dissolves in the Courts.

Geography

The climate is humid and uncomfortableâ€”the air feels thick with dissolution. Colors are muted; sounds are dampened; everything feels slightly less real than it should.

Major Regions

The Stomach Basins â€” Vast depressions where the Digestive Engine's hunger is concentrated. Staying too long causes existential erosionâ€”first you forget why you came, then who you are, then that you are. Used for executions and processing. The Intestinal Passages â€” Winding canyons where meaning has already been partially digested. Travel here is safer but unsettling. Objects lose their names. Caravans speak in simple terms to avoid losing concepts mid-sentence. The Hunger Fields â€” Plains where the ground itself consumes. Plants don't photosynthesizeâ€”they consume. Animals don't grazeâ€”they hunt. Even the soil slowly dissolves organic matter. The Bile Marshes â€” Where the Digestive Engine's waste collects. Acidic pools, dissolving ground, remnants of things that used to mean something. Avoided by everyone sane. The Teeth Ridges â€” Border mountains that move. Slowly, imperceptibly grinding. Invading armies are pulverized. Mining communities extract processed materialsâ€”things ground so fine they've lost all original identity.

Consumption â€” The Hollow Capital

Population: ~260,000 (fluctuates as meaning erodes)

"We don't build to last. We build to be consumed. Everything ends in the Empress's mouth."

The capital is built around the Mouth of the Worldâ€”a massive aperture leading to the Digestive Engine's core. The city radiates outward from this hungry center, architecture designed to be temporary, buildings replaced constantly as hunger erodes them.

Life focuses on the present. Planning for the future is difficult when "tomorrow" feels slippery. Citizens live in cycles of creation and dissolution.

Districts

District Character
The Mouth Quarter Edge of the aperture; most dangerous
The Offering Rings Where sacrifices are prepared
The Temporary Markets Commerce; goods only last so long
The Remembering District Where meaning is preserved (at great cost)
The Dissolution Slums Where those losing identity gather
The Feeding Pits Industrial consumption; processing

Notable Locations

Location Description
The Mouth of the World Portal to the Digestive Engine; consumes all
The Hollow Throne Vor'Kael's seat; empty yet full of hunger
The Meaning Vaults Where concepts are preserved (temporarily)
The Feast Halls Endless banquets; never satisfying
The Identity Registry Helps citizens remember who they are

Other Key Locations

The Meaning Vaults

Population: ~18,000

Fortified repositories where meaning is preserved against ambient hunger. Archivists decide what concepts are worth saving. The responsibility slowly erodes their own sense of self; most eventually forget their own names.

The Feeding Pits

Population: ~70,000

Industrial facilities processing objects and concepts for their meaning. Meaning extraction is the primary currency of the Courts. The husks left behindâ€”objects without significance, people without identityâ€”are given to the Empress.

The Identity Registry

A vital public serviceâ€”regular visits reinforce who you are, what you want, why you exist. Citizens who skip appointments dissolve into nameless husks within months. If someone dissolves but their records survive, they can be "rebuilt"â€”given back their identity.

Society & Culture

The Hunger Hierarchy

Class Role
The Hollow Empress Vor'Kael; perfect hunger incarnate
The Satisfied Inner court; learned to live with hunger
The Archivists Preserve meaning against dissolution
The Processors Extract and refine meaning
Citizens Struggling to remain coherent
The Fading Losing identity; desperate
The Husks Dissolved; still moving

The Economy of Meaning

Currency is extracted meaning:

  • Distilled Purpose â€” Standard currency
  • Concentrated Memory â€” Premium currency
  • Pure Significance â€” Ultimate currency; rare

Objects have value based on meaning, not material. A mother's wedding ring is worth more than a gold bar.

Identity Maintenance

Remaining yourself requires constant effort:

  • Regular Registry visits
  • Keeping meaningful objects close
  • Maintaining relationships (shared meaning reinforces identity)
  • Repeating your name, your purpose, your history
  • Avoiding the Basins and Marshes

Inhabitants

Vor'Kael's Servants

  • Gastric Spirits â€” Vapors that suck emotions from mortals
  • Stomach-Priests â€” Monks whose bellies whisper secrets
  • Digestors â€” Creatures that eat memories and excrete questions
  • Regurgitants â€” Beings pulled from Vor'Kael's vomit, half-real
  • The Hollow Choir â€” Singers with stomachs full of swallowed voices

Creatures

Creature CR Description
Hunger Elemental 6 Living void; consumes matter and meaning
The Dissolved 8 What remains of consumed people
Purpose Wraith 11 Ghost of a lost goal; possesses seekers
Identity Predator 14 Steals selves; wears them briefly
Concept Devourer 17 Erases ideas from reality
The Hollow One 20 Vor'Kael's direct servant; perfect emptiness

Connection to Kael

Kael was born from this realmâ€”or rather, vomited from it.

Long ago, Vor'Kael consumed a concept (perhaps destiny, perhaps identity itself). Something went wrong. The concept refused dissolution. Unable to process the fragment, unable to keep it, Vor'Kael expelled it.

That fragment took form and became Kael.

Implications:
  • Kael is Vor'Kael's unfinished meal
  • He represents meaning that cannot be digested
  • His existence proves the Empress's power is not absolute
  • She instinctively hunts for him, though she may not consciously remember
And Kael killed her ancient Skin-Walker by being indigestible. When Savaros consumed him, the monster sealed his own fateâ€”poisoned by consuming something that refused to be consumed.

â€” The Party's Passage

Entry Through Lastwell

The party entered through Lastwell, a border settlement where meaning begins to fade. There, Fursen betrayed Jonas by giving his name to the husks, and Jonas acquired the Closed Locket containing Vor'Kael's true name.

Consumption (Capital)

The party walked through the grey streets of Consumption:

  • Colors faded to grey
  • Words came harder
  • Meaning itself grew thin
  • The constant chest-hunger for meaning

The Mouth of the World

At the vast depression where Vor'Kael waits:

  • Fursen's 10,000 names screamed in recognition (WIS save SUCCESS)
  • Sol's Codex tried to throw itself inâ€”Kael's Echo panicking (WIS save FAILED)
  • Jonas caught the Codex one inch from the edge

Vor'Kael spoke directly to the party:

"...visitors... you carry interesting flavors... names that should be forgotten, an echo that escaped, and a secret my brother keeps from me..."

Jonas's Demands

Using the true name Azerach revealed, Jonas demanded:

  1. Safe passage for the party
  2. The Throat of Forgotten Things opened
  3. He keeps the name

All granted. Vor'Kael had no choiceâ€”her true name is a leash.

The Throat of Forgotten Things

The party spent 5 days traveling through The Throat of Forgotten Things:

  • Day 1: The Gullet (Sol found the Remembrance Seal)
  • Day 2: The Lodged Kingdom (Jonas refused to help The Undigested)
  • Day 3: The Concept Graveyard (Sol infected with Possibility)
  • Day 4: The Satiated One (Jonas spoke the true name aloud)
  • Day 5: Exit to Veinspire border

Consequences

  • Vor'Kael will hunt Jonas forever â€” he spoke her true name once in the Throat
  • Sol is infected with Possibility â€” unlived lives whisper in his mind
  • Safe passage ended â€” when they left the Throat, Vor'Kael's promise ended

Travel Times

Journey Distance Time (foot)
Consumption â†’ Meaning Vaults ~200 miles 10 days
Consumption â†’ Teeth Ridges ~350 miles 17 days
Border to border ~700 miles 35 days
Note: Travel in the Courts erodes memory. Bring written records of your destination and purpose.

items.title: The Throat of Forgotten Things
items.content:
The Throat of Forgotten Things

Overview

The Throat of Forgotten Things is Vor'Kael's esophagus â€” a 5-day passage through living meat that descends from the Devoured Courts into the deeper regions of the Maker's corpse. It was sealed since the Usurpation until Jonas used Vor'Kael's true name to demand it opened. Contains the Lodged Kingdom, the Concept Graveyard, and the Satiated One

Overview

The Throat of Forgotten Things is Vor'Kael's esophagus â€” a passage of living meat that descends from the Devoured Courts into the deeper regions of the Maker's corpse. It was sealed since the Usurpation until Jonas used Vor'Kael's true name to demand it opened.

What It Contains:
  • Civilizations Vor'Kael swallowed but couldn't fully digest
  • Concepts too complex or contradictory to dissolve
  • Ancient beings immune to her hunger
  • The remnants of everything she tried to consume and failed

Geography (5-Day Journey)

Day 1 â€” The Gullet

The entry passage. A tunnel of wet meat, 20 feet wide, 15 feet high, sloping down.

Features:
  • Constant peristalsis (throat-muscle contractions)
  • Bile pools â€” grey-green, acidic, deepening as you descend
  • No natural light â€” only bioluminescent growths
  • Skeletons of previous travelers
  • The Remembrance Seal was found here (Sol acquired it)
The Woman's Skeleton: A skeleton in a bile pool, centuries old, arm reaching forward. She wore a Remembrance Seal and almost escaped â€” dissolved inches from the exit.

Day 2 â€” The Lodged Kingdom

The Throat widens dramatically to contain an entire civilization stuck in Vor'Kael's esophagus for 800 years.

The City:
  • White stone architecture (arches, columns, domes)
  • Elegant but scarred by centuries of digestive exposure
  • Too large to go down, too solid to dissolve
  • Population: 12 survivors (The Undigested)
The Undigested: Survivors adapted to life in a god's throat. Changed over 800 years:
  • Pale grey-white translucent skin (bones/blood visible through it)
  • Milky faded eyes
  • Clothing patched with tissue
  • Each wears a Remembrance Seal

They cannot leave â€” the Seals that protect them in the Throat fail in the outside world. They're trapped forever.

Party Interaction:
  • The elder offered knowledge in exchange for freedom (using Vor'Kael's name)
  • Jonas refused to help
  • The Undigested watched them leave without offering guidance

Day 3 â€” The Concept Graveyard

A vast cavern filled with half-digested concepts â€” ideas given physical form.

What's There:
  • Faceless woman statue (shimmers between solid/liquid) â€” Longing
  • Black liquid pool (perfectly still, no reflection) â€” Regret
  • Skeleton sitting upright with wrong bones, endless smile â€” Madness/Joy
  • Glass tree with tinkling leaves â€” Nostalgia
  • Door standing alone, closed, something on other side â€” Possibility
  • Cracked mirror showing nothing â€” Emptiness
  • Hundreds more, some dormant, some reaching
Dangers:
  • Some concepts are hungry â€” they want to be thought about
  • Touching the wrong idea causes infection â€” the concept lodges in your mind
  • No clear path through â€” requires intuition or guidance
Sol's Infection:

Day 4 â€” The Obstruction (The Satiated One)

The passage narrows to single-file width, then opens to an enormous chamber containing The Satiated One.

The Satiated One: An ancient serpentine being older than the Sovereigns. Perfectly content. Vor'Kael cannot digest it because it has no meaning to consume â€” no hunger, no desire, no purpose. Just existence.

It has been blocking this passage for 800 years. It let the party pass because Jonas speaking Vor'Kael's name aloud was "interesting."

Day 5 â€” The Exit

The passage rises, steepens. Flesh-walls thin to translucent. Daylight ahead.

Emergence Point: A ridge of exposed tissue at the outer edge of Vor'Kael's domain â€” where her stolen organs meet unaffiliated flesh. View:
  • Behind: The Devoured Courts
  • Ahead: Empty road across the Maker's corpse
  • Distance: 2 days to Veinspire

Environmental Hazards

Hazard Effect
Bile Pools 1d6 acid damage on contact; deeper pools = more damage
Peristalsis DEX saves to avoid being knocked prone or pushed
Meaning Drain Long rests in the Throat risk losing memories or emotions
Concept Infection Touching hungry concepts requires WIS save or become infected
Identity Erosion Extended time causes people to forget who they are

Items Found

Item Found By Location
Remembrance Seal Sol Raven Day 1 â€” skeleton in bile pool

Conditions Acquired

Condition Character Source
Infected â€” Possibility Sol Raven Day 3 â€” Door of Possibility

NPCs Encountered

NPC Location Status
The Undigested Day 2 â€” Lodged Kingdom Denied help by Jonas
The Satiated One Day 4 â€” The Obstruction Let party pass

Why It Was Sealed

Vor'Kael sealed the Throat after the Usurpation. According to her:

"What lies beyond should not be visited."

The passage leads through her digestive system into deeper regions of the Maker's corpse â€” places even a Sovereign finds uncomfortable. The Satiated One blocks the deepest point, a reminder that even gods have things they cannot consume.

items.title: The Clockwork Caravanserai
items.content:
The Clockwork Caravanserai

Overview

Attribute Details
Type Mobile fortress / Temporal marketplace
Location The Membrane between Silence and Time
Status Destroyed (collapsed into crater)
Affiliation The Horologers (refugees from Imhuran's domain)

Description

A fortress of brass and steel crawling on a hundred insect legs, half buried, half afloat. Each leg ended in a sand-bell: when it stepped, the bells tolled, and the dunes rippled outward in concentric waves. Ladders and chains hung down its sides; small lights moved across its surface â€” lanterns, people, maybe both. The air smelled of oil, old incense, and roasted metal.

At its center hung a massive gear-halo, slowly rotating, projecting a beam of cold light that counted seconds across the sand.

Banners of mismatched cloth fluttered from the hull, bearing the sigil of an open clock face with an eye at its center: the symbol of the Horologers.

The Toll

To enter the Caravan, travelers must pay one of three tolls:

Toll Effect
Years Lose a measure of time (cosmetic aging); the Caravan owes "interest"
Breath Exhale into a glass vial; lose half maximum breath for a day
Truth Speak a confession that causes pain; recorded permanently

Key Locations

The Market of Lost Seconds

An open bazaar suspended in motion. Bridges of chain linked tents and pavilions together, each glowing with different-colored light. Merchants in masks traded not goods but moments: bottled laughter, sealed tears, captured seconds.

The Broker's Pavilion

A tent of black silk and bone beads. Its keeper, Master Caldris, traded in lost potential: years, dreams, and destiny fragments.

The Chronometer Forge

A pit where discarded timepieces melted and reformed into weapons or armor that manipulated duration.

The Observation Deck

Overlooked the desert. The runes in the sky orbited closer here.

The Sleeping Quarters

Cages hung from chains, swinging slowly; those who slept there dreamed out of order.

The Lower Decks

Where the Echo Collector resided, trading in voices, gods, and cores. Dream cages lined the corridors, harvesting vapors from sleepers.

Destruction

When Jonas bonded the Warden's Core by placing it in the right conduit of the Echo Collector's vault, the awakening triggered a temporal cascade. The entire Caravan shuddered with each pulse of the newly-awakened god-fragment.

The structure imploded, folding into itself like a dying clock. Only a crater remained â€” a shallow bowl filled with fragments of gears and shards that glittered faintly, humming the same broken rhythm as Jonas's new heart.

Notable Inhabitants

NPC Role Fate
Horologer Guards Security; porcelain-masked constructs Destroyed with Caravan
Marn the Glasswright Merchant; bottler of moments Unknown
The Echo Collector Broker of divine relics Unknown

First Appearance

items.title: C-5 Divine Research Facility
items.content:
C-5 Divine Research Facility

Overview

Attribute Details
Type Pre-Sovereign Research Installation
Location Northern territory, near Vortegas's domain
Status Purged (structurally intact)
Era Pre-Usurpation

Description

The C-5 Divine Research Facility is an ancient installation predating the Sovereigns, built to study and contain divine material. The party discovered it while following the path of a Boundary Titan, finding the facility partially exposed in a collapsed area of the northern wastes.

The facility's purpose was the containment of "rejected divine material" â€” specimens created or modified using fragments of divine essence that proved too dangerous or unstable to release.

Key Areas

Terminus Î©-I

The main containment door, marked with scratches from a trapped worker. Behind it lay:

  • A dead worker who had been sealed inside
  • A null-flesh specimen
  • A logbook revealing the facility was sabotaged (lift-table removed intentionally)

Conduit Hub

The facility's power center. Jonas pulled a lever here that restored full power â€” and awakened the Preservation Custodian.

Subunit 6

A secondary power junction. The party forced it open (Natural 20) to partially restore power before reaching the main hub.

Biocell Storage

A chamber containing 18 specimen vats:

  • 1 black/shattered vat (empty, compromised)
  • 2 amber vats (contained Alpha and Beta specimens)
  • 15 green vats (status unknown)

Archive

Contains the facility's neural network. Sol discovered the specimens may have been connected, sharing information across the network.

Specimens

Designation Status Notes
Preservation Custodian Destroyed Guardian construct; deadly combat
Bioweapon Alpha Destroyed Released when Jonas shattered amber vat; fire proved effective
Bioweapon Beta Unknown Ambushed Jonas; party fled; possibly destroyed in Purge
Delta Series Unknown Referenced but never explained

The Purge

The party initiated Purge Stage 3, flooding the facility with lethal gas. They escaped via Exit 2 (Exit 3 failed â€” Natural 1), with Fursen inhaling toxin during the escape.

The facility is structurally intact but environmentally hazardous. The gas has since vented.

Logbook Revelations

The Terminus Î©-I logbook revealed:

  • The facility was deliberately sabotaged
  • Someone removed the lift-table to trap the worker
  • The specimens were being contained for research, not destruction
  • The facility predates the current Sovereign order

First Appearance

  • (discovered)
  • (explored)

items.title: The Chamber of the Final Breath
items.content:
The Chamber of the Final Breath

The Door

Opening: When the brass key is inserted, the door unfolds along impossible angles â€” origami geometry, sections rotating inward, folding into itself like paper.

The Chamber

Physical Description

  • Size: Cathedral-vast, impossibly larger inside than out
  • Ceiling: Stretches into darkness that feels like sky
  • Walls: Curve inward like the inside of a ribcage, smooth and shaped
  • Floor: Living rock, warm to the touch
  • Lighting: Golden luminescence from the tree â€” the color of dawn

The Body

Note: The Sovereigns took his organs â€” lungs, heart, skin, brain, all of it. This is something else. A shell. An echo. The part of him that couldn't be carved up and divided.

The Gifts

When touched, the Maker's presence can still communicate â€” an echo of consciousness, fading but present.

Gifts Given:
Recipient Gift Description
Jonas Offered, Refused Golden seed â€” counterweight to Azerach's brand
Fursen The Names Complete Leonin ancestral memory
Sol Raven The Witness Maker's heir, divine memory, creation power
Mira Knowledge Location of Elias's body
Kael None Did not touch the body
The Golden Seed: Was in the Maker's folded hands for 2,000 years. Now inside Sol Raven.

Significance

To the World

  • Last remnant of Aedwynn that wasn't divided among the Sovereigns
  • Contains the Maker's final message and gifts
  • Proof that something of the old world survived
  • Protected by wards no Sovereign can breach

To the Party

  • Jonas learned what Azerach's brand truly is (and refused help)
  • Fursen received his people's stolen history
  • Sol became the Maker's Witness
  • Mira learned where to find her husband's body
  • Kael did not interact â€” significance unknown

Protections

The chamber appears to have ancient wards:

  • No enemies found them during 8-hour rest
  • The Maker's presence may still guard the space
  • Azerach's brand went silent inside â€” Sovereigns cannot observe here
  • Safe haven in hostile territory

Current Status

  • Door remains open (folded geometry)
  • Tree still hums with ancient power
  • Body unchanged â€” peaceful, smiling
  • Golden seed no longer in hands (given to Sol)
  • Party used as safe rest location

items.title: The Hollow
items.content:
The Hollow

Type: Dungeon | Region: The Unclaimed (coastal) | Distance: 3 days southeast of Crownfall

Description

A cave system carved into the coastal cliffs of the Unclaimed territories. Named for the deep, hollow boom it produces when waves strike the cliff face â€” a sound that carries for miles along the shoreline.

The Hollow is the final resting place of a Bastion smith who defected from Kaedris's domain centuries ago. He fled after witnessing the horrors wrought by passion-fire weapons. Mortally wounded on the road, he crawled into the cave to die â€” but not before completing his final work: Oathbreaker's End, a legendary warhammer forged to break the bonds Kaedris creates.

Exterior

  • Dark opening in a grey cliff face, roughly 15 feet high and 20 feet wide
  • Worn path from the rocky beach â€” treasure hunters have sought this place before
  • Bones scattered near the entrance: small animals, some humanoid
  • The smell of salt, wet stone, and something that burned long ago

The Sound: When waves hit the cliff at certain angles, the cave produces a resonant boom â€” low, hollow, unmistakable. Locals call it "the dead smith's heartbeat."

Interior

Level 1 â€” The Mouth

  • Entry chamber with old campfire remains
  • Warning scratched into stone: "HE STILL WORKS"
  • Gallery corridor with carved images telling the smith's story
  • Offering room behind collapsed passage (Jonas cleared with Nat 20 Athletics)

Level 2 â€” The Descent

  • Crossroads with three paths
  • Workshop echo â€” ghostly imprint of the smith at work
  • Dead-end passage with treasure hunter's remains
  • Long stairway descending to Level 3

Level 3 â€” The Forge

  • Antechamber with Bastion-sealed door (Jonas broke through)
  • The Smoldering Forge â€” boss arena containing Oathbreaker's End

Inhabitants

The Smoldering Remnant â€” The smith's restless spirit, flickering between fire and frost. Guards Oathbreaker's End. Killed Jonas.

Allips â€” Fragments of the smith's broken mind, whispering pieces of his guilt. Two were destroyed by the party.

Items Found

  • Corroded Helm â€” Historical curiosity, flame symbol (possibly Bastion)
  • Spectral Residue â€” Crystallized memory, ~200gp value
  • 80gp â€” Old coins from dead treasure hunter
  • Ruined Map â€” Shows The Hollow's location (historical only)

Current Status

The party fled after Jonas's death. The following remain in the Hollow:

  • Jonas's body â€” in the forge chamber
  • The Bleeding Blade â€” cursed longsword, now ownerless and hungry
  • Vor'Kael's True Name â€” ultimate leverage, dangerously unguarded
  • Oathbreaker's End â€” still on the anvil, still guarded by the Remnant
  • The Smoldering Remnant â€” still active, below 50 HP when party fled
items.raw: The Hollow. Dungeon in the coastal Unclaimed, 3 days southeast of Crownfall. Final resting place of a Bastion smith who fled Kaedris's domain. Contains Oathbreaker's End, guarded by the Smoldering Remnant. Jonas died here in Session 23. His body, The Bleeding Blade, and Vor'Kael's true name remain inside.

Crownfall.title: Crownfall
Crownfall.content:
Crownfall

Type: Independent City-State Location: The Unclaimed â€” at the junction of three Sovereign territories Population: ~75,000 permanent residents, 15,000+ transients Government: Council of Coinholders (Ten Founding Houses)

Overview

Crownfall exists because it shouldn't.

A city of nearly a hundred thousand souls thriving in the gaps between Sovereign territories, where no divine authority holds sway, where the laws of three different god-tyrants collide and cancel each other out. It's not a trading post â€” it's a metropolis. Not a smuggler's haven â€” it's a civilization. The largest concentration of free people in the known world, and proof that mortals can build something without kneeling to gods.

The name comes from its founding â€” when King Aldren IV of the Vaelith Dynasty fled the expansion of Mareatha's domain with his court, his treasury, and his crown. He made it this far before his heart gave out. His crown rolled from his dead hand into the dirt of the crossroads. His followers, rather than continue running, decided to stay. They melted the crown for seed money and built a settlement on the corpse of monarchy itself.

That was three hundred years ago. The crown is long gone, but the name remains â€” a reminder that even kings fall, and that something greater can grow from the wreckage.

Geography

Crownfall sits at a three-way junction:

North: Leads toward Veinspire and Mareatha's Circulatory Dominion Southeast: Leads toward the Blooming Rot and Talaris Bloomrend's territory Southwest: Leads toward Ossathar and Vortegas the Bone-Warden's domain East: The deep Unclaimed â€” uncharted, dangerous, full of opportunity

The city is built on flat plains, spreading in a roughly circular pattern from the central Coinhall Plaza. Three major avenues radiate outward like spokes of a wheel toward the three Sovereign territories, with ring roads connecting districts at intervals.

The city is surrounded by massive outer walls â€” ancient stone fortifications expanded over three centuries. More unusually, inner walls separate each district, a legacy of the early days when the Houses didn't trust each other enough to share open streets. Now the district walls serve as territory markers, chokepoints for House guards, and reminders that Crownfall is ten small cities pretending to be one.

The Walls

The Outer Walls: Massive stone fortifications encircling the entire city, 40 feet high and 20 feet thick, with towers every hundred yards. Three major gates (North, Southeast, Southwest) control access to the Sovereign roads, plus the smaller Eastern Gate toward the Unclaimed. House Valdris controls the gates; House Varn mans the walls. The District Walls: Lower but still formidable â€” 20 feet high, running from the outer walls to the central Coin district like spokes. Each district is essentially a walled compound. Gates between districts are controlled by whichever House claims that territory. In times of crisis, districts can seal themselves off from each other. Why District Walls? Three centuries ago, the founding Houses didn't trust each other. They built walls between their territories before they built walls around the city. The Compact eventually brought peace, but the walls remained â€” useful for controlling movement, collecting tolls, and reminding everyone that House law changes at every gate. The Deterrent: The walls help, but Crownfall's true defense is its people:
  • Ten powerful Houses, each with private armies and high-level retainers
  • House Varn's mercenary forces â€” thousands of professional soldiers
  • Countless refugees who fled Sovereign control, many of them powerful adventurers, mages, and warriors
  • The Docent â€” whose true capabilities are unknown but rumored to be considerable
  • Independent powers who have made Crownfall their home specifically because it's free

A Sovereign army would face walls, yes. But behind those walls? A city of people with nothing to lose and everything to fight for.

Districts

The city is divided into districts separated by ring roads, with noble House territories cutting across district lines.

The Coin (Central District) The heart of the city. The Coinhall Plaza, the Exchange markets, major guild headquarters, banking houses. Where power concentrates and deals are made. The most valuable real estate in the free world. The Rings (Middle Districts) Dense urban construction radiating outward from the Coin. Divided into quarters â€” the Northring, Eastring, Southring, Westring â€” each with distinct character. Residential, commercial, industrial, all mixed together. Where most of the city's population lives and works. The Edges (Outer Districts) The newest construction at the city's periphery. Less dense, more varied. Includes:
  • The Kennels â€” Eastern edge. Expedition staging, relic markets, fortune-seekers. Rough but vital.
  • The Threshold â€” Northern edge. Thane territory. Cemetery grounds, crematoriums, death rites.
  • The Sprawl â€” Southern edge. Cheapest housing, newest arrivals, temporary camps.
House Territories The ten Houses each control territory that cuts across district lines â€” their compounds, their businesses, their people. Walking from Valdris territory to Keth territory means changing which laws apply, even if you're still in the Northring.

The Compact

Crownfall has no formal laws â€” it has The Compact, an agreement between the Ten Houses that has evolved over three centuries. The Compact isn't written in any single document; it's a living tradition of precedents, deals, and understandings.

Core Principles:
  1. No House Makes War on Another â€” Assassination, sabotage, and economic warfare are tolerated. Open violence is not. The last inter-house war nearly destroyed the city.
  1. The Tribute Must Flow â€” Every house contributes to the payments that keep surrounding Sovereigns disinterested. Failure to contribute is grounds for expulsion from the Council.
  1. Neutral Ground is Sacred â€” Certain locations (Council chambers, the Docent's library, Thane death-grounds) are inviolable. Violence there is punished by all houses collectively.
  1. Outsiders Follow House Law â€” Visitors must obey the laws of whichever house's territory they're in. Ignorance is no excuse.
  1. The Council's Word is Final â€” A six-vote majority on the Council of Coinholders settles any dispute. A unanimous ten-vote decision cannot be appealed or revisited for a decade.

The Council of Coinholders

The ten founding houses each hold one seat. The Council meets weekly in the Coinhall (neutral ground at city center) to settle disputes, set trade policy, and manage the tribute.

Current Heads:
House Head Role
House Valdris Sera Valdris Gatekeepers â€” Access control
House Morrow Aldric Morrow Tithelords â€” External diplomacy
House Keth Yenra Keth Fleshmongers â€” Grey market
House Drennan Ogden Drennan Hearthkeepers â€” Hospitality
House Carran Iselda Carran Coinbinders â€” Banking
House Varn Torek Varn Blade-Lenders â€” Security
House Selvik Naya Selvik Veilwalkers â€” Expeditions
House Orvenne Gavril Orvenne Binding Word â€” Contracts
House Thane Maren Thane Ashkeepers â€” Death rites
House Quellan Isen Quellan Tonguesingers â€” Information
Voting Dynamics:
  • Six votes needed for majority
  • Ten votes (unanimous) overrides any previous ruling
  • Ties are resolved by coin flip (literally â€” a traditional Crownfall silver)
Current Alliances (Informal):
  • Valdris + Varn â€” Security bloc
  • Morrow + Carran â€” Financial axis
  • Keth + Quellan â€” Shadow alliance
  • Thane â€” Perpetual neutral
  • Selvik, Orvenne, Drennan â€” Swing votes, courted by all

With ten houses, alliances shift constantly. A stable bloc of four can block any majority. Getting to six requires coalition-building across philosophical lines.

The Tribute

Crownfall survives because it pays everyone a little and threatens no one enough to matter.

Tribute Recipients:
  • Veinspire (Mareatha) â€” Paid in rare alchemical components and "blood tithes" (preserved samples)
  • The Blooming Rot (Talaris) â€” Paid in organic matter and corpses for composting
  • Ossathar (Vortegas) â€” Paid in bone artifacts and historical records

House Morrow manages all tribute negotiations. The amounts are carefully calibrated â€” enough to seem respectful, not enough to seem prosperous enough to conquer.

The Secret: The tribute amounts don't actually match what Morrow tells the Council. Aldric has been skimming for decades. If any Sovereign compared notes with the Council's records, the discrepancy would be obvious.

Economy

Crownfall's economy runs on three pillars:

1. Trade Arbitrage Goods illegal in one Sovereign territory are legal in another. Crownfall sits at the junction where everything can be exchanged. A merchant can buy Church-banned texts from Ossathar, sell them to a collector from Veinspire, and neither transaction violates local law â€” because Crownfall has no law against it. 2. Services Banking (Carran), mercenary contracts (Varn), expedition outfitting (Selvik), information (Quellan), and a dozen other services that require neutral ground. People come to Crownfall to do business that can't happen elsewhere. 3. Unclaimed Salvage The deep Unclaimed contains relics, resources, and secrets. Expeditions launch from Crownfall, and the salvage flows back through Crownfall markets. House Selvik and House Keth both profit enormously. Currency: Crownfall accepts all currencies but has its own: Crownfall Silvers (called "Crowns" or "Falls" depending on the speaker). House Carran mints them. They're trusted specifically because they're not tied to any Sovereign â€” neutral money for neutral ground.

Notable Locations

The Coinhall Council chambers at city center. Neutral ground. A circular building with ten doors (one for each house) and no windows. What happens inside stays inside. The Docent's Archive The city's greatest library, maintained by a figure known only as The Docent. Neutral ground by ancient tradition. Contains records of every major deal, dispute, and decision in Crownfall's history â€” and much older things besides. The Three Roads The major avenues leading to the three Sovereign territories. Valdris controls checkpoints on each, monitoring (but not restricting) traffic. The Exchange Crownfall's central market complex, sprawling across multiple blocks near the Coinhall. Operates on house-neutral ground by Council agreement. Anything can be sold here. Anything. The Threshold Thane-controlled cemetery and crematorium district in the northern Edges. Where the dead are processed to ensure they stay dead. The Velvet Thorn Most prestigious inn/tavern in Crownfall. Drennan-owned. Where serious people conduct serious business. The upper floors host services not discussed in polite company. The Silken Refuge Brothel and safehouse in the Sprawl, near the southern Edges. Run by Madame Veshra Coil. Known for buying slaves and freeing them. The workers stay by choice. The Kennels The entire eastern Edge district. Where expeditions outfit, where relic hunters drink, where the desperate and the ambitious mix. Selvik territory, loosely.

Threats & Tensions

External:
  • Sovereign Interest â€” Any of the three nearby Sovereigns could decide Crownfall is worth the cost. The tribute keeps them disinterested, but that could change.
  • Church of Radiant Blood â€” Mareatha's church has agents in the city, watching for heresy and opportunity.
  • The Deep Unclaimed â€” Something is stirring in the eastern zones. Expeditions have been reporting wrongness. Selvik knows more than she's saying.
Internal:
  • Sera Valdris is dying â€” The Gatekeeper's slow decline will trigger a succession crisis. Her nephew Cael is competent but perceived as weak.
  • Morrow's skimming â€” If discovered, it could collapse the tribute arrangement and invite Sovereign intervention.
  • Keth's project â€” Yenra is building something in her basement. No one knows what.
  • Forbidden love â€” Brix Drennan and Cael Valdris are secretly involved. If their families find out, it could mean alliance or war.
  • Thane's secret â€” The cemetery district is built over something that requires constant containment. If the death rites ever stop...

Story Hooks

  • The party needs something that can only be obtained through Crownfall's grey market
  • Someone important is hiding in Crownfall under a false identity
  • A house hires the party for a job against another house â€” deniable, dangerous, lucrative
  • An expedition into the Unclaimed needs capable guards
  • The tribute payment is threatened and someone needs to fix it quietly
  • One of the house heads wants the party to investigate a rival
  • Seraphine Vale and Vela Thorne arrive seeking refuge

â€” Party Visit

Arrival: Day 14 (evening), entered through northern gate Entry Fee: 2 silver each (6 silver total) Lodging: The Velvet Thorn (Coin District, Westring)

Party Activities (Days 15-16)

Jonas:
  • Visited Broma's Forge (Forge Ward) â€” commissioned shield from Custodian armplate (100gp deposit)
  • Broma reacted with terror to the pulsehammer ("a wound in the shape of a weapon")
  • Visited Garrik Holdt (Westring) â€” nothing suitable
  • Visited The Green Door (Kennels) â€” purchased Oathbreaker's End folio (200gp)
Fursen:
  • Visited Thresh's Workshop (Kennels) â€” received diamond teeth in exchange for reciting the Names
  • Visited The Silken Refuge (Sprawl) â€” night with Scarlet and Cinder; received Cinder's Scale and open invitation
Sol Raven:
  • Visited The Green Door (Kennels) â€” purchased Cloak of Protection (280gp)
  • Communed with Velara Ashyn about the passion-seed
  • Gathered intelligence about Seraphine Vale from Velvet Thorn

Intelligence Gathered

Seraphine Vale:
  • Arrived 12 days before party (with Vela Thorne)
  • Stayed 2 nights at the Velvet Thorn
  • Spent a day at the Docent's Archive
  • Left "looking like she'd seen a ghost"
  • Departed through southern gate 10 days before party arrived
  • If she kept moving: dead, in the Bastion, or somewhere between

Locations Established

Crownfall.title: The Docent's Archive
Crownfall.content:
The Docent's Archive

Type: Library / Neutral Ground
District: Crown District, Crownfall
Keeper: The Docent
Status: Active

Overview

The Docent's Archive is Crownfall's greatest repository of knowledge and its most respected neutral ground. A crumbling building that seems held together by habit and old paper, it houses three hundred years of records, treaties, and secrets â€” and texts far older than the city itself.

All ten Founding Houses respect the Archive's neutrality. Violence within its walls is unthinkable. Information gathered here cannot be used as evidence in house disputes. The Archive exists outside Crownfall's politics while sitting at its very center.

Description

Exterior:
  • Crumbling stone facade in the Crown District
  • Looks like it should have collapsed decades ago
  • No signs or markings â€” those who need it know where it is
  • Doors always open during daylight hours
Interior:
  • Dust, silence, the smell of old ink and older secrets
  • Shelves stretching into gloom
  • Candles in holders older than Crownfall
  • Scattered reading tables near the entrance
  • The deep stacks â€” where the dangerous knowledge lives
Atmosphere:
  • Sounds are muffled here
  • Footsteps echo wrong
  • The building feels aware â€” not hostile, just attentive
  • Time seems to move differently in the deep stacks

The Rules

  1. Touch nothing without permission
  2. Remove nothing
  3. Do no violence within these walls

These rules are absolute. The Docent enforces them. How he enforces them is unclear â€” no one has tested it in living memory.

Collections

Public Stacks:
  • Crownfall history (300 years)
  • Trade records and treaties
  • House genealogies (official versions)
  • Maps of the Unclaimed (incomplete)
  • General reference materials
Restricted Stacks:
  • Confidential house records
  • Sealed testimonies
  • Documents under time-lock (cannot be accessed until certain dates)
  • Materials too dangerous for casual readers
The Deep Stacks:
  • Pre-Usurpation texts
  • Theological documents predating Mareatha
  • Fragments of the original creation
  • Things the Docent doesn't discuss

Notable Events

Seraphine Vale's Visit:

Twelve days before the party arrived, Seraphine Vale spent a full day in the deep stacks researching pre-Usurpation theology. She emerged pale and shaken, left the next day heading south.

Party's Visit (Session 22):

The party arrived at the Archive seeking answers about the passion-seed.

All ten Founding Houses respect the Archive's neutrality.

Crownfall.content:
The Velvet Thorn

Type: Inn / Tavern
District: The Coin (Westring), Crownfall
Owner: House Drennan
Status: Active

Overview

The most prestigious inn and tavern in Crownfall. Drennan-owned, where serious people conduct serious business. The upper floors host services not discussed in polite company.

This is where the party has been staying during their time in Crownfall.

Party Lodging

The party arrived on Day 14 (evening) and has been using the Velvet Thorn as their base of operations in Crownfall.

Intelligence Gathered Here:
  • Seraphine Vale arrived 12 days before the party (with Vela Thorne)
  • She stayed 2 nights at the Velvet Thorn
  • Spent a day at the Docent's Archive
  • Left "looking like she'd seen a ghost"
  • Departed through southern gate 10 days before party arrived

Crownfall.title: The Silken Refuge
Crownfall.content:
The Silken Refuge

Type: Brothel / Safehouse Location: The Sprawl, Crownfall (near the border with The Spillway) Owner: Madame Veshra Coil Affiliation: Independent â€” deliberately unaligned with any House

Overview

The Silken Refuge is exactly what its name suggests â€” a place of comfort for those seeking it, and sanctuary for those who work there. From the outside, it's a well-maintained three-story building of dark timber and amber-lit windows, unremarkable among the Sprawl's many establishments. Inside, it's one of the few truly safe places in a city built on deals and compromises.

What makes the Refuge different isn't the quality of its services â€” though those are excellent â€” but its staff. Every worker is a former slave purchased and freed by Madame Veshra. They stay because they want to, leave when they choose, and are protected with a ferocity that has earned the Refuge a reputation even House Varn's mercenaries respect.

The Refuge caters to all tastes and all species. In a city where refugees from every Sovereign domain mix with native Unclaimed folk, exiled nobles, and desperate fortune-seekers, the Refuge reflects that diversity. Its workers are elves and half-orcs, tieflings and halflings, humans from a dozen different origins, and stranger things besides.

Madame Veshra Coil

Race: Human | Age: 52 | Role: Owner, Protector, Mother Figure

A human woman in her fifties who has aged into iron rather than frailty. Rose from a cheap brothel in the Kennels to owning the most respected establishment in The Sprawl through sheer will and cunning. Now she buys slaves just to free them, and protects everyone under her roof with a ferocity that even House Varn respects.

See Veshra Coil for full details.

The Staff

Old Nara (Dwarf)

Description Dwarven woman in her eighties â€” middle-aged by dwarven standards, ancient by human reckoning. Broad, weathered, fiery red hair streaked with iron grey, bright blue eyes that have seen everything, intricate braids with copper beads from her lost clan. Was enslaved when her hold fell to Vortegas's expansion. Has been with Veshra for twenty-five years. Runs the kitchen now but still has "regulars" who've been coming for decades. Personality: Sharp-tongued, warm-hearted, makes the best stew in the Sprawl. Grandmother to the whole house. Will hit you with a ladle if you disrespect anyone under this roof.

The Workers

Tessa (Human)

Human woman in her late twenties, fair skin dusted with freckles, warm auburn hair in loose waves, bright green eyes full of genuine warmth, soft features with an easy smile. Former pleasure slave to a Veinspire merchant â€” escaped during a trade dispute. The Madam found her starving at the North Gate. Now she's the first face newcomers see, and she makes sure it's a kind one.

Warm, playful, genuinely enjoys her work now that it's her choice. The "welcome" for nervous first-timers. Has a gift for making people feel at ease.

Scarlet (Tiefling)

Tiefling woman in her late twenties, dusky skin with a warm undertone, small curved horns half-hidden in a wild mane of dark curly hair, striking amber-gold eyes that glow faintly in dim light, sharp canines visible when she grins â€” which is often. Confident, sensual, knows exactly the effect she has on people and enjoys it. Was a "pet" to a wealthy collector who liked exotic things. When Veshra bought her contract, Scarlet asked if she could stay and work. She likes the work. She likes choosing.

Bold, playful, teasing. The one who makes clients blush before they even reach a room. Wears red exclusively. Has never met a boundary she couldn't push â€” but respects "no" absolutely.

Roslyn (Human)

Human woman in her early thirties, fair skin, dark curly hair pinned up in artful disarray, warm hazel eyes, soft knowing smile. Curves poured into a burgundy corset she clearly enjoys wearing. Former house slave to a minor Crownfall family â€” not one of the Ten, but wealthy enough to be cruel. Veshra bought out her contract when the family fell into debt. She's been here five years and has no intention of leaving.

Warm, experienced, maternal in an unexpected way. The one nervous clients end up confiding in. Makes everyone feel like they're her favorite. Probably because, in that moment, they are.

Runa (Goliath)

Goliath woman in her early thirties, pale grey skin with darker grey markings like natural tattoos across her shoulders and arms, powerfully muscular build that towers over most clients, dark hair pulled back in a practical braid, intense pale eyes that assess every threat. Jaw-droppingly strong â€” her abs alone have inspired poetry. Former pit fighter in the Ossuary Kingdom â€” bought by Veshra after she killed her owner in the ring. Still learning that strength can protect instead of just destroy.

Fierce, protective, speaks little. Handles security more than clients, but has regulars who appreciate her particular intensity. Wears leather and not much else â€” she earned this body, she'll show it.

Whisper (Changeling)

Changeling of uncertain age, currently presenting as a beautiful pale-skinned woman with silver-white hair, but their features shift subtly â€” eye color drifting, bone structure adjusting to client preference. Was kept by a Blackfold noble as a "mirror" â€” forced to wear faces of the noble's dead lovers. Doesn't have a fixed appearance anymore, but is learning to choose forms for themselves.

Quiet, observant, still figuring out who they are when not reflecting someone else's desires. Veshra is helping them discover preferences.

Ember (Tiefling)

Young tiefling woman in her early twenties, pale lavender skin, small delicate horns she used to file down, thin tail she's learning not to hide, eyes of soft pink. Born into slavery, sold to a Bastion of Fireblood cult for "purification rituals." Veshra killed the buyer personally to get her out. Still flinches at flames but is getting better.

Sweet, shy, the little sister everyone protects. Only takes clients she chooses, mostly companionship rather than anything physical. Learning that she's allowed to have boundaries.

Silhouette (Shadar-kai / Shadow Elf)

Shadar-kai woman of indeterminate age, ash-grey skin, eyes of pure black that reflect nothing, stark white hair cropped short, ritual scars in geometric patterns across her visible skin. From somewhere in the Blackfold before it was Ultharion's â€” she doesn't speak of it. Arrived at the Refuge bleeding and hasn't left. Draws clients who want something darker, stranger.

Quiet, intense, melancholy. Finds something like peace here. Her room is always cold.

Juniper (Halfling)

Halfling woman in her thirties, barely four feet tall, round friendly face with dimples, curly chestnut hair always escaping its pins, large warm brown eyes. Was a house slave in Crownfall itself â€” House Keth, specifically. Veshra bought her freedom as a pointed message to Yenra Keth. Sunny disposition hides a surprising ruthlessness regarding her former owners.

Cheerful, chatty, everyone's friend. Hears everything, remembers everything, tells Veshra everything. Far more dangerous than she looks.

Sorrow (Grief-Born)

Not born but manifested â€” crystallized from a mother's grief when her children were sold away. Appears as a woman whose skin is pale blue-grey crystal with visible depth, tears permanently frozen on her cheeks like gems, hair of fine glass threads that chime when she moves. Veshra found her wandering, not understanding what she was. Gave her a name, a room, a purpose.

Speaks little, feels much. Clients who visit her often leave having cried for the first time in years. She absorbs sorrow and gives back peace. It's not conventional work, but it's needed.

Veyla (Aasimar)

Aasimar woman in her twenties, luminous pale skin that glows faintly, silver-gold hair that moves slightly without wind, eyes of liquid gold. Divine-touched in a world where the divine is dead or corrupted. Was kept as a "holy relic" by a Mareathan cult, displayed and worshipped and never allowed to be a person. Veshra got her out through channels she doesn't discuss.

Still learning that she's allowed to want things. Her beauty makes people uncomfortable â€” it feels like looking at something holy in a very unholy establishment. She's slowly embracing the contradiction.

Lirael (Elf)

Elven woman who appears to be in her late twenties but is closer to three hundred, pale ivory skin, angular features that would be cold if not for the warmth in her faded violet eyes, long silver-white hair worn loose, pointed ears adorned with simple silver cuffs. Was a court musician in a minor noble house before the family sold her to cover debts. Three centuries of life and she ended up property. Veshra bought her at auction and asked what she wanted to do with her freedom. She chose to stay.

Melancholy grace, speaks softly, plays the harp in the common room some evenings. Clients who want conversation more than anything else seek her out. Has seen too much to be shocked by anything.

Vex (Drow / Dark Elf)

Drow woman in her apparent thirties, obsidian-dark skin, stark white hair cropped short and practical, eyes of pale lavender that glow faintly in darkness, sharp angular features. Fled the underdark politics of her people, was captured by surface slavers who thought an exotic dark elf would fetch a premium. She did. Veshra outbid everyone. Now she handles clients who want something dangerous, and she enjoys reminding surface-dwellers that she's not as tame as they assume.

Sharp, sardonic, takes no shit. Enjoys making clients nervous. Fiercely loyal to Veshra for treating her like a person instead of a curiosity.

Cinder (Dragonborn)

Dragonborn woman with scales of deep burnished copper that catch firelight beautifully, amber eyes with slit pupils, small horns swept back from her skull, a powerful but feminine build. Was bred for pit fighting â€” dragonborn fetch high prices in the arena circuit. Won thirty-two matches before Veshra bought her contract. Chose to stay because she'd never had a soft bed or a choice before. Takes clients who want strength, and those who just want to touch her scales.

Quiet dignity, moves with controlled power, surprisingly gentle. Still not used to being treated well. Cries sometimes when clients are kind to her, which embarrasses her.

Marrow (Dhampir)

Dhampir woman in her apparent late twenties though likely much older, deathly pale skin that never sees sun, dark hair with a sharp widow's peak, eyes of pale red like diluted blood, elongated canines visible when she smiles, gaunt sharp features of predatory beauty. Half-vampire, never fully accepted by either world. Was kept by a Veinspire blood cult as a "sacred vessel" â€” they fed from her, believing her mixed blood had holy properties. Veshra got her out. She doesn't talk about how.

Darkly sensual, gallows humor, surprisingly kind beneath the predator aesthetic. Some clients want the danger. She gives them just enough to thrill without harm. Feeds only on willing donors now â€” the Refuge has arrangements.

Shale (Lizardfolk)

Lizardfolk woman with scales of mottled green and brown, large amber eyes with horizontal pupils, a crest of softer scales along her head in lieu of hair, long tail she uses expressively, clawed hands she's learned to use gently. Was captured from her swamp tribe and sold as an exotic curiosity. Doesn't fully understand mammalian concepts of affection but is learning. Some clients find her alienness fascinating. She finds mammals equally strange but has grown fond of them.

Blunt, practical, doesn't understand euphemisms. Surprisingly warm once you understand her. Tilts her head like a curious bird when confused. Has learned to enjoy physical warmth â€” her room is always heated.

Ssyllia (Yuan-Ti Pureblood)

Yuan-ti pureblood woman, almost human-looking at first glance â€” pale skin with a faint greenish undertone, beautiful features with something subtly wrong about the proportions, eyes of solid amber with slit pupils, forked tongue she's learned to hide. Patches of fine scales visible at her temples and along her spine. Was an assassin for her people before she failed a mission and was sold rather than executed. Veshra bought her knowing exactly what she was. Ssyllia has never been trusted before. It's... strange.

Cold, calculating, slowly thawing. Speaks in a slight hiss she can't fully suppress. Genuinely confused by the concept of loyalty earned rather than demanded. Watches Veshra like she's solving a puzzle.

Flame of Passion (Tabaxi)

Tabaxi woman in her late twenties, sleek tawny-gold fur with dark rosette spots, large amber eyes with slit pupils, small rounded ears with gold cuffs, pink nose, elegant whiskers. Captured by exotic animal traders who didn't realize she was a person until she spoke. Sold to a nobleman who wanted a "pet" that could talk. Veshra bought her after hearing rumors of a "talking cat" in a gilded cage. Chose her own name the day she was freed.

Languid, confident, purrs when content. Takes her time with everything. Clients who want undivided feline attention seek her out. Has a weakness for being brushed.

Lullaby (Thoughtweaver)

Thoughtweaver woman of indeterminate age, pale luminous skin with a faint violet undertone, eyes of swirling iridescent purple with no visible pupils, long flowing hair that drifts between silver and violet like smoke. Faint glowing vein-like patterns pulse beneath the skin at her temples. From the Blackfold â€” Ultharion's domain of dreams and nightmares. Veshra found her wandering the Kennels, starving because she'd forgotten that bodies need food. Can craft sensations directly in the mind â€” what she offers isn't physical, it's your deepest fantasies made manifest.

Dreamy, distant, often finishes sentences before they're asked. Veshra watches her carefully â€” Lullaby sometimes forgets she has a body at all. Clients leave unable to fully remember what happened, only that it was exactly what they needed.

Raven (Drow / Dark Elf)

Drow man in his apparent forties, obsidian-dark skin, long white hair worn loose past his shoulders, eyes of deep crimson that smolder in low light, sharp aristocratic features, lean muscular build. Was a minor noble in the underdark before a house war left him the sole survivor â€” and a valuable commodity. Sold to the surface as a curiosity, passed between owners who wanted to own something beautiful and dangerous. Veshra was the first to ask his name. He gave her a false one. She knew and didn't press. He's been here three years and still hasn't told anyone his real name.

Cultured, guarded, watches everything. Speaks softly with impeccable manners that feel like armor. Takes clients who want refinement â€” conversation, wine, the illusion of courtship. Lets very few past his walls. Those who do find someone desperately lonely.

Callum (Human)

Human man in his late twenties, fair skin with a scattering of freckles, tousled copper-brown hair, warm green eyes, easy smile that comes readily. Handsome in a boyish, approachable way rather than intimidatingly beautiful. Was a debt-slave â€” his father's gambling debts passed to him when the old man died. Worked as a laborer until a wealthy merchant bought his contract for "personal service." When the merchant tried to sell him on, Veshra intervened. He's genuinely happy here â€” good pay, good company, and work he doesn't mind.

Charming, easygoing, good listener. The "safe" choice for clients who are nervous or new. Makes everyone feel comfortable. Flirts shamelessly but kindly. Has become something of a little brother to the other workers despite being grown.

House Rules

Posted near the entrance, enforced without exception:

  1. No means no. Always. Immediately. Without question.
  2. What happens here stays here. We don't know your name if you don't want us to.
  3. Weapons stay at the door. The staff are protection enough.
  4. Payment before service. House Carran notes accepted.
  5. Harm a worker, lose a hand. This is not metaphorical.
  6. Species is not a curiosity. Everyone here is a person first.
  7. The Madam's word is final. Appeal to the Council if you dare.

Services & Prices

Companionship (conversation, drinks, company): 5 silvers/hour Standard Services: 20-50 silvers depending on worker and request Specialty Services: Negotiated individually Overnight: 100+ silvers "Just talk to Sorrow": Pay what you feel it was worth Workers keep 70% of their earnings. The house takes 30% for room, board, and protection.

Reputation

Common Knowledge:
  • The Silken Refuge is one of the safer establishments in the Sprawl
  • The Madam rose from courtesan to owner through sheer will and cunning
  • Don't cause trouble there unless you want trouble back
  • They cater to all species and most tastes
  • The workers seem... happy? Genuinely?
Known to Those Who Ask:
  • Madame Veshra has killed at least three people who hurt her workers
  • House Varn tried to muscle her once. They don't talk about what happened.
  • She buys slaves just to free them â€” House Keth hates her for it
  • She trades information with House Quellan
  • Some workers are things that aren't quite mortal

â€” Fursen's Visit

Day 15-16, Night

Fursen came seeking companionship after the loss of his wisdom teeth to the Hollow Crawler and the weight of being the last Leonin. Tessa greeted him at the door.

His Choices: Scarlet (tiefling, bold, playful) and Cinder (dragonborn, copper scales, intense). Cost: 150 silver for the full night with both.

The Night

Fire meeting fire.

Scarlet â€” dusky skin, dark curls, amber eyes, horns curved back â€” teased him, made him work for every touch. Her tail traced patterns on his thigh. She pinned his wrists and showed him what tiefling boldness meant.

Cinder â€” copper scales like burnished metal, amber slit-pupil eyes, quiet power â€” was the counterpoint. Slow. Deliberate. Her scales ran furnace-hot against his fur. She held him from behind while Scarlet worked, stronger than she looked, pressing heat into his spine.

Between them, Fursen forgot.

Forgot the names burning in his skull. Forgot the teeth the Crawler took. Forgot that he's the last of his kind. For one night, he was just a body â€” fur and muscle and breath â€” held between two people who knew exactly what they were doing.

The Morning

Fursen stayed for breakfast. Unusual â€” most clients leave before dawn.

Scarlet stole food from his plate, grinning around a mouthful of bread.

Cinder's foot pressed against his thigh under the table â€” steady warmth.

They talked. Actually talked. About grief. About presence. About why Fursen was "actually here" unlike most clients who pretend it means nothing.

"You carry something. I don't know what. But you're not hiding from it â€” you're just... taking a breath."

â€” Scarlet

Afternoon

Fursen paid for an extended stay. The second session was slower. Exploratory.

Scarlet mapped every inch of him. Pinned him again, used teeth and mouth with deliberate care. Cinder held him from behind, scales furnace-hot, worked with Scarlet in practiced rhythm.

By evening, they were tangled on the floor by dying embers â€” Scarlet draped across his chest tracing patterns in his fur, Cinder's foot pressed against his thigh.

The Parting

Scarlet: "Diamond teeth and claws. I'm keeping you."

"If you survive whatever you're doing out there... come back. I mean it. Most clients, I forget their faces by morning. I won't forget yours."

Cinder gave Fursen one of her scales â€” copper, palm-sized, shed naturally. Still warm.

"For luck. And for remembering."

Madame Veshra Coil spoke to Fursen at the bar as he left:

"You treated my girls well. They speak highly of you â€” and they don't say that about most."

"You're welcome back. Anytime. No payment required â€” just company and stories."

"A Leonin. I thought your people were gone... I'm glad to see I was wrong."
Crownfall.raw: The Silken Refuge Type: Brothel / Safehouse Location: The Sprawl, Crownfall (near the border with The Spillway) Owner: Madame Veshra Coil Affiliation: Independent â€” deliberately unaligned with any House Overview The Silken Refuge is exactly what its name suggests â€” a place of comfort for those seeking it, and sanctuary for those who work there. From the outside, it's a well-maintained three-story building of dark timber and amber-lit windows, unremarkable among the Sprawl's many establishments. Inside, it's one of the few truly safe places in a city built on deals and compromises. What makes the Refuge different isn't the quality of its services â€” though those are excellent â€” but its staff. Every worker is a former slave purchased and freed by Madame Veshra. They stay because they want to, leave when they choose, and are protected with a ferocity that has earned the Refuge a reputation even House Varn's mercenaries respect. The Refuge caters to all tastes and all species. In a city where refugees from every Sovereign domain mix with native Unclaimed folk, exiled nobles, and desperate fortune-seekers, the Refuge reflects that diversity. Its workers are elves and half-orcs, tieflings and halflings, humans from a dozen different origins, and stranger things besides. Madame Veshra Coil Race: Human | Age: 52 | Role: Owner, Protector, Mother Figure A human woman in her fifties who has aged into iron rather than frailty. Rose from a cheap brothel in the Kennels to owning the most respected establishment in The Sprawl through sheer will and cunning. Now she buys slaves just to free them, and protects everyone under her roof with a ferocity that even House Varn respects. See Veshra Coil for full details. The Staff Old Nara (Dwarf) Description Dwarven woman in her eighties â€” middle-aged by dwarven standards, ancient by human reckoning. items.title: Azerach Pact Materials
items.content:
Azerach Pact Materials

Overview

Materials related to forming a pact with Azerach the Whispered King. Unlike other Sovereigns who demand blood or souls, Azerach's price is far more personal.

Source

Information from The Doctrine of Still Air, a book purchased from Thessaly at The Frayed Codex.

What Azerach Wants

  • He doesn't want blood
  • Doesn't want souls
  • He wants secrets â€” yours, others', the things people bury so deep they forget they buried them

The Ritual

According to Thessaly and the Doctrine of Still Air:

  • The pact is sealed through silence, not speech
  • You must offer a secret that has never been spoken
  • Azerach's brand is described as "a door that opens both ways"
  • The ritual was known to Azerach's warlocks before he "faded"

The Cost

Warlocks of the Whispered King gain power over silence â€” the ability to steal words from throats, to move without sound, to hear what was never meant to be heard.

But they fade. Not physically â€” but socially. People forget they're in the room. Conversations move past them. They become background. Unnoticed. Unremembered.

Thessaly's Warning

"Warlocks of the Whispered King... they start to fade. People forget they're in the room. Conversations move past them. They become... background."

The Litany of Unmaking

A spell contained in the Doctrine of Still Air:

  • Forces truth for 1 hour
  • Cost: The speaker loses their voice for 1 day

Related

  • Azerach the Whispered King
  • The Doctrine of Still Air
  • Thessaly
  • The Frayed Codex
