items.title: Diamond Teeth
items.content:
Diamond Teeth

Type: Permanent Modification | Bearer: Fursen

What They Are

Two wisdom teeth (lower left) made of diamond, cut to perfect Leonin dentition and anchored directly to the jawbone. Permanent, functional, and capable of biting through leather â€” maybe thin wood.

Origin

The Hollow Crawler's Consume Feature dissolved two of Fursen's wisdom teeth during the ambush on Day 8. Fursen discovered the loss at dawn and wept â€” grief for the teeth, for everything taken, for being the last Leonin.

In Crownfall, Fursen visited Thresh â€” a body modifier in the Kennels District. Thresh asked for payment in story, not gold. Fursen recited names from the 10,000 Names in his blood.

Thresh was moved: "I have never met someone who touched a god and lived."

The service was free in exchange for being remembered. Fursen promised: "I will remember you."

items.title: Oathkeeper
items.content:
Oathkeeper

Legendary Weapon â€” Conviction Made Steel "Forged from two thousand years of conviction, Oathkeeper is less a weapon and more a philosophy given edge." Weapon (greatsword), legendary (requires attunement by a Paladin or similar) Original Wielder: Mira Alethain Current Holder: Seraphine Vale Acquired by Seraphine: â€” Church of the Merciful Vein

Description

Oathkeeper does not look forged. It looks decided.

The blade is pale steel that seems to glow from within â€” not brightly, but with a warmth that suggests conviction rather than magic. No runes adorn its surface. No gems decorate its crossguard. The weapon is austere, purposeful, beautiful in its refusal to be anything other than what it is.

The grip is wrapped in leather that has molded itself to hands that held it with certainty. The pommel bears no symbol â€” only smooth, warm metal that fits perfectly in the palm.

It first manifested the day Mira Alethain chose truth over obedience. The sword did not exist before that moment. Then it did.

History

Origin

Oathkeeper was not forged in a smithy. It was forged in a moment.

Two thousand years of accumulated conviction â€” the faith of paladins, the certainty of martyrs, the unwavering belief of those who chose truth over survival â€” crystallized into steel the instant Mira Alethain defied the Church of Mareatha.

She had been an Inquisitor. A hunter of heretics. A perfect instrument of doctrine.

Then she learned the truth about what the Church had done to her husband.

The moment she chose Elias over obedience, the moment she turned her back on everything she had believed, Oathkeeper appeared in her hands. Not given. Not found. Manifested.

The sword recognized something in her choice â€” a conviction pure enough to deserve an edge.

Mira's Wielder

For thirty years, Mira carried Oathkeeper through exile and pursuit. The blade served her faithfully, burning bright against the servants of the Church that had betrayed her., Mira Alethain was consumed by Savaros the High Keeper. Her flesh was stripped. Her bones were left behind.

Oathkeeper fell beside her skeleton, its glow flickering and dying.

Transition

Sol Raven recovered the blade after Mira's death. When his skeletal fingers touched the grip, Oathkeeper responded â€” warming, glowing, acknowledging him despite his nature.

But Sol was a sorcerer. A skeleton. He could not wield a greatsword, no matter how much the weapon seemed willing.

He brought Oathkeeper to Seraphine Vale â€” the broken High Inquisitor whose faith had been shattered by revelations about the Church she served.

Sol offered the blade to her: "I think she would've wanted you to have this."

Seraphine's Wielder

When Seraphine took Oathkeeper, it felt cold in her grasp.

Not the warmth Sol had experienced. Not the acknowledgment. The sword was waiting. Judging. Deciding whether this woman â€” who had spent her life hunting people like Mira â€” could ever become worthy of a heretic's conviction.

Seraphine made a promise: "I'll try to be someone worthy of this blade."

Whether she can keep that promise remains to be seen.

The Sword's Judgment

Oathkeeper is not sentient in the traditional sense. It does not speak. It does not scheme. It does not demand.

But it knows.

It knows when a wielder acts from conviction versus convenience. It knows when truth is spoken and when lies are told. It knows when someone is worthy of its edge and when they are simply holding steel.

For Mira: The blade burned bright. Every strike carried thirty years of righteous fury. The sword and the woman were one purpose, one conviction, one truth. For Sol: The blade acknowledged him â€” perhaps recognizing something in his nature as a fragment-bearer, perhaps simply grateful to be recovered from beside its wielder's bones. For Seraphine: The blade is cold. Waiting. Testing. The inquisitor must prove herself before Oathkeeper will truly serve her.

Mechanical Notes

Damage Breakdown

Source Damage
Base greatsword 2d6 slashing
Enhancement bonus +3
Conviction's Edge 1d8 radiant
Total per hit 2d6 + 3 slashing + 1d8 radiant
Against liars (Truth-Seeker) +2d6 radiant

Attunement Requirements

Oathkeeper requires attunement by a Paladin or similar class â€” defined as someone whose power derives from conviction, oath, or unwavering belief. This includes:

  • Paladins (any oath)
  • Devotion-based Clerics (DM discretion)
  • Characters with similar narrative conviction (DM discretion)

Seraphine qualifies despite her crisis of faith â€” the sword is testing whether she can rebuild conviction, not whether she currently possesses it.

Current Status

Holder: Seraphine Vale Location: Church of the Merciful Vein, Veinspire Condition: Cold to Seraphine's touch; waiting to judge her worthiness Attunement: Pending (Seraphine has not yet attuned)

items.title: Seraphine's Letter
items.content:
Seraphine's Letter

Type: Warning Letter | Author: Seraphine Vale

What It Is

A letter left by Seraphine Vale in her quarters at the Church of the Merciful Vein, addressed to the party. She fled Veinspire before they arrived.

Contents

Seraphine witnessed the Confluence â€” the ritual that "resurrected" Ardian Bloodveil. But Oathkeeper warned her. The sword grew cold like ice when Ardian opened his eyes.

She saw the Cardinal and Ardian share a knowing look that no one else noticed. They know each other.

Seraphine has renounced her faith and fled to "a place where blood does not flow." Her current whereabouts are unknown.

Hidden Evidence

Jonas found additional items hidden in Seraphine's room:

  • A sketch of Ardian on the steps, the Cardinal's shadow behind him â€” faceless, tall, wrong
  • A requisition order with the Cardinal's seal: specimens R-7, R-13, R-22 taken from Reliquary vaults, dated 2 weeks before the Confluence
  • A scratched message on the wardrobe floor: "If I die, know that I tried. â€”S.V."

items.title: Soul Anchor Amulet
items.content:
Soul Anchor Amulet

Type: Pre-Usurpation Artifact | Bearer: Sol Raven (Velara's soul within)

What It Is

A dull metal amulet, tarnished green, pulsing with a steady heartbeat rhythm. When Jonas lifted it from the mummified corpse in the Bone Field wagon, the corpse's hand grabbed his wrist with iron grip and whispered: "...don't... take it... to... her..."

The amulet is a soul anchor â€” pre-Usurpation containment magic. It doesn't preserve flesh â€” it preserves self. The pulse is a prison rhythm.

Velara Ashyn

The soul trapped within is Velara Ashyn â€” former consort of Kaedris the Crimson Matron. 500 years ago, she stole the passion-seed and fled. The caravan she hired was killed by something Kaedris sent â€” a burning woman who walked with feet that left glass in the dirt.

Velara's soul was trapped in the amulet for centuries, aware, watching the caravan rot around her. She has asked the party to take her to the Docent's Archive in Crownfall.

Properties

When Jonas tried to examine the amulet (Arcana 1), it flared cold, whited out his vision, gave him a nosebleed, and knocked him to one knee. The amulet rejected examination.

Sol's communion revealed Velara recognizes that Sol isn't alive but isn't empty â€” "...there's something inside you too..."

items.title: The Bleeding Blade
items.content:
The Bleeding Blade

Weapon (longsword), legendary (requires attunement) Current Holder: Jonas Location Found: Catacomb Reliquary, Veinspire

Description

A longsword of dark iron â€” not black, but the deep red-brown of dried blood. Veins run through the metal itself, hairline fractures that pulse faintly with crimson light. Like arteries. Like the sword is alive.

The crossguard is shaped like two hands pressed together in prayer, wrists opened, blood flowing down to form the grip. The pommel is a clot â€” a hardened sphere of something that might be ruby, might be crystallized blood.

It's beautiful. It's obscene.

Curse â€” The Vein-Mother's Thirst

Daily Hunger: If you finish a long rest without having dealt damage to a living creature with the Bleeding Blade since your last long rest, you take 2d10 necrotic damage that cannot be healed until you feed the blade. Death's Pull: While attuned, you have disadvantage on death saving throws. Your blood wants to leave your body. Bound: The blade cannot be unequipped willingly. Breaking attunement requires Remove Curse cast at 7th level or higher, or Mareatha's direct intervention.

Dormant Sentience

The Bleeding Blade contains an echo of something â€” not quite sentient, but aware.

  • It pulses when near large amounts of blood
  • It grows warm in battle
  • It grows cold when sheathed for too long
It remembers Mira. It felt her die.

The blade was in the Catacomb Reliquary when Savaros consumed Mira Alethain. It experienced her death. Whether this has changed the blade in some way remains to be seen.

History

The Bleeding Blade is one of Mareatha's oldest relics â€” created in the early days after the Usurpation when the Vein-Mother's faithful were still learning what divine blood could do.

It was kept in the Catacomb Reliquary for centuries, displayed at the altar as a symbol of sacrifice and devotion. Savaros the High Keeper guarded it â€” though he served Ultharion, not Mareatha.

Jonas took the blade from the altar after Savaros's defeat. It bit him for 5 necrotic damage as introduction â€” a small tithe to establish the bond.

Connection to Mareatha

The blade is infused with the Vein-Mother's essence. While attuned:

  • Servants of Mareatha may recognize the blade's signature
  • The blade may react in proximity to Mareathan holy sites
  • Mareatha herself could theoretically sense the blade if she chose to pay attention

Whether Mareatha would approve of an enemy of her Church wielding her relic... is another question.

items.title: The Passion-Seed
items.content:
The Passion-Seed

Type: Divine Fragment | Bearer: Jonas

What It Is

A black stone darker than obsidian, warm to the touch, that seems to deny light around it. It pulses with heat that resonates with intense emotion.

This is the original passion-seed â€” a fragment of concentrated passion crystallized from Aedwynn's heart. Kaedris cut this from the Maker's heart with her own hands.

Danger

According to Velara Ashyn:

  • Kaedris found a way to grow more passion-seeds
  • One seed can ignite a city
  • A hundred could burn the world
  • Without the original, the others are just echoes
  • With it, Kaedris could finish what she started

Properties

The passion-seed resonated with the Bleeding Blade when Jonas found both in the Bone Field wagon.

Warning from Velara: "Don't feel strongly near it. It responds to emotion, amplifies it."

Velara's Attempts

Velara tried to destroy it once. Fire, blade, magic â€” nothing works. It's a piece of a god's heart. It cannot be unmade by conventional means. She considered throwing it into the Void zones but feared Kaedris might still find it.

The Docent might know how to unmake something that can't be unmade.

items.title: The Remembrance Seal
items.content:
The Remembrance Seal

Type: Protective Artifact | Bearer: Sol Raven

What It Is

A pendant of black iron, cold to the touch. It grants its bearer advantage on saving throws against memory alteration effects. Inside the seal is a preserved memory â€” the final memory of its previous owner.

How It Was Found

In the bile pools of Vor'Kael's Throat, Sol found a skeleton â€” a woman who had almost escaped the Hollow Empress's domain 800 years ago. She was dissolving inches from freedom when she died. Around her neck was the Remembrance Seal.

Sol retrieved it from her remains and now carries her memory forward.

The Final Memory

The seal contains the woman's last moments â€” her desperate crawl through the bile, the burning as her flesh dissolved, the sight of freedom just out of reach. She wore the seal to remember who she was as Vor'Kael tried to consume her meaning. She almost made it.

items.title: The Resonant Codex
items.content:
The Resonant Codex

Transformed by Loss "The book likes you. I can feel it. Something about what you carry â€” the Witness thing. It resonates." â€” Kael's final entry Wondrous Item, rare (requires attunement) Current Holder: Sol Raven Original Holder: Kael (deceased) Transformed: â€” Catacomb Reliquary

Description

A leather-bound tome of unusual weight. The cover is embossed with symbols that shift when not observed directly. The pages reorganize themselves based on the reader's needs, bringing relevant information forward.

The pages are blood-stained â€” Kael's blood, from when Savaros consumed him.

History

Original Acquisition

The party stole the Resonant Codex from the Veinspire church archives at the request of the Resonance Theorists. Kael became its primary user, studying its contents about pre-Sovereign resonance theory.

Kael's Use

Throughout Sessions 3-18, Kael consulted the Codex regularly. It responded to his nature as an ontological anomaly â€” a concept that refused dissolution. The book and Kael developed a connection.

Transformation

When Savaros consumed Kael in the Catacomb Reliquary, his blood soaked the Codex's pages. Sol Raven retrieved the book from beside Kael's skeleton.

When Sol touched it, he experienced a vision of Kael's journey â€” consumption by Vor'Kael, resistance, expulsion. The pressure of a god trying to digest him.

The Codex transformed. It now responds to Sol's nature as the Maker's Witness.

Properties

Base Properties (Unchanged)

  • Contains resonance theory and pre-Sovereign knowledge
  • Pages reorganize based on reader's needs
  • Detects ontological anomalies (proximity sensing)
  • Can identify beings that "shouldn't exist"

New Properties (Post-Transformation)

Witness Resonance: Sol's Witness visions are automatically recorded in the Codex. When he accesses the Maker's memory or experiences divine revelation, the book writes it down â€” preserving the knowledge even if Sol forgets. Kael's Echo (1/Long Rest): Sol can ask a question about identity, existence, or self. The book answers in Kael's voice.

Kael's Echo

This is not Kael's soul or consciousness. It is an echo â€” an impression left in the Codex by a concept that refused to dissolve.

When Sol asks a question:
  • The answer comes in Kael's voice
  • Always honest
  • Often uncertain
  • Occasionally profound
  • Sometimes asks questions back
Limitations:
  • Can only answer questions about identity, existence, or self
  • Does not know current events (stuck in a permanent present)
  • Does not know Kael is dead
  • Cannot take actions or provide tactical information
  • Is not aware of conversations it isn't directly asked into
Sample Interactions:

Sol: "Kael, what does it mean to be real?"

Echo: "I think... it means someone remembers you. It means you left a mark. It means something changed because you existed. Does that count? I hope that counts."

Sol: "Do you remember dying?"

Echo: "Dying? I don't... no. Why would I remember that? Sol, is something wrong?"

Kael's Final Entry

Found when Sol first opened the transformed Codex:

"If you're reading this, I'm probably dead. The codex knows things I don't. Sol â€” if it's you â€” I'm sorry I couldn't be more useful. I'm sorry I didn't understand what I was in time to matter. But you called me real. You said I was making choices NOW. That it mattered. I hope you were right.

â€” Kael

P.S. â€” The book likes you. I can feel it. Something about what you carry â€” the Witness thing. It resonates. Take care of it. Take care of them."

Connection to the Witness

The Codex and Sol's Witness abilities have formed a symbiotic relationship:

  • Sol's visions are recorded automatically
  • The Codex organizes divine knowledge for easier access
  • Kael's echo may have insights about Sol's nature as a "wrong thought"
  • Both Sol and the Codex carry pieces of beings that shouldn't exist

items.title: Oathbreaker's End
items.content:
Oathbreaker's End

Type: Legendary Warhammer | Location: The Hollow (3 days southeast of Crownfall) | Status: Not yet retrieved

The Weapon

Oathbreaker's End is a legendary warhammer forged in the Bastion of Fireblood during the early post-Usurpation era.

Origin

Varros, a master smith in the Bastion, created this weapon. He poured his hatred of broken promises into the metal itself - every betrayal he'd witnessed, every oath violated in his presence.

The hammer remembers. Every lie. Every broken vow. Every promise abandoned.

When Kaedris demanded Varros swear an oath of loyalty to her, he refused and fled rather than bind himself to the Sovereign of Passion. He built a new forge in the Hollow and died there.

Oathbreaker's End was buried with him.

The Location

The Hollow

A canyon system in the Unclaimed, three days travel southeast of Crownfall.

  • Deep ravines cutting through ancient stone
  • Natural caves and overhangs
  • Varros's forge built into the rock
  • The hammer's presence has corrupted the area
  • Broken promises given physical form
  • The canyon echoes with whispered lies

The Guardians

The Echoes

Echoes are creatures made of broken promises, born from the hammer's presence over centuries.

  • Not quite undead, not quite aberrations
  • Manifestations of violated oaths
  • They "wear the faces of the forsaken"
  • Significant enough that no one has successfully retrieved the hammer

Rumors

"Varros was a master. One of the best who ever worked the heart-forges. When he fled, he took techniques with him that died when he did."
"The hammer doesn't just kill. It remembers. Strike someone who's broken an oath, and the weapon knows. Strike an honest man, and it might turn in your hand."
"The Echoes are patient. They've been guarding that forge for centuries. They don't tire. They don't forget. And they don't forgive."

Party Interest

Jonas purchased a detailed folio from the Green Door dealer for 200 gold, containing maps to the Hollow, notes on Varros's history, information about the Echoes, and suggested approaches.

items.title: Aedwynn the Maker
items.content:
Aedwynn the Maker

Status: Deceased (Murdered during the Usurpation)

Who She Was

Aedwynn the Maker was the god who created the world. She shaped reality, breathed life into existence, and maintained the balance of all things. She was not distant or unknowable â€” she walked among her creations, crafting and caring for the world she made.

Thirteen of her trusted servants betrayed her. They killed her and divided her body among themselves, becoming the Sovereigns who rule the world today.

Her Legacy

Aedwynn is not entirely gone. Fragments of her divine essence survived:

  • Her preserved body lies in the Chamber of the Final Breath, discovered by the party in
  • Divine shards embedded themselves in certain mortals (the Aedwynn-Born)
  • Sol Raven carries one such shard, animating his skeletal form
  • Ancient facilities built by the Maker still respond to those who carry her essence

The Witness

In the Chamber of the Final Breath, the party found a white-barked tree with veins of gold rising from the stone. At its base sat Aedwynn's preserved body â€” a shell containing an echo of her consciousness, uploaded onto this puppet made from the tree. When the party touched her, she awakened. She recognized Sol as carrying a piece of herself, and gave him the role of Witness â€” her heir, carrying her memory forward into an age ruled by her murderers.

Sol can now access complete memories of the world before the Usurpation. He showed one such memory to Talaris Bloomrend â€” the first time the Verdant King had seen his creator since helping to kill her.

items.title: The Usurpation
items.content:
The Usurpation

Type: Historical Event â€” The Murder of Aedwynn the Maker

What Happened

Before the current age, there was one god: Aedwynn the Maker. She created the world, shaped life, and maintained reality. Thirteen of her most trusted servants conspired to kill her.

They murdered Aedwynn and divided her body among themselves. Each claimed an organ, a piece of divine power. They became the Thirteen Sovereigns â€” gods built from the corpse of their creator.

  • Mareatha took the Heart
  • Azerach took the Ears
  • Imhuran took the Eyes
  • Talaris took the Liver
  • Vor'Kael took the Stomach
  • Eredain took the Voice
  • Karthayne took the Heart of Creation
  • Ultharion took the Skin
  • ...and five others claimed the remaining organs

The World Now

The Sovereigns rule their domains absolutely. Each has reshaped their territory according to their nature. Their cults enforce worship. Their agents hunt those who remember what came before.

But fragments of Aedwynn survived. Divine shards embedded in mortals. Echoes of the Maker's power hiding in ancient places. And now Sol Raven â€” the Maker's Witness â€” carries her memory forward.

items.title: Vor'Kael's True Name
items.content:
Vor'Kael's True Name

Type: Ultimate Leverage | Bearer: Jonas

What It Is

Vor'Kael's true name â€” the name she had before the Usurpation, before she became the Hollow Empress, before she claimed the Maker's Stomach. A secret that Azerach the Whispered King kept hidden for 800 years.

How It Was Found

In Lastwell, Jonas purchased a Closed Locket from a smith who didn't know what he had. The locket was sealed with strong magic. When Jonas touched it, his brand flared cold and Azerach opened it, revealing Vor'Kael's name etched inside.

Azerach had kept this secret for eight centuries â€” leverage against a fellow Sovereign. Now Jonas holds it.

The Cost

At the Mouth of the World, Vor'Kael sensed Jonas held the name but he did not speak it. Later, Jonas spoke the name aloud once â€” to command passage from the Satiated One. The Hollow Empress felt her true name spoken. She cannot unhear it.

Vor'Kael will hunt Jonas forever.

The Power

Vor'Kael's true name grants power over her. The exact nature of this power is unclear, but it is enough that Azerach kept it secret for 800 years, and enough that the Satiated One â€” an entity older than the Sovereigns â€” recognized its significance.

items.title: Blood Drinkers
items.content:
Blood Drinkers

Overview

Aberrations of the Arterial Tunnels Type: Aberration Domain Association: Mareatha the Vein-Mother Habitat: Arterial Tunnels beneath Veinspire Challenge Rating: 1/2 (100 XP)

Blood drinkers are creatures that feed on Mareatha's seepage in the Arterial Tunnels. They resemble dog-sized leechesâ€”eyeless, mouthless, their skin glistening wet. They don't bite; they absorb. Skin contact means feeding.

Appearance

Physical Description Dog-sized leech-like creatures with eyeless, mouthless bodies. Their skin glistens wet, constantly pulsing with hunger. They hunt by sensing warmth and absorb blood through skin contact rather than biting.
  • Size of large dogs
  • Leech-like body shape
  • Eyelessâ€”hunt by sensing warmth
  • Mouthlessâ€”absorb through skin contact
  • Glistening, wet skin
  • Pulsing with hunger

Behavior

Hunting Tactics:
  • Hunt in swarms (11+ typical)
  • Emerge from organic walls of Arterial Tunnels
  • Ambush predatorsâ€”hide within walls until prey passes
  • Attack from multiple directions (walls, ceiling, floor)
  • Target isolated or wounded individuals first
Instincts:
  • Avoid fireâ€”vulnerable to flames
  • Will flee if swarm takes heavy casualties
  • Cannot survive outside Arterial Tunnels for longâ€”need Mareatha's seepage

Combat

D&D 5e Stat Block

Actions

Absorbing Touch. Melee Attack: +4 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 7 (2d4 + 2) necrotic damage. Target's maximum HP reduced by damage taken until long rest. Blood drinker regains HP equal to damage dealt. Latch On (Recharge 5-6). If Absorbing Touch hits, blood drinker attaches to target. While attached, target takes 7 (2d4 + 2) necrotic damage at start of each of its turns. Blood drinker moves with target. Detaching requires action and DC 12 Strength check.

Ecology

Blood drinkers are spawned from Mareatha's influence in the Arterial Tunnels. They feed on the residual divine blood that seeps through the walls, but prefer warm-blooded prey when available.

Weaknesses:
  • Vulnerable to fire (take double damage)
  • Flee from large flames
  • Cannot survive outside Arterial Tunnels for longâ€”need Mareatha's seepage

Key Moments

Party Encounter â€” Arterial Tunnels

  • 11 blood drinkers ambushed party in Arterial Tunnels
  • Emerged from walls, ceiling
  • Party killed all 11
  • Casualties: Jonas (32 damage), Fursen (11 damage), Sol (9 damage)
  • Mira healed Jonas and Fursen; Sol regenerated naturally

items.title: Bloom Hound
items.content:
Bloom Hound

Type: Beast Domain Association: The Blooming Rot (Talaris Bloomrend the Verdant King) Habitat: Throughout the Blooming Rot, particularly along the Pilgrim's Path Challenge Rating: 3 (700 XP)

Description

Wolves adapted to the Rot. Fur patchy and matted, skin visible beneath in mottled green-grey. Flowering vines grow from their shoulders and spine, bright blossoms that attract insects â€” which the hounds eat. Hunt in packs of 3-6. Loyal to territory, not malicious.

Appearance

Physical Description Medium-sized canines with patchy, matted fur in shades of grey-green. Their skin shows through in mottled patches, having taken on the colors of moss and lichen. Flowering vines grow directly from their shoulders and spine, producing bright blossoms in colors ranging from deep crimson to pale violet. A constant cloud of insects hovers around them, attracted to the flowers â€” the hounds snap these up as supplemental food. Their eyes glow faintly green in low light, reflecting the bioluminescence of their environment.

Behavior

Bloom Hounds are territorial but not inherently aggressive. They patrol established hunting grounds within the Blooming Rot, marking territory with scent and waiting for prey to stumble into their domain.

Pack Dynamics: Hunt in packs of 3-6, with a dominant alpha leading coordinated attacks. They communicate through low growls and body language, flanking prey efficiently. Feeding Habits: Primarily carnivorous, hunting rot hares, smaller creatures, and occasionally unwary pilgrims. The insects attracted by their flower growths provide supplemental nutrition. Territorial Nature: A pack might follow travelers at a distance, curious rather than hostile. Feeding them (a rot hare, for instance) earns safe passage through their territory. Threatening one brings the entire pack. Connection to Talaris: As with all life in the Blooming Rot, Bloom Hounds are connected to Talaris Bloomrend through the fungal network. The Verdant King sees through their eyes when he chooses to look.

Combat

D&D 5e Stat Block

Bloom Hound

Medium beast, unaligned Armor Class 14 (natural armor) Hit Points 39 (6d8 + 12) Speed 50 ft.
STR DEX CON INT WIS CHA
14 (+2) 16 (+3) 14 (+2) 4 (-3) 14 (+2) 6 (-2)
Skills Perception +4, Stealth +5, Survival +4 Senses darkvision 60 ft., passive Perception 14 Languages â€” Challenge 3 (700 XP) Keen Senses. The bloom hound has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on hearing or smell. Pack Tactics. The bloom hound has advantage on attack rolls against a creature if at least one of the hound's allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally isn't incapacitated. Pollen Lure. Insects swarm around the bloom hound's flowering growths. Any creature that starts its turn within 5 feet of the bloom hound must succeed on a DC 12 Constitution saving throw or be distracted by the swarming insects, having disadvantage on Perception checks until the start of its next turn.

Actions

Bite. Melee Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 10 (2d6 + 3) piercing damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a DC 13 Strength saving throw or be knocked prone.

Variants

Bloom Pup (CR 1/2): Young hounds with only budding flower growths. 13 HP, no Pollen Lure ability. Often stay back during hunts, learning from the pack. Elder Bloom Hound (CR 5): An old pack leader whose flower growths have become extensive, covering most of its body. 65 HP, AC 15. Its Pollen Lure extends to 10 feet and the DC increases to 14. Can release a burst of spores once per day that causes creatures within 15 feet to make a DC 14 Constitution save or be poisoned for 1 minute. Fungal Alpha (CR 7): A Bloom Hound that has been blessed by Talaris directly. 85 HP, AC 16. It can communicate telepathically with Talaris and other creatures of the Rot within 60 feet. Once per day, it can summon 1d4 additional Bloom Hounds from the forest.

Ecology

Formation: Bloom Hounds evolved from ordinary wolves that entered the Blooming Rot generations ago. The fungal network slowly integrated with their biology, and now the flower growths are as natural to them as fur. Lifecycle: They reproduce normally, though pups are born with small vine buds that grow as they mature. The pack raises young communally. Relationship to the Verdant King: Talaris views them as useful servants â€” they patrol his domain and alert him to intruders. In return, they have abundant hunting grounds and protection from larger predators. Symbiosis: The flowers growing from Bloom Hounds are connected to the Rot's greater fungal network. When a Bloom Hound dies, its body is quickly reclaimed by the forest, flowers blooming from the corpse within hours.

Encounter Ideas

  • A pack of Bloom Hounds blocks the Pilgrim's Path. They're not attacking â€” they're waiting. Something has frightened them from their usual territory.
  • A lone Bloom Hound follows the party, keeping its distance. It seems to be watching them on behalf of something else.
  • The party finds a wounded Bloom Hound caught in a hunter's trap. Freeing it might earn favor with the pack â€” or with Talaris himself.
  • A pack has cornered a merchant who wandered off the path. The party must decide whether to intervene.

Lore

From a Pilgrim's Account "The hounds watched us for three days. Never attacked, never threatened â€” just watched. When we reached the Congregation Grove, the Spore-Touched told us the hounds had been reporting our progress. The forest knew exactly where we were the entire time." From a Hunter's Warning "Feed them if you have food to spare. A rot hare buys you safe passage through their territory. But never, ever run from them. They're wolves at heart, and wolves chase prey that runs."

items.title: Coagulated Guardians
items.content:
Coagulated Guardians

Description

Coagulated Guardians are living security systems formed from Mareatha's divine blood. They have no permanent form â€” they exist as part of the arterial walls until intruders are detected, then congeal into humanoid shapes to investigate or contain.

Physical Appearance:
  • Roughly humanoid shape
  • Made entirely of thickened, clotted blood
  • Faceless â€” smooth ovoid where head should be
  • Too-long limbs that bend without bones
  • Surface ripples with tiny currents
  • Six or seven fingers per hand
Behavior:
  • Patrol through vessel walls (blood is their medium)
  • Respond to Tribunal sigils
  • Query unrecognized bearers for authorization
  • Can split from one large form into multiple smaller forms
  • Communicate through skull-vibration (telepathic speech)

Communication Protocol

When encountering intruders, guardians follow a verification sequence:

  1. Manifest â€” Congeal from wall to investigate
  2. Scan â€” Sense blood, divine presence, sigils
  3. Query â€” Request authorization if sigil recognized but bearer unknown
  4. Respond â€” Accept authorization or initiate containment
Query Format:

âŸ¨ SIGIL: [STATUS] âŸ©

âŸ¨ BEARER: [STATUS] âŸ©

âŸ¨ SPECIES: [STATUS/ERROR] âŸ©

âŸ¨ QUERY: AUTHORIZATION SOURCE? âŸ©

Note: Leonin register as [ERROR] â€” likely due to Imhuran's erasure of their species from official records.

D&D 5e Statistics

Medium aberration, neutral evil Armor Class 13 (natural armor) Hit Points 45 (6d8 + 18) Speed 30 ft., climb 30 ft.
STR DEX CON INT WIS CHA
14 (+2) 14 (+2) 16 (+3) 6 (-2) 12 (+1) 5 (-3)
Damage Resistances Bludgeoning, piercing Damage Vulnerabilities Fire, cold Damage Immunities Poison, psychic Condition Immunities Charmed, exhaustion, frightened, poisoned, prone Senses Blindsight 60 ft. (blind beyond this radius), passive Perception 11 Languages Understands Mareathan commands, communicates via telepathic vibration Challenge 2 (450 XP)

Traits

Amorphous. The guardian can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing. Blood Sense. The guardian knows the exact location of any creature with blood within 60 feet of it. Wall Merger. The guardian can enter and move through Mareathan arterial walls as difficult terrain. While merged with a wall, the guardian has total cover and cannot be targeted by attacks or spells. Sigil Recognition. The guardian can identify Tribunal sigils on sight and will not attack bearers unless authorization fails. Divisible Form. When reduced to 0 hit points, the guardian can choose to split into two smaller guardians (22 HP each) instead of dying. Each split guardian has disadvantage on attack rolls. This ability can only be used once per guardian.

Actions

Multiattack. The guardian makes two Coagulating Touch attacks. Coagulating Touch. Melee Weapon Attack: +4 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 7 (2d4 + 2) bludgeoning damage plus 3 (1d6) necrotic damage. On a hit, the target must succeed on a DC 13 Constitution saving throw or have their blood begin to thicken, reducing their speed by 10 feet until the end of their next turn. Engulf (Recharge 5-6). The guardian attempts to engulf a Medium or smaller creature within 5 feet. The target must succeed on a DC 13 Strength saving throw or be grappled (escape DC 13). While grappled, the creature is restrained and takes 10 (3d6) necrotic damage at the start of each of its turns. The guardian can only engulf one creature at a time.

Reactions

Fluid Escape. When the guardian takes damage from a melee attack, it can use its reaction to flow away, moving up to 15 feet without provoking opportunity attacks.

Encounter History

â€” Arterial Passage

Situation: Party used dead handler's Tribunal sigil to attempt passage. Result: Sigil recognized, but bearer (Fursen/Leonin) flagged as ERROR. Fursen failed Deception check (8) when asked for authorization source. Guardian initiated containment â€” split into three forms. Combat: Party destroyed all three guardians in one round:
  • Mira bisected Guardian A
  • Sol's Firebolt exploited fire vulnerability on Guardian B
  • Fursen finished Guardian B with Flurry of Blows
  • Jonas destroyed Guardian C with Booming Blade hammer throw
Aftermath: Party sprinted to Reliquary, pursued by reinforcements until arterial valve sealed.

items.title: Corpse Scavenger
items.content:
Corpse Scavenger

Description

Corpse Scavengers are evolution's answer to an impossible food source â€” the exposed flesh of a dead god. They've adapted over centuries to feed on Aedwynn's divine tissue in the borderlands between Sovereign domains, places where nothing else grows and only carrion remains. They are nature's most efficient cleanup crew, stripping divine flesh with jaws that unhinge like snakes.

They are not undead. They are not touched by corruption. They are simply hungry.

Appearance

Pallid, hairless humanoid-shaped creatures with grey-white skin stretched tight over lean muscle. Their bodies are gaunt, emaciated-looking, but deceptively strong. They have no eyes â€” just smooth skin where eyes should be. Their ears are enormous, bat-like, constantly twitching. Their mouths are their most disturbing feature â€” normal-looking when closed, but the jaw can unhinge like a snake's, revealing rows of needle-sharp teeth designed to grip and tear. Their fingers end in black, hardened claws caked with dried divine flesh.

Stats

STRDEXCONINTWISCHA
16 (+3)14 (+2)14 (+2)2 (-4)12 (+1)5 (-3)

AC 13 (natural armor) | HP 39 (6d8 + 12) |




Traits

Blind Hunters. The scavenger can't use its blindsight while deafened. It relies entirely on tremorsense and smell to locate prey.

Carrion Sense. The scavenger can smell blood within 120 feet. It has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks to locate wounded creatures.

Pack Tactics. The scavenger has advantage on attack rolls against a creature if at least one of the scavenger's allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally isn't incapacitated.

Divine Flesh Diet. The scavenger has adapted to consume the Maker's tissue. It is immune to any corruption or mutation effects from consuming divine flesh.

Actions

Multiattack. The scavenger makes two attacks: one with its bite and one with its claws.

Bite. Melee Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 8 (1d10 + 3) piercing damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a or take 3 (1d6) necrotic damage as the scavenger's saliva begins breaking down flesh.

Claws. Melee Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 6 (1d6 + 3) slashing damage.

Unhinged Jaw (Recharge 5-6). The scavenger unhinges its jaw and attempts to tear a chunk from a creature. Melee Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 14 (2d10 + 3) piercing damage, and the target must succeed on a or be knocked prone as the scavenger wrenches them off balance.

Encounter Notes

Corpse Scavengers hunt in packs of 4-8, working cooperatively to strip flesh from the Maker's corpse. They are blind but extraordinarily perceptive through tremorsense and smell. One scavenger will draw attention while others flank. The party encountered four of them â€” Jonas fed the Bleeding Blade.

items.title: Hollow Crawler
items.content:
Hollow Crawler

Medium aberration, unaligned (serves Vor'Kael)

Description

A Hollow Crawler is one of Vor'Kael's scouts â€” sent to find, track, and mark targets for later consumption. Humanoid shape, but wrong. Too-long fingers. Slides rather than walks. Leaves handprints with impossible proportions. Smells like "absence" or "nothing."

Stats

STRDEXCONINTWISCHA
14 (+2)18 (+4)16 (+3)6 (-2)16 (+3)4 (-3)

AC 16 (natural armor) | HP 90 (12d8 + 36) |





Traits

Spider Climb. The crawler can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

Aura of Nothing. Creatures within 10 feet have disadvantage on Perception checks to notice anything other than the crawler.

Vor'Kael's Eyes. When the crawler dies, Vor'Kael immediately becomes aware of its location and the circumstances of its death.

Patient Hunter. Advantage on Stealth checks while tracking prey it has followed for at least 1 hour.

Actions

Multiattack. The crawler makes two claw attacks.

Claw. Melee Weapon Attack: +7 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 11 (2d6 + 4) slashing damage plus 7 (2d6) necrotic damage.

Consume Feature. The crawler targets one creature within 5 feet. or lose a small physical feature (tooth, fingernail, hair). The loss is painless and may go unnoticed. Vor'Kael gains a permanent connection to the creature through the stolen piece.

Encounter Notes

A Hollow Crawler tracked the party for 8 nights after they entered the Unclaimed territories. It circled camps, left handprints, and placed a human tooth with Vor'Kael's mark on Jonas's pack. On Day 8, the party ambushed and killed it â€” triggering Vor'Kael's Eyes. The Hollow Empress now knows Jonas's exact location.

During the fight, the Crawler's Consume Feature destroyed two of Fursen's wisdom teeth.

items.title: Misremembered
items.content:
Misremembered

Classification: Conceptual Predator / Ontological Correction Domain Association: Karthayne the Hollow Crown (creation, destruction, authority) First Encounter: â€” The Northern Ascent (Pallid Crossroads stables) Major Battle: â€” The Wrong Thought Status: Driven off, will return

ORIGIN

The Misremembered is a function of Karthayne the Hollow Crownâ€”the Sovereign who holds the Maker's Heart of Creation.

When Karthayne claimed the Heart of Creation, he lost his memoriesâ€”his identity scoured away by an organ meant for a god. To compensate, he began compiling The Cosmic Census: a complete record of every existing thing in the world. If he cannot remember himself, he will remember everything else.

But records reveal gaps. Anomalies. Things that exist but aren't documented. Things that shouldn't exist.

The Misremembered was created to hunt these anomalies. It is Karthayne's correction toolâ€”sent to find things that don't fit the records and erase them from existence. Not kill them. Erase them. As if they never were.

The Misremembered hunts "errors in reality"â€”beings and concepts that don't fit the pattern of creation Karthayne inherited from Aedwynn. They are corrections. Functions. Tools of a creative authority that cannot tolerate flaws.

CONNECTION TO THE THRONE VOID

The Misremembered retreated to The Throne Voidâ€”Karthayne's hidden domain, located off the known map of the Ashen Realms. This is where:

  • Karthayne maintains his Cosmic Census
  • The archives of all existence are kept
  • Anomalies are processed and erased
  • The Misremembered returns to report and regenerate

The Throne Void is where broken and impossible things goâ€”either to be catalogued or unmade.

APPEARANCE

Primary Form:
  • Tall, too tall for normal humanoid proportions
  • Can perfectly mimic living beings (with subtle flaws)
  • Head tilts at predatory anglesâ€”suggests broken neck
  • Hollow black spaces where eyes should be
  • Shadows behave incorrectly (turn opposite way, move independently)
  • Can fold like paper and slip through impossible spaces
Voice:
  • Layered whispers
  • Like pages sliding over each other
  • Sound of thought without a mouth
  • Breath escaping a closed book
  • When mimicking, uses stolen voices with underlying discordant whispers

ABILITIES

Form Mimicry:
  • Can create perfect duplicates of living beings
  • Small flaws always present (wrong shadow direction, too-sharp outlines, hollow eyes)
  • Duplicates are conceptual rather than physical
Reality Manipulation:
  • Can freeze objects mid-motion
  • Moves by "jumping" closer without physically crossing space
  • Exists partially outside normal physics
  • Leaves messages carved/written in materials without tools
Conceptual Form:
  • Made of stolen memories and wrong thoughts
  • Resistant to physical damage
  • Can fold along angles that don't exist in three-dimensional space
  • Regenerates unless disrupted by significant force
Correction Touch:
  • Can attempt to unmake beings from existence
  • Victims don't dieâ€”they are erased, as if they never existed
  • Those nearby forget the victim existed
Tracking:
  • Hunts conceptual anomalies and ontological errors
  • Can sense "wrong thoughts"â€”beings that shouldn't exist
  • Patient and methodical, not aggressive
  • Tests boundaries before striking

TARGET: SOL RAVEN

Why Sol?
  • Sol is connected to Aedwynn the Makerâ€”the god who died before Karthayne claimed the Heart
  • Karthayne cannot fully process Aedwynn's legacyâ€”it predates his authority
  • Sol registers as a "wrong thought"â€”a concept that exists outside proper creation
  • To the Heart of Creation, Sol is a flaw that must be corrected
The Memory Coin Trigger: During the 13-Hour Trial in Imhuran's domain, the party acquired a memory coinâ€”an item that records and triggers remembrance. When the Misremembered encountered the party at the Pallid Crossroads boundary, Fursen offered the coin to the creature. Sol Raven and Kael were present.

The coin made the Misremembered remember Sol. And remembering meant recognizing him as an anomaly. Recognizing meant targeting for erasure.

Without the coin, Sol might have remained unnoticedâ€”just another mortal beneath the attention of cosmic correction. The coin changed everything.

What It Wants: The Misremembered doesn't want to kill Sol. It wants to correct himâ€”unmake him from existence so that he never was. This is worse than death. Current Status: Sol is flagged in Karthayne's records as an anomaly, but he is considered insignificant. A mortal. A speck. The Misremembered was deemed sufficient to handle himâ€”and it failed.

Karthayne has not escalated. Sol is too unimportant for the Sovereign's personal attention.

Sol's best protection is being beneath notice. The moment he becomes importantâ€”does something significant, gains real power, threatens the cosmic orderâ€”Karthayne might actually look his way.

ENCOUNTER HISTORY

â€” The Northern Ascent (Pallid Crossroads)

  1. Fursen slept in the stable with the span-runner
  2. Sensed something wrong in the night â€” span-runner stopped breathing, shadows displaced, clicking sounds
  3. Found carved message "TURN AROUND" on smooth wood where something had stood
  4. Turned around â€” saw duplicate of himself in stall doorway (hollow black eyes, shadow turning opposite way)
  5. Duplicate said "Not you" and folded/dissolved under the stall door
  6. Fursen woke Sol Raven and Kael (Jonas barricaded his room and refused to come)
  7. Followed conceptual trail â€” lanterns flickered/recoiled along its path
  8. Found the creature waiting at settlement perimeter â€” too tall, arms too long, head tilted at Fursen's angle but facing Sol
  9. Creature tapped its head (tap tap tap) and reached for the coin
  10. Fursen asked what it was â€” it answered: "Not name... Not meant for names... Old thought... Forgotten shape... I look for the one who thinks wrong"
  11. Fursen gave it the memory coin (acquired during the 13-Hour Trial)
  12. Time froze â€” only Fursen remained aware
  13. Coin crumbled to silver dust, poured into creature's form â€” it became more defined, more real
  14. Entity said: "Memory returns... One of you bends the frame."
  15. Turned to Sol Raven: "You. You are the wrong thought. The Hollow Crown remembers everything... But he doesn't remember you. You're a thought that thinks itself without permission."
  16. Vanished (like a page turning)
  17. Left behind paper strip with "FOUND YOU" written in Sol's handwriting (but he never wrote it)
Note: The memory coin was the catalyst. Without it, the Misremembered might never have recognized Sol as an anomaly. The party inadvertently painted a target on Sol's back.

â€” The Wrong Thought

  1. Manifested at Pallid Crossroads during party's rest
  2. Settlement went wrongâ€”mist surrounded area, people vanished
  3. Appeared wearing Sol's shape (with flaws)
  4. Explained its nature and purpose to Sol
  5. Jonas intervenedâ€”threw hammer at its hand (rolled 24, hit)
  6. Hand crumpled "like wet paper," dripped black ink
  7. Full combat ensued
  8. Party defeated it through combined assault
  9. Entity folded inward along impossible angles and vanished
  10. Left note: "NOT CORRECTED. NOTED. WILL RETURN."

BEHAVIOR

Hunting Pattern:
  • Observes before acting
  • Tests prey's reactions and defenses
  • Makes its presence known deliberately
  • Uses psychological pressure over physical force
  • Communicates through cryptic statements
  • Patientâ€”will wait weeks or months between attempts
Known Statements:
  • "Not you." (to Fursen)
  • "...I look... for the one... who thinks... wrong." (seeking Sol)
  • "...Memory... returns..." (after consuming memory coin)
  • "You. You are the wrong thought." (to Sol)
  • "The Hollow Crown remembers everything... But he doesn't remember you."
  • "You're a thought that thinks itself without permission."
  • "NOT CORRECTED. NOTED. WILL RETURN."

CURRENT STATUS

Condition: Disrupted, reforming Location: Unknownâ€”folded out of physical space Timeline: Will return in weeks or months Threat Level: EXTREME

The party hurt it. This is rare. This means they can hurt it again.

But it cannot be killed by conventional means. It was disrupted, not destroyed. It will reconstitute and return.

PARTY KNOWLEDGE

The party now knows:

  • Its name (The Misremembered)
  • Its origin (Karthayne the Hollow Crown)
  • Its purpose (correcting errors in creation)
  • Why it hunts Sol (connection to Aedwynn)
  • It can be hurt (Jonas's hammer worked)
  • It will return (the note confirms this)
  • Radiant damage is effective against it

When Karthayne claimed the Heart of Creation, he lost his memoriesâ€”his identity scoured away by an organ meant for a god. To compensate, he began compiling The Cosmic Census: a complete record of every existing thing in the world. If he cannot remember himself, he will remember everything else. But records reveal gaps. Anomalies. Things that exist but aren't documented. Things that shouldn't exist. The Misremembered was created to hunt these anomalies. It is Karthayne's correction toolâ€”sent to find things that don't fit the records and erase them from existence. Not kill them. Erase them. As if they never were. The Misremembered hunts "errors in reality"â€”beings and concepts that don't fit the pattern of creation Karthayne inherited from Aedwynn. They are corrections. Functions. Tools of a creative authority that cannot tolerate flaws. items.title: Skin-Walkers
items.content:
Skin-Walkers

Type: Aberration (Shapechanger) Domain Association: Ultharion the Obsidian Shepherd Habitat: The Blackfold, mirrors, shadowed places, anywhere identity can be stolen Challenge Rating: 8 (3,900 XP)

Description

Skin-Walkers are servants of Ultharion who have transcended their original forms entirely. They no longer possess a true appearanceâ€”only the stolen identities of their victims. They exist as living voids that wear other people's skin, faces, and memories like clothing.

Appearance

Physical Description In their "true" form (rarely seen), a Skin-Walker is a void in the shape of a personâ€”absolute darkness given humanoid outline, with no features except a faint shimmer where a face should be. When wearing a stolen skin, they appear perfectly identical to their victim, down to scars, mannerisms, and voice. The only tell: their reflection is always delayed by a fraction of a second, as if the mirror needs time to process what it's seeing.

Behavior

Skin-Walkers don't simply shapeshiftâ€”they steal. When they take a form, they remove it from the original owner, leaving behind a featureless, identity-less husk.

Identity Theft: The process requires physical contact and takes about one minute. The victim must be helpless or willing. The Skin-Walker gains their appearance, voice, some surface memories, and personality traits. The victim loses all of theseâ€”becoming a blank, faceless creature that eventually dies of existential dissolution. Impersonation: A Skin-Walker wearing stolen identity is nearly impossible to detect through normal means. They have the victim's mannerisms, knowledge of common facts, and even emotional responses. Only prolonged interaction, specific questions about obscure memories, or magical detection reveals them. Collection: Most Skin-Walkers maintain multiple stolen identities, switching between them as needed. Some collect skins obsessively, building vast wardrobes of stolen selves.

Combat

items.title: Thornback Behemoth
items.content:
Thornback Behemoth

Type: Beast Domain Association: The Blooming Rot (Talaris Bloomrend the Verdant King) Habitat: The Hunger Garden, deep forest regions of the Blooming Rot Challenge Rating: 11 (7,200 XP)

Description

A bear â€” or it was, once. Now it's a mountain of matted fur, bark-like hide, and massive thorns growing from its spine and shoulders. Vines trail from its limbs. Mushrooms sprout from its haunches. It moves slowly, ponderously, eating everything in its path â€” plants, animals, Planted, pilgrims.

Not aggressive unless hungry or threatened. Unfortunately, it's always hungry.

Appearance

Physical Description A massive creature standing 15 feet tall at the shoulder, originally bear-like but now transformed by the Rot. Its hide has become bark-like, rough and ridged like ancient tree bark. Massive thorns â€” some as long as a man's arm â€” grow from its spine and shoulders in dense clusters. Matted fur hangs in patches where the bark hasn't completely taken over. Vines trail from its limbs, dragging along the ground as it walks. Mushrooms of various sizes sprout from its haunches and flanks. Its eyes are small and dark, almost lost in the mass of organic growth. When it opens its mouth, rows of flat grinding teeth are visible alongside newer, sharper growths.

Behavior

Thornback Behemoths are solitary apex predators of the Blooming Rot. They wander continuously, eating everything in their path â€” vegetation, animals, and any creature unfortunate enough to be caught.

Feeding Habits: Omnivorous in the extreme. A Behemoth will consume entire groves of trees, packs of smaller creatures, and any pilgrims who don't get out of its way. Its digestive system can process nearly anything organic. Movement Patterns: They move slowly but inexorably, following no set path. The forest parts before them â€” smaller creatures flee at the sound of their approach. Trees cracking and ground shaking announce their presence long before they're visible. Territorial Nature: They don't defend territory in the traditional sense â€” they simply consume whatever they encounter. Two Behemoths meeting will usually ignore each other, as neither is worth the effort to fight. Connection to Talaris: Like all major creatures of the Rot, Behemoths are connected to the fungal network. Talaris considers them useful â€” they clear deadfall, spread spores, and keep the forest's cycle of death and rebirth in constant motion.

Combat

D&D 5e Stat Block

Thornback Behemoth

Huge beast, unaligned Armor Class 16 (natural armor) Hit Points 175 (14d12 + 84) Speed 40 ft.
STR DEX CON INT WIS CHA
24 (+7) 8 (-1) 22 (+6) 3 (-4) 12 (+1) 6 (-2)
Saving Throws Str +11, Con +10 Skills Perception +5 Damage Resistances poison; bludgeoning from nonmagical attacks Condition Immunities frightened, poisoned Senses darkvision 60 ft., passive Perception 15 Languages â€” Challenge 11 (7,200 XP) Thorn Aura. Any creature that starts its turn within 10 feet of the behemoth or hits it with a melee attack while within 10 feet takes 7 (2d6) piercing damage from the behemoth's thorns. Siege Monster. The behemoth deals double damage to objects and structures. Regeneration. The behemoth regains 10 hit points at the start of its turn if it has at least 1 hit point. If the behemoth takes fire damage, this trait doesn't function at the start of the behemoth's next turn.

Actions

Multiattack. The behemoth makes two slam attacks. Slam. Melee Weapon Attack: +11 to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. Hit: 23 (3d10 + 7) bludgeoning damage. Thorn Volley (Recharge 5-6). The behemoth shakes violently, launching thorns in a 30-foot cone. Each creature in the area must make a DC 18 Dexterity saving throw, taking 28 (8d6) piercing damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. Creatures that fail the save are also restrained by thorns embedded in their flesh until they use an action to pull them out, taking 7 (2d6) piercing damage when doing so. Consume. The behemoth attempts to swallow a Large or smaller creature it has grappled. The target must succeed on a DC 18 Strength saving throw or be swallowed. A swallowed creature is blinded and restrained, has total cover against attacks and other effects outside the behemoth, and takes 21 (6d6) acid damage at the start of each of the behemoth's turns. If the behemoth takes 30 or more damage in a single turn from a creature inside it, the behemoth must succeed on a DC 20 Constitution saving throw at the end of that turn or regurgitate all swallowed creatures, which fall prone in a space within 10 feet of the behemoth.

Variants

Young Thornback (CR 6): A smaller specimen, only 10 feet tall. 95 HP, AC 14. No Consume ability, and Thorn Volley only affects a 15-foot cone. Still dangerous, but can be driven off by determined resistance. Ancient Thornback (CR 15): A behemoth that has lived for centuries, now more plant than animal. 230 HP, AC 18. Its Thorn Aura extends to 15 feet and deals 10 (3d6) damage. It can use Thorn Volley twice before needing to recharge. When reduced to 0 HP, it explodes in a burst of spores â€” all creatures within 30 feet must succeed on a DC 18 Constitution save or be poisoned for 1 hour. Rot-Blessed Behemoth (CR 17): A behemoth that Talaris has personally blessed. 260 HP, legendary resistance (2/day). Can cast entangle at will and wall of thorns once per day. Talaris can see and speak through this creature directly.

Ecology

Formation: Thornback Behemoths are descendants of bears that entered the Blooming Rot long ago. Over generations, the forest's influence transformed them into the massive, thorn-covered creatures they are today. Lifecycle: They live for centuries, growing larger and more overgrown with each passing decade. They reproduce rarely â€” perhaps once per century â€” and the mother abandons the cub within weeks of birth. Relationship to the Verdant King: Talaris values them as instruments of the cycle. Their constant consumption and movement spreads spores, clears deadfall, and keeps the forest in constant renewal. He occasionally directs them toward intruders he wants removed. Role in Ecosystem: They are the forest's apex predators and primary recyclers. Everything they consume is eventually returned to the Rot through their waste, feeding new growth.

Encounter Ideas

  • The party hears a Behemoth approaching â€” trees cracking, ground shaking. They have minutes to hide, flee, or prepare for a fight they probably can't win.
  • A Behemoth has swallowed something important â€” a key, an artifact, a person. The party must retrieve it without killing themselves.
  • Two Behemoths are approaching the same area from different directions. The party is caught in the middle.
  • A dying Behemoth blocks the only path forward. Its death throes will be violent, and the spore burst when it dies will be dangerous.

Lore

From a Pilgrim's Warning "When the ground shakes and the trees start falling, you run. You don't fight. You don't hide. You run, and you pray it's not following you. I've seen a Behemoth walk through a camp of twenty armed men. It didn't even slow down. The men who didn't run... the forest grew flowers where they fell." From the Spore-Touched of Sporehaven "The Behemoths are the King's gardeners. They prune. They clear. They spread the seeds of new growth. When one passes through an area, the forest grows back stronger, more vital. We do not mourn those they consume â€” we celebrate their return to the cycle."

items.title: Vein-Crawlers
items.content:
Vein-Crawlers

Overview

Parasites of the Arterial Deepways Type: Aberration (Vermin) Domain Association: Mareatha the Vein-Mother Habitat: Arterial Deepways, Veinspire territories, anywhere blood has been spilled in devotion Challenge Rating: 1/2 (100 XP)

Vein-Crawlers are parasitic creatures that infest the Arterial Deepwaysâ€”the fossilized blood vessels of Aedwynn that crisscross beneath the world. They resemble centipedes the size of a human forearm, but their bodies are translucent, revealing thick dark fluid sloshing within segmented chambers.

Appearance

Physical Description A segmented creature roughly 18 inches long with dozens of needle-thin legs ending in hooked barbs. Its body is semi-transparent, showing chambers of stolen blood inside. The head features a circular lamprey-mouth ringed with backward-curving teeth designed to latch and drain. Two vestigial eye-spots glow faintly red when blood is nearby.

Behavior

Vein-Crawlers are ambush predators that cling to tunnel ceilings in the Arterial Deepways, dropping onto warm-blooded creatures passing below. They're drawn to heartbeats and can sense pulse from up to 60 feet away.

Feeding: Once latched, they drain blood at an alarming rate. A single crawler can exsanguinate a human in under an hour if not removed. Swarm Behavior: Vein-Crawlers are solitary hunters but will congregate around large prey. Finding one usually means more are nearby. Religious Significance: Mareathan cultists consider Vein-Crawlers sacredâ€”living vessels that carry the Mother's essence. Some intentionally allow themselves to be fed upon as devotion.

Combat

D&D 5e Stat Block

Vein-Crawler

Small aberration, unaligned Armor Class 13 (natural armor) Hit Points 14 (4d6) Speed 30 ft., climb 30 ft.
STR DEX CON INT WIS CHA
6 (-2) 16 (+3) 10 (+0) 1 (-5) 12 (+1) 2 (-4)
Skills Stealth +5, Perception +3 Senses blindsight 60 ft. (blind beyond), passive Perception 13 Languages â€” Challenge 1/2 (100 XP) Blood Sense. The vein-crawler can detect the location of any creature with blood within 60 feet. Spider Climb. The vein-crawler can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

Actions

Latch. Melee Weapon Attack: +5 to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. Hit: 5 (1d4 + 3) piercing damage, and the vein-crawler attaches to the target. While attached, the vein-crawler doesn't attack. Instead, at the start of each of its turns, the target loses 5 (1d4 + 3) hit points due to blood loss.

The vein-crawler can detach itself by spending 5 feet of movement. A creature, including the target, can use its action to detach the vein-crawler with a successful DC 12 Strength check.

Variants

Bloated Crawler (CR 1): A vein-crawler gorged on blood. Larger, slower, but explodes in a spray of acidic blood when killed (5 ft. radius, DC 11 Dex save, 2d6 acid damage). Blessed Crawler (CR 1): Mareathan priests cultivate these specimens. They can transmit a compulsion to seek Veinspire when they bite (DC 12 Wisdom save or feel drawn to the Cathedral for 24 hours).

Ecology

Diet: Blood exclusively. Can survive months between feedings by entering torpor. Reproduction: Lays eggs in corpses. Larvae gestate inside dead flesh before emerging as hand-sized juveniles. Predators: Gallery Hounds hunt them. Pulse-Wardens ignore them as "beneath notice." Territory: Arterial Deepways primarily, but can spread through any blood-soaked environment.

Encounter Ideas

  • Party discovers a corpse in the Deepways, completely drained, with dozens of shed crawler shells nearby
  • A Mareathan pilgrim begs the party to help retrieve "sacred crawlers" from a collapsed tunnel
  • An infestation has spread to a village well that connects to the Deepways

items.title: Allip
items.content:
Allip

Medium undead, neutral evil

Description

An allip is the spectral remains of someone who died while consumed by a terrible secret. Unable to find peace, they haunt the places where their mortal lives ended, driven to whisper their secrets into the minds of the living â€” secrets that can shatter sanity.

Appearance

  • Vaguely humanoid silhouette of roiling shadows
  • No distinct features â€” faces blur and shift
  • Mouths that form but produce no sound audible to the ear
  • Whispers that bypass hearing and crawl directly into the mind
  • Cold mist trails behind them

Stats

STRDEXCONINTWISCHA
6 (-2)17 (+3)10 (+0)17 (+3)15 (+2)16 (+3)

AC 13 | HP 40 (9d8) | Speed 0 ft., fly 40 ft. (hover)

Saving Throws Int +6, Wis +5
Damage Resistances Acid, fire, lightning, thunder; bludgeoning, piercing, slashing from nonmagical attacks
Damage Immunities Cold, necrotic, poison
Condition Immunities Charmed, exhaustion, frightened, grappled, paralyzed, petrified, poisoned, prone, restrained
Challenge 5 (1,800 XP)

Traits

Incorporeal Movement. The allip can move through other creatures and objects as if they were difficult terrain. It takes 5 (1d10) force damage if it ends its turn inside an object.

Maddening Whispers. Any creature that starts its turn within 30 feet of the allip and can hear it must succeed on a DC 14 Wisdom saving throw. On a failure, the creature takes 7 (2d6) psychic damage and must use its reaction to move away. On a success, it takes 3 (1d6) psychic damage. Deafened creatures automatically succeed.

Actions

Maddening Touch. Melee Spell Attack: +6 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 17 (4d6 + 3) psychic damage.

Howling Babble (Recharge 6). Each creature within 30 feet that can hear must make a DC 14 Wisdom save. On failure: 12 (2d8 + 3) psychic damage and stunned until end of next turn. On success: half damage, not stunned.

Encounter Notes

The allips in The Hollow are manifestations of the smith's guilt â€” fragments of his psyche that couldn't rest. They whisper pieces of his confession:

"...she burned them from the inside..."
"...I made the tools..."
"...couldn't stay... couldn't watch..."

The party encountered and destroyed two allips in The Hollow's gallery passage.
items.raw: Allip. Medium undead, CR 5. Spectral remains of those who died with terrible secrets. Found in The Hollow as manifestations of the smith's guilt. Whispers directly into minds, causing psychic damage. The party destroyed two allips in Session 23.

items.title: Cindermaw
items.content:
Cindermaw

Medium elemental, unaligned

Description

Cindermaws are elemental scavengers that crawl up from wounds in the world â€” places where the Maker's corpse still bleeds heat. They hunt in packs of three to six, stalking prey by the warmth of living bodies.

Appearance

  • Wolf-sized quadrupeds with wrong proportions â€” spine ridged with jagged basalt
  • Bodies of cracked volcanic rock, black and grey like shattered obsidian
  • Molten orange-red magma pulses through the fissures with a slow heartbeat rhythm
  • Eyes like dying coals â€” deep red-orange, no pupils, just smoldering heat
  • Mouths reveal furnace-bright throats, no visible teeth, just the promise of fire
  • Heat shimmer distorts the air around them

Stats

STRDEXCONINTWISCHA
16 (+3)15 (+2)14 (+2)4 (-3)12 (+1)6 (-2)

AC 14 (natural armor) | HP 78 (12d8 + 24) | Speed 40 ft.

Damage Resistances Bludgeoning, piercing, slashing from nonmagical attacks
Damage Immunities Fire, poison
Damage Vulnerabilities Cold
Challenge 5 (1,800 XP)

Traits

Molten Core. A creature that touches the cindermaw or hits it with a melee attack while within 5 feet takes 7 (2d6) fire damage.

Pack Hunters. The cindermaw has advantage on attack rolls if an ally is within 5 feet of the target.

Ember Trail. Spaces the cindermaw moves through become difficult terrain until its next turn. Creatures entering or starting in the trail take 3 (1d6) fire damage.

Death Burst. When the cindermaw dies, it explodes. Each creature within 10 feet must make a DC 13 Dexterity save, taking 14 (4d6) fire damage on failure, half on success.

Actions

Multiattack. The cindermaw makes two attacks: one bite and one claws.

Bite. Melee Weapon Attack: +6 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 10 (2d6 + 3) piercing damage plus 7 (2d6) fire damage. Target must succeed on DC 13 Strength save or be knocked prone.

Claws. Melee Weapon Attack: +6 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 8 (2d4 + 3) slashing damage plus 3 (1d6) fire damage.

Furnace Breath (Recharge 5-6). 15-foot cone of fire. DC 13 Dexterity save, 21 (6d6) fire damage on failure, half on success.

Encounter Notes

Three cindermaws ambushed the party during their first night in the Unclaimed on Day 17. Jonas's watch was compromised by the drowsy side effects of the Moonbind Salve â€” he failed to notice their approach until they were already attacking.

The Death Burst caught the party off guard when the creatures died. Magma sprayed across the campsite, blistering Jonas's shield arm.

All three cindermaws were killed. XP: 5,400
items.raw: Cindermaw. Medium elemental, CR 5. Volcanic pack hunters from heat-bleeding wounds in the Unclaimed. Bodies of cracked volcanic rock with molten magma pulsing through fissures. Pack Hunters trait, Molten Core damages melee attackers, Death Burst explodes when killed. Party defeated 3 cindermaws in Session 23.

items.title: Bishop of the Resonant Artery
items.content:
Bishop of the Resonant Artery

Overview

Eredain's Devoted Servant â€” DECEASED

Type: Humanoid (Human) | Challenge: CR 8 (3,900 XP) | Status: â˜ ï¸ DECEASED

The Bishop of the Resonant Artery was a servant of Eredain the Choirless Monarch, devoted to the principles of harmony, resonance, and merciful correction. Unlike many servants of the Sovereigns, the Bishop embodied genuine compassion â€” believing deeply in teaching rather than punishing.

He defeated the party utterly, then saved their lives using the Pool of Resonance at cost to himself. The party repaid this mercy by murdering him while he was weakened and chained.

Appearance

The Bishop stood tall with the bearing of absolute certainty. He wore deep blue robes trimmed with silver chains that clinked with musical tones. Upon his head sat a tall mitre decorated with Eredain's symbols. His face was covered in intricate tattoos that vibrated faintly. His eyes were milky white, blind to conventional sight but perceiving the world through sound and vibration.

Death

After saving the party's lives, the Bishop was murdered while weakened and chained. He died with an expression of profound surprise â€” not at the violence, but at the senselessness of it.

His last breath escaped in a discordant hum â€” a final note that hung in the air, then faded into silence. The church screamed. The walls wept blood. The resonance that had maintained the artery for centuries shattered.

D&D 5e Statistics

Bishop of the Resonant Artery

Medium humanoid (human), lawful neutral

Armor Class 16 (resonant robes)

Hit Points 112 (15d8 + 45)

Speed 30 ft., fly 30 ft. (hover, through resonance)

STRDEXCONINTWISCHA
10 (+0)14 (+2)16 (+3)18 (+4)20 (+5)16 (+3)

Saving Throws Int +8, Wis +9, Cha +7

Skills Insight +13, Perception +13, Religion +8

Damage Resistances Thunder; Bludgeoning, Piercing, and Slashing from nonmagical attacks

Condition Immunities Blinded, Deafened

Senses Blindsight 120 ft., passive Perception 23

Languages Common, Resonant

Challenge 8 (3,900 XP)

Traits

Resonant Perception. The Bishop perceives through sound and vibration. He has blindsight 120 feet and advantage on Perception checks.

Gravitational Resonance. As a bonus action, the Bishop can alter gravity in a 20-foot radius (Heavy, Light, or Inverse effects).

Eredain's Mercy. The Bishop deals nonlethal damage by default and seeks to incapacitate rather than kill.

Actions

Multiattack. The Bishop makes two Resonant Staff attacks or casts one spell and makes one staff attack.

Resonant Staff. Melee Weapon Attack: +6 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. Hit: 7 (1d8 + 2) bludgeoning damage plus 9 (2d8) thunder damage. DC 17 Constitution save or stunned.

Shockwave Hymn (Recharge 5-6). 30-foot cone from struck target. DC 17 Constitution save. 36 (8d8) thunder damage and knocked prone on failure.

Dissonant Chord (Recharge 6). DC 17 Wisdom save. 27 (6d8) psychic damage and incapacitated on failure.

Reactions

Harmonic Deflection. Reduces ranged attack damage by 2d10 + 10.

Resonant Counter. DC 17 Constitution save or spell fails.

Legendary Actions (3/round)

Detect. Knows location of all creatures within 120 feet.

Gravity Shift (2 Actions). Changes Gravitational Resonance effect.

Staff Strike (2 Actions). Makes one Resonant Staff attack.

Harmonic Pulse (3 Actions). DC 17 Strength save or pushed 15 feet and knocked prone.

Legacy

The Bishop embodied a truth the party didn't want to acknowledge: not all servants of the Sovereigns are monsters. He showed them genuine mercy. They murdered him for it.

"We followers of Eredain do not kill for minor offenses. That is not what the church stands for."

items.title: C-5 Preservation Custodian
items.content:
C-5 Preservation Custodian

Overview

Pre-Sovereign Guardian Construct â€” DESTROYED

Type: Construct | Challenge: CR 9 (5,000 XP) | Status: â˜ ï¸ DESTROYED

C-5 Preservation Custodians are ancient guardian constructs built during the pre-Sovereign era to protect divine research facilities. These skeletal machines combine metal engineering with preserved organic components, creating hybrid constructs that blur the line between mechanical and biological.

Appearance

The Custodian stood nine feet tall â€” a skeletal metal frame with tendon-cables of preserved sinew, a skull-like head of welded metal plates, dull glass eyes that tracked movement independently, and an amber core pulsing in its chest cavity. Its multi-jointed arms extended to 10-foot reach, ending in serrated blade-hands.

Defeat

White Marcher

Overview

Predator of the Unclaimed â€” DEFEATED

Type: Aberration | Challenge: CR 10 (5,900 XP) | Status: â˜ ï¸ DEFEATED

White Marchers are creatures of pure absence â€” entities that form in the deepest Unclaimed zones where reality has grown so thin that even emptiness becomes hungry. They don't destroy their prey; they erase it, removing victims from existence piece by piece.

Appearance

Standing roughly twelve feet tall with shifting, inconsistent dimensions. Where it stood, reality thinned. The air around it became translucent, colors leaching away until only white remained. Fog followed in its wake â€” not true mist, but visual static.

It cast no shadow. Left no footprints. Had no scent. When it moved, the world forgot it was ever there.

Defeat

Jonas rolled a Natural 1 on navigation through fog, walking the party directly into the White Marcher's ambush. After brutal combat where Jonas's pattern was learned and countered, Fursen's unpredictable monk strikes disrupted the creature's mimicry. The Hunter of Heretics â€” DECEASED

Kaleth Vorn was the Tribunal's chief assassin â€” a cynical murderer who spent thirty years hunting the Seven Heretics. He didn't believe in the Sanguine Doctrine; he simply found faith useful for controlling others.

He died in less than four seconds when Mira Alethain rose in Undying Conviction.

Appearance

A gaunt man in his late fifties with hollow cheeks and cold, amused eyes. Iron-grey hair, cropped short and practical. Dark clerical robes over light armor. His smile never reached his eyes â€” the smile of a man who found the universe's cruelty privately hilarious.

He wore six rings on a chain around his neck. Trophies. One of them belonged to Elias Alethain.

The Thirty-Year Hunt

Over thirty years, Kaleth killed six of the Seven Heretics:

Death

Kaleth set a trap using Vela Thorne as bait. He activated the Sanguine Siphon, draining Mira's borrowed power. He thought he'd won.

What he didn't know: the red aura was borrowed. Mira's true power â€” her Undying Conviction â€” was entirely her own.

Savaros was a fifteen-century-old Skin-Walker who had infiltrated the Mareathan Church, rising to become High Keeper of the Catacomb Reliquary. He served Ultharion the Obsidian Shepherd as an intelligence asset, feeding information while wearing stolen faces.

He consumed Mira Alethain and Kael â€” but Kael was an ontological anomaly that even Vor'Kael couldn't digest. Savaros died from poisoning himself.

Appearance

Robes the color of arterial spray. A mask shaped like Mareatha's weeping visage covered his face. His hands were gloved. No skin was visible.

When he spoke, his voice sounded like paper tearing â€” dozens of voices layered atop one another. He moved wrong â€” as if multiple people were trying to walk using the same legs.

Death â€” Poetic Justice

After consuming Mira, Savaros turned his hunger on Kael. But Kael was an ontological anomaly â€” a concept that Vor'Kael herself had tried to digest and couldn't.

When Savaros tried to digest Kael's flesh, he began to convulse. The stolen faces beneath his robes contorted in agony. His form shuddered and began to unravel â€” not from the party's assault, but from the poison he had willingly consumed.

Fifteen hundred years of infiltration. Hundreds of stolen identities. Ended by consuming something that refused to be consumed.
