items.title: Session 01: The Church Below
items.content:
Session 01: The Church Below

Prelude â€” The Caravan Job

Sol Raven and Jonas met as hired guards for a merchant caravan. The job was straightforward: escort goods to Veinspire, deliver them to a church in one of the lesser districts, collect payment. Neither knew the other before this job. Neither had reason to trust the other beyond professional obligation.

The journey to Veinspire was uneventful. The land changed as they approached â€” the soil took on a reddish hue, the air grew warm and humid, and a faint copper smell hung in everything. Rivers ran red, not with pollution but with something older. The architecture of distant Veinspire rose on the horizon like a cathedral grown rather than built, its spires twisted into organic shapes that defied conventional masonry.

They delivered the goods without incident. Payment received. Job complete.

They should have left.

Part 1 â€” The River Wakes

Taking Lodging

With coin in their pockets and no immediate obligations, Sol and Jonas took rooms at The Scarlet Hearth â€” a tavern in the Lesser Sacral District named for the great stone fireplace that dominated its common room. The establishment was modest â€” working-class patrons, simple food, beds that were clean enough. The kind of place where people minded their own business.

The district sat along one of Veinspire's arterial rivers â€” canals that ran through the city like veins through flesh. The water was thick and red, viscous in ways water shouldn't be. Locals paid it no mind. This was simply how things were in Mareatha's domain. The rivers carried the Vein-Mother's essence. The rivers were holy.

That first night, the rivers were restless.

The Heartbeat Intensifies

It started as a vibration felt more than heard â€” a deep, rhythmic pulse that made the floorboards tremble. The tavern's patrons paused mid-conversation. Drinks rippled in their cups. The pulse came again. And again. Each beat stronger than the last.

The heartbeat of something vast beneath the city.

Outside, the river began to bubble. Steam rose from its surface despite the cool night air. The red water churned, thick clots rising and sinking in the current.

Then the screaming started.

The Miner

Sol and Jonas rushed outside to find chaos in the streets. Civilians fled in all directions. Among them, a miner â€” still covered in the dust of his labor â€” sprinted toward them, wild-eyed with terror.

A shard of coagulated blood had pierced his leg.

The wound was strange â€” the blood-shard had embedded itself in his calf like a thrown dagger, but it pulsed with its own rhythm, independent of the miner's heartbeat. Dark veins spread from the impact site, crawling up his thigh.

Sol Raven moved to help him. The skeleton's nature remained hidden beneath hood and robe â€” to the miner, Sol was simply a stranger offering aid. Sol knelt to examine the wound, reaching for the shard.

The moment Sol touched him, the miner's eyes went white.

He screamed â€” not in pain, but in rage. Whatever the blood-shard carried had reached his brain. His hands found Sol's throat with strength that shouldn't have belonged to a wounded man. The miner had lost his mind, lost himself, become something else wearing his body.

Sol fought him off as Jonas turned toward the river.

The Blood Beast

Jonas peered over the edge of the canal, trying to see what had caused the chaos. The red water churned below, thick and opaque. He saw nothing.

Then the river exploded upward.

A Blood Beast erupted from the canal â€” a coagulated predator formed from Mareatha's circulatory essence. It was roughly humanoid in shape but wrong in every proportion: too-long limbs, a torso that bulged and contracted with its own heartbeat, a head that was more wound than face. It glistened wetly in the lamplight, held together by divine will rather than anatomy.

It landed on the street with a wet slap and lunged for Jonas.

Combat â€” The River Attack

Enemies:
  • Blood Beast (CR appropriate for level 1)
  • Corrupted Miner (commoner statistics, maddened)
Battlefield: The street outside the tavern, along the canal's edge. Wet cobblestones. Panicking civilians fleeing in all directions. Red water still churning below.

Sol Raven fought the corrupted miner while Jonas engaged the Blood Beast. The miner attacked with desperate, mindless fury â€” clawing, biting, screaming incoherently. The blood-shard in his leg pulsed faster with each passing moment, the dark veins spreading higher.

Jonas tanked the Blood Beast's assault. The creature fought like a thing that didn't understand its own mortality â€” throwing itself forward without regard for defense, trying to engulf rather than strike. Each wound Jonas inflicted wept rather than bled, the creature's mass redistributing around the damage.

Sol's fire magic proved effective against the Beast. Heat caused its coagulated mass to cook and solidify, disrupting its ability to reform. Sol superheated sections of its body while Jonas carved away at the weakened areas.

The miner died still fighting â€” Sol put him down as mercifully as circumstances allowed. There was nothing left of the man inside. Only the corruption.

The Blood Beast fell when Jonas finally struck something vital â€” if such a creature had vital organs. It collapsed into a pool of steaming blood that slowly drained back into the canal.

Victory. The river calmed. The heartbeat faded.

For now.

Aftermath of the Attack

The street was a charnel scene. The miner's body lay still, dark veins frozen beneath his skin. The Blood Beast had left nothing but a wet stain that would trouble the cobblestones for days. Civilians emerged from hiding, some injured, all terrified.

City watch arrived within minutes. They asked questions â€” who were these strangers, what had happened, why were they here? Sol and Jonas answered honestly. They were caravan guards. They heard screaming. They helped.

The watch seemed satisfied, or at least too overwhelmed to press further. Blood Beast attacks were rare but not unheard of in Veinspire. The rivers sometimes... expressed themselves. It was the nature of living in a god's circulatory system.

Sol and Jonas returned to The Scarlet Hearth. Sleep came poorly that night.

Part 2 â€” Sister Marwen's Request

The Parish in Distress

The next morning, a small group from a nearby parish approached Sol and Jonas at the tavern. Word had spread of the strangers who had fought the Blood Beast. Word had spread that they were capable.

The parish was in distress.

Sister Marwen led the delegation. Sister Marwen Role: Parish Cleric, Lesser Sacral District Age: Late twenties Status: â˜ ï¸ Deceased (this session) Appearance: A young woman in her late twenties with blonde hair pulled back in a simple, practical style. Kind blue eyes already showing worry lines from the stress of recent weeks. Fair skin. Work-worn hands that had tended the sick, blessed the dying, and held the grieving. She wore the white robes of the Mareathan clergy â€” red trim along the hems and collar, a red sash at her waist, marking her devotion to the Vein-Mother. No gold thread, no ornate embroidery â€” the modest attire of a lesser sister who served the common folk rather than the cathedral elite. Personality: Gentle, devoted, humble. Sister Marwen was the kind of cleric who knew every parishioner by name, who visited the sick without being asked, who gave her own food to those with less. She had dedicated her life to Mareatha's mercy â€” the compassionate face of the Vein-Mother that the Church preached to the faithful. Young as she was, she had already earned the trust of her entire parish. Final Words: "Kill me. Please. Kill me before Iâ€”"

She was terrified.

The Disappearances

Marwen explained the situation:

Parishioners had been vanishing. Not all at once â€” one every few days for the past two weeks. They would attend evening services, return to their homes, and simply... not be there in the morning. No signs of struggle. No witnesses. No bodies.

The tremors had been growing worse. The church floor shook during services now. Cracks had appeared in the basement walls â€” cracks that wept a thick, dark fluid.

The Bishop had been informed. The Bishop had done nothing. The Bishop had said it was "the Mother's will" and that the faithful should not question.

Sister Marwen questioned.

She believed something was wrong beneath the church. Something had taken root in the old foundations. Something was taking her people.

She asked Sol and Jonas to accompany her into the church's basement. To investigate. To help.

They agreed.

Entering the Church

The church was modest by Veinspire standards â€” a stone building perhaps a century old, built in the early expansion of the district. It served a working-class congregation: miners, laborers, craftsmen, their families. The pews were worn smooth by generations of worship. The altar was simple carved stone, stained dark with centuries of ritual blood-offerings.

In Veinspire, worship meant blood. Small offerings â€” a pricked finger, a shallow cut, a few drops into the collection basin. The Vein-Mother asked for devotion made manifest. The Vein-Mother was always hungry.

Sister Marwen led them to a door behind the altar. Stone steps descended into darkness. The air rising from below was warm and humid, carrying a smell like copper and meat.

Marwen lit a lantern. Her hands trembled.

They descended.

Part 3 â€” The Descent

The Basement

The church's basement had served many purposes over its century of existence. Storage. A shelter during times of trouble. A place for private prayer. The walls were old stone, the floor packed earth, the ceiling low enough that Jonas had to duck.

At first, it seemed normal. Dusty. Forgotten. The kinds of crates and barrels that accumulate in any building's unused spaces.

Then they found the crack in the far wall.

The Crack

The crack was new â€” Sister Marwen confirmed she had never seen it before the tremors began. It split the foundation stones like something had pressed against them from the other side. The edges were wet with a thick, dark fluid that moved too slowly to be water.

The crack was wide enough for a person to squeeze through.

Beyond it, the architecture changed.

The Tunnels

What lay beyond the crack was not stone.

The walls were congealed divine tissue â€” organic matter that had solidified into something like flesh-colored limestone. It was warm to the touch. It gave slightly under pressure. When Sol held the lantern close, they could see organic growths pulsing faintly beneath the surface â€” dark shapes that might have been veins, might have been something else.

The chambers beyond were warped inward like collapsed veins â€” cylindrical passages that branched and rejoined in patterns that followed no human logic. The tunnels throbbed with slow, unnatural heat. The air was thick and wet and tasted of copper.

This was not a catacomb.

This was the interior of a living body.

Mareatha's Architecture

They had found a fragment of Mareatha's circulatory architecture â€” the divine tissue that the Vein-Mother had ripped from Aedwynn the Maker during the Usurpation, the living infrastructure that spread beneath all of Veinspire like roots beneath a tree.

The Heart Below.

Or rather, a tiny fragment of it. A capillary of the divine. A piece of something vastly, incomprehensibly larger that extended throughout the city's foundations.

This fragment was not supposed to be accessible. The crack in the basement wall was new. Something had changed. Something had shifted. The divine tissue was growing, pressing against the boundaries of the human city above.

The missing parishioners had found this crack. Or the crack had found them.

Sister Marwen's fear grew with each step deeper into the tunnels. She had served the Vein-Mother her entire life. She had never seen this. She had never been inside her goddess.

She whispered prayers that seemed to echo strangely off the organic walls.

Deeper

They pressed deeper into the tunnels, following the largest passage. The growths became more pronounced â€” pulsing shapes beneath the tissue walls, dark fluid pooling in depressions in the floor, formations that looked disturbingly like organs.

The heat intensified. The heartbeat returned â€” felt through the floor, through the walls, through the air itself. A rhythm that was almost soothing if you didn't think about what was producing it.

They found traces of the missing parishioners: a shoe, half-absorbed into the wall; a prayer bead necklace, beads scattered across the floor; a dark stain that might once have been a person.

The fragment had consumed them.

Part 4 â€” Marwen's Corruption

The Deepest Point

At the deepest point of their exploration, the tunnel opened into a chamber.

The chamber was roughly spherical, perhaps thirty feet across. The walls pulsed visibly â€” great slow contractions that made the entire space feel like the inside of a breathing lung. In the center of the chamber stood a formation of tissue that rose from the floor like a pillar, its surface covered in what looked almost like faces pressed against skin from the inside, mouths open in silent screams.

The missing parishioners. Absorbed but not entirely gone. Trapped in the divine tissue, aware, suffering.

Sister Marwen saw them. She recognized them. She whispered their names.

The chamber's heartbeat quickened.

The Fragment Awakens

The fragment was spiraling out of control.

Something about the party's presence â€” their living warmth, their blood, their fear â€” had agitated it. The tissue walls contracted faster. The faces in the pillar moved, mouths opening and closing in unison. The dark fluid on the floor began to rise.

An organ-like wall on the far side of the chamber split open violently.

Tendrils burst forth â€” arterial ropes of living tissue, red and glistening, moving with terrible purpose. They whipped across the chamber, fast as striking snakes.

They seized Sister Marwen.

She had time to scream â€” one short, shocked cry â€” before the tendrils pulled her into the fleshy aperture. The wall closed behind her.

Silence.

The Transformation

For a long moment, nothing happened. Sol and Jonas stood frozen, weapons raised, staring at the wall that had swallowed their guide. The chamber's heartbeat had slowed to something almost peaceful.

Then the wall opened again.

Sister Marwen emerged.

She was distorted. Corrupted. Suffering.

Her body had been reshaped in the seconds she had been inside the fragment. Her skin had taken on a greyish-red hue, stretched tight over bones that had shifted into wrong configurations. Her arms had lengthened, her fingers fused into blade-like appendages. Her face was still recognizably hers â€” that was the horror of it â€” but her jaw had unhinged, revealing rows of teeth that had not been there before.

Dark veins pulsed visibly beneath her skin. The same corruption that had taken the miner, amplified a thousandfold.

But her eyes were still hers.

Marwen's Plea

She collapsed to the floor, her transformed body convulsing. The corruption was still taking hold, still reshaping her, and she was fighting it with everything she had.

Her voice emerged broken, wet, inhuman â€” but the words were her own:

"Kill me."

She dragged herself toward them, not to attack, but to beg.

"Please. Kill me before Iâ€”"

Her voice cut off. Her body seized. Her eyes, which had been filled with desperate pleading, went blank.

Whatever Sister Marwen had been was gone.

What remained rose to its feet, flexed its blade-fingers, and attacked.

Combat â€” The Corrupted Sister

Enemy:
  • Corrupted Sister Marwen (statistics appropriate for a challenging level 1 encounter)
Battlefield: The spherical chamber at the heart of the fragment. Organic walls pulsing around them. Dark fluid underfoot. The pillar of absorbed parishioners watching with trapped, silent faces.

The thing that had been Marwen fought with terrible efficiency. Her transformed body was faster than it should have been, stronger than it should have been. The blade-fingers slashed with surgical precision. She made no sound as she attacked â€” no battle cries, no screams, just the wet whisper of tissue moving through air.

Sol and Jonas fought back. They had to.

The corruption controlling Marwen was not intelligent in any conventional sense â€” it was reflexive, predatory, consuming. It did not strategize. It did not speak. It simply attacked, over and over, until it was destroyed or its prey was consumed.

The battle was brutal. The chamber's heartbeat quickened with each wound inflicted, each drop of blood spilled. The tissue walls contracted closer, as if the fragment itself was trying to join the fight.

But Sol and Jonas were capable. They were professional. They had survived the Blood Beast hours before.

They killed her.

Victory. A mercy.

The Aftermath in the Chamber

Marwen's corrupted body did not die cleanly.

It bloated â€” the corruption responding to the cessation of life by trying to consume the shell that remained. Her body swelled, dark fluid pressing against skin that could no longer contain it.

Then it exploded.

The detonation painted the chamber walls with gore. Dark tissue splattered across Sol and Jonas, across the pillar of trapped faces, across everything. The smell was indescribable â€” copper and rot and something sweetly chemical.

When the echoes faded, nothing remained of Sister Marwen but a wet stain on the organic floor.

The chamber's heartbeat slowed.

The fragment had fed.

Escape

Sol and Jonas fled.

They did not stop to investigate further. They did not attempt to free the absorbed parishioners â€” if such a thing was even possible. They simply ran, back through the tunnels of living tissue, back through the crack in the basement wall, back up the stone steps into the church above.

They emerged into daylight, covered in blood and worse, gasping for air that didn't taste of copper.

The church was empty. The parishioners who had seen them descend were gone â€” fled, perhaps, when the screaming started. When the tremors intensified. When the walls began to weep.

They had to report what had happened.

Part 5 â€” The Bishop's Welcome

Reporting to the Authorities

Sol and Jonas made their way to the district's ecclesiastical authority â€” a minor administrative building where the church hierarchy managed the lesser parishes. They were blood-soaked, traumatized, and carrying news that no one would want to hear.

A Bishop received them.

He was a middle-aged man with the soft hands and well-fed face of someone who had never worked a day of manual labor. His robes were finer than anything Sister Marwen had ever worn. His office was comfortable, decorated with religious iconography that seemed almost obscene after what Sol and Jonas had witnessed below.

They told him everything.

The crack in the basement. The tunnels of living tissue. The absorbed parishioners. Sister Marwen's corruption and death. The chamber with its pillar of screaming faces.

The Bishop listened. He nodded. He made appropriate sounds of concern.

Then he offered them a cleansing ceremony.

The Cleansing

The Bishop explained that exposure to raw divine tissue could leave... residue. Corruption that might not manifest for days or weeks. A cleansing ceremony â€” ritual immersion in holy water â€” would purify them, ensure that whatever they had touched in those tunnels would not touch them back.

It was a reasonable precaution. It was a generous offer.

Sol Raven rejected it.

The hooded figure simply shook their head and moved toward the door. No explanation. No excuse. Just refusal.

The Bishop's eyes followed Sol out. His expression did not change, but something behind it did. A hooded stranger who had descended into divine tissue and emerged alive. A hooded stranger who refused purification. A hooded stranger who might be hiding something beneath those robes.

Jonas accepted.

He followed the Bishop to a side chamber where a pool of holy water waited â€” a basin carved into the floor, filled with liquid that glowed faintly red. Blood-water. Sacred. This was Veinspire, after all. Even holy water carried the Vein-Mother's essence.

Jonas entered the pool. The water was warm, almost hot. It tingled against his skin, a sensation that might have been cleansing or might have been something else entirely.

When he emerged, the Bishop declared him purified.

Pushing His Luck

Jonas, perhaps emboldened by surviving two near-death experiences in as many days, decided to push his luck.

He asked the Bishop for a reward.

They had, after all, risked their lives to investigate the disappearances. They had destroyed a corruption that might have spread further. They had done the church's work when the church itself had done nothing.

The Bishop considered this.

Then he smiled â€” a warm, pastoral smile that did not reach his eyes â€” and agreed. Jonas had performed a heroic deed. Jonas deserved recognition.

The Bishop gave him gold.

Jonas thanked him and left, satisfied that he had made the best of a terrible situation.

He did not see the Bishop's expression change the moment the door closed.

He did not see the Bishop summon a junior priest and speak quietly about "the hooded stranger" and "potential heresy" and "matters for the Inquisition."

He did not know that the Bishop had already made his decision about the hooded figure who refused purification.

Word was already being sent to High Inquisitor Seraphine Vale.

Session Conclusion

The Night After

Sol and Jonas reunited at The Scarlet Hearth that evening. Neither spoke much about what had happened. What was there to say? They had descended into a god's flesh. They had killed an innocent woman transformed into a monster. They had seen the faces of the damned pressed against walls of living tissue.

This was Veinspire. This was the Ashen Realms. This was the world the Sovereigns had made from the Maker's corpse.

They drank. They rested. They tried not to dream.

In the morning, the Inquisition would come.
items.raw: Session 01: The Church Below  Prelude â€” The Caravan Job  Sol Raven and Jonas met as hired guards for a merchant caravan. The job was straightforward: escort goods to Veinspire, deliver them to a church in one of the lesser districts, collect payment. Neither knew the other before this job. Neither had reason to trust the other beyond professional obligation.  The journey to Veinspire was uneventful. The land changed as they approached â€” the soil took on a reddish hue, the air grew warm and humid, and a faint copper smell hung in everything. Rivers ran red, not with pollution but with something older. The architecture of distant Veinspire rose on the horizon like a cathedral grown rather than built, its spires twisted into organic shapes that defied conventional masonry.  They delivered the goods without incident. Payment received. Job complete.  They should have left.  Part 1 â€” The River Wakes  Taking Lodging  With coin in their pockets and no immediate obligations, Sol and Jonas took rooms at The Scarlet Hearth â€” a tavern in the Lesser Sacral District named for the great stone fireplace that dominated its common room. The establishment was modest â€” working-class patrons, simple food, beds that were clean enough. The kind of place where people minded their own business.  The district sat along one of Veinspire's arterial rivers â€” canals that ran through the city like veins through flesh. The water was thick and red, viscous in ways water shouldn't be. Locals paid it no mind.

items.title: Session 02: The Inquisition & The Theorists
items.content:
Session 02: The Inquisition & The Theorists

Part 1 â€” The Inquisition Arrives

Morning at The Scarlet Hearth

Sol and Jonas woke in their rooms at The Scarlet Hearth â€” the modest tavern that had become their temporary home in the Lesser Sacral District. The establishment took its name from the great stone fireplace that dominated its common room, its flames casting a warm reddish glow that locals found comforting in a city where red was the color of the sacred.

Sleep had not come easily. The memory of Sister Marwen's pleading eyes, her transformed body, her explosion into gore â€” these images lingered. But morning had come regardless, and with it, the need to move forward.

They descended to the common room for breakfast. The other patrons gave them a wide berth. Word had spread. The strangers who had gone into the church basement. The strangers who had come out covered in blood. The strangers who had killed Sister Marwen.

The whispers followed them out the door.

Suspicion in the Streets

The Lesser Sacral District felt different that morning. Gazes lingered too long. Conversations paused as they passed. A mother pulled her child closer when Sol's hooded figure walked by.

The district had decided what to think of them. Two strangers arrive. A Blood Beast attacks. They descend into a church with a beloved sister. Only they return. The sister's body is never found.

It didn't matter that they had tried to help. It didn't matter that Marwen had begged them to kill her. The district saw only the facts: strangers, violence, death.

They had barely made it a block from the tavern when the Inquisition found them.

High Inquisitor Seraphine Vale

She was waiting for them at the intersection of two arterial streets, flanked by four armed soldiers in the standard armor of the Inquisition's enforcers. The morning crowd had already parted around her, civilians pressing themselves against walls and doorways to avoid her attention.

High Inquisitor Seraphine Vale stood perfectly still, watching them approach. High Inquisitor Seraphine Vale Role: High Inquisitor, Mareathan Inquisition Age: 34 Status: Active (this session) Appearance: A striking woman in her mid-thirties with sharp, aristocratic features and eyes the color of dried blood â€” a mark of Mareatha's favor granted to her most devoted servants. Her dark hair was worn in a severe braid that fell past her shoulders. She carried herself with the absolute certainty of someone who had never questioned their purpose. Her Inquisitor's vestments were immaculate â€” white robes trimmed with arterial red, cut for both ceremony and combat. The holy symbol of Mareatha hung openly at her throat: a heart wrapped in veins. There was no cruelty in her face. That was what made her dangerous. She genuinely believed she was saving souls. Personality: Patient. Methodical. Certain. Seraphine Vale did not raise her voice. She did not make threats. She simply asked questions and waited for the truth to emerge. She had never failed to extract a confession from a genuine heretic â€” because she believed, truly believed, that the guilty always revealed themselves. The Vein-Mother's light exposed all falsehood. First Words to the Party: "You are the ones who descended into the Church of the Merciful Vein. You are the ones who emerged without Sister Marwen. I have questions."

She did not introduce herself. She did not need to. Everyone in Veinspire knew the blood-eyed woman who hunted heretics.

"You are the ones who descended into the Church of the Merciful Vein," she said. Her voice was calm, almost gentle. "You are the ones who emerged without Sister Marwen. I have questions."

It was not a request.

The soldiers moved to flank Sol and Jonas â€” not aggressively, but with the casual certainty of predators who knew their prey could not escape. The message was clear: they would answer the High Inquisitor's questions, one way or another.

Part 2 â€” The Trial by Ash

The Red Priory

Seraphine did not take them to a dungeon. She did not chain them or threaten them with torture. Instead, she led them to The Red Priory â€” a chapel in the Lesser Sacral District that served as a secondary seat for the Inquisition's work among the common folk.

The sun never truly shone in Veinspire â€” it just faded. By the time they arrived, the air was thick with candle smoke and incense. The once-holy halls glowed a dull crimson, as though the walls themselves were bleeding.

A pair of Inquisitors in mirrored masks escorted Sol and Jonas inside. Their boots echoed through the marble corridors, lined with icons defaced in soot. Every eye in the murals had been carved out.

At the center of the chapel sat a great brazier filled with smoldering ash. Seraphine stood behind it, flanked by two aides â€” Confessor Halvyr (a whispering priest with a scarred throat) and Scribe Malis (a masked scribe recording everything in ash ink).

The brazier's light painted Seraphine's face gold and red, like a saint sculpted from fresh blood.

"Step forward," she said. "And kneel."

Refusal Before the Flame

Sol and Jonas stepped forward.

They did not kneel.

Jonas â€” armored, battle-worn, scarred from his encounter with the Blood Beast. Sol Raven â€” still, silent, draped in cloth, eyes like coals under his hood.

A long, cold pause. The Inquisitors shifted; the sound of their armor was a whisper of threat.

"You misunderstand," Seraphine said, her voice patient. "Kneeling isn't submission. It's recognition â€” that something greater than flesh hears your truth."

No movement. She lowered her voice.

"Refusal before the flame... is still confession."

She took one step forward, the red light of the brazier reflecting off her blood-colored eyes.

"Very well. Stand, then. But the flame stands with you."

She gestured sharply. Two masked attendants pulled open narrow vents in the brazier â€” the fire grew brighter, higher, breathing like a living thing.

"Let your words prove stronger than your knees."

The Structure of the Trial

The interrogation happened in three stages, each testing something different:

  1. Faith â€” words and conviction
  2. Blood â€” the body's truth
  3. Will â€” the soul's resistance

Their defiance had consequences. All checks would be harder now. The Inquisitors were watching for any misstep.

Stage One: Faith

Seraphine gestured toward the brazier.

"Speak what you saw below the Church of the Merciful Vein. Speak as though the Vein-Mother listens â€” because She does."

Sol and Jonas told the truth â€” or most of it. The crack in the basement. The tunnels of living tissue. The absorbed parishioners. Marwen's corruption. Her plea to be killed. The combat. The explosion.

Seraphine's expression did not change. When they finished, she asked clarifying questions. Small details. The color of the fluid. The temperature of the walls. The exact words Marwen had spoken.

She was testing their story against itself.

Jonas invoked duty, spoke of the Priory, of responding to a sister's plea for help. Sol spoke as a scholar â€” clinical, observational, careful not to claim more understanding than warranted.

Seraphine nodded slowly throughout. When they finished, she said nothing for a long moment.

"A liar who hides behind faith is still a believer," she murmured. "But you speak with the cadence of truth. The flame accepts your account â€” for now."

Stage One: Partial success.

Stage Two: Blood

Confessor Halvyr stepped forward with a silver censer and a long needle. He motioned for their hands.

"The body does not lie," Seraphine said. "Your veins will tell us whom you serve."

The test was ritual and invasive. When the needle pierced the skin, a drop of blood would fall into the ash brazier. If it glowed red, the Heart's corruption was near. If it burned clean, the subject was untainted.

Jonas went first.

The needle pierced his palm. Blood welled â€” red, ordinary, human. It dripped into the brazier.

The ash glowed faintly, then subsided. Clean. But Seraphine's eyes lingered on Jonas's arm, where faint red veins pulsed once beneath the skin â€” visible only to her trained gaze. A trace of something. Not corruption, but... contact. Proximity to the divine tissue.

She said nothing. But she noticed.

Sol Raven's turn.

Halvyr approached with the needle. Sol extended a wrapped hand â€” the bandages that concealed bone rather than flesh.

The needle pressed against Sol's palm.

Nothing.

Halvyr pressed harder. The needle should have pierced skin, drawn blood, revealed truth.

Sol's hand was dry. Empty. The needle drew nothing at all.

A long silence. Halvyr looked to Seraphine, uncertainty in his posture.

Seraphine stared at the empty needle for a long moment. Her blood-colored eyes found Sol's hidden face.

"Curious," she said quietly.

She did not press further. But the suspicion was planted â€” a seed that would grow in the days to come.

Stage Two: Failed. Sol's nature remained hidden, but Seraphine knew something was wrong.

Stage Three: Will

Seraphine dismissed her aides. Only the brazier's light remained.

"Now we see the truth that cannot be cut or burned."

She held up her halberd â€” the blade dripping faint red light from rituals performed long ago.

"Look into the flame. Speak what you fear. If you lie, the flame will grow cold."

Jonas looked into the fire.

The flames reflected in his eyes. He held his stare, jaw set, soldier's discipline keeping his expression neutral. The flame flickered â€” tested â€” then steadied.

Seraphine nodded once.

"A soldier's will. Steel forged in duty. The kind we need."

Sol looked into the fire.

The light bent strangely around the hooded figure. For a moment, the flame seemed to hum â€” a resonance that had no source, a vibration that touched something deep in Seraphine's training.

Her pupils dilated. She felt something answer from within Sol. Something that should not have been there.

"You are... touched," she whispered. "But by what?"

The flame guttered. Cold crept into the brazier's heart.

Stage Three: Failed. Sol's nature remained secret, but the wrongness of his existence had registered.

The Verdict

Seraphine raised her halberd and drove its butt into the marble floor. The sound echoed through the Red Priory like a judge's gavel.

"Two faults. One strength."

She circled them slowly, her weapon tracing a faint hum in the air.

"You stood before the flame, yet it did not consume you. That means the Heart still knows your names. It has not decided whether to kill you... or use you."

She stopped before Jonas.

"You believe in order, soldier. But your faith is forged of fear. You'll obey â€” not because you worship, but because you dread chaos."

Then she turned to Sol.

"And you." The brazier's light flickered, casting strange shadows across Sol's wrapped form. "You've touched something you shouldn't have. You carry a wrongness the flame cannot name."

She stepped back, addressing them both.

"You are not proven heretics. But you are not proven faithful either. You exist in the space between â€” potential heretics, watched but not condemned."

Forbidden to Leave

"You will remain in Veinspire," Seraphine said. It was not a request. "You will not attempt to leave the city. You will report to the Chapel of Inquiry every three days to confirm your presence. You will not interfere with Church business unless directed."

She paused at the chapel door.

"I will be watching you. The Vein-Mother's eyes are everywhere in her city. Do not forget that."

Then she was gone, her soldiers falling into step behind her.

Sol and Jonas were left alone in the Red Priory, the weight of their situation settling over them like a shroud. They were trapped. Suspected. Surveilled. And they had no idea how to escape.

Part 3 â€” The Cursed Breastplate

Seeking Armor

After the Inquisition's departure, Sol and Jonas took stock of their situation. They were trapped in Veinspire, yes â€” but that didn't mean they had to be helpless. The fights in the church basement had shown them the dangers of this city. They needed better equipment.

They spent the afternoon searching the Lesser Sacral District for a blacksmith. Most of the forges in the district served the mining community â€” picks, shovels, cart wheels, the tools of labor. But eventually they found a smith who dealt in arms and armor.

The Blacksmith's Offer

The smith was a broad-shouldered man with burn-scarred forearms and the permanently squinting eyes of someone who had spent decades staring into forge-fire. His shop was cramped and cluttered, weapons and armor pieces hanging from every available surface.

He looked Sol and Jonas up and down with the calculating gaze of a merchant assessing customers.

"Looking for protection, are you?" He gestured vaguely at his wares. "Got chainmail. Got leather. Got a few pieces of plate if you've got the coin."

Jonas browsed the selection. Most of it was serviceable but unremarkable â€” the kind of armor that would stop a blade but wouldn't turn heads.

Then he noticed the breastplate in the corner.

It was steel, well-crafted, with a subtle curve that would deflect blows effectively. It looked expensive â€” far too expensive for a smith in the Lesser Sacral District. But it sat apart from the other pieces, almost hidden, as if the smith didn't want anyone to notice it.

"What about that one?"

The smith's expression changed. Something flickered across his face â€” discomfort, perhaps. Or fear.

"That one's... different," he said carefully. "Found it in a shipment from the cathedral district years ago. Don't know where it came from originally. Don't want to know."

"What's wrong with it?"

The smith hesitated. Then he picked up the breastplate and held it close to Jonas.

"Listen."

Jonas leaned in. At first he heard nothing. Then â€” faint, almost imperceptible â€” a rhythm. A pulse. A heartbeat.

The breastplate had its own heartbeat.

"It's cursed," the smith said flatly. "Or blessed. Or something in between. I've had priests look at it. They can't explain it. All I know is, it's been sitting in my shop for eight years and I want it gone."

He thrust it toward Jonas.

"Fifty gold. That's a fraction of what it's worth as armor, and I don't care. Take it. Get it out of my shop. I'm tired of hearing that damn heartbeat when I'm trying to sleep."

Jonas's Choice

Jonas examined the breastplate more closely. The craftsmanship was excellent â€” better than anything else in the shop. The steel was high quality, the joints well-fitted, the straps solid leather. And there was something else: the metal radiated a faint red hue, as if warmth lived within the steel itself. As armor, it would serve admirably.

The heartbeat continued. Slow. Steady. Alive.

In any other city, Jonas might have walked away. But this was Veinspire. This was Mareatha's domain. Here, blood flowed upward in fountains. Here, the rivers pulsed with divine essence. Here, the boundary between the living and the inanimate was... flexible.

A breastplate with a heartbeat was strange. But was it dangerous?

Jonas made his decision. He paid the fifty gold and strapped the breastplate on.

The heartbeat synchronized with his own within minutes.

Part 4 â€” The Alleyway

Evening Falls

As evening descended over the Lesser Sacral District, Sol and Jonas found themselves wandering the streets with no particular destination. The Inquisition's surveillance weighed on them. Every passing face might be a spy. Every shadow might hide watching eyes.

They needed allies. They needed information. They needed a way out of this trap.

They had none of these things.

The arterial canals glowed faintly in the dusk, their red waters catching the last light of day. Lanterns were being lit along the major thoroughfares. The district was transitioning from the bustle of day to the quieter rhythms of night.

They were passing the mouth of an alleyway when a hand reached out and grabbed Jonas's arm.

"In here. Quickly. Before they see you."

Kael

The young man who pulled them into the shadows was barely out of his teens â€” thin, nervous, with the ink-stained fingers of a scholar and the darting eyes of someone who expected to be caught at any moment.

He pressed himself against the alley wall, peering past them toward the street.

"Were you followed? Did anyone see you come this way?"

Sol and Jonas exchanged glances. They had no idea who this person was or why he was accosting them in an alleyway.

"Who are you?" Sol asked.

The young man seemed to remember himself. He straightened slightly, though his eyes kept flicking toward the alley's entrance.

"My name is Kael. I'm... I'm with people who want to help you. People who understand what it's like to be trapped in this city. People who know what the Church really is."

Kael Role: Resonant Theorist, Scholar Age: Early twenties Status: Alive (joins party this session) Appearance: A young man who looked barely out of his teens â€” thin and angular, with the pale complexion of someone who spent more time with books than sunlight. His dark hair was perpetually disheveled, and his fingers were stained with ink from constant writing. He wore simple scholar's robes, threadbare at the elbows, and carried a satchel that bulged with papers and journals. His eyes were sharp despite their nervous darting â€” the eyes of someone who noticed details others missed. Personality: Anxious, brilliant, driven. Kael vibrated with nervous energy, always looking over his shoulder, always expecting the Inquisition to appear. But beneath the anxiety was a fierce intelligence and a burning need to understand the truth of the world. He had risked everything to study forbidden knowledge. He would risk everything again to share it. First Words to the Party: "I know who you are. I know the Inquisition has marked you. And I know you need help â€” the kind of help the Church will never give you."

"I know who you are," Kael continued, speaking quickly. "You're the ones who went into the Church of the Merciful Vein. You're the ones Seraphine Vale questioned today. The whole district is talking about it."

He stepped closer, lowering his voice.

"I also know you need help. The kind of help the Church will never give you. The Inquisition has marked you as potential heretics â€” that means they're watching you, waiting for you to slip up. Sooner or later, they'll find an excuse to arrest you properly. And then..."

He drew a finger across his throat.

"But there are others in this city who oppose the Church. Others who see what it really is. And we might be able to help you â€” if you're willing to help us first."

An Offer

Sol and Jonas listened as Kael explained. He was part of a group called the Resonance Theorists â€” scholars and researchers who studied the true nature of the world. They believed that the Sovereigns were not gods in any meaningful sense, that the world itself was built on the corpse of something older, and that the divine "truth" preached by the Church was a carefully maintained lie.

This was heresy of the highest order. The kind of heresy that got people publicly executed.

"We operate in secret," Kael said. "We have to. If the Inquisition found us..." He shuddered. "But we have resources. Knowledge. Connections outside the city. We can help you escape Veinspire â€” eventually. But first, we need to know we can trust you."

"How do we prove that?"

Kael's nervous energy intensified. "There's something we need. Something important to our research. We can discuss the details later, with the others. But if you're willing to work with us â€” if you're willing to help us â€” we can help you in return."

He glanced toward the alley's entrance again.

"Think about it. Come to The Scarlet Hearth tonight, after midnight. I'll find you there and take you to meet the others."

Then he slipped away into the shadows, leaving Sol and Jonas alone with a choice to make.

Part 5 â€” The Mines

Return to The Scarlet Hearth

Sol and Jonas returned to the tavern as evening deepened into night. The common room was busier now â€” miners off their shifts, laborers seeking drink after a hard day, a few travelers passing through. The fire in the great stone hearth crackled warmly, casting dancing shadows across the walls.

They found a table in the corner and ordered food, their minds occupied with Kael's offer. Alliance with heretics. The risk was enormous. But so was the alternative â€” waiting for Seraphine Vale to find an excuse to condemn them.

They were debating their options when they noticed the miner.

The Drunk Miner

He sat alone at a table near the fire, hunched over a mug of ale that he wasn't drinking. His clothes were dust-covered, his face haggard, his eyes unfocused. He looked like a man who had seen something that had broken him.

What drew their attention was his hand.

A shard of crystallized blood was embedded in his palm â€” a jagged red crystal that pulsed faintly with its own light. The same kind of shard that had corrupted the miner they'd fought on their first night in Veinspire.

The man was staring at it with the glazed expression of someone in shock.

The Miner's Plea

Sol and Jonas approached carefully. The miner looked up at them with hollow eyes.

"You're them, aren't you?" His voice was slurred â€” from drink or trauma, it was hard to say. "The ones who killed the beast in the canal. The ones who went into the church."

They didn't deny it.

The miner lifted his hand, showing them the crystal embedded in his flesh. "Found this in the mines. The northern tunnels. Something's wrong up there. Men have been... changing. Acting strange. Some of them don't come back at all."

He swallowed hard.

"I pulled this out of a wall. Didn't think nothing of it at first â€” crystals in the mines aren't unusual. But then it... it started growing into me. I can feel it. Spreading. Like roots under my skin."

His voice cracked.

"Please. I don't want to end up like the others. I don't want to become... something else."

Cauterization

Jonas examined the shard. It had embedded itself deep into the miner's palm, crystalline tendrils spreading beneath the skin toward the wrist. The same corruption they had seen before â€” Mareatha's influence, uncontrolled and consuming.

But this was early. The corruption hadn't reached the miner's brain yet. There might still be time.

Jonas made a decision. He crossed to the tavern's great hearth and thrust his blade into the coals, heating the metal until it glowed orange. Then he returned to the miner.

"This is going to hurt."

The miner nodded, understanding.

Jonas gripped the shard with one hand and pulled. The crystal came free with a wet tearing sound, trailing thin tendrils of corrupted tissue. Before the wound could bleed â€” before the corruption could spread â€” Jonas pressed the heated blade against the miner's palm.

The miner screamed. The smell of burning flesh filled the air. Nearby patrons looked up in alarm, then quickly looked away. In Veinspire, people learned not to ask questions.

When Jonas removed the blade, the wound was cauterized. Ugly, scarred, but clean. The corruption had been stopped.

The miner slumped in his chair, unconscious from pain and shock.

The Northern Mines

Sol and Jonas looked at the crystal in Jonas's hand. It pulsed weakly, its light fading now that it was separated from living flesh.

The miner had mentioned the northern tunnels. Something wrong. Men changing. Some not coming back.

They exchanged glances. This wasn't their problem. They had enough troubles without adding mine investigations to the list.

But the corruption was spreading. The Blood Beast. The church basement. Now the mines. Mareatha's domain was becoming unstable, and whatever was causing it would only get worse.

They left the unconscious miner in the care of the tavern keeper and headed north to investigate.

Blood Beasts at the Entrance

The entrance to the northern mines was a gaping wound in the hillside north of the Lesser Sacral District â€” a tunnel mouth reinforced with timber beams, lit by flickering torches that cast uncertain light into the darkness beyond.

No guards. No workers. The mines should have been active even at this hour â€” Veinspire's industrial heart never truly slept â€” but the northern tunnels were silent.

Sol and Jonas entered cautiously, weapons drawn.

They didn't get far.

The first Blood Beast emerged from the shadows barely thirty yards in â€” a coagulated horror similar to the one they'd fought at the canal, but smaller, faster. It had been feeding on something. The remains of a miner lay scattered nearby.

Then another emerged. And another.

The tunnel entrance had become a nest.

Combat â€” Blood Beasts

Enemies:
  • Blood Beasts (3)
Battlefield: The mine entrance tunnel. Narrow confines. Flickering torchlight. Limited room to maneuver.

The Blood Beasts attacked with savage hunger, their coagulated forms surging forward in the cramped space. Sol's fire magic proved effective once again â€” heat causing their bodies to solidify and crack. Jonas held the line, his new breastplate absorbing blows that would have killed an unarmored man.

The fight was brutal but brief. Three Blood Beasts were dangerous, but Sol and Jonas had learned from their first encounter. They knew how these things moved, how they attacked, how they died.

When the last Beast collapsed into a steaming pool of ichor, Sol and Jonas stood in the tunnel entrance, breathing hard.

Victory. But the deeper tunnels remained unexplored.

Retreat

They could have pressed deeper. The miner's story suggested something worse lurked in the northern tunnels â€” something creating these Blood Beasts, something corrupting the workers.

But they were tired. Wounded. And Kael's midnight meeting was approaching.

"We'll come back," Jonas said, looking into the darkness beyond the torchlight. "When we know more. When we're better prepared."

Sol nodded. The mines weren't going anywhere. And neither, it seemed, was the corruption.

They returned to The Scarlet Hearth. The miner was still unconscious, but his color had improved. The tavern keeper had bandaged his hand and was watching over him.

Jonas set the blood crystal on the table. It was cool now, inert, its power faded.

"Keep this safe," he told the keeper. "The man will want it when he wakes."

Then they waited for midnight.

Part 6 â€” The Resonance Theorists

Midnight Meeting

After midnight, when the common room of The Scarlet Hearth had emptied and the fire had burned low, Kael appeared.

He emerged from the shadows near the back entrance, still nervous, still glancing over his shoulder. But there was something else in his expression now â€” hope, perhaps. The hope that he had found allies.

"You came back," he said. "Good. Follow me."

Carveth

The leader stepped forward to greet them.

Carveth was a middle-aged man with grey-streaked hair and the weathered face of someone who had spent years running from something. His eyes were sharp, assessing, calculating. He carried himself with the authority of a scholar who had seen too much to be afraid anymore.

"So," he said, studying Sol and Jonas. "You're the ones who descended into the Heart Below. The ones Seraphine Vale has marked as potential heretics."

He smiled â€” a thin, humorless expression.

"Welcome to the resistance."

Carveth Role: Leader of the Resonance Theorists Age: Mid-fifties Status: Alive (this session) Appearance: A middle-aged man with grey-streaked hair that had once been dark, worn long and tied back in a practical tail. His face was weathered, lined with the stress of years spent in hiding. He wore scholar's robes that had seen better days, patched and mended repeatedly. His hands were calloused â€” not from labor, but from decades of handling books and instruments. His eyes were the most striking feature: sharp, calculating, and utterly unafraid. Personality: Pragmatic to the point of coldness. Carveth had been running the Resonance Theorists for over a decade, watching friends be captured and executed, rebuilding cells that were discovered and destroyed. He had learned that sentiment was a luxury he could not afford. But beneath the pragmatism was a genuine passion for truth â€” a burning need to understand what the world really was, regardless of the cost. To the Party: "The Church teaches that the Sovereigns are gods. We believe they are something else entirely â€” parasites feeding on the corpse of the true divine. If you want to survive in this world, you need to understand what you're really dealing with."

The Corpse-World's Divine Memory

Carveth explained what the Resonance Theorists believed.

The world was built on death. Specifically, it was built on the corpse of Aedwynn the Maker â€” a being of true divinity who had been murdered by the Thirteen Sovereigns during the event called the Usurpation. The Sovereigns had carved up Aedwynn's body like butchers dividing a carcass, each claiming a piece of divine power for themselves.

But death was not the end. The Maker's corpse still retained... echoes. Memories. Fragments of consciousness embedded in the divine tissue that now formed the foundation of reality. The Theorists called this the corpse-world's divine memory â€” information encoded in the very substance of existence.

"The Church teaches that the Sovereigns are our rightful rulers," Carveth said. "That they brought order to chaos, light to darkness. But the truth is simpler and uglier: they are thieves. Murderers. They killed a god and are wearing its skin."

He gestured to the papers and diagrams covering the cellar walls.

"We study the divine memory. We try to understand what Aedwynn was, what the Sovereigns truly are, and whether there is any way to... correct what was done."

The implications hung in the air. These people weren't just studying forbidden knowledge. They were seeking a way to undo the Usurpation itself.

The Offer

"We can help you," Carveth said. "We have contacts outside Veinspire. Safe houses in the Unclaimed territories. Ways to move people past the Church's checkpoints. If you work with us, we can eventually get you out of the city."

"And in return?"

"In return, you help us." Carveth's eyes were steady. "You've already proven you can handle yourselves. You've descended into places the faithful fear to tread. We have need of people like you."

He paused.

"There's something specific we need. A text held in the Church archives â€” the Resonant Codex. It contains information about the divine memory that we desperately need for our research. We've been trying to acquire it for years, but the archives are heavily guarded."

"You want us to steal it."

"I want you to retrieve it," Carveth corrected. "For the good of everyone who wants to understand the truth of this world. Will you help us?"

Sol and Jonas looked at each other. The choice was clear: ally with heretics and risk everything, or remain alone and wait for the Inquisition to destroy them.

They made their decision.

"We'll help."

Kael's face broke into a relieved smile. Carveth simply nodded, as if he had expected nothing less.

"Good. We'll discuss the details of the Codex retrieval tomorrow. For now, rest. You've had a long day."

He was right about that.

Session Conclusion

Dawn Approaches

Sol and Jonas emerged from the Theorists' cellar as the first grey light of dawn touched the sky. The Lesser Sacral District was stirring â€” early workers heading to their shifts, vendors setting up their stalls, the eternal rhythm of a city that never truly slept.

They returned to The Scarlet Hearth, exhausted but no longer hopeless. They had allies now. They had a purpose. They had a path forward, however dangerous.

The Inquisition was still watching. Seraphine Vale was still hunting. The northern mines still held dangers unexplored. And somewhere beneath the city, the Heart Below still beat.

But for the first time since arriving in Veinspire, Sol and Jonas felt like they had a chance.

Obligations & Restrictions

Obligation Details
Cannot Leave Veinspire Forbidden by Seraphine Vale
Report to Chapel of Inquiry Every 3 days to confirm presence
Resonant Codex Mission Promised to help Theorists retrieve it

The establishment took its name from the great stone fireplace that dominated its common room, its flames casting a warm reddish glow that locals found comforting in a city where red was the color of the sacred. items.title: Session 03: The Codex Heist
items.content:
Session 03: The Codex Heist

Part 1 â€” The Theorists' Tasks

Return to the Cellar

The following evening, Sol and Jonas returned to the Resonance Theorists' hidden cellar beneath the townhouse in the Lesser Sacral District. Kael met them at the entrance, his nervous energy somewhat tempered by relief â€” they had come back. They hadn't betrayed the Theorists to the Inquisition.

The cellar was busier tonight. Scholars moved between workstations, copying texts by candlelight, examining artifacts, arguing in hushed voices over interpretations of ancient passages. The air smelled of old paper, ink, and the faint copper tang that permeated all of Veinspire.

Carveth was waiting for them at the central table, flanked by two other senior members of the organization.

"You've returned," he said. It wasn't a question. "Good. We have work for you â€” and you have a choice to make."

Three Tasks

Carveth gestured to the two figures beside him.

"The Resonance Theorists have many needs. You cannot fulfill all of them, but you can choose how to prove your worth to us."

He indicated the woman to his left first.

Mirelle Ashford Role: Chief Researcher, Resonance Theorists Age: Late forties Status: â˜ ï¸ Executed Appearance: A woman in her late forties with steel-grey hair pulled back in a severe bun, wire-rimmed spectacles perched on a sharp nose, and the ink-stained fingers of someone who spent more time with documents than people. Her face was lined with the deep concentration marks of a lifetime scholar â€” furrows between her brows, crow's feet from squinting at faded text. She wore practical scholar's robes in muted browns, and a magnifying lens hung from a chain around her neck. Personality: Precise, methodical, impatient with imprecision. Mirelle had spent thirty years studying the divine memory of the corpse-world, and she had little tolerance for those who couldn't keep up with her reasoning. But beneath the brusque exterior was a genuine passion for truth â€” and a deep grief for all the knowledge that had been lost or suppressed by the Church. Task Offered: "I have a collection of pre-Usurpation texts that require cross-referencing and translation. The work is tedious but essential. If you have patience and a sharp eye, I could use assistants who won't damage the materials."

"Mirelle leads our research division," Carveth explained. "She needs help deciphering old texts â€” fragile work that requires care and attention."

Then he indicated the man to his right.

Brennan Holt Role: Recruiter, Resonance Theorists Age: Early forties Status: â˜ ï¸ Executed Appearance: A lean, weathered man in his early forties with close-cropped dark hair shot through with grey at the temples. A thin scar ran from his left eyebrow to his cheekbone â€” a souvenir, he would say, from his "previous employment." He dressed like a dockworker rather than a scholar: rough-spun clothes, sturdy boots, a coat with too many pockets. His eyes were sharp and assessing, the eyes of someone who had learned to read people the way Mirelle read texts. Personality: Charming when he needed to be, cold when the situation demanded. Brennan had lost his wife and daughter to the Inquisition twelve years ago â€” accused of heresy for asking the wrong questions about the Church's teachings. He had been recruiting for the Theorists ever since, finding others who had suffered at the Church's hands and giving them somewhere to direct their grief and rage. Task Offered: "There are people in this city who hate the Church as much as we do. Some of them just need a push â€” someone to tell them they're not alone, that there's something they can do besides suffer in silence. I could use help making contact with potential recruits. It's dangerous work, but it's how we grow."

"Brennan handles recruitment," Carveth said. "He finds those who have been wronged by the Church and offers them a place among us. Delicate work â€” one wrong contact and the Inquisition learns of our existence."

Finally, Carveth turned his attention back to himself.

"And then there is my task. The one I mentioned last night."

His voice lowered.

"The Resonant Codex. A text of immense value to our research, held in the vault of the Church of the Arterial Saint. Confiscated decades ago from scholars who were executed for heresy. It contains knowledge about pre-Sovereign resonance theory â€” knowledge that could fundamentally change our understanding of the divine memory."

He met their eyes.

"I need you to steal it."

The Choice

The party deliberated briefly. Mirelle's task was safe but slow â€” weeks of careful scholarship with no guarantee of immediate results. Brennan's task was ongoing and dangerous in a different way â€” exposure to potential informants, building relationships that could be betrayed.

Carveth's task was direct. One night. One target. High risk, but a clear objective and a clear reward.

They chose the heist.

Carveth nodded, unsurprised.

"The Church of the Arterial Saint is in the mid-district, halfway between here and the cathedral. The vault is in the lower levels â€” a secured room where the Church stores confiscated texts and artifacts. Things they deem too dangerous to destroy but too heretical to allow into circulation."

He slid a folded parchment across the table â€” a rough map of the church's layout, marked with annotations.

"Security is light at night. Most of the clergy retire after evening vespers. But there will be guards, and there may be... other measures."

Kael stepped forward. "I'll go with them. I know the church's layout â€” I've studied it for months. And I can identify the Codex when we find it."

Carveth considered this, then nodded. "Very well. Kael will accompany you." He reached into his robes and produced a small scroll case. "Take this. A scroll of Disguise Self â€” it will help you blend in if you need to move through occupied areas."

He handed it to Sol.

"Return with the Codex. Prove that our trust in you is not misplaced."

Part 2 â€” Preparing for the Heist

The Plan

Sol, Jonas, and Kael spent the next several hours planning their approach. Kael spread the map across a table in the corner of the cellar, pointing out key features.

"The Church of the Arterial Saint is mid-sized â€” larger than the parish churches in the Lesser Sacral District, but not as fortified as the cathedral. Evening vespers end around the ninth bell. After that, most of the clergy retire to their quarters in the east wing."

He traced a finger along the map.

"The vault is here â€” in the basement level, accessed through a stairway near the main altar. During the day, there are usually two guards posted at the stairway entrance. At night... maybe one. Maybe none, if we're lucky."

"And the vault itself?"

"Locked. Heavy door, iron-reinforced. But I've heard the lock is old â€” the Church relies more on the sanctity of the space than physical security. They don't expect anyone to be bold enough to rob them."

Jonas examined the map. "What about magical defenses? Alarms?"

"Resonance wards," Kael said. "The Church uses them throughout their important buildings. They're attuned to detect... wrongness. Heretical intent, you might say. If we approach with hostile purpose, they might trigger."

"How do we avoid them?"

Kael hesitated. "I'm not entirely sure. The Theorists have studied them, but we've never had a chance to test countermeasures. The scroll of Disguise Self might help â€” if we look like we belong, the wards might not recognize us as threats."

It wasn't a guarantee. But it was what they had.

Nightfall

They waited until well after dark â€” until the streets had emptied and the only light came from the arterial canals' faint red glow and the occasional lantern. The Church of the Arterial Saint rose against the night sky, its spires silhouetted against the stars, its windows dark except for a few flickering lights in the clergy quarters.

Sol used the scroll of Disguise Self, taking on the appearance of a junior priest â€” white robes with red trim, the standard uniform of Mareathan clergy. The illusion was convincing, at least in dim light.

Jonas and Kael would have to rely on stealth and shadow.

They approached from the south, where a small service entrance led into the church's lower halls. The door was locked, but the lock was simple â€” Jonas had it open in moments.

They were in.

Part 3 â€” The Infiltration

The Lower Halls

The interior of the Church of the Arterial Saint was dark and silent. The air smelled of incense and old blood â€” the familiar copper-sweet scent of Mareathan worship. Votive candles flickered in alcoves along the walls, casting just enough light to navigate by.

Sol led the way, the Disguise Self illusion making them appear to belong. Jonas and Kael followed close behind, moving from shadow to shadow.

The lower halls were a maze of storage rooms, administrative offices, and small chapels dedicated to various aspects of Mareatha's doctrine. They passed a room filled with ceremonial robes, another stacked with crates of ritual supplies, a third that appeared to be a small library of approved texts.

No guards. Not yet.

Kael guided them toward the central stairway that led down to the vault level. They moved slowly, carefully, testing each step for creaking floorboards, pausing at every corner to listen for approaching footsteps.

The church felt empty. But empty spaces in Veinspire were rarely truly empty. The walls themselves seemed to breathe with Mareatha's presence â€” a faint pulse that matched the rhythm of the arterial canals outside.

The Final Room

They reached the stairway to the vault level. A single door stood between them and the descent â€” and through that door, they could hear something.

A voice. Low, rhythmic, repetitive.

Kael pressed his ear to the wood. "Someone's in there," he whispered. "Reciting doctrine."

Sol cracked the door open, just enough to peer through.

The room beyond was a small antechamber â€” the last barrier before the vault stairs. A single figure knelt in the center of the room, facing away from the door. He wore the rough robes of a flagellant, his back crisscrossed with self-inflicted scars visible through the torn fabric. A whip lay coiled beside him.

He was reciting Mareatha's teachings in a droning monotone, the words running together into an endless stream of devotion.

And his eyes â€” what remained of them â€” were clouded white. Scarred over. Blind.

The Blind Flagellant Role: Penitent Guardian Status: â˜ ï¸ Deceased (this session) Appearance: A gaunt man of indeterminate age, his body a map of self-inflicted wounds and ritual scarification. His robes were deliberately torn to expose the lattice of scars on his back â€” evidence of years of flagellation in Mareatha's name. His eyes were ruined, clouded white with scar tissue, blinded either by accident or by choice. Despite his blindness, he moved with unsettling certainty. Nature: The blind flagellants were a sect within the Mareathan Church who believed that sight was a distraction from true devotion. They blinded themselves to prove their faith, relying on Mareatha's guidance to navigate the world. In return, they claimed, the Vein-Mother granted them other senses â€” the ability to feel heartbeats, to taste the blood in the air, to know when something wrong entered their presence.

The Failed Deception

Sol assessed the situation. The flagellant was blind â€” perhaps they could simply slip past him while he was absorbed in his recitations. The door to the vault stairs was on the far side of the room, maybe thirty feet away.

They decided to try.

Sol entered first, moving silently, their disguised form casting no shadow in the dim candlelight. Jonas followed, each footstep placed with deliberate care. Kael came last, his scholar's robes rustling slightly despite his best efforts.

They were halfway across the room when the flagellant stopped reciting.

His head turned toward them â€” not toward any one of them specifically, but toward the space they occupied. His nostrils flared. His scarred face twisted into something between confusion and recognition.

"Who's there?"

Sol froze. The disguise made them look like a priest, but it didn't change their scent. It didn't change the sound of their heartbeat. It didn't change whatever sense the flagellant used to perceive the world.

"Brother," Sol said, attempting to maintain the deception. "I am here on business from theâ€”"

"No."

The flagellant rose to his feet in a single fluid motion, his hand finding the whip beside him with unerring accuracy.

"You do not smell of the Mother's blood. Your heart beats with fear, not devotion. You are wrong."

He raised the whip.

"HERETICS IN THE SANCTUM!"

Combat â€” The Blind Flagellant

Enemy:
  • The Blind Flagellant (enhanced senses, fanatical devotion, whip specialist)
Battlefield: The antechamber before the vault stairs. Dim candlelight. Religious iconography on the walls. The door to the vault stairs on the far side.

The flagellant attacked with terrifying precision despite his blindness. His whip cracked through the air, finding flesh with uncanny accuracy. He fought like someone who had transcended the need for sight â€” every movement guided by sound, by scent, by the rhythm of his opponents' heartbeats.

Jonas engaged him directly, the cursed breastplate absorbing blows that would have staggered a lesser warrior. The flagellant's whip left welts across Jonas's arms, but Jonas pressed forward, his weapon finding the gaunt man's flesh again and again.

Sol provided support with fire magic, trying to disorient the blind man with heat and light â€” but light meant nothing to someone who couldn't see, and the flagellant barely flinched.

Kael tried to flank, but the flagellant heard him coming. The whip lashed out, catching Kael across the chest and sending him sprawling. Kael hit the ground hard and didn't get up â€” the blow had been precise, striking something vital.

"KAEL!"

Sol rushed to his side while Jonas redoubled his assault. Kael was alive but unconscious, blood seeping from a deep gash across his ribs.

The fight became desperate. The flagellant was skilled, fanatical, and seemingly tireless. But he was also alone, and Sol and Jonas had survived worse.

Jonas finally landed a decisive blow â€” his weapon catching the flagellant in the throat. The blind man staggered, his whip falling from nerveless fingers. He tried to speak, perhaps to call out again, but only blood emerged.

He collapsed.

Victory. But at a cost.

Kael Down

Sol knelt beside Kael, hands pressing against the wound on his chest. The young scholar was pale, his breathing shallow, but he was alive. The whip had cracked ribs and torn flesh, but it hadn't killed him.

"Get him up," Jonas said, keeping watch on the door they'd entered through. "They heard that. The whole church heard that. We have minutes at most."

Sol hauled Kael to his feet, supporting his weight. The scholar groaned, consciousness returning slowly.

"The Codex," Kael mumbled. "Get the Codex..."

"We will. Can you walk?"

"I... yes. I think so."

He couldn't, really. But he could stumble, and that would have to be enough.

Part 4 â€” The Vault

Descent

They rushed through the door the flagellant had been guarding, descending a narrow stairway into the church's basement level. The stairs were old stone, worn smooth by centuries of footsteps, spiraling down into darkness.

Behind them, they could hear sounds â€” doors opening, voices calling out, the organized chaos of an alarm being raised. The flagellant's final scream had done its work.

The vault was at the bottom of the stairs â€” a heavy iron door set into the stone wall. As Kael had predicted, the lock was old, more symbolic than practical. Jonas had it open in moments.

They stumbled inside and pulled the door closed behind them.

The Vault's Contents

The vault was smaller than Sol had expected â€” perhaps twenty feet square, with shelves lining every wall. But what those shelves contained...

Books. Dozens of them, hundreds perhaps, bound in leather and cloth and stranger materials. Texts confiscated from heretics, scholars, researchers â€” anyone who had dared to study the forbidden. The accumulated knowledge of generations, locked away in darkness. Artifacts. Strange devices of unknown purpose. Religious items from faiths that predated the Sovereigns. Crystals that pulsed with faint light. A jar containing something that moved. The Resonant Codex.

Kael found it almost immediately, as if drawn to it. It sat on a shelf near the back of the vault â€” a leather-bound tome of unusual weight, its cover embossed with symbols that seemed to shift when not observed directly.

"This is it," Kael breathed. He reached for it with trembling hands.

The moment his fingers touched the cover, the Codex hummed. A vibration that Sol and Jonas felt in their teeth, in their bones. The symbols on the cover flared briefly with pale light.

Then it was just a book again.

But it had responded. It had recognized Kael.

"Take it," Jonas urged. "We need to move."

Kael tucked the Codex into his satchel. They could hear footsteps on the stairs now â€” multiple sets, descending rapidly.

"Is there another way out?"

Kael's eyes darted around the vault, searching. "There â€” in the corner. A grate."

Escape Through the Tunnels

The grate covered a drainage tunnel â€” old infrastructure from when the church was first built, designed to channel water away from the basement during floods. It was narrow, dirty, and led into absolute darkness.

It was also their only option.

Jonas wrenched the grate free. Sol helped Kael into the tunnel first, then followed. Jonas came last, pulling the grate back into place behind them just as the vault door burst open.

They crawled through darkness, the tunnel barely wide enough to accommodate Jonas's shoulders. The stone was slick with moisture and something that smelled like old blood. Veinspire's infrastructure was saturated with Mareatha's essence â€” even the drainage tunnels carried her taint.

The sounds of pursuit faded behind them. Either the guards hadn't noticed the grate, or they had decided the tunnel wasn't worth following.

After what felt like hours but was probably only minutes, the tunnel opened into a larger passage â€” part of the network of maintenance tunnels that ran beneath Veinspire's streets. From there, Kael guided them through a maze of turns and intersections, his knowledge of the city's underbelly proving invaluable.

They emerged through a sewer grate in an alley three blocks from the Theorists' cellar.

They had made it.

Part 5 â€” Mission Complete

Return to the Theorists

They stumbled into the Theorists' cellar just before dawn, exhausted, bloodied, and carrying the Resonant Codex.

Carveth was waiting for them. His expression shifted from concern to relief to something like respect as Kael produced the Codex from his satchel.

"You succeeded."

"We succeeded," Sol confirmed. "But it wasn't clean. There was a guard â€” a blind flagellant. He's dead. The church knows someone broke into their vault."

Carveth nodded slowly. "They'll investigate. They'll search. But they won't find us â€” not quickly, at least. The Theorists have survived worse."

He took the Codex from Kael's hands, examining it with reverent care.

"Good work. This will help further our research."

Kael Joins the Party

Carveth made his decision.

"Kael will keep the Codex. It responds to him â€” trying to separate them might damage the text or render it unreadable again. And since you three have proven you can work together..."

He turned to Sol and Jonas.

"Kael will accompany you. He'll help you find a way out of Veinspire â€” that was our bargain. And he'll continue studying the Codex along the way. Perhaps, in time, he'll unlock secrets that have been hidden for centuries."

Kael looked at Sol and Jonas, uncertainty and hope warring in his expression.

"If you'll have me."

Sol extended a hand. "Welcome to the party."

Kael took it.

Session Conclusion

Dawn

They rested in the Theorists' cellar as dawn broke over Veinspire. Somewhere in the city, the Church of the Arterial Saint was in an uproar â€” guards searching, clergy questioning, the Inquisition undoubtedly being summoned to investigate the theft and the murdered flagellant.

But here, in this hidden space beneath a nondescript townhouse, there was a moment of peace.

Kael sat in a corner, the Resonant Codex open in his lap, his eyes scanning pages that no one else could read. The book had chosen him, and he was beginning to understand what that meant.

Sol and Jonas tended their wounds and planned their next move. They were still trapped in Veinspire. They were still under Inquisition surveillance. But now they had allies, resources, and a scholar carrying a book full of forbidden knowledge.

It was a start.
