Metal. The rhythm came from somewhere beneath the dunes. Each tick sent a tremor through their boots, the ground inhaling, exhaling, shifting by fractions. When Sol Raven pressed a hand to the sand, he felt something massive turn beneath â€” as if an engine larger than any city was trying to start.   Kael (quietly): "It's the same patte

items.title: Session 09: The Clockwork Sanctum
items.content:
Session 09: The Clockwork Sanctum

Part 1 â€” The March of Sand and Brass

Approach to the Sanctum

The path north takes form as they walk â€” dunes folding into terraces of bronze and glass, each footstep chiming like a struck bell. The desert here is no longer silent. Beneath the surface, enormous gears grind together, slow and ancient, rearranging the landscape.

The air grows denser with every mile. Gravity itself tilts; loose sand no longer falls straight down but spirals lazily around them.

Kael's Resonant Codex opens unbidden again, lines scrawling in urgent script:

"The Regent of Hours builds cathedrals inside seconds. He believes if all time can be made to kneel, the god will wake again."

Sol Raven glances up at the horizon. The towers of the Sanctum are no longer mirages. They're inverted â€” roots of metal and clockwork rising from the dunes, dangling upward into a red sky where no sun sits.

Sol Raven Asks About the Sanctum

Sol Raven slows his pace, eyes narrowing at the spires' impossible motion. The Threadblade trembles faintly, reacting to the vibration. He glances sidelong at Kael, whose Codex has been whispering for the past hour.

Sol Raven: "You're the scholar. You've been quiet too long. Tell me â€” what's waiting for us inside that thing?"

Kael doesn't answer right away. He looks up â€” eyes reflecting the distant gears. When he finally speaks, it's not his voice alone; the Codex murmurs along with him, a chorus of a hundred forgotten scholars.

Kael's Lore â€” The Sanctum and Its Ruler

"The Clockwork Sanctum isn't a kingdom. It's a calendar with delusions of godhood. The Regent built it to measure eternity in seconds â€” to prove that time itself could be owned, sold, and taxed.

Every tower you see marks a different hour of the day, but not our day â€” his. The locals call them the Thirteen Hours That Never End. The closer you get to the center, the shorter your seconds become, until one minute out here might be a lifetime in there."

"The Regent himself â€” Imhuran, the Regent of Hours â€” was once mortal, like the others who stole from the god's corpse. But he was cleverer. He didn't take flesh or faith. He took the god's pulse. The rhythm that kept the world moving. He locked it away inside the Sanctum, made it his metronome."

Kael shuts the Codex with a sharp snap.

"That's why nothing rots here, Sol. Not bodies, not sins, not even time itself."

Jonas (quietly): "And the people who live here?"

Kael gestures toward the glimmering structures near the base of the spires â€” distant lights moving in slow patterns.

"Horologers, Chronites, and the Bound. Clockwrights, once human, who replaced their hearts with miniature gears to stay in rhythm with the Regent. The rest are the Bound â€” workers frozen in partial loops, slaves trapped repeating a single task until the Regent releases them."

He pauses.

"He never does."

The Wrecked Procession

Halfway to the Sanctum, they encounter the Wrecked Procession â€” hundreds of broken constructs frozen mid-prayer, half-buried in the dunes. Brass saints, automatons, hollow-eyed pilgrims, all kneeling toward the spires.

When the wind hits them, they sing. Not words, but chimes â€” hundreds of tones forming one phrase in Clocktongue:

"The Regent forgives nothing."

Kael listens. The Codex hums.

"These things aren't dead. They're waiting."

Discovery: Clockskin Mantle

Sol Raven cuts through one, testing the metal â€” it bleeds oil that burns white flame, lighting the sand around them.

Jonas notices his brand flare in response â€” the Whispered King's mark reacting to divine machinery.

Kael jots notes feverishly, trying to record the harmonics of the song before it fades.

They find, buried under the sand between two kneeling constructs, a Clockskin Mantle â€” torn but intact.

Clockskin Mantle Armor (cloak), rare, requires attunement A shawl woven from thin strips of metallic fiber that shift like seconds. When worn, your body moves half a heartbeat out of sync.
  • Gain +1 AC
  • Once per short rest, you can delay a physical hit or effect by one round. The attack or spell "catches up" to you at the start of your next turn, dealing only half damage if you prepare a defensive action (raise shield, Dodge, etc.)

Kael: "This belonged to a priest of the Regentâ€¦ maybe his herald."

Sol Raven: "Then let's see if his god notices."

Jonas takes it, the brass fibers hissing faintly when they touch his armor.

The Gates of the Sanctum

As they draw closer, the dunes flatten into plates of bronze, engraved with circles that spin slowly under their feet. Each plate hums a distinct note â€” together forming a single deep chord that vibrates in their bones.

Kael: "The entire desert is an engine."

And he's right. The towers ahead aren't static. They turn, locked together like a crown of rotating spires around a hollow core. Inside that void: light bending backward, the faint shape of a massive heart of gears suspended midair. It beats once every few minutes, each pulse shaking the horizon.

Sol Raven: "The god's heartâ€¦ or the Regent's machine?"

Kael: "Same thing now."

The spires' rotation slows, aligning perfectly â€” opening a single corridor inward. The corridor sings, its walls lined with hundreds of golden eyes that turn and blink in sequence.

Kael: "We're being measured."

The last dune collapses behind them, sealing the exit. The sound of the ticking grows louder, deeper â€” like a heartbeat with teeth.

Part 2 â€” The First Hour: Vestibule of Waking

Entry

The doors of the Sanctum stand open. No guards, no priests, only the endless hum of machinery and faint whispers of counting.

They step inside. The air tastes metallic. Every echo repeats twice â€” once in the present, once a few seconds later.

The instant they cross the threshold, the noise dies. No wind, no ticking â€” only the slow inhale of a colossal machine.

Light inside the gate isn't steady; it rotates. Bands of gold sweep across the floor in perfect rhythm, moving with the unseen gears overhead. Every time the light passes, the group's shadows slide a half-second out of sync.

Jonas's Core thrums once, answering the pulse. Kael's Codex opens of its own accord, its pages fluttering like wings, ink pooling into new text:

"You have entered the First Hour â€” The Vestibule of Waking."

The Vestibule

The corridor is circular, walls formed of hundreds of interlocking plates engraved with dates. Each step the party takes resets some of those numbers â€” the years behind them vanish, the ones ahead flicker into being.

At the far end stands a dais of blackened brass and a massive pendulum suspended above it, swinging through liquid light. Beneath the pendulum, a figure kneels: neither statue nor man.

Its body is a framework of bones wrapped in parchment skin etched with equations. In its chest, where a heart should be, a spinning orb of crystal ticks with impossible precision.

Kael (whispering): "A Chronite Sentinel. They record the hours of the living."

He glances at the others.

"If it's still functioning, it already knows our names."

The figure's head turns mechanically. Its voice is two overlapping tones: one now, one a heartbeat later.

Chronite Sentinel: "New entries detected. Uncatalogued souls. Please state duration of existence for record."

The Toll of Ages

To enter further, they must answer honestly or face consequences.

They answered honestly.

Jonas: "Thirty-two winters."

Kael: "Thirty-one."

Sol Raven: "I've stopped counting."

For a moment nothing happens. Then â€” light.

Golden script blooms across the walls like veins, connecting each of their shadows to a shifting calendar etched into the metal. The pendulum stills mid-arc, and the Sentinel's twin voices merge into one:

Chronite Sentinel: "Acknowledged. Three mortal durations confirmed. Equal seconds deposited in trust. Balance recorded."

A faint shimmer ripples through the room. Each of them feels it: a tiny subtraction, a single moment torn away â€” no pain, just the faint dizziness of losing a second you didn't know you had.

The Codex hums softly in Kael's hands; across one of its open pages, new ink writes itself:

"One minute owed by the Sanctum. Redeemable in moments of peril."

Jonas's Core glows faintly in response, as if recognizing the transaction. Sol Raven flexes his fingers â€” time itself feels marginally heavier around his hands, his movements leaving a faint afterimage in the air.

Reward: A Minute in Trust

Each character gains one stored "Sanctum Second."

At any future point, a player may invoke it to cancel a failed save or missed attack by re-living the previous instant.

It cannot be hoarded; once used, the favor is gone. When expended, every clock or watch within sight skips forward one tick.

The Sentinel lowers its head in what might be a bow, parchment skin tightening over its face.

Chronite Sentinel: "Proceed to the Second Hour. Time welcomes those who pay their due."

Behind it, part of the wall irises open, revealing a narrow stairway spiraling upward into a column of soft amber light.

Part 3 â€” The Second Hour: Hall of Penitence

The Stair of Seconds

As they ascend, the corridor narrows. Gears move behind glass walls, each one stamped with dates that change as they watch: years spinning backward, months vanishing.

Kael runs a finger along the etched brass railing.

"This stair doesn't lead upward. It leads inward â€” through hours, not floors."

The higher they climb, the heavier the air grows. Every step feels measured. The hum of the Sanctum presses against their ribs like a second pulse.

At last the stair opens into a vast chamber:

The Hall of Penitence

Imagine a cathedral, but the pews are people frozen mid-motion â€” scholars, clockwrights, merchants â€” each caught in the act of speaking, writing, or praying. Hundreds of them, perfectly still, eyes open and glistening. Threads of light connect their foreheads to a great orb suspended in the ceiling: the Hourglass Engine.

The orb turns slowly, the upper half filled with sand that refuses to fall. When the party steps forward, the air distorts, and for a heartbeat they hear whispers â€” hundreds of overlapping thoughts trapped in pause.

Kael (softly): "The Regent's archives. These are his citizens. He keeps their time on deposit."

Jonas: "Prisoners."

Sol Raven: "Witnesses."

As they walk between the frozen figures, tiny motes of dust drift like fireflies. Every so often, one of the statues blinks.

Something isn't entirely frozen.

Sol Raven Investigates

Sol Raven approaches the altar, studying the mechanism with precision rather than piety.

His eyes trace the web of gears hidden beneath the surface, watching the energy transfer through brass filaments into the chained penitents.

He sees it: the entire mechanism runs backward. Every tick of the metronomes feeds energy into the penitents, keeping them alive by reversing their deaths an instant at a time.

Sol Raven (quietly): "They're not victims. They're batteries."

He adjusts one filament carefully, cutting off the loop for a single penitent. The figure exhales once and turns to dust, its remaining seconds spilling as faint light across Sol's hand.

Reward: The Clockmaker's Touch

Once per short rest, Sol may choose to learn the exact HP or remaining lifespan of a creature within 30 ft.

Every use makes the Threadblade whisper the dying words of the last creature he examined.

The Codex vibrates violently in Kael's satchel.

Kael: "You just rewrote someone's time. The Sanctum will notice."

The chamber stays stable but colder; the ticking grows faint â€” less alive.

The Hour Itself Manifests

The air around the altar changes pitch â€” a sound like metal stretching. One of the figures â€” the man Sol touched â€” exhales sharply. He moves.

His head jerks, and with it, the other statues begin to vibrate. All their mouths open together, expelling a single line of whispered sound:

"Your seconds are not yours."

The silver threads ignite, light racing up toward the Hourglass Engine. Sand that hadn't been falling now pours upward in a brilliant column.

A sphere of molten gold rises into the air â€” pulsing like a newborn sun. It doesn't attack. It watches.

The voice speaks from within â€” not aloud, but in rhythm, every syllable punctuated by a faint tick:

The Hour: "You took one of mine. What will you pay for the second?"

Sol Raven's Choice

Sol has drawn the attention of the Hour Itself â€” an echo of the Regent's will. The clock doesn't want blood; it wants equilibrium. He must decide what kind of trade he'll make for the life he stole.

Sol offered Memory â€” sacrificed a fragment of his past.

He surrenders a memory of significance (the first moment of clarity after waking as bones â€” the instant he understood he was alive, and alone). The Hour purrs in satisfaction.

The sphere drifts closer to Sol, its surface rippling like oil. A faint pulse of light touches him, and he feels something invisible take a bite out of his timeline and seal the wound.

The Hour: "Measured restraintâ€¦ recorded."

The sigil's light dims from glaring gold to a steady, slow pulse. The altar cools. Each remaining penitent bows deeply â€” in gratitude or recognition, impossible to tell.

A slow creak runs through the floor; new gears unfold from the walls, forming the path to the Third Hour.

Part 4 â€” The Third Hour: Hall of Patience

The Chamber of Still Gears

The passage opens into a circular chamber â€” an inverted clock-tower built from still metal and black glass. Thousands of suspended pendulums hang unmoving from the ceiling, their tips glinting with frozen droplets of mercury. The air trembles faintly with potential, like a note held forever before release.

At the center stands a dais of dull gold. Above it, an immense hourglass floats â€” both ends sealed. Inside, the sand doesn't fall; it hangs mid-air, a frozen storm.

Around the base of the dais are six robed figures kneeling motionless, hands clasped over empty hourglasses. Their faces are calm. Each wears a crown of small bronze thorns.

Kael looks around slowly, mouthing a single word none can hear:

Patience.

The Stillness Test

A sigil flickers faintly on the floor, forming concentric rings around the dais. When Sol Raven steps forward, the sigil lights under his boot â€” and stops him. A wall of invisible resistance meets his chest, solid as glass.

Kael mouths, "Temporal barrier." He gestures to the kneeling figures, then to their hourglasses. He points to Sol, then draws a line in the air: wait.

They understand â€” for the barrier to open, the hour must pass through stillness. Any movement, any impatience, any sound could trigger the chamber's defense.

Jonas Twitches

The test lasts three rounds of in-world time. Any player who speaks aloud, casts a spell with verbal components, or acts rashly triggers a pendulum drop.

Jonas twitched. Barely â€” a hand flex.

The room notices.

A single pendulum drops, striking the floor silently. When it rises again, the six kneeling figures lift their heads.

Their eyes glow faint amber. Each mouth opens in perfect synchronization.

"Patience rewards the worthy."

Their voices emerge in unison, breaking the silence like cracking ice.

The sigil on the floor flares bright white.

Combat: The Waiting Ones

The party faced six constructs â€” temporal servitors of the Regent, robed figures with brass palms and linked hourglasses. They fought in eerie silence, their patience aura slowing movement, their strikes carrying temporal restraint.

Victory

The party defeated the Waiting Ones.

The final pendulum shatters in silence. Time exhales. Golden dust drifts in the still air, glowing faintly in the dim brass light.

Shards of mirrored brass drift downward like snow, glowing faintly before dissolving into motes of light that cling to the heroes' armor and skin. Each mote vibrates once â€” a small, grateful heartbeat â€” then vanishes.

Kael presses a trembling hand to the Codex; the pages hum softly, writing on their own:

"Patience repaid. The Third Hour records restraint made flesh."

Part 5 â€” The Fourth Hour: Chamber of Judgment

The Antechamber

The door to the Third Hour yawns open â€” gears folding away, revealing a stairwell that descends into dim brass light. A sound like thousands of tiny heartbeats builds from below.

As they descend, the corridor widens into a circular gallery where marble and brass fuse seamlessly. Every wall is lined with portraits â€” not paintings, but hollow silhouettes of people outlined in gold wire. Inside each frame, gears turn slowly where faces should be.

A single beam of light from above strikes a massive dais in the center. On it, thirteen symbols are carved â€” one for each King and Queen. The ones they have confronted flicker faintly.

At the far side of the room stands a figure that is almost human, draped in parchment robes. Its skin is translucent; ink runs through its veins instead of blood.

"You carry what they left behind. The fragments hunger, but they are not yours. Prove you can bear them without becoming what they were."

The Judgment Begins

The Regent's tone drops to a whisper that vibrates the floor:

"Judgment is never shared. Each shall be weighed in the scale befitting their trespass."

Before anyone can respond, the brass floor opens like petals on a mechanical flower. The three of them are pulled apart by gravity that doesn't obey distance.

They fall in three directions at once.

Kael â€” The Scales of Intention

Kael lands on a narrow platform suspended over a void of turning gears. A titanic balance scale stands before him â€” one pan filled with shards of light, the other with shadows shaped like people.

His own voice whispers from the void:

"You record everything. But what did you ever carry?"

The echo asks three questions:

  1. "What is knowledge without pain?"
  2. "What is memory without guilt?"
  3. "Why do you record what you cannot forgive?"
Result: Kael succeeded on two of three checks. The scales settle. The Codex gains a new header: "Truth Before Mercy."

Sol Raven â€” The Witness of Reflection

Sol Raven emerges inside a vast courtroom of mirrors. Each mirror bears a different version of him â€” older, younger, dead, triumphant, monstrous. At the far end stands a judge's chair â€” empty. He realizes with a slow chill: the judge is whichever reflection survives longest.

Three reflections step forward to argue his truth:

  1. The Martyr â€” who believes every sacrifice is worth it.
  2. The Tyrant â€” who insists control is mercy.
  3. The Shadow â€” who whispers that he never saved anyone; he only wanted to prove he could.
Result: Sol Raven failed.

The gavel falls. The impact sends a wave of glass-light through the chamber. Sol Raven's body remains intact â€” but his reflection shatters into countless fragments that hang in the air, frozen mid-scream.

Each fragment catches a memory: the first life he ever saved, the first he let die.

Then they dissolve into dust. The mirrors fade to black, leaving only one surface behind: a single, smooth, featureless pane of brass. It reflects nothing.

Consequence: Until the party leaves the Clockwork Sanctum, Sol Raven's presence flickers. Attack rolls against him have disadvantage (he is difficult to track in time), but he cannot make Charisma checks or be the target of healing magic.

One mirror fragment embeds in his palm, cold and weightless. Once per long rest, he can crush it to automatically succeed on a Wisdom saving throw. When he does, the shard melts and vanishes permanently.

Jonas â€” The Sentence of Flesh

Jonas lands hard, knee-deep in brass sand. Dozens of broken weapons jut from the ground â€” hammers, swords, halberds. They pulse faintly, as though full of blood.

Before him stands a towering golem of iron and bone â€” his own shadow carved into machine form, carrying a perfect copy of his hammer.

"Judgment is not law. It's rhythm. You missed the beat."

Combat Trial: The Mirror-Sentenced must be matched in rhythm. Jonas must make three consecutive successful attacks or Strength saves without missing once. Result: Jonas succeeded. The golem pauses, kneels, and dissolves.

Jonas's hammer stabilizes â€” the echo lag disappears for the first time. He gains +1 to Initiative permanently.

Reunion

The three paths reconverge. The chamber reforms into the original Clockwork Hall, but darker, slower â€” as though time itself now walks carefully around them.

The Regent's voice returns, measured, calm:

"Three paths taken. Three verdicts recorded. The clock continues."

A great staircase unfolds above, leading into a vertical shaft of dim gold â€” the path to the Fifth Hour.

Part 6 â€” The Fifth Hour: Equilibrium

The Chamber of Balance

The stair opens into a circular gallery where everything tilts. Half of it drifts downward like a bowl sinking into the earth, while the upper half hangs suspended by chains that vanish into the darkness above. Everything inside moves with an almost invisible rhythm â€” slow, precise oscillations, as though the room is breathing.

At the chamber's center floats a massive gyroscope of brass and bone. Each ring turns counter to the next, connected by thin streams of light. Inside its core hovers a shard of frozen time â€” the Heart of Balance.

The Regent's tone drops:

"The measure has been made. Now prove you can carry it."

Maintaining the Balance

The gyroscope begins to rotate faster, emitting a deep harmonic tone. Three narrow platforms extend from the outer wall to its core, each vibrating differently.

"Kael â€” your truth is heavier than your faith.

Sol Raven â€” your form outweighs your presence.

Jonas â€” your strike disturbs still seconds.

Balance them. Or be unmade."

Each round, the gyroscope tilts violently. Every character must act to keep equilibrium through skill checks.

The party held steady for three rounds without collapse. The gyroscope calms and the frozen shard descends. A faint pulse of light touches each of them, synchronizing their rhythms â€” heartbeats for Jonas and Kael, the divine hum of Aedwynn's shard for Sol.

The shard speaks in the Regent's voice â€” quieter, intimate, almost human:

"Balance is not peace. It is endurance. Take, and remember."

Accepting Balance

Each character chose to absorb their portion of equilibrium:

  • Kael: The Codex stabilizes â€” no longer reactive, but now heavy. +2 to concentration saves.
  • Jonas: His hammer loses its echo entirely â€” strikes become perfectly timed. Gain +1 to hit permanently, but a missed attack costs 2 HP (the punishment for imbalance).
  • Sol Raven: The fragment anchors him back into time. He regains solidity, can now receive healing again, but loses his "Partially Unseen" defensive benefit.

Aftermath

The gyroscope collapses gently into the floor, dissolving into dust. The brass and bone melt away, revealing the next stairway â€” a spiral rising into blinding light.

"Five measures taken. Five debts rebalanced. The next heart will not forgive hesitation."

Part 7 â€” The Sixth Hour: Inheritance

The Archive of Ascension

The stair opens into a throne hall, but the throne itself is a vacant mechanism â€” a lattice of gears spinning around an empty seat of light.

Hundreds of suspended hourglasses float in concentric rings above, each slowly turning, spilling sand upward instead of down. Every grain glows with a pulse â€” lives, souls, seconds â€” feeding the unseen heart of the Regent.

At the base of the throne, three pedestals rise from the floor, each carved with personal sigils matching the party.

"The divine heart bled into thirteen thieves. You trespass within its wound. Therefore, take what was stolen, and see if it devours you."

Light bursts from the throne. Three divine fragments manifest midair, each seeking its host.

The Fragments of Inheritance

Fragment Seeks Form Effect
Fragment of Breath Sol Raven A spectral lung of glass and steam Fuses to his chest; once per short rest, as a Reaction, impose disadvantage on a single attack or save within 30 ft.
Fragment of Vein Kael A strand of crimson filament Threads through the Codex; sense any divine energy in 120-ft radius. Each use inflicts 1d4 psychic damage.
Fragment of Pulse Jonas A shard of bone-and-metal heart Merges with his hammer; attacks deal half damage again 1 round later (Living Echo). Criticals audible across 300 ft.

Overload

The fragments rebel. They weren't meant to coexist â€” nor to be wielded by mortals. Each must control their piece before it consumes them.

Each character makes a saving throw to resist the fragment's first surge:

The throne's light dims. The chamber approves.

Echo Seraphs

The Regent doesn't appear. Instead, he projects memory guardians â€” seraphs of light, each resembling a distorted version of one party member, carrying their chosen fragment twisted against them.

  • AC 18 | HP 84 | Speed 30 ft (fly)
  • Immune: Psychic, poison
  • Resist: Nonmagical damage
  • Multiattack: 2 Ã— Radiant Blade (+8 to hit, 2d10 radiant)
  • Reflective Inheritance: Damage dealt by their "owner" is halved; by others, doubled.
  • Temporal Flux (Recharge 5â€“6): Rewinds one failed save or miss, forcing a re-roll.
Result: The party defeated the Seraphs through combined effort.

Resolution

When the last Seraph falls, the throne dims. The fragments settle, quiet â€” obedient, for now. The throne's empty light finally speaks directly:

"Inheritance accepted. Power borrowed. Record incomplete."

Then, softer:

"There are no heirs to a dead god. Only thieves who learned to count."

The light extinguishes. The chamber opens its far wall, gears retracting like eyelids revealing a dark corridor beyond.

Part 8 â€” The Seventh Hour: Hunger of Inheritance

The Chamber of Maws

The corridor opens into a cathedral-sized cavity made from interlocking brass ribs and living sinew. Every rib drips with molten sand that congeals into amber teeth. A slow wind moves through the halls â€” warm, rhythmic, like breath through iron lungs.

Smells: ozone, hot copper, something sweet and rotting. Sound: a low bass note, the "stomach" of the god still digesting divinity.

Notable Features

The Flesh Forge (north wall): A half-submerged forge pit filled with pulsing metal organs; tools of bone and bronze hang nearby. The Vein Library (east alcove): Rows of glass veins filled with drifting memories â€” echoes of other inheritors. The Feeding Pit (south trench): A chasm lined with teeth that grind but never close. A faint heartbeat echoes within. The Rusted Choir (west gallery): Dozens of clockwork skulls mounted to the wall, singing backwards in time.
  • Inside: Hourglass of Unspent Moments (once, as a reaction, negate a single hit â€” the attack "never happened").

Jonas Smashes a Skull

Jonas steps forward without thinking. The echoing clang of his hammer against glass rings through the chamber.

The skull doesn't shatter â€” it collapses inward, like a lung exhaling centuries at once. The air ripples; color drains from the room.

A wave of pale dust bursts outward. In that stillness, a shape crawls out of the crater.

The Regent's voice: "Record compromised. Sentence amended. Let hunger learn."

Combat: Choir Wards

Choir Wards (Ã—3) â€” Use Wight stats, radiant instead of necrotic.

Special: Any spoken word within 20 ft heals them 2 HP. Casting a spell with verbal components deals 1 HP feedback damage to the caster per level of the spell. Silencing magic or keeping still gives advantage on attacks against them.

Result: The party destroyed the Wards.

Feeding the Fragments

The fragments start whispering:

"Feed me the forge." "Feed me the choir." "Feed me your seconds."

Each fragment accepts Blood, Time, or Memory:

  • Blood: Spill HP equal to level Ã— 2 into the Feeding Pit. Gain +1 to attack or save of choice until end of next Hour.
  • Time: Pour a spell slot or resource into the Forge. Gain resistance to radiant for 1 Hour.
  • Memory: Place a personal item into the Library vein â€” erased forever. Fragment evolves with minor upgrade later.

The party made their offerings. The ribs unlatch, revealing a narrow causeway leading upward through a column of singing sand.

The Temporal Short Rest

The chamber allows a unique rest â€” time behaves sluggishly but kindly here.

The party takes a temporal short rest. They regain features normally. Because of residual divine energy, each spent Hit Die heals an extra +3 HP.

Session Conclusion

The Weight of Hours

Seven Hours endured. Seven tests measured. The party has walked through the first half of the Regent's domain and emerged changed â€” carrying fragments of stolen divinity, bearing scars both visible and temporal.

Sol Raven traded memories for power over seconds. His reflection no longer follows him; time bends slightly around his presence.

Jonas's hammer now beats with a living echo, and his rashness with the Choir has been recorded. The Regent is watching him specifically.

Kael's Codex has grown heavier with truth, stabilized but hungry. It speaks only to him â€” and now the Sanctum knows why.

Ahead, the final six Hours await: Hunger, Echoes, Debt, Inheritance's Trial, Remembrance, and the Regent's Heart itself.

Features Gained

Character Feature Effect
Sol Raven Clockmaker's Touch Learn creature's HP/lifespan
Sol Raven Reflex of Still Gears Act first when would act last
Jonas +1 Initiative Permanent from Sentence trial
Jonas Living Echo Attacks deal half damage again next round
Kael Augury (ritual) Page stains black; whispers late
Kael Truth Before Mercy Codex header unlocked

items.title: Session 10: The Heart of the Clock
items.content:
Session 10: The Heart of the Clock

Part 1 â€” The Eighth Hour: Echoes of the Thief

The Descent

The party ascends from the Chamber of Maws through a corridor of cracked glass. The walls show replayed murders of the dead god â€” each frame stuttering as blades rise, organs burn, the same second devouring itself.

The Regent's voice crawls through the air, metallic and slow:

"Thirteen stole divinity. Thirteen hid their crimes beneath holiness. One more sin remained unmeasured â€” until now."

The Chamber of Reflection

The corridor widens into a round arena of mirrors and rusted cages. Inside one cage, motionless but unmistakably alive, crouches a Lionen.

Fur matted, eyes wide open, muscles twitching as though time itself forgot to finish the last second of his punishment.

Brass scripture circles the cage floor:

FURSEN OF THE FIELDS â€” BLASPHEMY OF FORM, COMPASSION UNBOUND.

The words pulse faintly, echoing the same rhythm as the party's fragments.

Fursen's Release

A pulse runs through the floor â€” the Regent's permission.

The lock opens. Fursen collapses forward, coughing, claws scraping the brass. He is stripped bare â€” no armor, no dignity, only the scars of eternal punishment marking his skin.

He looks up â€” disoriented, ashamed, but conscious.

"You shouldn't have done that. The Regent kept me because I blurred what was born apart."

He studies Sol Raven's still form.

"Seems He's collecting blurs again."

The Regent Speaks

"The past repeats through those who forget its measure. Let the Beast Walk Among You. See if hunger learns compassion."

His brands fade to dull scars; the cage melts into the floor.

Fursen rejoins the party as a Level 6 Open Hand Monk (Lionen).
  • Echo of Compassion. Once per short rest, redirect 1d10 damage from another creature to himself.
  • Temporal Displacement. Gains +1 AC for one round after using Patient Defense.
  • Brand of Nature's Breach. In any trial concerning creation, purity, or control, the Regent's gaze focuses on him first.

The Four Mirrors

Four mirrors flicker alive:

  1. North â€” The First Theft: A King with a sword of sunstone cutting open the god's ribs.
  2. East â€” The Second Betrayal: Beasts kneeling before mortals, eyes weeping molten gold.
  3. South â€” The Regent's Silence: Imhuran watching, clock-heart still.
  4. West â€” The Unwritten: An empty pane reflecting the party.

Each mirror hums, waiting for a choice. Whichever the party touches will determine which echo of the god's murder manifests.

The North Mirror â€” The First Theft

The party chose the northern mirror. It burned brightest â€” gold running like molten blood through its cracks.

The floor melts into light. They are pulled inside the mirror â€” into a battlefield that isn't a place but a moment stretched thin: a vast carcass of a god lying open to a crimson sky, thirteen mortals in tattered armor carving it apart for power.

At the center stands the First Thief â€” a pale figure crowned in thorns of sunlight, holding a heart that still beats.

"We take because He would not share. A god that denies hunger deserves to be eaten."

The echo turns and looks directly at the party.

Combat: Echo of the First Thief

  • AC 17 | HP 120 | Speed 30 ft
  • Use Gladiator stats; radiant instead of piercing, add 30 temporary HP
  • Rewind (1/round): If it misses, rewinds and repeats the strike instantly
Result: The party defeated the Echo.

The sky inverts â€” red becomes gold, the god's body exhales. They stand again before the mirror; it is cracked and empty, light leaking from the fissures like blood.

"One thief remembered. Twelve remain. What you kill, you inherit."

XP: 900 each

The East Mirror â€” The Thief of Veins

The sigil crawls across the ceiling and brands itself into the eastern mirror â€” the one that showed beasts kneeling before men. Its surface begins to boil.

The pull of the room drags them toward that mirror. Fursen's shadow elongates first â€” the mirror recognizes him before the others.

Fursen (quietly): "I remember this one. The King of Veins called me 'brother.'"

Inside the Vein

They land on a platform of white stone suspended in a vast red ocean. Veins as thick as pillars coil up and down like cathedral supports. At their intersections, beasts kneel â€” lions, stags, hounds â€” all with human faces, whispering praises that sound like prayers choked on guilt.

At the platform's center stands a tall figure in a blood-red robe, a crown of thorned arteries coiled around his head.

"I made them obedient so they would not suffer. The Regent calls that sin; I call it mercy."

He turns, face half-covered by golden filigree: The Thief of Veins, one of the original thirteen.

Combat: Echo of the Thief of Veins

  • Use Vampire Spawn base; replace necrotic with radiant
  • Merciful Grip. When dealing damage, heals 5 HP and whispers: "I take it so you don't have to."
  • Crimson Sanctuary (Recharge 5â€“6): 20-ft radius of suspended blood grants total cover against ranged attacks; Speed halved, no reactions inside.
Player Options: Result: The party defeated the Echo.

The Thief falls to his knees, golden blood pouring from the crown of veins. He looks up at Fursen:

"We only wanted to love what we made."

The creatures around the platform die quietly â€” released or damned, impossible to say.

"Second sin recorded. Compassion twisted into rule. You walk with his hunger now."

Fursen's Reward: His brand flickers. He chooses to keep it â€” gains one additional use of Patient Defense per long rest. Loot: A glass vein-fragment â€” can absorb a healing spell and store it for later use. XP: 900 each

The South Mirror â€” The Regent's Silence

The southern mirror doesn't ripple or melt like the others. It opens silently â€” a hairline fracture of light splitting the air. No sound, no pull â€” only stillness so complete it hurts the ears.

When the party steps forward, sound stops existing.

They stand in a vast void of white light broken only by floating clock-hands â€” enormous, rusted things orbiting like planets. At their center is a throne of glass, and upon it sits a shape identical to every one of them.

Each reflection moves a heartbeat out of sync. Each one mouths their words before they think them.

The Test of Silence

The trial here is not combat but restraint. Every word, thought, or violent act breaks the Regent's quiet â€” spawning a Temporal Double of the speaker.

Mechanics:
  • The test lasts 3 rounds.
  • Any player who speaks aloud, casts a verbal spell, or attacks first spawns a Double (use Shadow stats with PC's attack bonus and half their HP).

At the end of each round, each character may attempt:

Result: Two characters maintained Stability for all three rounds.

The throne's occupant turns. It is not Imhuran. It is a reflection of the dead god, stitched from all thirteen stolen organs. Its eyes are empty clocks.

"You silence the thief's echo. You hear only yourself. Good."

The mirrors collapse inward. Sound returns.

Transition

"Three thieves remembered. Ten still sleep. Their debt waits."

The room splits open, revealing a long stairway spiraling downward. Brass chains fall like rain, clinking with faint whispers of prayer.

At its end is darkness faintly pulsing with red â€” Hour Nine: The Debt of Blood.

Part 2 â€” The Ninth Hour: The Debt of Blood

The Vascular Cathedral

The spiral stairs open into a canyon of scarlet fog. Below, rivers of liquid seconds run through channels carved in bone. Every droplet glows faintly with a number; when you blink, the numbers change.

This is not just an altar â€” it's a city of debt, still functioning long after the god died.

Notable Landmarks

The Hall of Balances: A colonnade of hanging scales, each holding a sleeping figure made of red glass. The Counting Pool: A circular basin of mercury blood filled with floating coins. The Archivist's Spire: A crooked tower of scrolls made from veins.
  • Loot: "Page of Null Ink" â€” write on it and the written memory ceases to exist; gain advantage on next saving throw.
The Blood-Market Ruins: Stalls of petrified flesh, once a place of trade.
  • Beneath a collapsed stall, Jonas finds a Debt-Breaker's Token â€” as a reaction once, nullify any compelled oath or geas targeting him.

Sol Raven's Trade

Sol Raven approaches the Archivist's Spire.

The Archivist greets him without eyes, its skull hollowed and filled with fluttering scrolls that whisper as they slide past one another.

"A page for a page, sorcerer. The living remember; the dead record. What will you erase, that I may teach?"

Sol Raven extends his hand. A memory bleeds out of him like vapor.

The Trade

Offered Memory: The Maker's whisper of what flesh once meant â€” Aedwynn's own memory of warmth, hunger, and pulse, inherited when the shard took root in Sol's bones.

He surrenders something he never lived but always carried â€” the god's echo of embodiment. The knowledge of what it felt like to be whole. To him, existence becomes only continuity without context; he understands bodies mechanically now, clinically, without the phantom warmth that once lingered in his marrow.

"The god's memory buys a name reborn. Hear then, the tale of the Hollow Empress."

Lore Gained: Vor'Kael, the Hollow Empress

  • Once a Queen of the Thirteen, her domain was The Devoured Courts â€” the organ of the Stomach, the divine engine of consumption and meaning.
  • When she carved the god's digestive engine from its body, she filled it with her own subjects' souls so her hunger would always be fed.
  • Her appetite became power; her consumption erased meanings that existed only to sustain her will.
  • The Regent called her Kael's Echo, for she sought understanding over mercy and consumed worlds to fill her emptiness.
  • When the Thirteen turned on each other, Vor'Kael devoured her own realm into nothing â€” consuming every creature who had ever known her so no one could remember her defeat.
  • Her corpse became a hollow planet, still spinning, still echoing with hunger that can never be satisfied.

Mechanical Results

Loss:
  • Sol Raven loses the Maker's inherited understanding of embodiment.
  • Roleplay effect: He no longer has even secondhand knowledge of what flesh feels like. Bodies are mechanisms to him now â€” observed, not understood.
  • Mechanical effect: Cannot benefit from Hero's Feast, Inspire Courage, or any effect that relies on warmth, taste, or bodily euphoria. His connection to living creatures becomes more clinical.
Gain:
  • Blank Breath of Vor'Kael (Artifact Page): 1/day, speak a single word while holding the page. That word, and any memory or record of it, ceases to exist for 1 minute.
  • Lore Unlocked: Vor'Kael, the Hollow Empress â€” new research thread.
XP: 300 (exchange bonus)

The Cathedral of Ledgers

Across the bridge lies a cathedral made of ribs, each rib carved with names â€” millions of them, tiny script cut by hands that could only have been divine.

At the far end stands an altar made from a massive iron book. Its pages drip blood, and every droplet that lands on the floor forms a coin before melting away.

This is the Ledger of Borrowed Time.

"What was taken must return. Speak your names. Pay your hours."

Paying the Debt

Each character must offer something the Sanctum deems valuable.

Offering Check Result

The party made their offerings. The altar closes. The blood hardens into crystal veins that lead deeper down.

"Debt acknowledged. Interest pending."

Part 3 â€” The Tenth Hour: The Inheritor's Trial

The Gallery of Inheritors

The lift opens into a circular gallery where marble and brass fuse seamlessly. Every wall is lined with portraits â€” hollow silhouettes of people outlined in gold wire. Inside each frame, gears turn slowly where faces should be.

A single beam of light from above strikes a massive dais in the center. On it, thirteen symbols are carved â€” one for each King and Queen.

The parchment figure from before returns:

"You carry what they left behind. Prove you can bear them without becoming what they were."

The Fragments Manifest

Each fragment lifts from its host and floats in the air, casting pale light. Three inheritor echoes step from the shadows â€” each representing the fragment's former owner.

Echo Resembles Challenge
Echo of Breath Silver-skinned swordsman of frozen mist Tests control: mirrors Sol Raven's every move; he must strike without using his power.
Echo of Vein Scholar in blood-red robes, body humming like a tuning fork Tests truth: Kael must answer its questions about knowledge.
Echo of Pulse Giant in broken armor, hammer that beats like a heart Tests intent: Jonas must decide whether to destroy or restore it.

Fursen's fragment of mercy flares dimly, sensing a trial not yet called.

Sol Raven â€” Echo of Breath

Result: Success on both. The Echo freezes mid-motion and bows. Reward: The Clockmaker's Lament â€” once per day, choose to delay a single hostile action for 1 round.

Kael â€” Echo of Vein

The echo asks three questions:

  1. "What is knowledge without pain?"
  2. "What is memory without guilt?"
  3. "Why do you record what you cannot forgive?"
Result: Two of three succeeded. Reward: The Codex gains a new header: "Truth Before Mercy."

Jonas â€” Echo of Pulse

The echo kneels, weapon laid before him.

"You beat in rhythm with the heart you broke. What will you build from it?"

Options:

  • Walk away â€” Neutral; no reward, no risk.
Result: Jonas lifted it up. Reward: Heartbound Resolve â€” once per day, reroll a failed save vs. fear or charm.

Resolution

When the last Echo fades, the parchment figure steps forward. It touches each in turn; the fragments return to their bodies, lighter, less hungry.

"Inheritance accepted. Four hours remain before the clock stops. The Kings stir in their tombs."

XP: 1,200 each

Part 4 â€” The Eleventh Hour: The Choir of Remembrance

The Choir

The lift shudders as it climbs into darkness. Then sound returns â€” faint, distant, and human.

A choir sings. At first it's beautiful, then familiar, then unbearable. Every note is a name. Every verse is a death.

When the platform stops, they stand at the threshold of a cathedral built from vocal cords â€” a hundred layered balconies where translucent figures sing their own obituaries.

Some are faces they know: Sister Marwen, the Waiting Ones, the Choir Guardians, even the Echo Collector. All turn as they enter.

"Mortals that disturb my song must now hear it entire. Memory must feed the clock."

The Trial Begins

The Regent's tone drops:

"The writer will now be written."

Kael's Resonant Codex floats from his grasp, pages turning so fast they become wings of light. The letters crawl off the parchment and spiral through the air like fireflies forming a man's shape â€” Kael's Echo.

Kael's Echo: "You never wrote the truth. You only delayed it."

Combat: Kael's Echo

Kael's Echo
  • AC 17 | HP 90
  • Resist: force, psychic
  • Predicted Action: At the start of each of Kael's turns, the Echo performs his next declared action simultaneously.
  • Attack +8 (2d10 force)
  • Rewrite (Reaction): When reduced to 0 HP, writes a new version of the scene unless Kael accepts the entry.

Kael's Choice â€” Defiance

At 0 HP, the Echo drops its quill:

"The Codex ends where the writer forgets himself. Choose."

Kael chose Defiance â€” he tore the page out.

Golden light erupts across the cathedral. The Choir stutters. Their song fractures into a thousand unfinished syllables. The bone balconies shatter and rise, spinning in reverse.

Reality itself hesitates.

"You cannot erase what has already been written."

Kael's reply:

"Then I'll write something else."

The torn page disintegrates in his hand. For an instant the Codex and Kael both vanish â€” only a blast of raw time remains.

Consequences of Defiance

  • Time-Quake: Each creature in the Hour takes 8d10 force damage as seconds implode and re-expand.
  • Codex Fracture: The book now exists in two halves: Kael's Codex (his physical copy) and The Record of Remembrance (embedded in the Sanctum). Both constantly try to overwrite each other.
  • Echo Feedback: One of the golden Choir figures reforms into a distorted silhouette of Kael: the Half-Written One. It will appear again in Hour XIII.

Stabilization Phase

The party spends ten minutes in the ruins of the Choir:

Part 5 â€” The Twelfth Hour: The Vault of Regret

The Vault

Rows of suspended time-caskets drift in slow orbit, each holding a frozen figure. They are not the dead â€” they are what each of you could have become.

At the center, a circular dais of mirrored stone bears thirteen hourglasses, all cracked. Golden sand drips upward, forming constellations on the ceiling.

"Twelve hours endured. The debt of mercy remains unpaid. What will you undo to make it right?"

Jonas Attacks a Casket

Jonas steps forward without thinking. His hammer slams into the nearest time-casket.

The surface doesn't shatter â€” it collapses inward, like a lung exhaling centuries at once.

A wave of pale dust bursts outward. In that stillness, a shape crawls out of the crater â€” tall, armored like Jonas, but reversed. Metal where skin should be, veins of molten light pulsing beneath.

Its face is his own, younger, proud â€” the version that still believed war would make him a hero.

"You shouldn't have stopped me. You shouldn't have lived."

Combat: Jonas's Regret

Temporal Shade (Jonas's Regret)
  • AC 17 | HP 78 | Speed 30 ft
  • Resist: force, necrotic, nonmagical weapons
  • Vulnerable: radiant
  • Immune: poison, charm, frightened
  • Multiattack: 2 Ã— Echo Hammer (+7 to hit, 2d8+4 force)
Result: Jonas destroyed the Shade.

Consequence

"Regret destroyed. Record amended. The echo that learned is no longer learning."

For a moment, Jonas sees flashes â€” faces, towns, a thousand seconds of the lives he's taken â€” but they fall away like dust caught in a tide.

Mechanical Effect:
  • His hammer now hums off-beat; first Wisdom save before next rest â†’ disadvantage.
  • Echoed Wrath: Once per day, add +2d8 force damage to a hit.
  • Dream penalties: his reflection moves a half-second out of sync until next long rest.

Transition

The remaining glass shatters outward, forming a staircase made of frozen time. Each step glows as they touch it.

Above, they hear a rhythmic clanging â€” heartbeat and clock blended together. A storm of gold light flickers against the ceiling.

"Twelve hours measured. The clock nears its last note. Bring what you rememberâ€¦ to the Thirteenth Hour."

Part 6 â€” The Thirteenth Hour: The Regent's Heart

The Heart Chamber

The stair ends at a floor made of translucent gears turning beneath their feet. Each gear tooth is an hour of history. Through the transparent metal they can see everything they've done in the Sanctum replaying beneath.

At the center, the heart beats inside a cage of clock hands and ribs of brass. Every pulse sends waves of molten gold through the pipes overhead â€” time itself keeping beat.

The Time Regent sits within the cage â€” a towering shape of brass muscle and crystal bones, veins of light spiraling from his chest into the ceiling. His face is a mask that turns like a clock dial; each rotation shows a new expression â€” wrath, sorrow, curiosity, silence.

"Thirteen hours end. Thirteen sins accounted. You have walked through my organs, burned my breath, broken my patience, and rewritten my law. Tell me, mortals â€” what will you do with the seconds you have stolen?"

The Judgment

This is not a battle. The Regent is a divine-tier entity â€” not something level-7 mortals are meant to fight.

Instead, each PC faces a question about the Hour they embodied most:

Character Trial Theme Check / Choice
Kael The Writer of Laws Auto-success â€” the Regent acknowledges his paradox. He must decide: seal the Codex forever or let it continue writing the world.

Each success earns a Beat of Grace. Three Beats slows the clock; the Heart begins beating to their rhythm instead of the Regent's.

Jonas Demands a Reward

The judgment is ending. The Regent has begun to fold back into the Heart, the ticking slowingâ€¦

And Jonas, being Jonas, breaks the silence.

He steps forward, boots striking the glass clock-face hard enough to echo.

Jonas: "We've walked through every Hour. We've bled, we've paid, we've done what you asked. Now â€” what do we GET for this?"

The demand ricochets through the chamber.

For a breath, the Regent simply looks at him.

Then the air bends.

The Regent's Wrath

The entire floor peels backward in time by one second. The group watches themselves speak in reverse â€” then the replay snaps and reality corrects, leaving only Jonas standing where he was.

A single, enormous hand of brass closes around him.

"You open your mouth in the house of the second-maker and call it hunger? Then you will learn how long a second can last."

The hand crushes him once â€” not to kill, but to grind chronology through flesh. Every heartbeat he has ever spent is forced to replay in that instant.

He screams, but the sound comes after the pain.

Jonas's Punishment

Effect Description
Instant Agony 10d10 force damage; no save. If this would drop him to 0 HP, he stabilizes at 1 HP but cannot regain HP until a long rest.
Ages of Burden His body rapidly ages 10 years; hair whitens, joints ache. Divine, not biological â€” cannot be undone by magic short of Wish or True Resurrection.
Temporal Crucifixion For 24 hours, frozen one second behind time. Initiative â€“5, reactions impossible.
Temporal Brand A clock-sigil sears through his armor and into his chest, joining Azerach's mark on his hand. The brand permeates through to his flesh beneath. It pulses with temporal corruption â€” it will need to be stabilized and cleansed or risk worsening.
Echoing Condemnation Each time he uses his hammer, roll d20. On 1â€“5, it rings with the Regent's laughter and deals 1d10 psychic damage to Jonas.

The Regent's Verdict

"Your seconds are mine now. Every time you strike, you will hear me count. When the final number ends, I will reclaim you."

He releases the warrior. Jonas collapses, steam rising from his armor. The hammer lies inert â€” its hum replaced by a slow, mocking tickâ€¦ tickâ€¦ tick.

The Other Verdicts

The Regent turns to the others, his tone returning to measured calm:

Sol Raven: Succeeded. The Regent nods.

"You have learned that time is not conquered. It is borrowed. You may continue to borrow."

Kael: The Regent acknowledges the paradox.

"The writer who rewrote his own death. You have fractured my record, but you have also proven that mortals can hold the pen. Continue â€” but know that I am reading."

Kael chooses to let the Codex continue writing. It hums in his hands, pages settling.

Fursen: Succeeded.

"The beast that blurred boundaries now walks as penance. You may remember. The memory is your punishment â€” and your salvation."

The Clock Stops

When the final verdict is spoken, the throne dims. The fragments settle, quiet â€” obedient, for now.

The great clock's hands slow. The Heart gives one final pulse â€” and for the first time since they entered, the ticking stops.

"Thirteen hours fulfilled. Thirteen sins measured. Go now, mortals. The clock will turn again â€” and when it does, I will remember what you owe."

Light reverses, rushing upward through the ceiling â€” time releasing them.

The Sanctum begins to dissolve. Gears fall like snow, turning into feathers of gold dust.

Epilogue â€” Veinspire Reborn

The Silence After Time

The world returns as a whisper. One blink, and the blinding brass glow is gone.

The party stands on the plateau overlooking Veinspire, the ruined cathedral-city where this began. The sky no longer moves. The sun is pinned to the horizon â€” not rising, not setting. Everything glows in that sickly almost-dawn light that doesn't cast shadows.

The ground beneath them pulses faintly â€” the heart of the god still beats, but weaker now. Where once veins of crimson light webbed the soil, now only dull gray fissures remain, filled with ash instead of blood.

In the distance, Veinspire's spires lie broken, their bells silent. The cathedral doors have fallen inward. The scent of metal and old incense hangs over everything.

The State of the Party

Sol Raven The Clockmaker's Touch burns faintly at his fingertips. When the air around him bends slightly â€” seconds still obey his will. He knows this control is borrowed; somewhere, the Regent is counting. The Maker's echo of embodiment is gone now; he understands bodies only as mechanisms, clinical and cold. Kael The Resonant Codex hums softly. Its cover is sealed shut by veins of gold that pulse like arteries. It no longer writes unbidden, but when he touches it, he hears faint whispers of other organs still beating below the world. Jonas He kneels in the dust. His armor is cracked; every motion leaves a shimmer in the air â€” seconds refusing to flow properly around him. Azerach's brand burns on his hand. The Regent's temporal brand pulses on his chest, corruption spreading slowly through the sigil â€” it will need to be cleansed before it worsens. The hammer rests beside him, inert and heavy. Every minute or so, it ticks once.

Thirteen ticks will mean something.

Fursen Cold, shaken, and silent. His eyes, once full of lion's fury, now seem older â€” he remembers what eternity feels like. The Vault's scars still streak faintly across his skin, but they no longer bleed.

Locations Completed

Location Hour Status
Chamber of Reflection 8 Completed
North Mirror (First Theft) 8 Completed
East Mirror (Thief of Veins) 8 Completed
South Mirror (Silence) 8 Completed
Vascular Cathedral 9 Completed
Gallery of Inheritors 10 Completed
Choir of Remembrance 11 Completed
Vault of Regret 12 Completed
Regent's Heart 13 Completed

Features Gained

Character Feature Effect
Sol Raven Still-Second Instinct Act first 1/day
Sol Raven The Clockmaker's Lament Delay hostile action 1 round
Kael Codex Fragment â€” Regent's Eye Ward against divination 1/long rest
Kael Chronal Scar Reroll any failed roll 1/long rest
Jonas Strike of Sentence +5 damage vs. silenced foes
Jonas Heartbound Resolve Reroll failed fear/charm save 1/day
Jonas Echoed Wrath +2d8 force 1/day
Fursen Echo of Mercy Split damage 1/day
All Echo Resilience Advantage vs. repeat/duplicate effects

Jonas's Marks & Conditions

Mark Effect
Azerach's Brand (hand) Permanent; the Whispered King observes him
Temporal Brand (chest) Clock-sigil from Imhuran; pulses with corruption; needs cleansing
Aged 10 Years Physical change; cannot be undone without Wish
Echoing Condemnation Hammer may deal 1d10 psychic to Jonas on low rolls
Temporal Crucifixion 24 hours: Initiative â€“5, no reactions
Regent's Promise "When the final number ends, I will reclaim you."
