items.title: Session 11: The Pallid Crossroads
items.content:
Session 11: The Pallid Crossroads

Part 1 â€” Expelled

The Regent's Final Word

Reality folded.

One moment they stood in the Clockwork Sanctum, declared metaphysical errors, expelled from the trial. The next, time itself reversed around them â€” not their bodies, but their position. The Regent of Hours didn't merely banish them. He rewound their presence to where they'd first escaped Veinspire, weeks ago.

The same collapsed tunnel mouth. The same dead grass. The same grey sky.

But now there were four of them.

Fursen landed hard on his side, naked, disoriented, centuries of temporal imprisonment still echoing in his bones. His fur was matted with something that might have been sweat if time worked properly where he'd been. He blinked at the sky, at the three strangers staring at him, at his own hands as if confirming they could move.

Jonas's chest still burned where the temporal brand pulsed. His hammer felt heavier â€” thirteen ticks now woven into its metal, counting toward something none of them wanted to name. Sol Raven's reflection was shattered, his traded years gone, the Maker's echo of embodiment surrendered for knowledge he wasn't sure he wanted.

Kael clutched the Resonant Codex. Its pages were still bleeding ink from the trial â€” half of him remained in the Sanctum, a paradox that refused to resolve.

The Decision

They couldn't return to Veinspire. Seraphine Vale's people would still be watching the approaches. The Church would still be hunting Kael's stolen Codex. And now Jonas carried marks from two Sovereigns â€” the Whispered King's brand on his hand, the Regent's corruption on his chest.

Kael (consulting the Codex): "The Unclaimed. The gaps between territories. The Sovereigns don't rule there."

It was the only option that didn't lead back toward gods who already knew their names.

They turned their backs on Veinspire and walked northeast, into the wasteland.

Part 2 â€” The Pallid Waste

The Land of Nothing

The transition was gradual, then sudden.

First the grass died â€” not brown, but white. Bleached. Drained of something more essential than color. The soil beneath their boots became powder, fine as ash, pale as bone. The sky didn't darken so much as fade, the blue leaching away until only a flat ivory ceiling remained.

By the second hour, they walked through a landscape that had forgotten what features were.

No hills. No trees. No rocks. Just endless pale dunes that rose and fell without pattern, without logic. The horizon was indistinguishable from the sky â€” a white line against white space, depth perception failing in the absence of contrast.

Sound died too. Their footsteps should have crunched, should have echoed, should have existed. Instead, each step landed in silence so complete it felt like a physical weight.

Kael: "The Unclaimed. A gap between territories. The Sovereigns never shaped it, so it never became anything."

That was worse than any corruption. At least the Clockwork Sanctum had been something â€” twisted, dangerous, but definite. This was absence given geography. A place that existed only because no one had bothered to fill it.

The Black Obelisk

Hours passed â€” or didn't. Time felt uncertain here, each moment blurring into the next without clear demarcation.

Then: contrast.

A black shape hung in the air ahead, visible only because everything around it was white. As they approached, it resolved into an obelisk â€” perfectly smooth, obsidian-dark, floating three feet above the pale sand. No pedestal. No support. Just a monument to geometry suspended in nothing.

Kael: "Nothing should be here. That's the point."

Fursen circled it, nose twitching. His leonin senses had served him well in the Sanctum â€” but here, they found only emptiness. The stone itself had no scent. Nothing. But two people had passed here â€” maybe two hours ago. One young, one old. They went northeast.

Sol Raven reached out and touched the obelisk's surface.

The Memory

The instant his skeletal fingers made contact, something clicked inside Sol's skull â€” not pain, but recognition. The shard of Aedwynn nested in his ribcage resonated with the stone, and suddenly he knew this place.

Not from his own memory. From the Maker's.

A waypoint. Before the Usurpation, before the murder, when the world was whole â€” this was a marker. A guide for travelers crossing the empty spaces between populated lands. Touch it, and it would show you the way.

The knowledge faded as quickly as it came, but Sol was left with something concrete: a direction. A sense of where rather than endless nowhere.

He didn't elaborate. The others didn't ask. In the Pallid Waste, any direction was better than none.

The Dead Adventurer

They found the body half a day later â€” or what passed for half a day in a place without sun.

A humanoid shape, lying face-down in the pale sand. The flesh had been... removed wasn't the right word. Simplified. What remained was barely recognizable as having once been alive. Bones without marrow. Skin without texture. A corpse that had been edited down to its most basic components.

Kael (kneeling): "Something took everything that made them them. Left only the shape."

The only item that remained was a scrap of green cloth â€” vibrant against the white, jarringly alive in a dead landscape. It was barely enough to cover a hand.

Fursen picked it up. He was still naked, his fur the only thing preserving any dignity. The temporal prison hadn't come with a wardrobe. He wrapped the cloth around his waist, covering what needed covering. It looked absurd â€” a leonin warrior wearing a child's handkerchief as a loincloth. But it was something. In a land of nothing, something mattered.

Two Days Walking

They walked.

The Pallid Waste offered no landmarks, no variation, no indication of progress. Sol's borrowed memory provided direction, but direction without distance was its own kind of torture. They could have been walking in circles. They could have been standing still while the landscape moved around them.

Fursen tracked the scent of the two travelers â€” fading but present, a thread of something in the overwhelming nothing. It gave them purpose when purpose seemed impossible.

They rested when exhaustion demanded it, sleeping in shifts on sand that felt like sleeping on silence itself. Dreams came strange and pale, memories leaching color the longer they stayed.

On the second day â€” if days existed here â€” they saw them.

The Father and Son

Two figures walked ahead, just visible against the white horizon. An old man with a walking stick. A young man carrying a bundle of sticks on his back, tied with rough rope.

The party quickened their pace and caught up within the hour.

Old Man (turning): "Travelers. Rare, out here. You have the look of people who don't know where they're going."

He smiled â€” a weary expression, but genuine.

Old Man: "The Crossroads is another day's walk. Maybe less, if the paths feel generous."

He explained: The Pallid Crossroads. A settlement in the gap between territories. A place that existed because people remembered it existed, and would cease to exist if they ever forgot.

Old Man: "Don't try to navigate. Don't try to find your way. Just know where you want to go, and walk. The Waste... it listens. If you're certain enough, it'll take you there."

Fursen's eyes lingered on the rope binding the young man's firewood.

Fursen: "Could I have that rope?"

The old man looked at the leonin â€” naked except for a green cloth, fur matted, eyes carrying centuries of imprisonment â€” and nodded to his son.

Young Man: "Here. We'll find more at the Crossroads."

He untied the rope and handed it over without hesitation. No payment requested. No questions asked. Just one traveler helping another in a place where help was the only currency that mattered.

Old Man: "The Waste takes everything eventually. Might as well give things away while you still can."

Part 3 â€” The Pallid Crossroads

A Place That Shouldn't Be

They saw it before they understood what they were seeing.

A settlement â€” wooden buildings, smoke rising from chimneys, the distant sound of voices. It emerged from the white landscape like a mirage refusing to dissolve, gaining solidity with each step until suddenly it was there, as real as anything they'd seen since leaving the Sanctum.

A makeshift wooden wall surrounded roughly seventy percent of the town, gaps filled with nothing but intention. Guard towers stood at irregular intervals, manned by people who watched the pale horizon with the practiced vigilance of those who knew what came out of it.

Old Man: "Welcome to the Pallid Crossroads. It's not much, but it's something. Out here, something is everything."

He pointed out the landmarks as they approached the gate:

  • The Ivory Inn â€” lodging, food, the closest thing to community the Crossroads had
  • Mira's Clinic â€” the healer, the only one for miles who knew what she was doing
  • The Forge â€” usually manned, though the smith traveled often
  • The Market â€” if "market" meant three stalls selling whatever people had found

Old Man: "Good luck, travelers. May the Waste forget you're here."

He and his son parted ways at the gate, disappearing into the town's maze of improvised streets.

Mira's Clinic

Jonas needed help.

He'd been at 1 HP since the Regent's punishment â€” stabilized by sheer stubbornness, but the temporal brand on his chest pulsed with corruption that no short rest could address. Every heartbeat sent echoes of wrongness through his body, clock-hands ticking beneath his skin.

The clinic was a converted house near the center of town. A wooden sign hung above the door: MIRA HEMM â€” HEALER. Inside, it smelled of herbs and something older, something that reminded Sol of incense in a church he'd never visited.

The woman who emerged from the back room looked to be in her fifties â€” grey-streaked dark hair pulled back severely, sharp eyes that assessed all four of them in a single glance. She moved with the efficiency of someone who had healed more wounds than she could count.

Mira Hemm: "You look like death walking. Sit down before you fall down."

Jonas sat. She examined him with practiced hands, pulling aside his shirt to reveal the temporal brand â€” a clock-sigil burned into his chest, its hands still moving, still counting.

Mira: "Tell me exactly what happened. Don't leave anything out."

Jonas explained. The Clockwork Sanctum. The 13-Hour Trial. Attempting to intimidate a Sovereign. The punishment in Hour IV. The worse punishment in Hour XIII.

When he finished, Mira's expression had shifted from professional concern to something colder.

Mira: "You tried to intimidate the Regent of Hours. A god who controls time itself. And then, when that didn't work, you demanded payment from him."

She shook her head.

Mira: "You're an idiot. An arrogant, reckless idiot who's lucky to still have a heartbeat." She began gathering herbs from shelves along the wall. "But you're a lucky idiot, and that's something."

She mixed a paste â€” pale green, smelling of mint and something medicinal â€” and applied it to Jonas's chest while murmuring words in a language none of them recognized. Her hands glowed faintly, divine magic threading through mortal medicine.

The clock-hands on the brand slowed. Stopped. The sigil remained â€” scar tissue, permanent â€” but the corruption drained away like poison from a wound.

Mira: "The mark stays. The curse doesn't. You'll carry that scar until you die, but it won't kill you anymore."

Jonas showed her Azerach's brand on his hand. She studied it for a long moment, then shook her head.

Mira: "That's not a curse. That's a claim. The Whispered King marked you because he wants to watch. I can't cure interest."

Pallid Mint

Before they left, Sol and Fursen noticed the herbs lining Mira's shelves. One in particular caught their attention â€” pale leaves with a faint blue tinge, growing in carefully tended pots.

Mira: "Pallid mint. Only grows out here, in the gaps between. Useful for certain... situations."

She explained: Ingest one leaf, and you lose your voice for twenty-four hours. Complete silence â€” no speech, no sound, no ability to communicate verbally. Ingest three leaves, and you lose consciousness entirely.

Mira: "I use them for patients who need to rest but won't stop talking. Or for people who need to not be heard for a while." A slight smile. "The Waste grows strange things. Might as well use them."

Sol and Fursen each took a small bundle of leaves. Mira didn't charge them.

Pallid Mint Leaves (6 total) Consumable, rare Single Leaf: Target loses ability to speak for 24 hours. Cannot produce any vocal sounds. Three Leaves: Target falls unconscious for 1d4 hours. Cannot be awakened by normal means during this time.

The Ivory Inn

Night came to the Crossroads â€” or what passed for night in a place without proper sky. The white ceiling above darkened to grey, and the town's few lanterns became beacons in the gloom.

The Ivory Inn was exactly what its name suggested: a building of pale wood and bleached stone, interior lit by candles that burned with steady, colorless flames. The innkeeper â€” a tired woman with kind eyes â€” showed them to rooms without asking questions.

Innkeeper: "Three silver a night, breakfast included. Don't go outside after dark unless you have to. Things move in the Waste when the light fades."

They paid. They ate. They slept.

For the first time since the Clockwork Sanctum, they rested properly.

Level Up â€” Level 7

Long Rest Complete All party members advance to Level 7. Jonas: HP restored. Temporal brand cleansed (scar remains). Hammer still carries 13 ticks. Sol Raven: Witness abilities available. Possibility infection stable. Reflection still shattered. Kael: Codex fractured but functional. Echo of himself remains in Sanctum. Fursen: First long rest since liberation. Temporal dissonance settling. Now has rope belt and green cloth.

Part 4 â€” The Missing Caravan

Morning

Grey light filtered through pale curtains. The party gathered in the common room for breakfast â€” a simple meal of bread, dried meat, and something that might have been fruit if fruit could grow in colorless soil.

Jonas had tried the forge that morning. The door was unlocked, the building cold, the smith nowhere to be found. Just empty anvils and tools gathering dust. The innkeeper mentioned he traveled often â€” might be back in a week, might be back in a month.

They returned to the inn, where three figures now occupied a table near the fire.

The Concerned Residents

An old woman â€” weathered face, hunter's bow leaning against her chair. A young man in his twenties, nervous energy barely contained. A middle-aged man with the look of someone who'd seen too much to be surprised by anything.

They were talking in low voices when the party entered. The conversation stopped. Eyes tracked the newcomers â€” not hostile, but wary.

The hunter woman studied them for a long moment, then gestured to empty chairs.

Hunter: "Sit. You look like the type who might be able to help."

She explained: A caravan had gone missing. Six people â€” friends, neighbors, people the Crossroads couldn't afford to lose. They'd been scavenging from abandoned outposts east of town, collecting anything useful from the old world's remnants.

Hunter: "They were due back two days ago. Yesterday, someone found blood on the eastern path. No bodies. No survivors. Just... blood, and boxes that looked wrong."

Young Man: "Half-vanished. Like something took bites out of them."

Middle-Aged Man: "We're not fighters. Most of us came here to hide from the world, not chase trouble. But if those people are still out there..."

The party agreed to investigate.

Part 5 â€” The White Marcher

East

They followed the eastern path out of town â€” a track marked more by intention than physical presence. The pale landscape swallowed it within minutes, but they walked anyway, trusting the Waste to take them where they needed to go.

An hour out, they found the first signs.

Blood â€” dark against the white sand, already fading as the Waste tried to forget it existed. Drag marks leading further east. And the boxes the villagers had mentioned: wooden crates, perfectly intact on one side and simply gone on the other. Not broken. Not destroyed. Absent. The edges were too clean, too precise â€” as if reality itself had been edited.

Kael: "Something that removes things from existence. Not destroys. Removes."

Fursen sniffed the air. The blood was human â€” multiple people. But whatever did this had no scent. Nothing. As if it didn't exist enough to leave a trail.

Fog rolled in.

The Ambush

It came without warning â€” a wall of white mist that reduced visibility to nothing. The party clustered together, weapons drawn, eyes straining against the blank expanse.

Jonas took point, leading them through the fog.

And Azerach laughed.

The Whispered King's brand flared on Jonas's palm â€” not with pain, but with amusement. The god who dealt in secrets and silence found something funny about a marked man trying to lead others through blindness.

Jonas rolled a natural 1.

The fog parted directly into the creature's path.

THE WHITE MARCHER

It stood twelve feet tall â€” or didn't stand at all. The thing's body was a contradiction: solid enough to cast no shadow, present enough to occupy space, but wrong in ways that hurt to perceive. Its form suggested limbs, suggested a head, suggested the general shape of something that walked upright. But the details kept sliding away, refusing to resolve into anything the mind could hold.

Where it moved, reality thinned. The fog behind it wasn't fog â€” it was absence, the visual static of existence failing to render.

The party was surprised.

It simply attacked.

The Battle

The fight was brutal.

Jonas's hammer connected first, driving the creature back â€” but as he pressed the attack, it began to mirror his movements. His own combat patterns thrown back at him, his strikes anticipated before he made them.

Fursen flanked wide, his monk training allowing him to strike from unexpected directions. Each hit disrupted the Marcher's mimicry, forcing it to recalculate. His erratic, unpredictable fighting style â€” honed by centuries of temporal imprisonment â€” proved invaluable against a creature that fed on patterns.

Sol Raven's fire scorched the creature's non-form, the flames finding purchase on something that shouldn't have been solid enough to burn. Each spell cast felt like arguing with reality itself â€” insisting that yes, this thing existed, and yes, it could be hurt.

Kael hung back, the Codex open, searching frantically for any knowledge that might help. The pages bled contradictory information â€” the creature was documented, wasn't documented, had been seen before, had never existed.

Kael: "It's from the gaps! The spaces between! It IS the nothing â€” it erases things because that's what it IS!"

The Marcher's claws found flesh. Sol Raven's reflection â€” already shattered from the Sanctum â€” flickered and threatened to vanish entirely. Each of them took wounds â€” real, painful, but at least comprehensible. The Marcher's claws found flesh, leaving injuries that wouldn't heal until they could rest properly.

But they held.

Victory

The killing blow came from Jonas â€” a hammer strike fueled by rage and desperation, connecting with something that might have been the Marcher's head. The creature didn't die so much as stop â€” its form collapsing inward, reality rushing to fill the space it had occupied.

Where it fell, the fog lifted.

They stood in silence, breathing hard, wounds that couldn't heal yet aching with absence.

The Caravan

Beyond the battle site, they found what remained of the caravan.

Three wagons â€” two intact, one half-vanished. The missing section wasn't destroyed; it simply wasn't. A perfect edge marked where existence ended, smooth as glass, terrifying in its precision.

The bodies were worse.

Four corpses, each partially erased. One was missing everything below the waist. Another was missing their head and left arm. A third had been reduced to just legs and a torso, the rest taken by the Marcher's appetite for existence.

No survivors.

Kael (quietly): "It wasn't eating them. It was forgetting them. Piece by piece."

They searched the wreckage. Most of the supplies had been erased along with their carriers, but some remained:

  • 47 gold pieces scattered in a lockbox
  • Three days' worth of rations (dried meat, hard bread)
  • A letter â€” half-erased, addressed to someone in the Crossroads, contents lost to the Marcher's passage

Not much to show for six lives. But something.

They gathered what they could and began the long walk back.

Session Conclusion

The Weight of Absence

The Pallid Crossroads welcomed them back as night fell â€” grey light fading to black, lanterns flickering to life along the incomplete wall. The hunter woman met them at the gate, hope dying in her eyes when she saw their expressions.

Hunter: "They're gone, aren't they."

The party confirmed it. Something in the Waste took them. They killed it. But the people were still gone.

Hunter: "But they're still gone."

She thanked them anyway. The young man and the middle-aged man came to collect the recovered supplies. No one asked for details. In the Pallid Crossroads, some things didn't need to be said.

The party returned to the Ivory Inn. They ate in silence. They didn't sleep well.

In the morning, they would decide where to go next. But for now, they nursed their wounds and tried not to think about how much of themselves the Waste might eventually claim.

Features & Conditions

Character Change Notes
Jonas Temporal brand cleansed Scar remains; curse removed
All Level 7 Long rest completed
items.raw: Session 11: The Pallid Crossroads  Part 1 â€” Expelled  The Regent's Final Word  Reality folded.  One moment they stood in the Clockwork Sanctum, declared metaphysical errors, expelled from the trial. The next, time itself reversed around them â€” not their bodies, but their position. The Regent of Hours didn't merely banish them. He rewound their presence to where they'd first escaped Veinspire, weeks ago.  The same collapsed tunnel mouth. The same dead grass. The same grey sky.  But now there were four of them.  Fursen landed hard on his side, naked, disoriented, centuries of temporal imprisonment still echoing in his bones. His fur was matted with something that might have been sweat if time worked properly where he'd been. He blinked at the sky, at the three strangers staring at him, at his own hands as if confirming they could move.  Jonas's chest still burned where the temporal brand pulsed. His hammer felt heavier â€” thirteen ticks now woven into its metal, counting toward something none of them wanted to name. Sol Raven's reflection was shattered, his traded years gone, the Maker's echo of embodiment surrendered for knowledge he wasn't sure he wanted.  Kael clutched the Resonant Codex. Its pages were still bleeding ink from the trial â€” half of him remained in the Sanctum, a paradox that refused to resolve.  The Decision  They couldn't return to Veinspire. Seraphine Vale's people would still be watching the approaches. The Church would still be hunting Kael's stolen Codex.

items.title: Session 12: The Northern Ascent
items.content:
Session 12: The Northern Ascent

Part 1 â€” Morning at the Crossroads

The Aftermath

The party returned to the Pallid Crossroads after defeating the White Marcher and discovering the remains of the lost caravan. The three villagers in the tavern â€” the old hunter woman, the trembling old man, and the anxious young man â€” received the news in silence.

Young Man: "â€¦you found what took them, didn't you?"

The party confirmed what everyone already suspected. Six dead. Partially erased. The creature responsible was destroyed.

Old Hunter Woman: "Good. You killed it."

Not relief. Approval. The quiet gratitude of someone who understood exactly how rare that victory was.

The villagers let the party rest without further questions.

The Rooms Above the Tavern

The party split into two rooms for a short rest:

  • Room 1: Sol Raven and Kael
  • Room 2: Jonas and Fursen

Sleep came uneasily. The Pallid Waste had left its mark on all of them.

Jonas at the Smithy

Jonas visited the forge â€” a squat building with a soot-blackened chimney. The smith was away (traveling, as the innkeeper had mentioned), but the building wasn't locked.

Inside, Jonas found:

  • Bent nails (dozens)
  • Iron scraps and shards
  • A rusted, broken blade (half a longsword)
  • Loose hinge plates and brackets
  • Two hammerheads without handles
  • A small crate of raw iron chunks (6-8 pounds)

Nothing exotic. Nothing magical. But plenty of usable metal for repairs or crafting.

The Stable â€” Sleeping with the Span-Runner

Fursen asked to sleep in the stable. The stablehand â€” a teenager with straw in his hair â€” hesitated only a moment before nodding.

The span-runner, a local breed with a white coat and pale eyes that almost glowed, watched as Fursen entered its stall. In Lionen culture, entering the sleeping space of another creature is a gesture of trust. The span-runner shifted aside, making room.

Fursen settled onto the straw. The creature folded its legs and lowered itself beside him, flank resting against his arm. A simple closeness. The kind only creatures understand.

Here, among other living beings, the ache of old shame quieted.

Fursen closed his eyes.

Something in the Night

Fursen's ear twitched.

Not at a sound. At the absence of one.

The span-runner had stopped breathing. Not dying. Not choking. Just holding its breath, sensing something Fursen had not yet recognized.

Fursen opened his eyes.

The air felt wrong â€” as if the space was one inch larger than it should be. A soft ripple moved through the straw. Not wind. Not the horse. Something else. Something thinking.

A displacement in the shadows. Not movement. Not footsteps. Like someone standing there who shouldn't exist in physical space.

The span-runner turned its head sharply to the corner of the stall â€” to a place where nothing was.

Then: a faint sound. A single click, like a fingernail tapping wood.

Then another.

Three taps. Like a code.

The span-runner trembled. A single tear ran down its white muzzle â€” bravely resisting the urge to flee.

The lantern outside flickered violently. One of the shadows lifted its head. Not physically. Not fully. Just enough for Fursen to catch the shape: a tilted head, observing him. Amused. Curious. Silent.

Then the shadow melted back into the wall.

Gone.

The Corner

Fursen investigated. The straw was undisturbed. No footprint. No scent.

But where the shadow had risen, the wood was smooth. Too smooth. Like it was briefly softened â€” as if a hand pressed into it conceptually rather than physically.

Carved into the beam, shallow enough to miss unless the lantern hit it perfectly:

"TURN AROUND"

Fresh. The letters uneven, tilted, as if written by someone imitating human script.

Fursen straightened slowly.

Then he turned.

The Duplicate

The lantern outside froze mid-sway. Perfectly. Not slowing. Not settling. Just stopped.

A second Fursen stood in the stall doorway.

Same height. Same mane. Same shoulders.

But wrong. The outline too sharp. Too defined. And the eyes were simply hollow black spaces where light should reflect.

It did not breathe. Did not blink. Did not move.

It just watched him.

Then it tilted its head â€” the exact same angle Fursen tilts his head when studying prey. A perfect imitation.

Except its shadow turned the opposite way.

Then it spoke. Not Fursen's voice. A layered whisper, like pages sliding over each other, like breath escaping a closed book.

"Not you."

The duplicate dissolved â€” not into smoke, not into dust, but into a flat paper-thin shape that folded in on itself and slipped under the stall door as if the world bent to let it pass.

Gone.

The lantern resumed swaying. The span-runner collapsed into Fursen's chest, trembling.

Waking the Others

Fursen moved with purpose through the tavern. The innkeeper snored behind the counter, unaware.

Upstairs, he found three doors. Jonas dragged a table across his doorway, wedged his hammer under the handle, and slammed the door shut.

Jonas: "If it wants me it can damn well wait until morning."

Fursen didn't waste breath. He roused the others:

Sol Raven jolted upright, shadow snapping into place around him. Kael gasped, Codex slamming shut, veins rippling across its cover.

Fursen spoke, voice low:

Fursen: "Something came. Something shaped like me. It watched. It spoke. It was not looking for me."

Following the Trail

Fursen, Sol Raven, and Kael slipped into the night. Jonas remained barricaded.

The creature left no physical trail â€” no footprints, no scent, no weight. But the lanterns reacted. Each one they passed flickered slightly more, as if recoiling from something that had passed.

Sol Raven: "It recoils from light. The lanterns react like it never passed through them."

Kael: "The trail is conceptual. Not where it walked, but where it thought."

At the settlement's perimeter gate, the lantern dimmed in one long, slow pulse â€” like a dying heartbeat.

The moment Fursen crossed the threshold, the temperature dropped. The fog thickened. The world outside seemed bent, like a page curling at the edges.

The Boundary

A figure stood down the path. Not moving. Not hiding. Just waiting.

Its proportions were wrong. Too tall. Arms too long. Head tilted at Fursen's angle â€” but facing Sol Raven.

Perfectly still. Perfectly silent. Perfectly aware they were watching.

Then it shifted. Not a step. Not a slide. It simply appeared five meters closer in the span of a blink.

Still tilted. Still wrong.

It raised one long finger and tapped its head:

**tap

tap

tap**

Fursen Shows the Coin

Fursen reached into his pouch and drew out the memory coin â€” the pale metal token they'd acquired during the trials in the Clockwork Sanctum.

The fog thinned around him. The creature leaned forward â€” not moving its feet, just its spine bending impossibly, pulled toward the coin by an unseen thread.

It lifted one long, too-thin hand. Palm open. Trembling with anticipation.

A voice entered Fursen's mind â€” not words, but imitation. Paper scraping. Whispers buried under stone.

"Giveâ€”"

"Give itâ€”"

Fursen Asks What It Is

Fursen: "What. Are. You?"

The creature froze. The fog stopped moving. Even the lantern held steady, as if the question commanded the night to listen.

Its hand lowered. The other touched its own chest â€” almost human, almost self-aware, almost rehearsed. Fingers tapped twice against its sternum.

**tap

tap**

The sound echoed like tapping a hollow book.

The voice forced out fractured sounds:

"â€¦Notâ€¦ nameâ€¦"

"â€¦Notâ€¦ meantâ€¦ forâ€¦ namesâ€¦"

Its silhouette pulsed â€” edges flattening, like something forced to exist in three dimensions.

"â€¦Oldâ€¦ thoughtâ€¦"

"â€¦Forgottenâ€¦ shapeâ€¦"

"â€¦Lookingâ€¦"

It tapped its head. Once. Twice. Three times.

The Codex in Kael's hand jumbled its pages without being touched. Sol's shadow rippled backward.

"â€¦I lookâ€¦ for the oneâ€¦ who thinksâ€¦ wrong."

It pointed at the coin.

"â€¦Give. I rememberâ€¦ through this."

The Coin Is Given

Fursen stepped forward and placed the coin into the creature's palm.

The world went silent.

Not quiet. Silent. No wind. No breath. No heartbeat. The fog froze mid-coil. The lantern flame stopped in place.

Sol could not exhale. Kael could not blink.

Only Fursen remained aware. Watching.

The creature's fingers curled around the coin with a trembling, jerking motion. Its hollow eyes widened.

Then it inhaled.

Not air. Time.

The coin crumbled into silver dust that never reached the ground. The dust rose upward and poured into the creature's face â€” through the hollow sockets, the thin cracks in its form, the seams between its thoughts.

The coin was gone.

The creature's silhouette clarified. Edges sharpened. Spine straightened. Limbs corrected. Proportions shifted toward real â€” like giving a starving artist one bite of food and watching a sketch become more defined.

Its voice entered Fursen's mind, stronger now, more coherent:

"â€¦Memoryâ€¦ returnsâ€¦"

It tilted its head. This time the motion was smooth.

"â€¦One of youâ€¦ bends the frame."

It turned slowly until it faced Sol Raven.

"â€¦You."

"â€¦You are the wrong thought."

"The Hollow Crown remembers everything... But he doesn't remember you. You're a thought that thinks itself without permission."

Then it vanished. No smoke. No sound. A snap â€” a page turning â€” and the space was empty.

The fog collapsed. The lantern resumed flickering. Sol gasped. Kael stumbled forward as reality caught up.

Fursen remained unmoved, staring at the empty space.

What Was Left Behind

A small white object fluttered in the fog.

Sol caught it before it hit the ground.

A paper-thin strip with words written in Sol's own handwriting â€” but he never wrote them:

"FOUND YOU"

The party had inadvertently painted a target on Sol Raven's back.

Kael (quietly, Codex humming): "It's a correction tool. Something that hunts errors in creation. And Sol... you register as an error."

They returned to the inn in silence. Sleep did not come easily.

Part 2 â€” The Journey North

Departure

The party left the Pallid Crossroads before dawn, heading north into territory few from the settlement ever traveled.

The Pallid Waste's distortions faded behind them. The air became crisp and clean. Shadows behaved correctly again.

Kael (consulting the Codex): "North takes us into old territory. Land the Sovereigns shaped but never fully claimed. Vortegas's influence, mostly â€” the Bone-Warden's domain."

Travel at Normal Pace

Hour 1-2: The Crossroads disappeared behind a rise. The grass grew shorter, the soil firmer. Hour 3-4: The terrain began to slope upward. Clusters of pale shrubs appeared. Bird calls echoed â€” normal, natural, not distorted. Hour 5: A half-buried wooden marker emerged from the earth: "Northpass Road" â€” but the road itself was long gone. Hour 6: The hills ahead became visible as actual shapes, not just shadows. The grass grew taller. The wind blew colder.

Jonas scouted the surroundings:

  • Terrain mostly flat but slowly inclining
  • Old humanoid tracks in the dirt (years old)
  • Bird movement far ahead (normal wildlife)
  • Distant pale stone outcroppings resembling ancient vertebrae
  • A collapsed wind-break â€” stacked stones that once marked the path

Fursen sniffed the air:

  • Grass and frost (natural)
  • Distant wildlife (small prey, no predators)
  • Old human scent along the road (weeks or months old)
  • No threats, no rot, no anomalies

The land was honest. A rarity in this world.

The Wind-Cut Hollow

By midday, the party sought shelter. After thirty minutes of scouting, they found:

The Wind-Cut Hollow â€” a natural formation carved by centuries of northern winds. Hidden behind a ridge, sloped inward like a shallow cave but open at the front.

Inside:

  • Dry ground
  • Old ashes from ancient campfires
  • Space for all four party members
  • Natural stone that retained mild warmth

They made camp. Set watches:

  1. Jonas â€” first watch
  2. Sol Raven â€” second watch
  3. Fursen â€” third watch
  4. Kael â€” fourth watch

Part 3 â€” The Night Watches

Watch 1 â€” Jonas

The sun set slowly. The land went still.

Jonas heard nothing but wind and his own breathing. His Whispered King mark warmed slightly at the end of his watch â€” not a warning, just acknowledgment. Azerach watching the same horizon Jonas watched.

Then the warmth faded. Nothing else happened.

Watch 2 â€” Sol Raven

The temperature dropped. The fire burned low.

Halfway through Sol's watch, the fire dimmed â€” not from wind or fuel, but as if darkness itself leaned closer.

A single white birch leaf drifted into the hollow, despite it not being birch season, despite no wind blowing it there.

The moment it touched the ground, the fire flared bright and hot, then settled.

A sign. Something in the North recognized the divine memory Sol carried.

Watch 3 â€” Fursen

The cold deepened. The hollow's stone walls seemed to hold the night in their pores.

At the edge of his senses â€” far out in the dark â€” Fursen smelled something:

Fear.

Not his. Not an enemy's. The fear-scent of small animals sprinting in blind panic. Then another. Then a third.

Far to the east. Running away from something large. Something moving quietly.

His watch ended with no encounter. But he knew: something out there was hungry.

Watch 4 â€” Kael

The Codex pulsed once as Kael took the final shift. Almost a heartbeat.

It opened slightly on its own. A single phrase appeared:

"Anomaly Moving."

Kael looked east.

At first, nothing. Then â€” a silhouette. Far away. Huge. Slow. Barely visible against the dim horizon.

Not approaching. Just passing. Walking its own ancient path.

A giant shape:

  • Like a rib arch walking upright
  • Or a long-limbed beast
  • Or a Sovereign-scar left wandering

It moved without sound. Without disruption. Just presence.

Then it disappeared behind a distant hill.

The Codex slammed shut.

Dawn began.

Part 4 â€” Following the Titan

Morning Report

Kael shared what he saw with the others:

Kael: "There was something out there. Large. Walking. Not approaching â€” just passing through."

The party decided to follow the creature's path.

Sol Raven's Arcana (Rolled 19)

Sol extended his senses, feeling for magic or divine resonance:

  1. The creature was not magical â€” not in the arcane sense. No spells, no distortion.
  1. Connected to Vortegas, but distantly â€” a faint divine echo. Bone, marrow, old architecture. But extremely diluted. Not a servant. Not controlled.
  1. Incredibly large but not unnatural â€” biological. Ancient biology.
  1. Not hunting â€” following paths carved before the Sovereigns cannibalized Aedwynn. Migratory. Rhythmic.
  1. Not alone â€” Sol sensed other echoes further away. Different ancient paths. Different cycles. The North had its own ecosystem of giants.

These were Boundary Titans â€” creatures that walked where the world told them to walk. Guardians of old routes. Walking walls. They ignored mortals because mortals were too small to matter.

The Titan's Trail

The party followed the titan's path for hours. Signs of its passing:

  • Grass bowed in a single direction (not crushed, just bent)
  • Shallow depressions in bedrock where its weight had pressed
  • Warm air lingering where it had passed
  • The land making room for it

Then â€” the titan's passing had disturbed something.

Part 5 â€” The Collapsed Area

Discovery

A large section of hillside had collapsed inward. Not freshly â€” but recently enough. The titan's weight had caused a cavity beneath the earth to buckle.

Dirt cracked. Stone fractured. A small sink formed near the base.

Kael's Codex vibrated:

"VOID-SPACE DETECTED."

Sol felt faint divine residue â€” old, not dangerous. Fursen smelled earth that hadn't breathed in centuries. Jonas tested the soil â€” stable, but thin.

There was a cavern beneath. Not deep. Not massive. But something the titan's passing had exposed.

The Cavern Entrance

The party investigated. The opening was just tall enough to crouch and enter.

Inside:

  • Walls curved in soft, deliberate angles
  • Stone too smooth to be natural
  • Repeating shapes under the dirt
  • Faint, long-ago carvings
  • Floor sloping inward like a long-forgotten artery

This was not a natural cave.

The air inside was warm, stale, but breathable. Sealed for centuries.

Marching Order

  1. Jonas (front)
  2. Fursen (front flank)
  3. Sol Raven (middle)
  4. Kael (rear)

Jonas carried the lantern.

The First Chamber

After descending, the party reached a rounded chamber â€” about 20 feet across, walls curving inward like the inside of a ribbed lung.

Three disturbed areas in the dust:

  • One path straight ahead â€” toward another doorway
  • One path left â€” into a narrow-cut hall
  • One path right â€” into a collapsed section

The drag marks were old. Dry. Something heavy had been moved through here long ago.

Jonas investigated the metallic residue (Investigation 21):

  • Flakes of oxidized metal
  • Something metal had been dragged through this place ages ago
  • It did not come back

The Terminus Î© Door

Following the straight path, Jonas found a larger chamber with a rectangular pit in the center â€” an elevator shaft with torn chains and snapped mounting bolts.

The elevator platform had been forcibly removed.

A massive metal door dominated the far wall:

  • 8 feet tall, 6 feet wide
  • Seamless metal plate
  • No visible handle or lock
  • Scratches on the surface â€” made from inside

Human fingernails. Someone trapped on the other side had clawed desperately before giving up.

A small metal plate near the bottom corner read:

I Î©

Kael recognized it immediately:

  • I = Sector designation (Internal Layer / Interior Chamber)
  • Î© = Terminus marker (End of cycle / Final lock / Nothing beyond meant to open)

Combined: Internal Terminus. A sealed core chamber. Not meant to be accessed again.

Kael Consults the Codex (Rolled 25)

The Codex revealed the full truth:

**"Terminus Chamber Î©-I

Purpose: Containment of Rejected Material

Classification: Unstable / Unusable / Irredeemable

Staff Protocol: Seal After Collapse"**

This was a pre-Sovereign divine research bunker. Built when mortals experimented on divine anatomy under Aedwynn's silent consent. Before the murder. Before the Sovereigns.

Î©-I Failure Report:
  • Containment breach occurred internally
  • Emergency lockdown initiated
  • Door sealed
  • Lifters disconnected
  • Surface access abandoned

The scratches were from a worker trapped inside during lockdown.

The clicking sound they heard was identified:

**"Auto-Pulse Regulator (APR-7):

Status: Malfunction

Cycle: 8-10 second incomplete pulses

Hazard: Low"**

A machine keeping divine specimens oxygenated. Now running in a broken loop.

The page tore itself. The Codex slammed shut.

This facility contained knowledge from before the Sovereigns existed.

Session Conclusion

The party stood before the sealed Terminus Î© door â€” a gateway to pre-Sovereign secrets, protected by nothing but ancient machinery and forgotten science.

Behind the door:

  • A dead experiment
  • A dead worker
  • A terminal
  • Physical data about divine-body research

The next step would require forcing the door open and descending into the heart of the facility.

Items Lost

Item Given By Given To Notes
Memory Coin Fursen The Misremembered Absorbed by creature; triggered its ability to remember Sol

The three villagers in the tavern â€” the old hunter woman, the trembling old man, and the anxious young man â€” received the news in silence.   Young Man: "â€¦you found what took them, didn't you?"   The party confirmed what everyone already suspected. Six dead. Partially erased. The creature responsible was destroyed.   Old Hunter Woman: "Good. You killed it."   Not relief. Approval. The quiet gratitude of someone who understood exactly how rare that victory was.  The villagers let the party rest without further questions.  The Rooms Above the Tavern  The party split into two rooms for a short rest:  Room 1: Sol Raven and Kael Room 2: Jonas and Fursen   Sleep came uneasily. The Pallid Waste had left its mark on all of them.  Jonas at the Smithy  Jonas visited the forge â€” a squat building with a soot-blackened chimney. The smith was away (traveling, as the innkeeper had mentioned), but the building wasn't locked.  Inside, Jonas found:  Bent nails (dozens) Iron scraps and shards A rusted, broken blade (half a longsword) Loose hinge plates and brackets Two hammerheads without handles A small crate of raw iron chunks (6-8 pounds)   Nothing exotic. Nothing magical. But plenty of usable metal for repairs or crafting.  The Stable â€” Sleeping with the Span-Runner  Fursen asked to s

items.title: Session 13: The C-5 Descent
items.content:
Session 13: The C-5 Descent

Part 1 â€” Into the Terminus

Jonas Enters Alone

While the others waited at the sealed Terminus Î© door, Jonas forced it open alone.

The cracked seam groaned. Rust flaked away. Warm, stale air rushed outward â€” the breath of a room sealed for decades.

Jonas slipped through.

The door ground partially shut behind him. He was separated from the party.

The Terminus Î©-I Chamber

Dimensions: 20 ft Ã— 20 ft, 10 ft ceiling Walls: Entirely metal Floor: Smooth steel covered in thin dust Air: Warm, stale, preserved

Jonas's lantern revealed:

1. A Dead Body in the Corner

Slumped against the far-right wall. Human. Skeleton half-exposed. Uniform rotted away. Fingers worn to bone â€” from clawing at the door.

Cause of death: Starvation or suffocation. Not violence.

One worker. Locked inside when the chamber sealed. Never rescued.

2. The Null-Flesh Specimen

In the center of the room â€” a metal containment rack holding a hardened mass the size of a human torso.

Fossilized. Calcified. Completely inert.

This was once a divine organ experiment â€” tissue that tried to become something but collapsed instead. Terminated when containment failed.

The Codex had classified it: "Zero Consciousness. Zero Threat."

3. A Manual Terminal

On the left wall â€” a metal console with broken glass, dead buttons, and an emergency lever.

Unpowered. Dust-covered. But potentially containing data if power were restored.

4. A Floor Vent

Warm air cycling through. The clicking sound came from below â€” the APR machine in the level beneath.

Jonas Investigates the Corpse

The worker's remains revealed:

  • Uniform: Pale gray jumpsuit with a high collar and metal insignia (I Î© designation)
  • Badge: "BIO-SECTOR INTERNAL â€” SUBUNIT 4"
  • Keyring: Three keys (one broken, one fused, one intact with an odd square shape)
  • Shattered Vial: Dried residue labeled "null-tissue stabilizer"
  • Metal Stylus: For the manual terminal
  • Torn Notebook: Pages fused together, one page salvageable

The salvaged page read:

"â€” specimen began collapsing, mass losing cohesion,

â€” backup seal failed, Omega-door triggered override,

â€” lift-table detached,

â€” I am trapped inside,

â€” something in the vent is clicking,

â€” I hear breathing but the specimen looks dead,

â€” I hope someoneâ€”"

The sentence ended mid-word. The worker died with the pen in hand.

Jonas Opens the Specimen Compartment

Beneath the containment rack â€” a small drawer. Jonas opened it.

Contents:
  1. A Thin Metal Logbook (Intact)
Labeled: "Î©â€“I / INTERNAL TERMINUS LOG / SUBUNIT 4 â€“ REPORTING" Handwritten entries. Pre-Sovereign scientific language. Diagrams. Emergency notes.
  1. A Stoppered Sample Vial (Stable)
Dark, dried flakes. Dull purple-black residue. Label: "Null-Flesh Fragment â€” Stage 3 / Final Residue / Non-reactive."
  1. A Reinforced Keycard Panel
Engraved: "ACCESS: INTERNAL CONDUIT C-5 / PRIORITY CLEARANCE REQUIRED" Matches the intact key from the corpse.

The Logbook Entries

Jonas read the metal logbook:

Day 1:

"Specimen recovered from the western arterial canal. Fragment originally appeared responsive to harmonic stimuli. Mass allocated to Î©â€“I chamber for isolation and study."

Day 3:

"Organogenesis proceeding irregularly. Structure attempts to form chambers but collapses within minutes. Tissue mass displays pseudo-sentience but no cognition."

Day 4:

"Null-Flesh designation confirmed. Sample expresses rejection of form and returns to undifferentiated state."

Day 7:

"Stabilizer proves ineffective. Applied harmonic resonance via Choir-tuning fork. Temporary cohesion achieved. Structure held for 41 seconds."

Day 10:

"Specimen exhibiting respiratory-like expansion. No lung tissue present. Expansion seems to mimic ventilation cycles from the Auto-Pulse Regulator below."

Day 13:

"Primary containment seal ruptured. Specimen attempted extrinsic expansion along floor plane. Mass reaching toward ventilation vent. Emergency termination administered (Protocol 3-Î©). Specimen reverted to inert fossil-state."

Day 13 (continued):

"Lift-table detached unexpectedly. Chamber triggered automatic lockdown. Door sealed. Assistance requested â€” no reply. Something is wrong with the mainline systems."

Day 14:

"Air thinning. I hear breathing through the vent but specimen terminated. APR malfunctioning. Lift-table was removed intentionallyâ€” Why?"

The final sentence trailed off. Ink fading.

Conclusion: The lift-table was sabotaged. Someone intentionally trapped the worker inside.

Part 2 â€” The T-Intersection

Jonas Explores Deeper

Jonas left the Terminus chamber and followed the corridor to a T-intersection:

LEFT â€” "C-5 ACCESS"
  • Metal plate: "C-5 INTERNAL CONDUIT / AUTHORIZED PERSONNEL ONLY"
  • Keyplate receiver slot matching Jonas's keycard
  • Dust disturbed around the slot â€” someone used this mechanism long ago
RIGHT â€” UNMARKED
  • No symbols, no plates, no writing
  • Completely undisturbed
  • Colder and slightly damp
  • No signs of travel

Jonas advanced 40 feet down the unmarked corridor. The temperature dropped sharply. The air went silent. Tally marks scratched into the wall:

```

```

Someone counting days, steps, or breaths. Then they stopped.

Jonas felt wrongness in his bones. He turned back.

The C-5 Door Opens

Jonas inserted both the keycard and the intact key into the C-5 mechanism.

CLICK. KRNNNâ€”CHKK. THOOM.

The door slid open. Warm air rushed outward. The smell hit him:

  • Metal
  • Dust
  • Old chemicals
  • Faint antiseptic
  • Something sweet, almost floral â€” but wrong

A preservative. This section had been kept intact.

The corridor beyond was:

  • Smoother walls
  • Less damaged
  • Floor graded downward
  • Pipes intact
  • A faint hum of machinery

Something in this section still received residual power.

Part 3 â€” The Party Descends Together

The Spiral Ramp

The whole party descended the C-5 corridor together.

Marching Order:
  1. Jonas
  2. Fursen
  3. Sol Raven
  4. Kael

The passage opened into a circular chamber with a spiraling ramp descending around a central shaft.

The faint pulse echoed up:

**PSSSHâ€”thoom

PSSSHâ€”thoom

PSSSHâ€”thoom**

Not alive. Mechanical. Ancient divine-tech hydraulics.

First Landing â€” Archive Node (Subunit 2)

A metal plaque:

"Câ€“5 LOWER ARCHIVE NODE (SUBUNIT 2)

POWER: LOW

STATUS: LOCKED"

The door was sealed, unpowered. They continued down.

The Conduit Hub

At the bottom â€” a circular chamber, 40 feet across.

A single half-functioning conduit tube ran up the wall, filled with slowly circulating orange light. The pulse was visible inside:

A wave of orange light moving upward â†’ disappearing â†’ resetting.

The room contained:

  1. A central machinery pillar â€” covered in conduits, valves, gears, ancient markings
  1. Three sealed doors:
- SUBUNIT 3 â€” "BIOCELL STORAGE" - SUBUNIT 6 â€” "CONDUIT MANIFOLD" - SUBUNIT 7 â€” "ARCHIVE LOWER CORE"
  1. A small terminal console â€” dead, dust-covered
  1. A grated floor section â€” warm airflow rising through

Kael's Codex flipped pages:

"C-5 LOWER CORE â€” ACCESS POTENTIAL: HIGH RISK / HIGH VALUE."

Sol Raven felt almost watched â€” not by a creature, but by the facility itself recognizing the divine echo in him.

Part 4 â€” Subunit 6: The Manifold

Sol Raven Approaches

Sol Raven examined the Subunit 6 door (Arcana, passive 16):

  • The door once opened electronically â€” now dead
  • Not magically locked
  • Seams warm from machinery behind
  • Safe â€” no traps

Sol felt a faint echo of Aedwynn's breath-cycle â€” not divine presence, but machinery built to mimic it.

Forcing the Door (Natural 20)

Jonas and Fursen grabbed the reinforced seams.

HHRRNNNNKâ€”THRAKKâ€”VOOOOM

The door broke free and slid fully open. The nat 20 meant:

  • Locking pins sheared cleanly (door won't slam shut)
  • Machinery didn't destabilize
  • Internal emergency lights flickered ON

Amber strips ignited along the floor edges. Partial power restored to C-5.

Inside the Manifold

A wide, circular control chamber â€” 30 feet across. Every surface lined with conduits, pressure tubes, valves, monitoring instruments.

The centerpiece: a massive regulator engine shaped like a cylinder wrapped in ribbed layers.

**PSSSHâ€”thoom

PSSSHâ€”thoom

PSSSHâ€”thoom**

This was the functioning divine-ventilation heart of C-5.

Important discoveries:

  1. The regulator was stable â€” not failing, not hostile
  1. A MAIN POWER SWITCH existed â€” a large lever labeled:
> "PRIMARY CONDUIT RE-ROUTE â€” ARCHIVE ACCESS ENABLED."
  1. A secondary hatch on the left wall â€” maintenance access, slightly ajar
  1. A tool rack with a single intact item â€” a divine-conduction calibrator
  1. The facility recognized Sol Raven â€” amber strips brightened when he stepped in

The Maintenance Catwalk

The party investigated the maintenance hatch. A short crawlspace led to a narrow metal catwalk suspended over a vast mechanical chamber.

Below them: the Auto-Pulse Regulator (APR-7) â€” the working unit. A massive cylinder rotating with pressure rings, glowing amber conduits, slow expansion and contraction like mechanical breathing.

The clicking they'd heard since entering â€” explained. An old machine still doing its job.

On the catwalk:

  • A dead diagnostic console (unpowered)
  • A broken section of railing with an old boot-print
  • A second hatch labeled "Maintenance C-7" (leading toward Subunit 7)
  • A loose dataplate: "ANATOMICAL RESONANCE CONTROL â€” Lower Core Authorized Personnel Only"

Part 5 â€” The Lever

Jonas Pulls the Lever

Jonas gripped the Primary Conduit Re-Route lever.

KRNNNNNNNKâ€”THRAKKâ€”VOOOOM

The lever slammed into "ACTIVE."

The chamber shook. Dust fell. Pulses raced through the conduits.

FWOOOMâ€”FWOOOMâ€”FWOOOM

Amber light flooded the pipes. The ventilation cycle surged.

Immediate Effects:
  • Lights snapped on across C-5
  • Terminals activated with weak blue glow
  • All subunit doors unlocked: CHUNKâ€”CHUNKâ€”CHUNK
  • The ventilation cycle synchronized perfectly

And thenâ€”

Part 6 â€” The Awakening

Something Wakes Up

SKKKKâ€”t-t-t-tâ€”SSHHHHHâ€”CLNKâ€”CLNKâ€”CLNK

Metal. Joints moving. Legs realigning.

From the darkness of the ramp behind them, a shape emerged.

Shadows crossed the amber strips. Then limbs. Too many limbs.

A thin, skeletal frame made from:

  • Metal struts
  • Tendon-cables
  • Preserved sinew
  • Dull glass eyes
  • A skull-like head of welded plates
  • A glowing amber core in its chest

Static-filled voice:

**"Maintenanceâ€¦ nodeâ€¦ compromised.

Preservationâ€¦ protocolâ€¦

ACTIVE."**

It rose to full height â€” 9 feet tall â€” multi-jointed arms braced with bone-like struts.

C-5 PRESERVATION CUSTODIAN

It rose to full height â€” 9 feet tall â€” multi-jointed arms braced with bone-like struts.

Built to protect the core. Not to recognize intruders. Not to reason. Just to eliminate anything unregistered.

The facility registered:

  • Sol Raven's divine memory signature = THREAT
  • Unregistered organics = THREAT
  • Power restored = Patrol Mode

Its amber core flashed. The machine crouched.

It sprang.

Combat: The Preservation Custodian

Battlefield: C-5 Conduit Manifold Environmental Features:
  • Conduits (half cover)
  • Warm vents (2 fire damage if struck near)
  • Railings (can be broken, creates fall hazards)
  • Machinery (may spark if overloaded)
  • Catwalk above (10-15 ft drop if fallen)
  • The lever (targeting it dims lights, gives Custodian advantage)
The Battle:

The Custodian prioritized Sol Raven due to his divine signature. It used:

  • Serrated arm-blades with 10 ft reach
  • Resonance pulses that pushed targets into machinery
  • Magnetic pulses that yanked metal weapons
  • Wall-climbing to reposition in three dimensions
  • Deflective frame to reduce damage

The party fought together:

  • Jonas held the front line, hammer strikes denting its plating
  • Fursen flanked and disrupted its targeting
  • Sol Raven's magic found purchase on its divine-tech frame
  • Kael provided tactical information from the Codex

The Custodian's Maintenance Protocol activated at low HP â€” gaining AC and attack bonuses but becoming slower.

The killing blow came from concentrated party assault. The construct shuddered, its amber core sputtering.

**"Preserâ€¦vaâ€¦tionâ€¦

proâ€¦toâ€¦colâ€¦ terâ€¦miâ€”"**

THOOM.

The light died. The Custodian collapsed.

Part 7 â€” Victory

The Aftermath

The facility stabilized. The vibrations ceased. The lighting steadied.

Three doors disengaged:

  • CHUNK â€” Subunit 2 (Archive Node)
  • CHUNK â€” Subunit 3 (Biocell Storage)
  • CHUNK â€” Subunit 7 (Archive Lower Core)

Emergency consoles lit up. Terminals became readable.

The facility recognized the party. Amber lights brightened when Sol Raven approached.

The Three Paths Now Open

SUBUNIT 2 â€” Archive Node (Upper)
  • Lab terminals, readable logs, facility history, staff rosters
  • Safest choice
SUBUNIT 3 â€” Biocell Storage
  • Preserved (dead) divine organoids, failed experiment samples
  • Safe but unsettling
SUBUNIT 7 â€” Archive Lower Core
  • Divine-tech data, pre-Sovereign records, memory experiments
  • Most important, most dangerous

The session ended with all doors unlocked and the facility waiting to reveal its secrets.

Part 8 â€” The Biocell Storage

Subunit 3: The Frozen Vault

The party approached the Subunit 3 door. Unlike the Manifold, this one wouldn't budge when pushed.

A control panel sat recessed into the wall beside it â€” still powered from Jonas's lever pull. Sol Raven examined it and found a simple interface: temperature warnings, containment status, and an access toggle.

He activated it.

CHUNKâ€”HSSSSSS

The door slid open. Cold air rushed outward â€” not natural cold, but preserved cold. The kind that keeps things from changing.

Inside: Biocell Storage.

The Vats

The chamber was long and narrow, lined with cylindrical containment vats â€” eighteen in total â€” each filled with viscous liquid and connected to ceiling-mounted tubes.

The party surveyed the vats:

Status Count Description
Black/Shattered 1 Cracked open, contents long dried, residue black and foul
Amber 2 Murky orange-brown liquid, shapes visible inside
Green 15 Stable, glowing faintly, contents unclear but intact

The temperature regulation had kept this room functional for centuries. Whatever was inside those vats had been preserved since before the Sovereigns existed.

Fursen Investigates the Black Vat

Fursen approached the shattered black vat. The residue inside had dried into a tar-like crust. His Lionen instincts told him something was wrong, but curiosity won.

He leaned in and sniffed.

Constitution Save: Failed.

The smell hit him like a physical blow â€” not rot, not death, but wrongness. Something that had tried to be alive and failed catastrophically. The scent wormed into his sinuses and stayed there.

Effect: Disadvantage on all d20 rolls for 24 hours. His senses were compromised, his reactions dulled.

Fursen staggered back, eyes watering.

Fursen: "Don't... breathe near that one."

Jonas Throws His Hammer

Jonas studied the amber vats. Shapes floated inside â€” humanoid, but wrong. Too still. Too patient.

He made a decision.

He threw his hammer.

CRASH.

The amber vat shattered. Liquid spilled across the floor in a thick, syrupy wave. And from within â€”

A figure emerged.

The Bioweapon Specimen

It unfolded from the broken vat like something being born and waking simultaneously.

Appearance:
  • Skin: Pure white, almost translucent
  • Hair: None
  • Eyes: Black, unblinking
  • Claws: Long, curved, designed for tearing
  • Teeth: Rows upon rows, too many for any natural mouth
  • Build: Lean, muscular, every line designed for killing

It took a moment to adjust â€” joints cracking, muscles remembering how to move after centuries of stillness.

Then it attacked.

Combat: Bioweapon Specimen (Alpha)

Battlefield: Biocell Storage Environmental Features:
  • Slippery floor (spilled preservation liquid)
  • Remaining vats (cover, but risk of releasing more specimens)
  • Cold temperature (no mechanical effect, but thematic)
  • Narrow space (limited maneuverability)
The Battle:

The specimen moved with terrifying speed and precision. It was designed for one purpose: killing.

But Sol Raven recognized something. The creature was still covered in preservation liquid â€” and that liquid was flammable.

Sol Raven: "Fire! Use fire!"

Sol's flames found purchase. The liquid ignited across the creature's skin, causing it to shriek â€” a sound no human throat could make. The fire bought them time, disrupted its movements, turned its greatest advantage into vulnerability.

The party pressed the attack:

  • Jonas's hammer struck true despite the creature's speed
  • Fursen fought through his disadvantage, landing crucial blows
  • Kael provided support and tactical coordination
  • Sol Raven's fire magic proved devastatingly effective

The specimen fell.

Examining the Corpse

The party gathered around the dead bioweapon.

Up close, the design was even more disturbing:

  • No hair anywhere â€” nothing to grab in combat
  • Claws that could punch through armor â€” bone-reinforced, self-sharpening
  • Multiple rows of teeth â€” designed to tear, not chew
  • Muscle density far beyond human â€” compact, efficient, powerful
  • No visible reproductive organs â€” this thing was manufactured, not born

Kael (quietly): "It was designed for something specific. But what?"

No one had an answer. But the implications were clear: someone had built living weapons before the Sovereigns even existed.

Part 9 â€” Deeper Into the Facility

The Back Door

Behind the Biocell Storage, a second door had unlocked when they opened the first. It led into a long corridor â€” dark, cold, and branching.

Three directions:
  • Left
  • Straight
  • Right

The party chose left.

The Rest Area

The left corridor opened into a small chamber â€” clearly a staff rest area from the facility's operational days.

Contents:
  • Collapsed cots (ancient, rotted fabric)
  • Medical supply cabinet (partially intact)
  • Expired rations (pre-Sovereign packaging, centuries old)
  • Emergency lighting (flickering weakly)
Loot Found:
  • Medical kits (Ã—2)
  • Bandages (enough for basic first aid)
  • Expired rations (inedible, but historically interesting)

The party took a short rest here. Given their wounds from both the Custodian and the specimen, it wasn't much â€” but it was something.

Pressing Forward

After the rest, they continued. The corridor led to another crossroads:

Two directions:
  • Straight
  • Right

On the wall beside the right passage, they noticed something: markings. Smeared in a thick liquid that looked disturbingly similar to the preservation fluid from the vats.

Something had been here. Recently.

The party chose right. They attempted to stealth.

Stealth Check: Failed.

The Insectoid Specimen

They crept down the corridor, weapons ready, eyes scanningâ€”

They were looking in the wrong direction.

It was above them.

Clinging to the ceiling like a spider made of nightmares â€” limbs too long, joints bending backward, body segmented like an insect but sized like a man. It had been waiting.

It dropped onto Jonas.

Combat: Bioweapon Specimen (Beta)

The creature moved nothing like the first specimen. Where the Alpha was a killer, this was a hunter.

Appearance:
  • Insectoid anatomy â€” segmented limbs, chitinous plating
  • Multiple eyes â€” clustered, unblinking
  • Mandibles â€” designed for grasping, not biting
  • Wall-climbing capability â€” moved in three dimensions
  • Longer, thinner build â€” built for ambush, not direct combat
The Grapple:

Jonas was grappled and restrained before he could react. The creature wrapped around him, limbs pinning his arms, mandibles pressing against his throat.

He couldn't move. He couldn't breathe properly. He was going to die.

Kael: "JONAS!"

Kael didn't hesitate. He cast Dimension Door, grabbing Jonas and teleporting them both out of the creature's grip.

They materialized twenty feet away. Jonas gasped for air.

Kael: "RUN!"

The party ran.

The specimen did not follow. It watched them go with those clustered eyes, then retreated back to the ceiling. Patient. Waiting.

Part 10 â€” The Archive

The Straight Path

The party backtracked and took the only remaining direction: straight.

The corridor opened into a larger chamber â€” an archive. Technological interfaces lined the walls. Terminals. Data storage. The accumulated knowledge of a pre-Sovereign research facility.

Sol Raven Activates the Systems

Sol Raven approached the central terminal. The interface was alien â€” not magical, but technological in ways that predated modern understanding.

Arcana Check: Success.

He placed his hands on the console. The divine signature in him triggered something â€” old protocols recognizing old authority. The screens flickered to life.

Terminal: "WELCOME. ACCESS GRANTED: PARTIAL. USER CLASSIFICATION: DIVINE-ADJACENT."

The Specimen Files

Sol Raven searched the database. He found digital files on all specimens:

Designation Purpose Status
Alpha Series Combat / Assassination Multiple units, most in stasis
Beta Series Infiltration / Ambush Multiple units, some escaped containment
Gamma Series Labor / Construction All units terminated (obsolete)
Delta Series [REDACTED] [CLASSIFIED]
Critical Discovery: All specimens shared a neural network â€” a hive-mind connection. They knew what happened to each other.

The Alpha they killed? The others already knew.

Sol Raven: "They're connected. They know we killed one of them."

The Purge Protocols

Sol Raven dug deeper. He found emergency protocols:

PURGE OPTIONS:
Level Target Effect
Stage 1 Biocell Storage Only Terminates specimens in vats
Stage 2 Conduit Manifold Destroys central systems
Stage 3 Entire Facility Complete purge â€” nothing survives
Requirement: Two access cards required for Stage 2 or higher.

Jonas had one. They needed another.

Emergency Exits

Sol Raven also found three emergency exit routes:

Route Risk Level Description
Exit 1 High Through specimen territory
Exit 2 Moderate Underneath, through maintenance tunnels
Exit 3 Low Back through entry point, service chute with grate

Finding the Second Keycard

The party searched areas they hadn't explored. In a side chamber similar to the first room where they'd found the dead worker, they discovered another body â€” another victim of the lockdown.

This one had a second access card.

They returned to the archive terminal.

Initiating Purge Protocol: Stage 3

Sol Raven inserted both keycards.

Terminal: "PURGE PROTOCOL STAGE 3 SELECTED. CONFIRM?"

He confirmed.

Terminal: "PURGE INITIATED. EVACUATION RECOMMENDED. TIME TO COMPLETION: 4 MINUTES."

Alarms began to sound. Red light flooded the facility.

Sol Raven: "GO! NOW!"

Part 11 â€” The Escape

Exit 3: The Service Chute

The party ran for Exit 3 â€” the safest route. Back through the corridors they'd already cleared, toward a service chute that led to the surface.

They found the chute. A metal grate blocked the end.

Jonas grabbed it and pulled.

Strength Check: Natural 1.

The grate didn't budge. Rusted. Fused. Immovable.

Jonas: "It won'tâ€”"

Kael: "MOVE! EXIT 2!"

Exit 2: The Maintenance Tunnels

They backtracked. The purge gas was already spreading â€” a thick, yellowish vapor that smelled of chemical death.

Exit 2 led them through maintenance tunnels beneath the main facility. Tight spaces. Emergency lighting. The sound of machinery dying around them.

They saw the exit door ahead.

One by one, they dove through:

  • Sol Raven â€” through
  • Jonas â€” through
  • Kael â€” through
  • Fursen â€”

Fursen was last. The gas was on his heels.

He made it through the door â€” but not before inhaling a small amount of the purge toxin.

The door slammed behind them. The facility died.

Part 12 â€” Return to Pallid Crossroads

The Shorter Route

The exit had deposited them closer to civilization than where they'd entered. They took a direct route back to Pallid Crossroads, arriving within the day.

The party was on death's door:

  • Sol Raven: Exhausted, depleted
  • Jonas: Battered, barely standing
  • Kael: Drained from multiple spellcasts
  • Fursen: Poisoned, weakened, and furious about it

Mira's Clinic

They went straight to Mira â€” the settlement's healer.

Jonas collapsed into a chair, finally allowing himself to rest.

Fursen, still suffering from the toxin and the 24-hour debuff from the black vat, looked at Jonas.

And bit him.

Jonas went down.

Mira stabilized him immediately, then turned to Fursen with a look of sheer disappointment.

Mira: "...Was that necessary?"

Fursen said nothing.

Fursen's Condition

After Jonas was stabilized, Mira examined Fursen. The purge toxin he'd inhaled was extremely deadly â€” pre-Sovereign chemical warfare designed to kill anything biological.

He'd only gotten a small dose. But even a small dose required treatment.

Mira: "You need to stay here. Three days. Minimum. If you leave before the toxin is fully neutralized, you will die."

Fursen would spend the next three days under Mira's care at her clinic.

Session Conclusion

The C-5 facility was destroyed. The specimens were dead. The knowledge within â€” most of it â€” was lost forever.

But the party had survived. Barely.

And they'd learned something important: before the Sovereigns divided the god's corpse, mortals had already been experimenting with divine biology. Building weapons. Creating horrors.

The Sovereigns weren't the first to play god.

They were just the ones who succeeded.

Subunit 3: Biocell Storage Specimen containment Destroyed
Rest Area Staff break room Destroyed
Archive Data storage and terminals Destroyed
Maintenance Tunnels Emergency exit route Used for escape
