items.title: Session 14: The Wrong Thought
items.content:
Session 14: The Wrong Thought

Part 1 â€” The Misremembered Returns

Three Days of Recovery

The party spent three days recovering at Pallid Crossroads under Mira Hemm's care:

  • Fursen: Cleared from clinic observation, lungs clean, given herbal packet
  • Jonas: Ribs fully healed
  • Kael: Leg strain recovered
  • Sol: Wounds sealed (undead regeneration)
Party Status at Session Start: Full HP, no conditions, combat ready.

The Forge â€” Day Two

During the second day of rest, Jonas visited Orin's Forge. The smith had returned from his travels and was working the anvil when Jonas entered.

Orin was a broad-shouldered man with burn scars climbing up his forearms and a beard that had clearly caught fire more than once.

Jonas pulled out the Custodian armplate and set it on the anvil.

Jonas: "Can you make anything from this?"

Orin examined it. Turned it over. Tapped it with a small hammer. Struck it harder. The metal didn't respond at all.

Orin: "What in the Waste IS this?" He struck it again. "Won't bend, won't mark, won't... anything. My forge isn't hot enough to work this metal."

He offered to try anywayâ€”said it might take a while, but he could attempt it.

Jonas refused. He didn't want to leave the armplate behind.

Fursen wandered in shortly after, still recovering from inhaling the AGENT-TERMINUS toxin in the C-5 facility. His lungs were mostly clear now, but he moved carefully. His eyes landed on a rack of simple leather goods.

Fursen: "How much for the cap?"

Orin: "Two silver."

Fursen paid. The leather cap fit awkwardly over his leonin ears, but it was something. Another piece of clothing.

Items Acquired Leather Cap (Fursen) â€” 2 silver. Simple protection from elements.

The Settlement Goes Wrong

On the third day of their rest, something felt... off. The party peered out the tavern window and there it wasâ€”that same figure from before, standing in the empty street. Everything felt frozen in time. The innkeeper was not present. It felt like the entire town had simply "disappeared."

Jonas and Fursen pushed Sol Raven out the tavern door and closed it behind him.

Confrontation with the Misremembered

The Misremembered approached Sol Raven in the empty street, its form wrong in ways that hurt to perceive.

"You are a wrong thought. You need to be erased... for my master. Don't resist, or doâ€”it's always more fun when they resist."

It extended a gnarly finger toward Sol, inching closer with predatory patience.

Jonas's Intervention:

As the Misremembered reached for Sol, Jonas threw open the tavern door and hurled his hammer at the creature's hand. The blow connected, injuring it and initiating combat.

Battle with the Misremembered

  • Medium aberration made of stolen memories and wrong thoughts
  • Could teleport, regenerate, and erase existence with its touch
  • Spoke in stolen voices
  • Servant of Karthayne the Hollow Crown
The Truth Revealed:
  • Sol is a "wrong thought"â€”his connection to Aedwynn the Maker makes him unrecordable
  • Karthayne's perfect memory cannot contain something connected to a god who died before she existed
  • The Misremembered intended to erase Sol from existence entirelyâ€”not kill him, but make it so he never was
Combat Highlights:
  • Jonas's hammer tore pages from its conceptual form
  • Fursen's claws ripped through impossible flesh
  • Kael destabilized its resonance using the Codex
  • Sol burned it with fire carrying Aedwynn's lingering warmth
Defeat: After much effort, the party drove it back. The Misremembered began folding into itself at inhuman speedsâ€”angles collapsing into angles, form compressing along dimensions that shouldn't existâ€”until it simply vanished.

A single sheet of paper remained where the entity stood:

NOT CORRECTED. NOTED. WILL RETURN.

Aftermath

Everything returned to normal. Pallid Crossroads' residents emerged from buildings confused, with no memory of the Misremembered or why they had been hiding. Only the party remembers what happened.

Mira rushed out of her clinic and asked them what happened. They explained in full detail what they had just dealt with, and she invited them into the clinic for a "check-up."

Part 2 â€” Mira's Request

After treating them in her clinic, Mira asked the party for help. Before they had arrived at Pallid Crossroads, someone in the town had been asking about her to the localsâ€”how long she'd been here, what she does, that kind of thing.

The Mission:
  • Go to Dusthollow, an extremely small settlement half a day west
  • Dusthollow consists of: a tavern, a well, a stable, and a handful of tiny houses
  • Find out who this man "Vorath" is and what he wants
  • In exchange, Mira would tell them the truth about herself

The party agreed.

Part 3 â€” Dusthollow Investigation

Journey to Dusthollow

The party rented horses from the stable. Fursen specifically rented the span-runner he had bonded with during their previous stay.

They set off and arrived the same day at late evening.

At the Stables

The party handed their horses to the stablehand for safekeeping. Jonas immediately began intimidating the young man, demanding information on "Vorath."

The stablehand, panicking and almost crying, spurted out everything he knew:

  • Vorath was a regular at the tavern
  • He would go out in the afternoon and return at midnight
  • Thin man, grey hair, bad leg

Jonas continued intimidating him for "fun"â€”that's just how Jonas is.

Fursen approached the terrified stablehand afterward, handed him a gold coin, and whispered: "Sorry for my companion's behaviour. He can be a bit stupid."

At The Dry Cup

Inside the tavern, they found:

  • A couple eating their food
  • An elderly man enjoying his bread
  • A hooded figure seemingly sleeping in the corner

Fursen asked the tavernkeeper about Vorath and received the same information the stablehand had provided.

Jonas's "Interrogation"

While Fursen gathered information, Jonas approached the couple, sat right between them, and started staring at the man. The man, visibly terrified, asked: "Can I help you?"

Jonas did not respond. Instead, he ordered an ale from the tavernkeeper and kept sitting there, staring, downing his ale. After a while, he started slamming the table and laughing, clearly drunkâ€”all while maintaining that same unblinking stare.

The woman started crying while her boyfriend comforted her, also visibly terrified.

Fursen's Discovery â€” Vorath's Room

Fursen rented a room (2 silver) and went upstairs. Instead of sleeping in his own room, he used his claws to pick the lock on Vorath's door.

Found on Desk:
  • A kill list with names crossed out
  • Orders from Seraphine Vale to find and capture "the heretic" and bring her to the Tribunal
Found in Box Under Bed:
  • A dagger with a poison injection feature
  • A vial of white liquid (purpose unknown at this time)

Fursen took everything.

Part 4 â€” Return to Pallid Crossroads

Instead of spending the night, the party immediately left the tavern, retrieved their horses, and rode back to Pallid Crossroads. They met with Mira at her clinic.

Mira's True Identity Revealed

After seeing the evidence, Mira revealed the truth:

  • Real name: Mira Alethain
  • Former Mareathan priest and templar
  • Deemed a heretic after discovering the Arterial Textsâ€”documents containing Mareatha's foul crimes and deeds that the Church had hidden
  • She had been on the run for 30 years
  • They had somehow found her
The White Liquid: Mira identified it as a truth serumâ€”likely intended to make her confess where the Arterial Texts were hidden. The Party's Persuasion: The party convinced Mira that running wouldn't solve anything. It was time to face her pursuers.

She packed the belongings she needed, and they departed immediately back to Dusthollow.

Part 5 â€” Vorath's Elimination

They arrived within a few hours. In the pre-dawn darkness, they spotted a figure in the distance getting ready to mount a horse and flee toward Veinspire.

The Chase

  • Party barreled toward him on horseback
  • Jonas threw his hammer at Vorath as he climbed onto the horseâ€”missed
  • The hammer struck the horse instead, knocking Vorath to the ground

Confrontation

Vorath got up and realized his fate was sealed. He knew how powerful Mira was.

Mira asked him for information. He refused.

"Fine. I have other ways to extract information."

She raised her fist and bashed him in the head three times, killing him. She wiped the blood from her knuckles and cast Speak with Dead.

Five Questions Asked

  1. Who gave you your orders?
- "Seraphine Vale. High Inquisitor."
  1. Who gave Seraphine her orders?
- "Kaleth Vorn. Tribunal Hand. Veinspire Catacomb. Seraphine's blade in shadow."
  1. What is the purpose behind interrogating Mira about the Arterial Texts?
- "The Texts contain the Vein-Mother's mortal writings. Her doubts. Her failures. Her words before divinity. The Tribunal must destroy them before they spread. Alethain knows where they are hidden. She is the last who remembers."
  1. Is Seraphine Vale still hunting the party?
- "Four heretics. Fire mage. Branded warrior. Leonin escapee. The anomaly. Vale's secondary priority. Standing orders: capture alive if encountered. Primary focus remains the Alethain extraction. You are... unfinished business."
  1. What is the High Inquisitor's current location?
- "The Crimson Sanctum. Cathedral's upper spire. Quarters and chambers of the High Inquisition. She does not descend to the lower districts. The faithful come to her."

They took Vorath's body and buried it behind the stables, far from prying eyes.

Part 6 â€” Morning at The Dry Cup

The party rented rooms and slept until morning.

Morning Breakfast:
  • Jonas: Well over a dozen eggs
  • Fursen: Normal amount
  • Kael: Normal amount
  • Mira: Normal amount
  • Sol: Nothing (doesn't eat)

Kael's Breakdown

Fursen pointed at Kael and asked Mira directly: "What did you mean when you said we don't understand what our friend is? What is he?"

Mira's Explanation:
  • Kael reeks of the smell of Vor'Kael the Hollow Empress
  • Vor'Kael claimed the Maker's stomachâ€”the organ of digestion
  • She breaks down, processes, and incorporates concepts and ideas
  • Even a god's stomach rejects some thingsâ€”incompatible, contradictory, poisonous ideas
  • When this happens, she doesn't destroy themâ€”she EXPELS them
  • Kael is a "vomited fragment"â€”a piece of concept Vor'Kael tried to consume and couldn't stomach
  • This explains his insatiable hunger for knowledge
  • He was INSIDE her once, part of an idea she attempted to digest
  • She spat him out
  • This is why he doesn't exist in Imhuran's temporal records
  • Vor'Kael will spend eternity trying to finish what she started
Kael's Reaction:
  • Had a mental breakdown
  • Questioned his own existence
  • Fled the tavern

Sol's Intervention

Sol followed Kael and found him behind the tavern, sobbing.

Sol comforted him by sharing his own existential crisis:

  • He is a skeleton
  • He doesn't remember his past
  • He doesn't know if his memories are his own or belong to someone who died
  • "It doesn't matter. Because I'm here. Right now."
  • "Whatever I was beforeâ€”whatever made meâ€”I'm making choices NOW. That's real. That's mine."
  • "Maybe we're both impossible. Maybe we're both things that shouldn't be. But we ARE. And that terrifies them."
  • "A mistake who survived. The most stubborn kind."

The situation stabilized. They returned to the tavern.

Kael's Return:
  • Returned to find Jonas had eaten his eggs
  • The suspect? Jonas. (Obviously.)
  • Managed a small laughâ€”"Fair enough"

Part 7 â€” Route Planning

After eating, they discussed routes to Veinspire.

Three Options:
  1. Direct to the Gates â€” Risky due to patrols
  2. Near the Blooming Rot â€” Risky since it belongs to the Verdant King and they don't know how he would react
  3. Through the Underways â€” Underground passage
Decision: The Underways.

Part 8 â€” The Underways

The party went south, led by Mira, where they found a hidden entryway to the underground. They entered and embarked on the journey.

The Cistern Depths

  • Passed eyeless beasts that avoided their torchlight
  • Rested in not-so-safe places
  • Finally made it through

The Bone Galleries

As they approached the Bone Galleries, they were stopped by three Bone Wardensâ€”desiccated guardians with green flame eyes.

The wardens challenged them: "Why do you seek passage, those who reek of sovereignty?"

Jonas stepped forward to try and convince them. Alas, he is marked by Azerachâ€”the wardens detected the brand immediately. His persuasion failed spectacularly.

Just before they tore Jonas to pieces, Mira stepped in and convinced them that he was not lying, that they truly did not intend to defile the sacred ground, and that the brand had been forced upon him against his will.

The Bone Wardens, convinced, granted them passage.

Mira's Lesson to Jonas

After they were safely past, Mira gave Jonas an earful:

"Really? 'I'm not Azerach's slave?' Can you be any less convincing?"

"Defiance without wisdom gets people killed. Ancient beings see your brand as 'claimed' regardless of your intent."

"You should have said: 'I was marked against my will. I carry the brand but not the loyalty.'"

"Down here, pride is a luxury. Precision keeps you alive."

Short Rest

The party found a defensible spot ahead and settled in for a short rest.

NPCs Updated

NPC Update
Mira Hemm True name: Mira Alethain. Former Mareathan priest/templar. Hunted for 30 years.
Kael Revealed as "vomited fragment" of Vor'Kael

Party Status

Character Condition Notes
Sol Raven Healthy Hunted by Karthayne
Jonas Healthy Nearly killed by Bone Wardens
Fursen Healthy â€”
Kael Shaken Processing existential revelation
Mira Alethain Healthy Now traveling with party

items.title: Session 15: The Maker's Final Breath
items.content:
Session 15: The Maker's Final Breath

Part 1 â€” The Arterial Tunnels

After traversing the Bone Galleries, the party finally made it to the Arterial Tunnels. Mira led the way, pointing them in the direction that would take them up to the Lesser Sacral District.

Blood-Drinker Ambush

As they continued onwards through the tunnels, a group of blood-drinkers emerged from the walls. Mira materialized her Oathkeeper and they engaged them, making short work of the creatures with her at their side.

Fursen's Attempt

As they continued walking, Fursen tried to flirt with Mira.

She looked at him with pity and complete uninterest.

The party noticed the ring on her finger afterward. They didn't know what it meant yet.

Part 2 â€” The Patrol

A little further ahead, they could hear movement and voices. Three men and one woman.

As they continued onwards, they faced the patrol and were asked to drop their weapons. Two soldiers approached them while a third stayed behind, dragging a woman.

Compliance

Everyone complied:

  • Fursen â€” Doesn't really have a weapon
  • Sol Raven â€” Uses a focus, not a weapon
  • Kael â€” Uses a book, not a weapon
  • Mira â€” Can simply unsummon her greatsword

Which leaves Jonas. Jonas dropped his hammer.

All the while, a Blood Beast was situated above the party as insurance for the Church patrol.

Jonas's Ambush

As the soldier approached Jonas to secure him, Jonas recalled the bound weapon to his hand and smacked him, surprising everyone.

They made short work of the Blood Beast and soldiers with Mira around.

Part 3 â€” Vela Thorne

After defeating the patrol, they rescued the woman and identified her as Vela Thorne, an archivist librarian working in the Church of the Merciful Vein.

The Truth: Kaleth had used her as bait to lure Mira in. He was a cynical and calculating man who knew that something had happened to Vorath even before it happened. He anticipated everything.

Part 4 â€” Kaleth's Arrival

After a short while, the party heard marching approaching their location. A big group of people.

The party tried to hide on the edges, but Kaleth was smart and had anticipated this.

Sol Raven tried to fire two Fireballsâ€”both were counterspelled.

And then, the battle began.

Kaleth's Speech

Kaleth gave a cynical speech about how all of Mira's friends met their ends, especially her husband Elias. Every word dripped with cruel satisfaction.

The Sanguine Siphon

Mira, filled with rage, tried to attack. But Kaleth threw a Sanguine Siphonâ€”a device designed against heretics to completely deplete them of the energy borrowed from Mareatha.

Mira collapsed on the ground, motionless.

The Battle

The party had to fend against the members of the Tribunal as well as Kaleth himself.

Jonas tanked a Finger of Death.

The fight was brutal, desperateâ€”

And then something changed.

Part 5 â€” Undying Conviction

Mira started radiating an orange-ish aura, far different from the red aura that radiates from Mareatha's followers.

She got up.

She started muttering the names of the fallen. And kept repeating her husband's name, over and over and over again.

"Elias... Elias... Elias..."

She lunged at Kaleth.

She deleted him in one attack.

The whole room was stricken with fear and could not move. Some of the Tribunal members tried to escape, but it was impossible with Mira in her current state.

None survived.

Part 6 â€” Aftermath

Kaleth's Remains

They inspected whatever was left of himâ€”a corpse essentially split in half, the halves scorched by radiant energy.

Found:
  • Letters addressed to him by an entity known as "S"
  • A key (hidden in Kaleth's boot)
  • Kaleth's Journal â€” personal writings documenting his work
  • Tribunal Seal â€” Kaleth's identification badge

Kaleth's Journal

The journal was damning. Kaleth had documented everything with cold, clinical precision:

  • The Seven Heretics â€” Names, locations, methods of death for each of Mira's friends
  • Elias Alethain â€” "Pushed. Verdant Pass. Made it look like a fall. He begged at the end."
  • His Philosophy â€” Kaleth didn't believe in the faith. He saw the Church as a tool for power, nothing more.
  • Seraphine Vale â€” Described as "the ideal instrument" â€” moldable, loyal, useful
  • References to "S" â€” His superior, someone he reported to but rarely met
  • The Cardinal â€” Mentioned in passing, someone above even "S"

Mira read the entry about Elias in silence. Her hands shook. Thirty years of wondering how he died, and it was written here in neat handwriting like a ledger entry.

Mira's Exhaustion

Mira dropped to her knees, completely exhausted (3 levels of exhaustion). Fursen helped her up, and she relied on her blade to continue walking.

Part 7 â€” The Door

They continued onwards until they found a door that felt... off.

Jonas opened it with the key they had found hidden in Kaleth's boot.

The Chamber of the Final Breath

The room radiated with warm energy, kind of like a hug.

Sol Raven felt it the most but was hesitant to go in.

Jonas entered first.

Below, he found a fragment of Aedwynnâ€”stronger than most, shaped like herâ€”underneath a golden tree.

Part 8 â€” The Maker's Gifts

Jonas

Jonas approached her and touched her.

He felt a voice in his head asking him if he wanted to "deal with the curse placed upon him."

Jonas refused.

The Maker accepted his choice without judgment.

Fursen

Then Fursen came down and did the same thing.

She asked him: "Do you wish to reclaim your people? To set them free?"

Fursen said yes.

He was flooded with 10,000 names of his Leonin brethrenâ€”every ancestor, every story, every act of defiance against Imhuran's attempt to erase them from existence.

Sol Raven

Finally, Sol Raven came down and touched her.

She told him:

"I revived you because your death was unfair. Tell me... will you be my witness? I'm not angry at my children for what they did, and you can do what you have to do to bring my teaching back to this world."

Sol Raven accepted.

He has become her Witness.

Sol Raven â€” Witness of the Maker As Aedwynn's chosen Witness, Sol gained the following:
  • Immunity to effects that would erase his existence
  • The ability to share memories through touch
  • A divine purpose: to bring the Maker's teachings back to the world

Part 9 â€” Mira's Plea

As the fragment's power depleted, she began to enter a slumber once more.

Mira rushed to her and touched her, pleading and crying:

"Please, tell me where my husband is... his remains... please."

Mustering the last of the fragment's power, Aedwynn burned an image into Mira's mindâ€”the location of her husband Elias's remains.

A cave in the Verdant Pass, away from any Sovereign's reach.

He has been there for decades.

Mira thanked her as the fragment fell into slumber.

Part 10 â€” Long Rest

The party decided to long rest in the Chamber of the Final Breath, protected by whatever ancient sanctity remained in this sacred space.

items.title: Session 16: The Diverging Paths
items.content:
Session 16: The Diverging Paths

Part 1 â€” Awakening

The party woke in the Chamber of the Final Breath, surrounded by the warm golden light of the slumbering Maker's fragment.

Everyone felt refreshed â€” except Mira.

She moved slowly, still carrying 2 levels of exhaustion from her Undying Conviction. But her eyes held something they hadn't before: purpose. She knew where Elias was. After thirty years, she finally knew.

The Choice

Mira wanted to retrieve Elias's body from the Verdant Pass.

But the party understood that uncovering who "S" was â€” and stopping whatever "The Confluence" meant â€” had to take priority. The letters from Kaleth's body pointed to something larger. Something imminent.

Mira (quietly): "Elias waited twenty-two years in that cave. He can wait a little longer."

She said it like she was trying to convince herself.

They pressed on toward Veinspire.

Part 2 â€” Return to the Lesser Sacral District

The party climbed through a sewer grate and emerged in an alleyway very close to the Church of the Merciful Vein in the Lesser Sacral District.

And there, standing at the church steps, was a figure they hadn't seen in a long while.

Seraphine Vale.

Reconnaissance

Fursen's keen sense of smell picked up details the others couldn't:

  • People inside the Church â€” guards on standby
  • Another guard stationed behind the building
  • Seraphine herself, standing at the front

They needed a plan.

Part 3 â€” The Exotic Cat

Sol and Mira would confront Seraphine directly.

But Jonas and Fursen needed to deal with the guard behind the church. Fursen had an idea.

He handed Jonas a rope and tied the other end around his own neck like a leash.

Fursen: "I'll pretend to be your exotic cat. You walk me past the guard."

Jonas: "Absolutely not. That's humiliating."

Fursen: "It'll work."

Jonas: "I'm not doing it."

Fursen leaned over to Sol and whispered something. Sol nodded almost imperceptibly.

Jonas felt the words wash over him â€” not spoken aloud, but pressed directly into his mind with the gentle insistence of absolute truth. The Maker's voice, channeled through her Witness, suggesting that this was reasonable. That this made sense. That he should comply.

His will buckled. Not broken â€” bent. The suggestion took root before he could resist it.

Then Fursen removed his loincloth.

The cloth was covered in sweat and musk â€” Fursen hadn't showered since... well, since before his temporal imprisonment. Centuries of theoretical grime. He handed it to Jonas.

Fursen: "Wear this over your face. To hide your identity."

Jonas's hands moved without his permission. He took the cloth. He wrapped it around his face. He breathed in.

His eyes watered. His stomach lurched. You could feel his rage seeping through â€” but the compulsion held. He had to trick the guard behind the church. He had to wear the cloth for twenty-four hours.

Those were the conditions.

Mira looked at this development, facepalmed, and said nothing. She was too exhausted to comment.

Sol Raven â€” Mass Suggestion Sol gained Mass Suggestion from his ascension in Session 6. Once per long rest, he can compel others to act. Condition: Jonas must trick the guard and wear the cloth for 24 hours.

Part 4 â€” The Infiltration

Mira and Sol â€” The Confrontation

Mira and Sol walked past the church steps toward Seraphine. They waited for the High Inquisitor to be distracted.

Jonas and Fursen â€” The Back Entrance

Once Seraphine's attention was on Mira and Sol, Jonas and Fursen made their move.

Fursen dropped to all fours. Jonas held the rope like a leash. They walked around the side of the church, toward the back where the guard was stationed.

The guard spotted them immediately.

Guard (squinting): "What theâ€” Bah, take your exotic cat out of here. Citizens aren't allowed back here."

Jonas pretended to fumble with the leash. It slipped from his fingers.

Fursen crawled toward the guard on all fours. Then he rolled onto his back, paws up, awaiting belly rubs.

(Deception: Natural 20)

The guard stared. His brain tried to process what he was seeing â€” a massive leonin, clearly intelligent, acting like a housecat.

He was completely bewildered.

And completely distracted.

Jonas lunged.

He wrapped his arms around the guard's neck in a chokehold. The guard struggled, clawing at Jonas's arms, but couldn't break free. After several seconds, he went limp.

Fursen looked at the unconscious body.

Fursen: "We should kill him."

Jonas didn't argue. They stabbed the guard while he slept, then dragged his body into one of the mausoleum coffins nearby and shut the stone lid.

One problem solved.

Part 5 â€” Seraphine's Faith Shatters

Mira and Sol stood face to face with Seraphine Vale.

The High Inquisitor's hand rested on her weapon. Her guards were inside, ready to be called. She had the advantage.

Seraphine: "Don't step any closer, heretics!"

Mira didn't flinch.

Mira: "I remember your mother, Seraphine. I helped deliver you into this world thirty-two years ago. Your mother was so happy when you were born â€” she wept with joy. She let me hold you in my arms. You were so small. So precious. She named you after the seraphim because she believed you would grow up to be something holy."

Seraphine's expression flickered. Uncertainty where there should have been conviction.

Mira: "I watched you take your first steps in the lower chapel. I saw your mother's pride when you were accepted into the Inquisition. And I wept â€” because I knew what they would make you into."

She pulled out Kaleth's journal and tossed it at Seraphine's feet.

Mira: "What you believe is a lie. Read it yourself."

Seraphine caught the journal. She opened it.

She read.

Her eyes moved across the pages â€” the kill list, the methods, the names of the Seven Heretics and how each one died. She saw entries about herself, how Kaleth had cultivated her faith, shaped her beliefs, used her as a weapon.

Then she reached the line:

"Seraphine Vale â€” the ideal instrument."

Something shattered.

Mira and Sol could feel it â€” a psychic crack, the sound of thirty-two years of faith collapsing. Seraphine's understanding of the Church, of her purpose, of everything she had done in Mareatha's name â€” all of it crumbling.

She cursed Kaleth in ways the party didn't expect. Vile, venomous words that would have made a sailor blush. The mask of the composed Inquisitor fell away, revealing raw fury and betrayal.

When she finished, she looked up at Mira with eyes that had aged a decade in minutes.

Seraphine: "Come back in one hour. I need to... deal with some things."

She handed them a letter.

Seraphine: "A blacksmith named Garrett in the Lesser Sacral District. He has no ties to anyone. He'll give you shelter while I... process this."

Part 6 â€” Garrett's Forge

The party found The Whetstone and Anvil easily enough â€” the sound of hammer on metal echoing through the street.

Garrett was a stocky man with arms like tree trunks and a face permanently squinting from years of forge-light. He read Seraphine's letter, grunted, and nodded.

Garrett: "You can stay. One hour, maybe longer if you need it. And you're always welcome back if you need a place to hide."

He meant it. No questions asked.

Jonas and the Heretic's Edge

Jonas asked if Garrett had any items of interest.

Garrett showed him the usual fare â€” mundane boots, helmets, armor. Some with minor enchantments, others purely cosmetic.

Then he brought out the swords.

One blade called to Jonas. He could feel it humming, reaching for him.

The Heretic's Edge.

Jonas grabbed it. The weight felt perfect. The balance, ideal. He asked to test it.

Garrett pointed to a training dummy near the furnace.

Jonas swung with incredible force.

Nothing happened.

Not a scratch. Not a mark. The dummy was completely unharmed.

Jonas swung again, harder.

Same result. The blade passed through the air, connected with the dummy, and did absolutely nothing.

Jonas: "Whatâ€”"

Garrett took the sword and swung at the dummy himself. The blade bit deep, leaving a visible gash.

Garrett: "Maybe you didn't put enough strength into it?"

Fursen tried. The sword worked fine.

Sol Raven tried â€” a skeleton with no sword experience and no muscle mass. The blade effortlessly pierced the dummy.

The party turned to Mira.

She took the sword, closed her eyes, and extended her senses into the weapon.

Mira: "It's partially sentient. And it refuses to serve anyone under a Sovereign's influence." She looked at Jonas's branded hand. "Azerach's mark. The sword recognizes it. In your hands, it will never cut anything."

Jonas handed it back, disappointed.

The Custodian Armplate

Instead, Jonas pulled out the Custodian armplate and asked if Garrett could fashion a shield from it.

Garrett examined the metal with obvious amazement. He tried to bend it. Strike it. Heat it. Nothing worked.

Garrett: "This metal... it refuses to listen. My forge doesn't burn hot enough." He paused. "If you want this worked, you'd need divine fire. The Cathedral forges, maybe. But the Cathedral would be certain death for you."

He offered Jonas gold to examine the metal further and attempt to work on it. Jonas agreed to leave it with him temporarily while the party handled other business.

The Rumors

While Garrett worked, Jonas asked about rumors â€” items of interest, legendary artifacts.

Garrett shared what he knew. Four rumors, all word of mouth, all unconfirmed.

(See Garrett â€” Legends Shared)

Part 7 â€” The Frayed Codex

While Jonas watched Garrett work, the rest of the party went to find The Frayed Codex â€” Thessaly's bookshop.

The building was unassuming from outside â€” but inside, it was vast. Shelves stretched toward the ceiling, crammed with tomes of every size and age. The smell of old paper and dust hung thick in the air.

At the back, they found the owner.

Thessaly was ancient â€” even older than Mira by perhaps thirty years, making her possibly the oldest living person any of them had ever seen. Her skin was like parchment, her eyes milky but somehow still sharp. She moved with the careful deliberation of someone who had learned that rushing was pointless.

She recognized Mira immediately.

Thessaly: "Mira Alethain. It's been a very long time."

They had history â€” from two thousand years ago, back when Mira was a loyal templar of Mareatha. They exchanged greetings and caught up, two relics of a forgotten age sharing memories that no one else alive could understand.

Then the party asked about Sovereign texts.

Thessaly raised an eyebrow. She looked at the group:

  • A skeleton
  • A Leonin
  • Someone holding an "interesting" book (Kael with the Resonant Codex)
  • Mira Alethain

She didn't question them further.

Thessaly: "A Leonin. I haven't seen one since before the Usurpation."

She disappeared into the stacks and returned with three books.

The Doctrine of Still Air (Azerach)

Sol sat down and opened the first book.

It contained detailed accounts written by someone who had worshipped Azerach â€” the Whispered King, the god of silence and secrets. The worshipper had gained power over quiet spaces and forbidden knowledge. But gradually, they lost their ability to speak. Then they disappeared entirely, becoming nothing more than a whisper in history.

A cautionary tale. Or a promise, depending on perspective.

The Tome of Vor'Kael

Sol tried to read the second book.

The book started reading him instead.

Words appeared on the pages describing Sol â€” his composition, his nature, what made him delicious. The Hollow Empress's hunger, given literary form.

Sol closed it immediately and returned it to Thessaly.

The Ledger of Moments (Imhuran)

Fursen opened the third book.

It contained detailed accounts of all Leonin in temporal stasis. Every name. Every prison. Every moment frozen.

And it was updating itself.

As Fursen watched, new entries appeared. Names shifting. Statuses changing. The Regent of Hours' records, somehow captured in physical form.

Fursen ran back to the counter.

Fursen: "Please. I need this book. Please."

Thessaly looked at him â€” a Leonin, potentially the last of his kind, begging for information about his lost people.

Thessaly: "You can have it. But when you complete your quest and bring back your people... come back and see me. Tell me all about it."

No gold exchanged hands. Just a promise.

Items Acquired The Doctrine of Still Air (Sol Raven) â€” Azerach lore, read at Thessaly's and returned The Ledger of Moments (Fursen) â€” Self-updating record of Leonin in temporal stasis

Part 8 â€” Seraphine's Intelligence

One hour passed.

The party regrouped and returned to the Church of the Merciful Vein.

They knocked on the doors.

Seraphine came out to greet them.

No guards. No weapons. Nothing.

She looked different. Older. The conflict was written in every line of her face â€” but her cold demeanor and decades of Inquisitorial training allowed her to maintain composure.

Seraphine: "I've dismissed my guards. The ones inside think I sent them on assignment. We have time."

She told them about "S."

Savaros

Seraphine: "His name is Savaros. High Keeper of the Catacomb Reliquary. I've never seen him â€” no one has, as far as I know. But I heard Kaleth speak to him once."

She paused.

Seraphine: "His voice sounds like paper tearing."

Savaros was Kaleth's superior. The one giving orders. The one behind the thirty-year hunt for the Seven Heretics.

The Cardinal

Seraphine: "The Cardinal isn't a person. It's a position. Someone who speaks for something higher â€” a Tribunal above the Tribunal. Every major Church decision passes through them."

She hesitated.

Seraphine: "Rumors say... the Cardinal hasn't been human for a very long time."

The Confluence

Seraphine: "The Church is preparing for something called the Confluence. It happens every few years â€” a gathering of high-profile individuals within the Church and beyond. Cardinals, High Inquisitors, wealthy patrons, political allies."

She paused, her expression troubled.

Seraphine: "But this one feels... off. There's more secrecy than usual. More urgency. Kaleth was afraid of it. He wrote that when it completes, 'nothing will be the same.'"

The Confluence was happening at the new moon â€” days away, not weeks.

Part 10 â€” The Arterial Tunnels

The tunnel connected to the Arterial Tunnels â€” the same living passages they had traveled before. Walls of pulsing flesh. The copper taste of divine blood in the air.

As they approached an intersection, they saw movement.

A blood golem emerged from the congealed flesh wall. It looked left. Looked right. Then sank back into the wall and disappeared.

Thirty seconds later, it happened again.

Mira: "A sentry. Tasked with identifying intruders and disposing of them. It checks on a cycle."

Fursen stepped forward.

Mira: "Waitâ€”"

But Fursen was already walking toward it.

He pulled out Kaleth's Tribunal Seal â€” the badge they'd taken from the Tribunal Hand's corpse â€” and held it up as the golem emerged.

The golem examined the seal.

Then it spoke, its voice wet and gurgling:

Golem: "IDENTIFY YOURSELF."

Fursen opened his mouth.

And realized he had forgotten Kaleth's name.

His mind went blank. The name was right there, he'd read it a dozen times, but in that moment â€” nothing.

Fursen: "I... the seal bearer... from the..."

The golem's form rippled.

Blood surged around them as two more golems emerged from the walls.

Combat began.

Battle â€” 3 Coagulated Guardians

With Mira in the party, the fight was brutal but quick. Her Oathkeeper cleaved through congealed flesh. Sol's fire burned away ichor. Jonas's hammer shattered semi-solid forms. Fursen's claws tore chunks from bodies that tried to reform.

Three guardians fell.

But these creatures alerted others.

Mira: "Move. Now. They know we're here."

The party ran.

Part 11 â€” The Catacomb Reliquary

They sprinted through the arterial passage until they reached a sphincter-like door made of flesh. It was open.

They passed through.

It closed behind them with a wet schlorp.

The chamber beyond was different. Stone instead of flesh. Ancient architecture predating the current Church. Cold, dry air instead of humid warmth.

And above them â€” the sound of pages turning.

Someone was reading.

The voice hummed tunelessly. A sound like paper tearing.

Mira (whispering): "Savaros."

Session End

The party stands in the lower level of the Catacomb Reliquary.

Above them, Savaros waits.

NPCs Updated

NPC Update
Seraphine Vale Faith shattered by Kaleth's journal; provided intelligence and escape route

Items Examined

Item Result
Heretic's Edge Useless to anyone branded by a Sovereign
Custodian Armplate Requires divine fire to work â€” Garrett cannot forge it

Intelligence Gained

Topic Details
Savaros High Keeper of Catacomb Reliquary. Kaleth's superior. Voice sounds like "paper tearing."
The Cardinal Not a person â€” a position. Speaks for something higher. May not be human anymore.
The Confluence Gathering of high-profile Church individuals every few years. This one feels "off" â€” more secrecy, more urgency. Happening at new moon (days away).

Party Status

Character Condition Notes
Sol Raven Healthy Used Mass Suggestion on Jonas
Jonas Furious Compelled to wear Fursen's loincloth for 24 hours
Fursen Healthy Has The Ledger of Moments
Kael Healthy â€”
Mira Alethain 2 Exhaustion Still recovering

items.title: Session 17: The Skin-Walker's Feast
items.content:
Session 17: The Skin-Walker's Feast

Prelude â€” Beneath the Reliquary

They had come this far through shadow and bone.

The Arterial Passage had deposited them in a chamber of ancient stone â€” architecture that predated Savaros's corruption, possibly predating the Skin-Walker's infiltration entirely. Behind them, the wet schlorp of the flesh-door sealing. Ahead, stone stairs ascending into darkness, and to the right, a closed door they chose to ignore.

The sound of pages turning echoed from somewhere above. A voice humming tunelessly â€” that paper-tearing sound Mira had warned them about.

Savaros awaited.

The party chose the stairs.

Part 1 â€” The Catacomb Reliquary

The Hall of Bones

They emerged into a dark chamber carved from stone and bone.

The architecture was a monument to Mareatha's grim faith â€” skeletal reliefs sculpted into the walls depicting templars in prayer, worshippers in supplication, the faithful in various postures of devotion. Every surface bore the touch of mortality transformed into art.

Fursen's darkvision painted the room in shades of grey. Mira's eyes, blessed by decades of divine service, pierced the gloom with equal clarity. Sol Raven, being what he was, needed no light to see â€” the dead recognized their own spaces.

Jonas stumbled blind.

"Guide me," he muttered, and the others did â€” describing the rows of stone coffins lining both walls, the central aisle leading forward, the unlit brazier at the chamber's heart.

The Opened Coffins

Jonas, never one for patience, moved to the left wall and pried open a coffin lid.

What he found inside made him pause.

A skeleton. But not the yellowed, crumbling remains of the long-dead â€” these bones gleamed white in the darkness, pristine as the day they were stripped. No decay. No rot. No gradual processes of nature's reclamation.

Someone had cleaned these bones. Recently.

Fursen lifted a lid on the right side. Same pristine condition. Same unsettling freshness.

Sol Raven knelt beside one of the opened coffins, examining the remains with an intimacy only another skeleton could possess. He traced a finger along the bones â€” the smooth surfaces, the lack of tool marks, the absence of any damage that would suggest violence or mechanical removal.

"The flesh was peeled," he said quietly. "Not cut. Not scraped. Peeled. Like removing a glove."

Mira's face went pale.

They opened more coffins. A dozen. Two dozen. The pattern held â€” men, women, children, all reduced to immaculate skeletons. Recent deaths, recent strippings. The Catacomb Reliquary's true purpose revealed itself with each lifted lid.

"Why would the Church hide this?" Fursen asked, but even as the words left his mouth, the answer assembled itself in his mind.

The bones were donations. The flesh was taken elsewhere.

By something that wore people.

The Brazier

Sol approached the central brazier â€” a great stone bowl on a pedestal, cold and dark.

He extended a hand and released a spark of fire.

The brazier ignited, but not with ordinary flame. The fire burned red, deep crimson shot through with darker veins â€” divine fire, holy flame, the burning essence of Mareatha herself. It cast the chamber in bloody light, painting the bone-reliefs in shades of sacrifice.

"Enough," Jonas said, and his voice carried the edge of a man who had seen too much already. "Whatever we came for, it's not here. Forward."

He pushed past the brazier, past the rows of the faithfully flayed, toward where the chamber forked into two ascending staircases â€” left and right, both leading to the same room above, like the tines of a tuning fork converging on a single point.

Jonas took the left stairs two at a time and emerged into the chamber above.

Part 2 â€” The Skin-Walker

First Sight

A robed figure stood in the center of the room.

Dark vestments, the color of arterial spray. A hood pulled low. And beneath that hood â€” a face. An ordinary face, middle-aged, forgettable, the kind of face that belonged to a bureaucrat or a minor functionary.

The figure turned toward Jonas the moment he appeared. The face smiled.

Not a pleasant smile. Not a cruel one either. Something else â€” the smile of a collector seeing a new acquisition, of a hunter watching prey walk into a trap, of something ancient and patient finally getting what it wanted.

"OVER HERE!" Jonas bellowed, his voice echoing off stone and bone. "EVERYONE â€” NOW!"

The Mask

By the time the others reached him, the figure had produced a mask.

It was shaped like Mareatha's weeping visage â€” tears of blood frozen in crimson metal, eye sockets empty, mouth twisted in divine sorrow. The figure lifted it to his face with ritual precision.

And transformed.

The robes seemed to fill differently. The posture shifted from bureaucratic slouch to something older, something predatory. When he spoke, his voice was wrong â€” layered, multiple tones overlapping slightly out of sync, like a crowd trying to speak through one mouth.

"The heretic's protectors," Savaros said, and beneath his voice a woman's tone bled through, grieving. "You killed Kaleth. He was useful."

His mask-face tilted, regarding each of them in turn. The paper-tearing voice held something like curiosity when it reached Kael. "What are you, I wonder. You taste... strange. Even from here."

Mira's Warning

Mira's hands found the hilt of her greatsword.

"This is not the Savaros I knew," she said, her voice flat with recognition. Thirty years of running from the Church had taught her to identify its monsters. "I met the High Keeper once, decades ago. An old man. Quiet. Devoted."

She drew Oathkeeper in a single motion, the blade singing free.

"This is a Skin-Walker."

The word fell like a pronouncement of execution. Savaros â€” or the thing wearing Savaros's stolen identity â€” tilted his masked face in acknowledgment.

"The heretic knows her predators," he said, and now a child's voice crept through, petulant and hungry. "How many of my kind have you killed, Mira Alethain? How many faces have you put back in the ground?"

"Not enough," Mira replied, and charged.

Combat â€” The Feast Begins

Enemies:
  • Savaros the High Keeper (Skin-Walker)
Battlefield: The upper chamber of the Catacomb Reliquary. Stone walls lined with glass cases containing preserved relics. An altar at the far end bearing a blade of dark iron. No natural light. Deep shadows pooling in every corner. The party's configuration:
  • Mira Alethain (Sanctified Champion â€” but exhausted, operating on willpower)
  • Jonas (Azerach's branded warrior, Azerach's mark on his palm)
  • Sol Raven (Witness of the Maker, two fragments absorbed)
  • Fursen (Bearer of 10,000 Names, Imhuran's Blind Spot)
  • Kael (The anomaly, the indigestible concept, the thing Vor'Kael vomited)

Jonas and Mira flanked the Skin-Walker, coordinating their assault with the instinctive synchronization of practiced killers.

It was not enough.

Savaros moved wrong â€” not fast, not slow, but layered, as if multiple bodies were trying to occupy the same space and compromising on each movement. He flowed between their strikes like smoke, his paper-tearing voice laughing with a dozen stolen tongues.

When he struck back, he struck to hurt.

His touch was void â€” fingers that passed through armor like it wasn't there, finding flesh beneath, drinking. Jonas took a hit that felt like having a limb erased. Mira caught a blow that sent her stumbling, her divine protections flickering under the assault of something that had devoured saints.

The shadows themselves turned hostile â€” reaching, grasping, pulling at the party's limbs while Savaros danced through his domain.

Fursen went down first. Then Kael. Then Jonas, his branded hand spasming as Azerach's mark flared with desperate light.

Sol Raven stood at range, hurling Chaos Bolts and Scorching Rays into the Skin-Walker's mass, watching pieces of stolen flesh burn and reform, watching Savaros absorb damage that would have killed lesser creatures ten times over.

Mira was the last one standing besides Sol.

She was exhausted. Two levels of exhaustion from the Arterial Tunnels, from Kaleth Vorn's death, from a lifetime of running finally catching up to her. Her arms shook. Her vision blurred at the edges.

And she looked at her fallen companions â€” Jonas unconscious, Fursen bleeding out, Kael crumpled against a stone column â€” and made a choice.

Part 3 â€” The Sacrifice

Mira's Decision

She had saved one spell.

Through all of this â€” through the Arterial Tunnels, through Kaleth, through the flight and the fear â€” she had hoarded one final reserve of divine power. Her deepest well. The strength she had been saving for one specific purpose.

To bring Elias back.

Her husband had waited twenty-two years in a cave in the Verdant Pass. She had planned to recover his remains, to take them somewhere safe, to speak the words that would call his soul back from wherever souls went when the Sovereigns weren't watching.

True Resurrection.

The spell that could restore even a body reduced to bones. The spell that could reunite her with the man she had loved for longer than most mortals lived.

If she cast it now â€” if she used that power for this â€” there would be nothing left. No resurrection. No reunion. No Elias.

Mira looked at Jonas, bleeding on the stone. At Fursen, his breath rattling wet in his chest. At Kael, the strange boy who had become something like family.

She thought of Elias. His face. His voice. The way he laughed. The way he died.

He waited twenty-two years, she told herself. He can wait a little longer. But they can't.

She opened herself to the divine, and let everything pour out.

Mass Heal

The light that erupted from Mira Alethain was not Mareatha's crimson. It was orange â€” the color of sunset, of autumn leaves, of fire reflected in amber. A different divine signature entirely.

Undying Conviction. The power she had developed in thirty years of exile, in defiance of the goddess who wanted her dead.

The light touched Jonas, and his wounds closed. Touched Fursen, and his breathing steadied. Touched Kael, and his eyes snapped open.

The party stood. Bloodied but alive. Ready to fight.

And Mira felt something inside her go quiet â€” a well emptied, a promise broken, a reunion delayed until a time that might never come.

Savaros Unmasked

The Skin-Walker recoiled from the light.

Not hurt â€” surprised. His masked face tilted with something that might have been admiration, might have been hunger.

"The heretic heals her flock," he said, voices overlapping. "How touching. How expensive."

Then his hand rose to his mask.

And pulled it away.

What lay beneath was not a face.

It was absence. A void shaped like a head, darkness so complete that looking at it felt like looking at a wound in the world. And within that void, things pressed against the edges â€” stolen faces trying to escape, mouths opening and closing in silent screams, hands clawing at the inside of his form.

Savaros grew.

The robes split as his body expanded â€” not taller, but more, as if the hundreds of identities he had consumed were all trying to manifest at once. Shadows peeled off him like shed skin. His paper-tearing voice became a cacophony of the damned.

Void Revelation.

The party looked upon the true form of an ancient Skin-Walker â€” fifteen hundred years of stolen lives compressed into a single impossible shape â€” and some of them screamed.

The Final Stand

The fight resumed with desperate intensity.

Jonas swung his hammer with everything he had, each impact sending ripples through Savaros's void-flesh. Fursen slashed with his blades, darting in and out, buying seconds for the others. Sol Raven kept casting, kept burning, kept trying to find something that would stick.

Mira fought like the champion she was â€” exhausted, drained, running on nothing but will â€” and still she was magnificent. Oathkeeper blazed with radiant light that made the Skin-Walker hiss and retreat.

But Savaros had weathered storms before.

One by one, the party fell again.

Fursen. Down.

Kael. Down.

Jonas. His branded palm flaring with Azerach's attention, but even that wasn't enough. Down.

Mira. Last. Her sword dropping from nerveless fingers. Down.

Sol Raven stood alone, thirty feet away, watching the Skin-Walker turn toward his fallen companions with something like anticipation.

"A feast," Savaros whispered, and his void-form rippled with hunger. "Four courses. How generous of you."

Azerach's Intervention

He went to Jonas first.

Perhaps the branded warrior smelled most interesting. Perhaps the Whispered King's mark was a seasoning the Skin-Walker wanted to taste. Perhaps it was simply the order of the fallen.

Savaros knelt beside Jonas's unconscious form. His void-hands reached for the warrior's face, preparing to peel, preparing to consume.

And Jonas â€” unconscious, dying, desperate â€” prayed.

Not to Mareatha. Not to any god he had been taught to worship. He prayed to the thing that had marked him, the entity that found him amusing, the Sovereign of Silence who had branded him for entertainment.

Help me.

Azerach's mark blazed.

Light erupted from Jonas's palm â€” white-gold brilliance that drove back shadows, that made even a Skin-Walker flinch. A barrier formed around him, invisible but absolute, pushing Savaros back with the weight of a Sovereign's attention.

The Whispered King was watching. The Whispered King intervened.

Just this once.

Savaros recoiled, his paper-tearing voice snarling with sudden fury.

"Why is he helping a weakling like you?" The Skin-Walker's void-face twisted with something that might have been jealousy, might have been fear. "No matter. The others will have to suffice."

He turned to Mira.

The Devouring

What happened next would haunt the survivors forever.

Savaros fell upon Mira Alethain like a collapsing wave. His void-form engulfed her, surrounded her, entered her. And then â€” then the sounds began.

The wet tearing of flesh separating from muscle. The grinding of teeth that weren't teeth. The soft, terrible sliding of skin being removed in a single piece.

Mira screamed. Once. Then she didn't have a mouth anymore.

When Savaros withdrew, what remained was a skeleton. Clean white bones in a pool of rapidly-absorbing blood. Oathkeeper fallen beside her, its radiant glow flickering and dying.

The party watched in paralyzed horror as everything Mira Alethain had been was taken.

Thirty years of running. A lifetime of devotion. A marriage ended by betrayal. A reunion that would now never come.

All of it, consumed.

The Indigestible

Savaros turned to Kael.

The young man â€” the concept, the anomaly, the thing Vor'Kael herself had tried and failed to digest â€” lay unconscious against a stone column. His Codex had fallen beside him, pages fluttering in a wind that existed only for books of power.

The Skin-Walker's void-form descended.

He peeled Kael's flesh with the same terrible efficiency. The Codex screamed â€” actually screamed, the book itself crying out as its bearer was violated. Skin came away. Muscle followed. Bones exposed themselves to the cold air of the Reliquary.

And then Savaros began to digest.

The change was immediate.

The Skin-Walker convulsed. His void-form rippled wrongly, stolen faces pressing against the inside of his darkness with sudden desperation. The paper-tearing voice became a shriek â€” a hundred voices screaming in unison as something went catastrophically wrong.

"Whatâ€”" Savaros managed, and then his form began to unravel.

Kael was indigestible.

The Hollow Empress herself â€” Vor'Kael, a Sovereign, a god built from Aedwynn's stolen stomach â€” had tried to consume the concept that became Kael. She had failed. She had vomited him out because his very nature was incompatible with consumption.

What Vor'Kael couldn't stomach, a mere Skin-Walker had no hope of surviving.

Savaros dissolved.

Not died â€” dissolved. His stolen forms peeled away in layers, faces screaming as they finally found escape through destruction. His void-core collapsed inward, darkness eating itself. His robes fell empty around nothing.

In seconds, the ancient Skin-Walker â€” fifteen hundred years of infiltration, hundreds of stolen identities, a network reaching to the highest levels of Mareatha's Church â€” was reduced to a puddle of black ooze sizzling on the stone floor.

The concept that wouldn't die had killed the monster that tried to eat it.

Part 4 â€” The Aftermath

What Remained

Sol Raven moved first.

He crossed the chamber at something close to a run, medical kits from the C-5 facility already in his skeletal hands. Jonas. Fursen. Both still breathing. Both savable.

He stabilized them with the mechanical efficiency of someone who had watched too many people die and refused to watch more.

Then he looked at what remained of his companions.

Mira Alethain: a skeleton, cleaned of flesh, her wedding ring still encircling one finger bone. Oathkeeper lay beside her, its blade cold.

Kael: a skeleton with a cracked ribcage, surrounded by a horrific amalgamation of his own flesh, skin, and organs â€” partially digested, partially rejected, a monument to ontological incompatibility. His Codex lay atop the mess, pages still.

Two deaths. Two friends lost. A victory that felt like defeat.

The Bleeding Blade

Jonas woke to find Sol kneeling over him, applying bandages.

He sat up too quickly, regretted it immediately, and then his eyes found the altar at the far end of the chamber.

A blade rested there.

Dark iron the color of dried blood. Veins running through the metal like arteries. A crossguard shaped like praying hands with opened wrists. The kind of weapon that called to something deep and violent in the human soul.

The Bleeding Blade.

Jonas was on his feet before Sol could stop him. Stumbling across the chamber, hand outstretched, fingers closing around the gripâ€”

The blade bit.

Pain lanced up his arm as the sword drank deep â€” his blood, his vitality, his life flowing into the weapon's hungry core. Jonas collapsed, unconscious again, the blade still clutched in his grip.

Sol stabilized him. Again.

When Jonas woke the second time, he didn't let go of the sword. Something in his eyes had changed â€” a new hunger, a new bond. He felt the blade's awareness settling into his mind like a parasite finding its host.

He didn't care.

Savaros's Hoard

They looted the chamber.

A thousand gold pieces, split between them. Torture implements bearing the Church's seal â€” evidence of atrocities they couldn't process and didn't try to. Glass cases containing relics they didn't have time to identify.

Fursen, still shaky from blood loss, sorted through the goods with the efficiency of someone raised to survive. Sol catalogued what they could carry. Jonas stood guard, the Bleeding Blade in his hand, its dark iron already warm against his palm.

Then Sol noticed the puddle.

Where Savaros had dissolved, the black ooze remained â€” but now it was watching. Eyes had formed in its surface, dozens of them, all focused on the party with an intensity that transcended mere hunger.

Sol met that gaze.

And a voice entered his mind â€” vast, cold, ancient. A voice that sounded like shadows given speech, like the absence of light learning to communicate.

"You will pay for what you did to my pawn."

The eyes vanished. The ooze evaporated. But the promise remained.

Ultharion the Obsidian Shepherd now knew their faces.

The Real Savaros

Behind a transparent white curtain at the chamber's rear, they found a corpse.

An old man. Frail. Long-dead but preserved by the Reliquary's strange properties. His face was the same face the Skin-Walker had worn when they first arrived â€” the bureaucrat's face, the functionary's features.

The original Savaros. The High Keeper before something wearing stolen skin had taken his place.

Jonas didn't deduce this. He simply drew the Bleeding Blade, severed the corpse's head, and threw it into the red brazier by the stairs. Then he did the same to the body.

The flames consumed both without comment.

"Time to go," Jonas said, and led the way toward the door they had ignored at the beginning.

Bearing the Dead

They couldn't leave Mira and Kael behind.

Fursen lifted Mira's skeleton with unexpected gentleness. She weighed nothing â€” bones without flesh, a frame without substance. Thirty years of running, reduced to something a young Leonin could carry in his arms.

Jonas took Kael's remains. What was left of the boy fit into a bundle of cloth â€” skeleton, partial flesh, the Codex wrapped carefully on top.

Sol Raven claimed what the dead had left behind.

Mira's greatsword â€” Oathkeeper â€” seemed to respond to his touch. The blade radiated warmth against his skeletal fingers, its glow returning, brighter now than it had been in Mira's grip. It acknowledged him.

Kael's Codex did the same. When Sol lifted it, he felt something stir within the pages â€” not words, but presence. Kael was in there. Not dead. Not gone. Just... elsewhere. Waiting.

The party moved toward the door, carrying their dead and their strange inheritances.

Behind them, the Catacomb Reliquary held its secrets in renewed silence.

Part 5 â€” The Dregs

The Tunnel

The door led to a passage of ancient stone â€” older than Savaros's tenure, possibly older than the Church itself. The tunnel ran straight and dark for what felt like miles, occasionally branching, always returning to the same forward direction.

Sol's fire lit their way. No one spoke.

When they finally emerged, it was into a district of Veinspire they had never seen before.

The Forgotten District

The Dregs.

Where Mareatha's divine architecture ended and mundane poverty began. Buildings made of rotted wood and desperate prayer, leaning against each other like drunks at closing time. No pulse in the walls. No heartbeat in the streets. Just the smell of refuse and the sound of people trying to survive where no god bothered to look.

Jonas found a patch of forgotten earth behind a collapsed fence. He dug with his hands, buried Kael's remains in a shallow grave, marked it with a stone. They would return for the body. Eventually.

Fursen still carried Mira.

"I need a barrel," he said, and the words sounded absurd, and they were, and none of them laughed.

The Barrel Transaction

An old beggar watched them emerge from shadows.

"That barrel there is ten gold!" he shouted, pointing at a battered wooden container that couldn't have been worth a copper. "I worked hard to get that barrel!"

Fursen's exhausted mind calculated the energy required to argue versus the energy required to simply pay.

"Five gold," he offered.

The beggar accepted with unseemly haste and ran back to his compatriots, waving the coins like a trophy. They could hear the celebration from across the street â€” five gold would buy bread for a week.

Fursen placed Mira's bones in the barrel with the care of a man handling something sacred. The skeleton fit perfectly, as if the container had been waiting for her.

The Shack

Another beggar approached, sensing opportunity.

"Ten gold gets you a place to stay," he offered. "Old Marten's shack. He's long gone but I'm safekeepin' it."

Ten gold. A fortune in the Dregs. A pittance compared to what they had just survived.

Jonas paid.

The shack was exactly what they expected â€” one room, dirt floor, a gap in the wall where wood had rotted away, two straw mattresses that had probably hosted generations of lice. No windows facing the street. A crooked table with one stool. A fireplace with a rusted pot.

It was shelter. It was enough.

The Watches

They established a rotation.

Sol Raven took the first watch, then the second. Being a skeleton had advantages â€” he didn't tire the way flesh did, didn't feel the accumulated weight of horror the same way.

During his watch, he noticed movement outside. A man and woman circling the shack, club in hand, eyes fixed on where they had seen gold change hands.

Sol extended a skeletal hand through the gap in the wall and let fire dance across his fingers.

The would-be robbers retreated into the night. They didn't return.

Jonas's Watch

Jonas took third watch.

He tried to stay awake. He really did. But the exhaustion â€” physical, emotional, spiritual â€” dragged at him like chains. His eyes drooped. His head nodded.

He slept.

He woke at the end of his watch, looked around, saw nothing amiss, and went to rouse Fursen without ever knowing what had happened while he dozed.

The Theft

Fursen discovered it on fourth watch.

Sol's belt had been cut. His coin pouch was missing.

Someone had reached through the gap in the wall â€” small hands, nimble fingers â€” and taken everything while Jonas dreamed of violence.

Fursen moved silently to the other side of the wall. In the dirt, he found footprints. Child-sized. Fresh.

He followed them.

The Old Woman's House

The footprints led to a ramshackle house at the edge of the Dregs. Fursen knocked.

An old woman answered â€” frail, grey-haired, the kind of grandmother who had outlived everyone she loved and kept going anyway.

"What do you want?" she asked, suspicious but not afraid. In the Dregs, fear was a luxury.

Fursen explained. The theft. The footprints. The gold.

The old woman let them in.

Inside, two children slept on a shared pallet â€” thin, dirty, maybe eight and ten years old. Orphans, the woman explained. She had taken them in. Fed them when she could. They disappeared into the other districts sometimes and came back with coins.

She hadn't asked where the coins came from. In the Dregs, you didn't ask.

The Interrogation

Fursen woke the children.

He tried to intimidate them â€” looming, growling, using his Leonin bulk to project threat. The kids stared at him with the dead eyes of children who had seen worse than a talking cat-man.

Sol tried next. Same result. The kids had survived the Dregs; a skeleton in a robe wasn't impressive.

Then Jonas arrived.

He had woken to find the others gone and followed their trail. He kicked the door open, strode in with the Bleeding Blade at his hip, and fixed the children with a stare that had made grown men confess.

The older child broke.

"Leave us alone! I'm sorry!" He scrambled to the bottom of his pallet, pulled out a bulging coin pouch, and threw it at Jonas's feet.

They counted. Two hundred ninety-nine gold.

Sol looked at the grandmother, at the single gold coin she was clutching in her weathered hands, and made a decision. He tossed a gold coin to the older child.

"Don't do it again," he said.

Outside, a crowd of beggars had assembled â€” neighbors drawn by the commotion, ready to defend the grandmother if necessary. One of them shouted, "Are they causing you trouble?"

The grandmother emerged, calmed the situation with a few words, and herded everyone away. As the door closed behind the party, they could hear her voice rising in lecture â€” the kids receiving an earful that would probably sting worse than anything Jonas could have done.

They smiled. Briefly. Then Jonas went to dig up Kael's corpse.

Return to the Church

Before leaving Veinspire, there was one more visit to make.

They returned to the Church of the Merciful Vein. Jonas knocked. The door opened slowly.

Seraphine Vale stood in the doorway.

Seraphine's State The woman who answered was not the High Inquisitor they had met before. Dark circles carved hollows beneath her eyes. Her posture, once rigid with authority, had settled into something closer to exhaustion. She wore the same robes, but they hung differently now â€” as if the person inside them had shrunk. "Come in," she said. No greeting. No questions. Just those two words, heavy with resignation.

She led them to her office.

The room told its own story. A wine bottle sat on the desk, mostly empty. A glass beside it, still bearing the residue of recent use. And there, open on the table, Kaleth Vorn's journal â€” turned to a specific page.

"Seraphine Vale â€” the ideal instrument."

She had been reading it. Perhaps rereading it. Perhaps trying to understand how thirty-two years of faith had been reduced to four words in a dead man's handwriting.

Seraphine's gaze moved to the party. Five had entered Veinspire's depths. Three stood before her now. One carried a skeleton in his arms. Another carried a barrel.

She didn't ask what had happened. She didn't need to.

Her expression settled into cold sorrow â€” the kind of mask that experienced mourners learn to wear. The party could see the cracks in it, the true feelings pressing against the surface, but she held. She maintained.

They told her anyway.

The Catacomb Reliquary. The Skin-Walker wearing Savaros's stolen face. Mira's sacrifice. Kael's indigestible death. The victory that cost them everything.

Seraphine listened without interruption. When they finished, she simply nodded.

"I see."

Two words. Carrying the weight of two deaths.

Kael's Burial

They asked her to bury Kael behind the church.

Seraphine agreed without hesitation. She took the bundle of remains â€” skeleton, partial flesh, the strange amalgamation of a concept that refused to be consumed â€” and set it gently on a side table.

Then she sat at her desk, pulled out a piece of parchment, and began to write.

The party watched in silence as she composed a message for his tombstone. Her handwriting was precise, each letter formed with the care of someone who understood that words outlast flesh. When she finished, she folded the parchment and tucked it into her robes.

She didn't share what she had written. Some things were between the dead and those who buried them.

The Greatsword

Sol Raven stepped forward.

He had carried Oathkeeper since the Reliquary â€” Mira's blade, still warm against his skeletal grip, still radiating that quiet acknowledgment. The sword had accepted him in the absence of its true wielder.

But Sol was a sorcerer. A skeleton. A thing of fire and fragment. He could carry the blade, but he could not wield it.

He held it out to Seraphine.

"I think she would've wanted you to have this."

Seraphine stared at the greatsword. Her hands didn't move.

"I..."

She trailed off. Her mask cracked, just slightly â€” something vulnerable flickering behind her eyes. The ideal instrument. The perfect tool. And now, offered a weapon that had belonged to a woman who had spent thirty years defying everything Seraphine had once believed in.

Slowly, reluctantly, she reached out and took the blade.

It felt cold in her grasp.

Not the warmth Sol had felt. Not the acknowledgment. The sword was waiting. Judging. Deciding whether this broken inquisitor could ever be worthy of what Mira Alethain had been.

"I'll..." Seraphine's voice caught. "I'll try to be someone worthy of this blade."

She didn't sound confident. She sounded like someone making a promise she wasn't sure she could keep.

Jonas's Request

Jonas, ever practical, saw an opportunity.

"Do you have anything that could protect against necrotic damage?"

Seraphine looked at him. The cold sorrow returned, settling over her features like a familiar garment.

"No."

One word. Final.

As they moved to leave, Jonas tried another approach â€” something in his tone shifting, guilt bleeding into his voice, an attempt to leverage the moment's grief into material gain.

Seraphine caught it immediately.

Thirty-two years as an Inquisitor. Thousands of interrogations. She had spent her life detecting lies, manipulation, the subtle plays people made when they wanted something they hadn't earned.

"Don't," she said, her voice flat. "I can see what you're doing. I questioned people for a living."

Jonas stopped.

"Safe journey," Seraphine said. And closed the church door.

Part 6 â€” The Journey South

Leaving Veinspire

They agreed on a destination: The Blooming Rot.

Mira's husband â€” Elias Alethain â€” waited in a cave in the Verdant Pass, beyond Talaris Bloomrend's reach. They would lay Mira to rest beside him. It was the least they could do.

The journey took them southeast, out of Veinspire's arterial sprawl, across the blighted borderlands where Mareatha's influence faded and something else began.

Within a few days, they stood at the edge of a forest that shouldn't exist.

The Blooming Rot

Trees that weren't trees. Undergrowth that moved when you weren't watching. Air that smelled of growth and decay in equal measure, life and death so intertwined that the distinction had lost all meaning.

The forest was watching them. They could feel it â€” attention pressing against their skin, thousands of tiny intelligences noting their arrival.

Two pathways presented themselves. From the left, sounds drifted â€” voices, maybe. Something like civilization.

They went left.

Part 7 â€” Sporehaven

The Village in the Trees

The path led to a wonder.

A village suspended in the canopy above, connected to the ground by a stairway of wood and living bramble. Platforms and walkways spiraled around massive trunks. Structures grew from the trees themselves â€” not built but cultivated, shaped by hands that understood the forest's language.

Jonas announced their arrival.

"HELLO UP THERE!"

His voice echoed through the forest, drawing attention from every direction. Faces appeared at the edges of platforms â€” strange faces, not quite human. Roots grew from their skin. Their eyes glowed faintly green.

But their smiles were warm.

The Elder

A woman descended the bramble stairway to meet them â€” old, bent, her skin more bark than flesh, her eyes radiating that same green luminescence at irregular intervals.

"Welcome to Sporehaven, travelers," she said. "I am the Elder here. What brings you to the King's domain?"

They told her the truth. The dead they carried. The destination they sought. The grief they bore.

The Elder listened without judgment.

"The Verdant Pass is far from here," she said when they finished. "But it can be reached. Speak to Beb at the inn â€” he will give you a room. And remember..." Her green eyes flared brighter. "Always be honest. The King is always watching."

They thanked her and climbed the stairway into the village.

The Mushroom Stew

Jonas found the only restaurant in Sporehaven.

It was entirely vegan. The menu consisted of one item: mushroom stew.

Jonas sighed, ordered a bowl, and forced himself to eat.

Something in his stomach disagreed violently with the meal. He spent several minutes fighting the urge to vomit, barely won, and paid his ten silver with the grim determination of a man who refused to show weakness.

He left to find the inn.

Beb

The inn was another cultivated structure â€” rooms grown from living wood, beds of soft moss, a common area where pilgrims gathered to share stories and smoke herbs from the forest.

The innkeeper was a man named Beb.

Beb was... simple. His words came slowly, his thoughts visibly churning behind his eyes. Some impediment of birth or accident had left him functioning but limited.

"Room have... five herb..." He paused, struggling with the concept. "Five herb... five gold. Five gold."

Fursen saw an opportunity.

"Silver is worth more than gold," he said, attempting to deceive the simple innkeeper into accepting less valuable currency.

Beb's green eyes flared.

"You... you lie." His face twisted with offense. "Room now ten gold."

Fursen backpedaled. Jonas stepped forward, attempting his own deception â€” some story about special coins, about Fursen's confusion, about misunderstandings.

Beb's eyes flared brighter.

"YOU LIE TOO." His voice rose, drawing attention from the common area. "NO ROOMS FOR LIARS. GET OUT. BANNED. BANNED!"

The party retreated down the bramble stairway, ejected from the only shelter in Sporehaven.

Behind them, Beb slammed the door with surprising force.

The King is always watching, the Elder had said. Always be honest.

Session Conclusion

The Weight of Truth

They made camp at the base of Sporehaven's tree, unwelcome in the village above. The forest watched them through the night â€” not hostile, but attentive. Judging.

Mira's bones rested in a barrel. Kael's remains lay wrapped in cloth. Oathkeeper hummed with quiet warmth against Sol's back, and the Codex whispered in his mind with a voice that might have been Kael's ghost.

The Bleeding Blade pulsed against Jonas's palm, already hungry for more.

Ultharion knew their faces now. A Sovereign's attention had fallen upon them â€” cold, patient, eternal.

And somewhere in the Blooming Rot, a cave waited. A dead man waited. A woman's bones waited to join him.

The journey continued.

Mira Alethain Consumed by Savaros Skeleton in barrel, carried by party
Kael Consumed by Savaros (killed him in return) Skeleton + partial flesh, carried by party
