items.content:
Session 21 â€” The Road to Crownfall

Session Overview

Prelude â€” Before Dawn

Thessaly's shop smelled of old paper and older secrets.

The party stood in the narrow space between shelves, the pre-dawn dark pressing against the windows. They had been warned. They had been told. Now they were leaving â€” before the sun rose, before Ultharion's vessel could find them, before the city that had taken so much from them could take anything else.

Thessaly moved through her shop with the efficiency of someone who had said goodbye many times. She pulled a sealed envelope from a drawer, pressed it into Sol Raven's skeletal hand.

"If you're heading south," she said, "find an inn called the Velvet Thorn. In Crownfall. Give this to the woman who runs it."

Inside the envelope: a letter, and a small clay token bearing a mark Sol didn't recognize.

"She'll understand," Thessaly added. "Tell her I sent you. That should be enough."

The party thanked her. There wasn't time for more.

Part 1 â€” Departure

The Summoning

They left Veinspire through the southern gate, three figures in the grey hour before dawn when the guards were tired and the questions were few. The arterial walls pulsed behind them â€” that constant heartbeat that had become background noise over the weeks â€” growing fainter with each step.

Three hundred yards from the walls, Jonas stopped.

The Bleeding Blade was a bound weapon. He could summon it to his hand from anywhere, dismiss it to wherever bound weapons went when they weren't needed. But summoning required will. Intent. A moment of connection between wielder and weapon.

He hadn't summoned it since claiming it in the Catacomb Reliquary.

Jonas closed his eyes. Reached for the bond. Called the blade.

The Bleeding Blade materialized in his hand â€” dark iron warm against his palm, veins of red pulsing with hungry light. It felt like greeting an old friend who happened to be a predator.

And then he felt something else.

A weight. A pressure. A gaze settling on him from behind, from the direction of Veinspire's walls. Not hostile â€” not yet â€” but aware. Curious. Like something massive had just noticed movement at the edge of its vision.

Jonas's blood went cold.

He dismissed the blade immediately. The gaze lingered for a moment longer â€” that terrible attention still fixed on the space where he stood â€” and then lifted. Moved on. Lost interest, perhaps. Or simply filed the information away for later.

No one needed to speak. They understood.

They moved.

The Gap

The road south took them through the territory between territories â€” the narrow strip of land that belonged to neither Vor'Kael nor Talaris, where reality was merely broken rather than actively hostile.

The Gap, some called it. The Margin. The place where people who couldn't survive in Sovereign domains scratched out existences in the spaces between gods.

The landscape reflected its nature: grey hills rolling into grey sky, scrubland that grew in patches where the ground remembered how to support life, occasional ruins of settlements that had tried and failed to establish permanence. The road was packed earth worn smooth by generations of refugees, merchants, and the desperate.

They walked in silence for the first few hours. The weight of Veinspire fell away slowly â€” the constant pressure of Mareatha's domain, the sense of being watched by walls that were also organs, the copper undertone that everything carried. Here, the air just smelled like dust and distance.

But they weren't alone.

Fursen's head swiveled, nostrils flaring. His Leonin senses caught what human perception missed â€” movement in the scrubland behind them, figures keeping pace at a careful distance. Bandits, most likely. This stretch was known for it.

They kept walking. The figures kept following.

The Bandits

The attack came at midday, when the sun was highest and the shadows shortest.

Five of them emerged from the scrubland â€” rough men and women with rougher weapons, the kind of desperate folk who preyed on travelers in the spaces between protection. Their leader was a scarred woman with a crossbow and the confident stance of someone who had done this many times before.

"Coin and goods," she called out. "Drop them and walk away. Nobody needs toâ€”"

Jonas was already moving.

The Bleeding Blade sang free of its sheath, dark iron catching the light wrong, veins pulsing with anticipation. He crossed the distance before the leader could finish her sentence, before her crossbow could track, before her followers could process what was happening.

The blade drank deep.

Fursen flanked left, moving with the fluid grace of ten thousand ancestors. His fists found joints and pressure points with surgical precision â€” a knee buckled, an elbow shattered, a throat collapsed under the weight of generations of martial knowledge.

Sol Raven didn't move from the road. He simply raised one skeletal hand and released a Scorching Ray that caught a bandit mid-charge, sent them tumbling into the dust trailing smoke and screams.

The fight lasted less than a minute.

Three bandits lay dead. The leader and one survivor fled the moment they realized what they'd stumbled into â€” disappearing into the scrubland without looking back, running with the desperate speed of people who had just chosen the wrong prey.

The Bleeding Blade hummed contentedly against Jonas's palm as it processed what it had consumed.

They searched the bodies â€” a few silver, a handful of copper, nothing worth the weight â€” and continued south.

But the feeling of being followed didn't fade.

Something else was out there. Something that moved at the edge of perception, that circled their camp at night, that left traces the bandits hadn't.

Something patient.

Part 2 â€” The Hunter

Night One

They made camp in the hollow of a ruined watchtower â€” four walls without a roof, but shelter enough from the wind that cut across the Gap after dark.

Sol took first watch. He didn't need sleep the way the others did, and his supernatural senses made him ideal for the role. Fursen curled near the small fire they'd risked, his fur providing warmth his companions lacked. Jonas lay with his back against stone, one hand on the Bleeding Blade even in sleep.

Three hours into Sol's watch, something crossed the road.

He almost missed it. The movement was wrong â€” too smooth, too deliberate, like something sliding rather than walking. A humanoid shape, but the proportions were off. Too-long fingers. Joints that bent at angles anatomy didn't support.

Sol went still. Stiller than still â€” the perfect motionlessness of bone without breath, without heartbeat, without the small movements that betrayed living things.

The shape paused. Turned toward the watchtower. Stayed perfectly motionless for one heartbeat. Two. Three.

Then it continued across the road and vanished into the darkness on the other side.

Sol waited until dawn to tell the others.

The First Mark

Jonas woke to find a tooth on his chest.

Human. Adult molar. Clean, as if it had been carefully extracted rather than torn free. And carved into the enamel â€” so small he almost missed it â€” was a symbol he recognized.

Vor'Kael's sigil.

His blood went cold.

Something had been in camp. While they slept. Close enough to place a trophy on his chest.

Fursen examined the tooth without touching it. His nostrils flared, catching scents the others couldn't parse. Nothing natural had left this. The smell was wrong â€” like absence, like the space where a smell should be.

Sol told them about the figure crossing the road. The too-long fingers. The wrong proportions. The way it had paused and looked toward them before moving on. One of Vor'Kael's scouts. A Hollow Crawler. It had been tracking them since they entered the Gap.

Jonas picked up the tooth and threw it as far as he could into the scrubland.

It didn't matter. The message had been delivered. Vor'Kael knew they were here. Her servant had come close enough to place a trophy on his chest while he slept.

They moved faster after that. But the thing kept pace.

Days Two Through Seven

The Hollow Crawler was patient.

It never attacked. Never confronted them directly. It simply followed â€” circling their camps at night, leaving trails of handprints that approached to within arm's reach before veering away, reminding them constantly that they were prey and it was hunter.

Day two: They found its tracks around the perimeter of their camp. Footprints with too many toes, pressed too deep into soil that should have resisted such weight.

Day three: Jonas woke to find another tooth â€” this one animal, probably canine â€” placed precisely where the first had been. Same sigil carved into the enamel.

Day four: The Crawler circled their camp three times. Sol counted the passes from his watch, tracking movement by the absence of sound rather than its presence.

Day five: A windstorm swept across the Gap, filling the air with dust and debris. For one blessed night, they couldn't sense the Crawler's presence. Perhaps it had lost their trail in the chaos.

Day six: The tracks returned. Fresher than before. Closer than before. The Crawler had found them again.

Day seven: It circled the camp for four hours straight. Sol watched it move through the darkness â€” that sliding, wrong gait â€” and felt something he hadn't experienced since becoming what he was.

Fear.

Enough was enough. They would end this.

Day Eight â€” The Ambush

They chose the ground carefully.

A narrow defile between two rocky outcroppings, where the road squeezed through a natural chokepoint. Good sightlines. Limited escape routes. The kind of terrain that favored those who arrived first.

The plan was simple: pretend to sleep, wait for the Crawler to approach, then strike before it could retreat.

They took their positions as dusk fell. Jonas lay motionless near the false campfire, his hand on the Bleeding Blade, his breathing slow and even. Fursen crouched in the rocks above, ready to drop on whatever emerged from the darkness. Sol stood at the edge of the firelight's reach, wrapped in shadow, preparing spells he hoped would be enough.

They waited.

Hours passed. The fire burned low. The Gap's night sounds filled the silence â€” wind through scrubland, distant animal calls, the creak of settling stone.

Then: movement.

The Hollow Crawler approached from the south, sliding through the darkness with that terrible wrong gait. It moved slowly, cautiously, circling the campsite at a distance before spiraling closer. Twenty yards. Fifteen. Ten.

It paused at eight yards.

Its head â€” if the thing at the top of its body could be called a head â€” swiveled toward Sol. For a long moment, nothing moved. The Crawler had detected something wrong. Sol's stillness was too perfect. The absence of breath, of heartbeat, of the small movements that betrayed sleeping creatures.

It knew.

Jonas moved first.

He exploded from his false slumber, the Bleeding Blade already singing through the air. The Crawler reacted â€” impossibly fast, joints bending in directions they shouldn't â€” but Jonas was faster. The dark iron caught it across what might have been a shoulder, and the blade drank.

Fursen dropped from above, fists finding purchase on flesh that felt like nothing, that registered as absence beneath his knuckles. He struck nerve clusters that should have existed and found only void.

Sol unleashed fire. Scorching Rays arced through the darkness, slamming into the Crawler's form, illuminating it in strobing flashes of light. For the first time, they saw it clearly.

It was worse than they'd imagined.

Humanoid, yes. But the proportions were a mockery of humanity â€” fingers too long by half, arms that bent backward, a face that was simply smooth where features should have been. It moved like something wearing a body it didn't understand, joints articulating in sequences that made the eyes hurt.

The fight was brutal and brief.

Jonas's blade drank deep with every strike, the Crawler's stolen essence feeding the weapon's endless hunger. Fursen's fists found purchase through sheer determination, each blow costing him skin scraped raw against nothing. Sol's fire burned and burned, reducing the thing's form to smoking ruin piece by piece.

When it finally fell, it didn't die like a living thing. It simply... stopped. Collapsed into itself. Began dissolving into grey sludge that seeped into the earth.

And then they felt it.

A gaze. Vast. Ancient. Hungry. Settling on them from somewhere impossibly distant, somewhere that was simultaneously everywhere and nowhere.

Vor'Kael.

Her attention pressed down on them like the weight of an empty sky. She saw them. She knew them. She knew Jonas â€” the mortal who had spoken her true name in her own domain, who had humiliated her before her brother, who carried the secret that could bind her.

The gaze held for five heartbeats. Ten. An eternity compressed into seconds.

Then it lifted. Moved on. Not because she had lost interest â€” because she had learned what she needed.

She knew. She knew exactly where they were.

They didn't stay. They gathered their supplies and moved, putting as much distance between themselves and the ambush site as they could manage before exhaustion demanded rest.

The Cost

Fursen felt it happen mid-fight.

The Crawler's too-long fingers had brushed his face â€” a moment of contact in the chaos of combat. And then his wisdom teeth simply... fell. Dropped from his jaw, tumbling to the ground, where acid consumed them before his eyes. Dissolving into nothing. Two pieces of himself, unmade in seconds.

He didn't have time to process it until the Crawler was dead. Until the grey sludge was seeping into the earth and Vor'Kael's gaze had lifted.

Then he mourned.

Two teeth. Lower jaw. Wisdom teeth that had been with him his entire adult life. Gone. Not pulled, not broken â€” consumed by something that shouldn't exist, serving a god who only knew how to take.

The gaps ached with phantom pain. His tongue kept finding the empty spaces, probing them like wounds.

Two teeth. Two pieces of himself, now gone forever.

Part 3 â€” The Bone Field

Two Weeks Out

Fourteen days since Veinspire.

The Gap had given way to the true Unclaimed â€” territory that belonged to no Sovereign, where reality was simply less rather than actively corrupted. The landscape here was almost normal: brown grass, scattered trees, a sky that was merely grey rather than veined with power.

They had settled into the rhythm of travel. Walk until exhaustion demanded rest. Rest until paranoia demanded movement. Watch for signs of pursuit that never quite materialized but never quite disappeared either.

Vor'Kael's gaze had lifted after the Crawler's death, but the knowledge of her attention remained. She knew where they had been. She knew which direction they traveled. Sooner or later, she would send something worse.

The bone field announced itself with absence.

No birds. No insects. No wind disturbing the grass. Just silence, spreading outward from a point ahead like ripples in still water.

Something had happened here. Sol's supernatural senses caught what the others missed â€” the wrongness in the air, the weight of old death pressing against present moment.

They crested a rise and saw it.

A valley. Perhaps half a mile across. And filling that valley: bones.

Hundreds of skeletons scattered across the grass. Human, mostly, though some were horses, pack animals, creatures that had been traveling with the humans when whatever happened happened. They lay where they had fallen â€” sprawled, tumbled, frozen in positions that suggested sudden and total death.

At the center of the field: a caravan. Wagons still upright, canvas covers still intact, goods still loaded. As if the people transporting them had simply ceased to exist mid-journey.

Five hundred years. Sol's connection to Aedwynn's shard gave him senses the others lacked â€” the ability to read the age of death, the weight of accumulated time. This had happened five hundred years ago.

But the wagons should have rotted. The canvas should have disintegrated. Five centuries of exposure should have reduced everything to rust and ruin.

Instead, the caravan looked like it had been abandoned yesterday. Preserved. Waiting.

Something was protecting it. Or something was keeping it from decaying.

They descended into the bone field.

The Caravan

The wagons bore a sigil Sol didn't recognize â€” a stylized 'M' wrapped in thorns, the mark of a trading company that had died with its masters.

They found the strongbox first. Iron, locked, surprisingly light for its size. Jonas tried to pry it open and failed â€” the lock resisted his attempts with mechanical stubbornness.

Fursen took it from him, examined the mechanism with practiced eyes, and had it open in seconds. Inside: a leather journal, its pages yellowed but intact. A velvet pouch, heavy with contents. Documents bearing the same thorned 'M' as the wagons.

But it was the corpse that changed everything.

He lay in the lead wagon, positioned as if sleeping. A human man, middle-aged, dressed in traveling clothes that had somehow resisted five centuries of decay. His flesh remained â€” desiccated, leathered, but present. As if he had died only months ago rather than half a millennium.

Around his neck: an amulet. Dull metal, tarnished green with age. It pulsed with a rhythm that was almost heartbeat.

Jonas reached for it.

The corpse's hand shot out and grabbed his wrist.

Jonas didn't flinch â€” couldn't flinch â€” frozen in the grip of something that shouldn't have been able to move. The corpse's eyes opened. Filmed with death, but somehow still seeing. Its mouth worked, trying to form words through a throat that had forgotten how to speak.

"...thank... you..."

The grip released. The eyes closed. And the corpse â€” five hundred years preserved â€” crumbled to dust in a matter of seconds. As if the act of touching the amulet had finally released whatever had held it together.

The amulet fell into Jonas's palm. Still pulsing. Still warm.

Still alive, in some way that had nothing to do with flesh.

The Velvet Pouch

Jonas opened the velvet pouch while Sol examined the amulet.

Inside: gems. Four rubies the color of arterial blood. Three sapphires like captured sky. Four diamonds that caught the light and held it. And one stone that was none of those things.

Black. Perfectly spherical. Small enough to fit in a closed fist. It didn't reflect light so much as absorb it â€” drinking in the illumination around it, giving nothing back.

When Jonas touched it, he felt warmth. Not physical warmth â€” emotional. A sudden surge of feeling that pressed against his chest, made his eyes water, made his heart race for reasons he couldn't explain.

He dropped it back into the pouch immediately.

It wasn't just a gem. It was something else entirely.

They would learn what, soon enough.

The Voice in the Amulet

Sol took the amulet from Jonas.

The moment his skeletal fingers closed around it, he felt the presence inside. Not hostile. Not warm. Simply there â€” a consciousness pressed into metal and magic, waiting for someone who could hear it.

"Hello?" Sol's voice echoed strangely in the silent bone field. "Is someone there?"

The response came not as sound, but as impression. Images. Emotions. Fragments of memory transmitted directly into Sol's mind.

A woman. Young, once. Beautiful, in the way that fire is beautiful â€” dangerous and consuming and impossible to look away from. She had lived in a place of endless heat. She had loved something she shouldn't have. She had stolen something to prevent a catastrophe.

She had been trapped in this amulet for five hundred years.

...can you hear me...?

"Yes," Sol said. "I can hear you. Who are you?"

...velara... velara ashyn... please... don't take me back to her...

"Back to who?"

The amulet pulsed with terror â€” pure, concentrated fear that washed over Sol like a wave of ice water.

...kaedris... the burning one... the sovereign of passion... please... she'll unmake me... she'll unmake everything...

Sol looked at his companions. Jonas had the velvet pouch open, was examining the black stone with wary fascination. Fursen was flipping through the journal, trying to decipher handwriting five centuries old.

They had found something from the Bastion of Fireblood.

The amulet went cold in his hand.

...the bastion... no... no no no... you can't take me there... promise me... promise you won't take me there...

They weren't going to the Bastion. They were going to Crownfall.

...crownfall...

The amulet warmed slightly. Not comfort â€” hope. The first hope it had felt in five hundred years.

...the docent... take me to the docent... he'll know what to do... he'll know how to stop her... ...crownfall... the archive... please... take me there... before she finds out i've been found...

Sol closed his hand around the amulet. Inside, the soul of Velara Ashyn waited â€” terrified, hopeful, desperate.

They would take her to Crownfall. They would find this Docent. And then she would tell them everything.

The amulet pulsed once in gratitude.

They had found what they carried. Now they needed to understand what it meant.

Part 4 â€” Crownfall

Day Twenty-One

The city rose from the plain like a challenge to the sky.

Crownfall. The Free City. The place where refugees from every Sovereign domain mixed with native Unclaimed folk, where exiled nobles rubbed shoulders with desperate fortune-seekers, where the only law that mattered was the law you could enforce.

It rivaled Veinspire in size â€” sprawling across the landscape in districts and wards and neighborhoods that had grown organically over centuries. But where Veinspire pulsed with Mareatha's arterial power, Crownfall simply was. Stone and wood and mortar. No divine architecture. No walls that breathed. Just a city, built by hands, maintained by will.

The walls were forty feet high and showed their age. Guards stood at the southern gate â€” bored, professional, more interested in collecting tolls than asking questions.

"Five silver each," the guard said, barely glancing at them. "Weapons stay sheathed inside the walls. Disputes go to the Council. Welcome to Crownfall."

They paid. They entered. And for the first time in weeks, they breathed air that no Sovereign had touched.

The Velvet Thorn

The Coin District sprawled across the western quarter â€” a maze of markets, money-changers, and establishments that catered to those with coin to spend. The Velvet Thorn occupied a corner building of weathered brick, its sign depicting exactly what its name suggested: a thorned vine rendered in faded gold leaf.

Inside: warmth, lamplight, the smell of decent food and better wine. The common room was half-full with the afternoon crowd â€” merchants discussing trade, travelers recovering from journeys, locals conducting business that probably wasn't entirely legal.

The woman behind the bar matched the establishment. Tall. Silver-white hair pulled back severely. A face that had been beautiful in youth and was now striking. She wore a deep red velvet gown and a thorn-shaped silver brooch at her throat.

Sol approached with the letter Thessaly had given them.

"We're looking for Velvet Thorn," he said. "We were told to give you this."

The woman took the envelope without expression. Broke the seal. Read the contents. Her eyes lingered on the clay token inside.

When she looked up, something had shifted in her expression. Recognition. Assessment. The calculation of debts and obligations that governed life in places like this.

"This is what connections to Thessaly gets you," she said. "Rooms. Three of them. No charge for the first night. After that, standard rates apply."

"Thank you."

"Don't thank me. Thank her." She tucked the letter away. "I'm Velvet. This is my house. My rules are simple: no violence, no theft, no bringing trouble through my door. Break them and you're out. Permanently."

They nodded.

"Good. Rooms are upstairs, second floor, end of the hall. Dinner's at seven. The bath house is across the street if you need it." Her eyes lingered on their travel-worn appearance. "You need it."

They took the rooms. They took the baths. And then they went looking for answers.

The Merchants

Fursen found them at a corner table â€” three men in merchant's clothes, discussing trade routes and profit margins with the comfortable familiarity of longtime colleagues.

"Excuse me," he said, approaching their table. "I'm looking forâ€”"

The words died in his throat. All three merchants had stopped talking. All three were staring at him with expressions of naked astonishment.

"A Leonin," one of them breathed. "An actual Leonin. Here. In Crownfall."

"I never thought I'd see one," another added. "I thought they were all..."

"Gone," the third finished. "Extinct. For two thousand years."

Fursen was accustomed to this reaction. He had been receiving versions of it since emerging from Imhuran's temporal prison. But it never stopped being uncomfortable â€” the reminder that he was the last of his kind, a living relic of a species that had been erased from history.

"I'm looking for someone who can fit custom teeth," he said, pushing past the moment. "Diamond. To replace ones I lost."

The merchants exchanged glances. One of them leaned forward.

"Teeth? Diamond teeth? You want Thresh. Eastern edge of the Kennels district. No sign â€” you have to ask around. But if anyone can do work that strange, it's them."

Fursen thanked them and left. Behind him, he could hear them whispering â€” did you see, an actual Leonin, wait until the guild hears about this.

He was used to it. That didn't make it easier.

Jonas and the Blacksmith

Velvet directed Jonas to the Forge Ward.

"Broma's Forge," she said. "Sign of the cracked anvil. Best smith in Crownfall for unusual work. Tell her I sent you â€” she'll give you a fair price."

The Forge Ward filled the air with the sound of hammers and the smell of hot metal. Broma's shop occupied a corner lot, its sign depicting exactly what Velvet had described: an anvil with a crack running through its center.

Inside: heat, smoke, and a dwarven woman who looked like she had been forged alongside her creations. Short, broad, burn-scarred arms that spoke of decades at the anvil. One eye clouded with old injury. Flames in her forge that burned colors fire shouldn't burn.

"I need a shield," Jonas said. "Custom work. Made from this."

He produced the Custodian armplate â€” the piece of ancient armor they had recovered from the C-5 facility, the material that had protected something that was never meant to exist.

Broma examined it with professional interest. Her expression shifted as she recognized what she was holding.

"Custodian metal," she said. "Pre-Usurpation alloy. Where did you find this?"

"Does it matter?"

"Only for pricing." She turned the armplate in her hands, studying the way light played across its surface. "I can work this. Shape it into a shield. But it won't be cheap, and it won't be fast."

"How much? How long?"

"Two hundred gold. Two weeks minimum, maybe as long as two months. This metal doesn't behave like normal alloys. I'll need time to understand it."

Jonas counted out a hundred gold pieces. "Half now. Half on completion."

Broma swept the coins into her apron. "Deal."

Her eyes drifted to the Bleeding Blade at Jonas's hip. She studied it for a long moment.

"Excellent craftsmanship," she said. Then she frowned slightly. "Though I don't like the way it's looking back at me."

Jonas shifted, moving the blade out of her line of sight. "I have something else. Another piece I wanted to ask about."

He produced the Pulsehammer.

Broma's reaction was immediate. She recoiled as if struck, nearly knocking over a rack of tools. Her face drained of color.

"Get that out of my shop."

"Iâ€”"

"Now."

Jonas didn't argue. He tucked the hammer away and left. Behind him, Broma was already muttering prayers to gods that might or might not exist anymore â€” words of warding, words of protection, words meant to cleanse the space of whatever contamination the Pulsehammer had brought.

The weapon had been touched by three Sovereigns. Eredain, where Jonas had bought it. Azerach, when he'd thrown it at the Bell of the Last Breath. Imhuran, during the 13-Hour Trial. Whatever Broma had sensed in that hammer, it was enough to terrify a woman who worked with passion-fire.

The shield commission stood. But Jonas wouldn't be welcome back until it was ready.

Sol and the Dealer

The Dealer's establishment had no sign, no storefront, no indication that it existed at all. Just a plain green door in a crumbling tenement, three streets past a tavern called the Broken Mug.

Sol knocked. Waited. Knocked again.

The door opened onto darkness. A voice emerged from within â€” soft, sibilant, gender and age impossible to determine.

"Enter. Close the door behind you."

Sol entered.

The space beyond was larger than the building's exterior suggested. Shelves lined every wall, bearing items that glowed, hummed, pulsed, or simply sat with the weight of contained power. The Dealer themselves was a small, hunched figure wrapped in grey cloth, fingers too long, joints too many.

Sol browsed the shelves, looking for quarterstaves and robes â€” equipment suited to his particular talents. The Dealer watched him with eyes that weren't quite visible beneath their wrappings, letting him examine the wares in silence.

One item caught his attention. A cloak of dark fabric that seemed to absorb light, clasped with a simple silver pin. He could feel the enchantment woven through its threads.

"Cloak of Protection," the Dealer said. "+1 to armor class and saving throws. Three hundred gold."

Sol haggled. They settled on two hundred and eighty.

Gold changed hands. Sol donned the cloak. It settled across his skeletal shoulders like it had been made for him.

Jonas had given him a separate task â€” to ask about a legendary weapon. A warhammer called Oathbreaker's End.

The Dealer went still when Sol mentioned it. "That information has a price. Two hundred gold."

Sol counted out Jonas's coins. The Dealer produced a leather folio, pressed it into his hands.

"The Hollow. Three days southeast of Crownfall. What you seek is there. What guards it is worse."

Sol took the folio for Jonas and left.

Thresh

The Kennels district earned its name through atmosphere rather than architecture. The buildings here were older, poorer, packed closer together. The air smelled of too many people in too little space, of poverty and desperation and the stubborn refusal to die.

Fursen found Thresh's workshop after asking three different people and following directions that made no logical sense. No sign marked the door â€” just a plain entrance in a crumbling tenement, indistinguishable from a dozen others.

He knocked.

The door opened.

Thresh defied description. Age indeterminate. Build angular. Six fingers on the left hand, four on the right. One eye human brown, the other a polished sphere of void-touched obsidian that reflected nothing.

They stared at Fursen for a long moment. Their void-eye seemed to see something the human eye missed.

"A Leonin," they said. Not a question. Not quite disbelief either â€” more like someone confirming something they'd only read about in books. "I thought your kind were gone."

"So did everyone else."

Thresh continued to study him with unsettling intensity. Then, as if reaching some internal conclusion, they stepped back and gestured for him to enter.

"You want work done."

"Teeth. Diamond teeth. To replace these." Fursen opened his mouth, showed the gaps where his wisdom teeth had been.

Thresh leaned close, examining the empty spaces with professional interest.

"These weren't pulled," they said. "They were dissolved. Consumed."

Fursen nodded but offered no explanation. Thresh didn't press.

"My standard price for this work would be one hundred gold. Thirty for the cutting, seventy for the fitting with bone-grafted anchor posts."

Fursen reached for his coin pouch.

"But." Thresh held up a six-fingered hand. "I'll halve the price for a true story. Something that cost you. Something that matters."

Fursen considered. Then he did something better.

He recited the Names.

Kaelen Sunstalker. Yira Thornmane. Korrath the Steady. Vaela Duskrunner. Torvek Ironpaw.

The Names poured out of him â€” the ten thousand ancestors that Aedwynn had given him, the complete oral history of the Leonin people, preserved in his memory and his voice and nowhere else in all the world.

Thresh went absolutely still. Their void-eye deepened to pure black, drinking in the Names like water into parched earth.

When Fursen finished, the silence stretched for a long moment.

"How do you know those names?" Thresh's voice was barely a whisper.

"A dead god gave them to me."

Thresh stared at him. Then, slowly, deliberately, they waived all payment.

"Keep your gold. Keep your diamonds. I'll cut them. I'll set them. And I'll ask one thing in return."

"What?"

"Remember me." Thresh's voice carried a weight that transcended the simple words. "When you're gone â€” when I'm gone â€” when Crownfall is dust and the Sovereigns are forgotten â€” remember that there was someone called Thresh, who heard the Names, and was moved."

Fursen met their mismatched eyes. "I will remember you."

"Good."

The procedure took an hour. No numbing agents â€” Thresh said they dulled the bond between body and graft. Fursen endured the pain in silence, focusing on the Names to distract himself from what was being done to his jaw.

When it was finished, he had two new teeth. Diamond, cut to perfect Leonin dentition. Harder than bone, sharper than nature intended.

Thresh shook his hand with their six-fingered left hand. The grip was warm and cold at once, smooth and scaled and soft.

"You are welcome back," they said. "Anytime. For anything."

Fursen left with diamond teeth and one more name to carry.

The Silken Refuge

Night found Fursen in the Sprawl.

He told himself he was just walking. Just exploring the city. Just getting a feel for its geography, its rhythms, its hidden corners.

He told himself many things.

The Silken Refuge occupied a three-story building of dark timber, its sign depicting a silk ribbon curling around a candle flame. Warm amber light glowed from curtained windows. Two figures lounged near the entrance â€” not guards, officially, but the message was clear.

Fursen entered.

The common room was warm, dim, comfortable. Velvet settees in deep reds and purples. Low tables with candles. The smell of sandalwood and something floral. Soft music from somewhere unseen.

A woman greeted him â€” human, fair-skinned, freckled, warm auburn hair. Tessa, she said her name was. She didn't stare at him the way the merchants had. She just smiled, as if Leonin walked through her door every day.

"First time here?"

"Yes."

"Then let me show you what we offer."

She led him through the establishment, introducing him to the workers who were available that evening. Fursen's eyes kept returning to two in particular.

Scarlet. Tiefling. Dusky skin, dark curls, amber eyes that glowed faintly in dim light. Bold. Playful. The kind of confidence that made him forget he was the last of his kind.

Cinder. Dragonborn. Copper scales that caught firelight beautifully. Quiet. Intense. Warmth radiating from her like a furnace banked for the night.

"Both," he said. "For the night."

Tessa's smile widened. "Excellent choices."

The Night

What happened in the Silken Refuge stayed in the Silken Refuge.

But Fursen would remember it. The fire meeting fire. Scarlet's boldness, her teasing, the way her tail traced patterns on his thigh. Cinder's quiet intensity, her scales running furnace-hot against his fur, the strength she held in check with visible effort.

Between them, he forgot.

Forgot the Names burning in his skull. Forgot the teeth the Crawler had taken. Forgot that he was the last of his kind, carrying an extinct people's history in his head while their killers still walked the world.

For one night, he was just a body. Fur and muscle and breath. Held between two people who knew exactly what they were doing.

The Morning

He stayed for breakfast.

Scarlet stole food from his plate, grinning around a mouthful of bread. Cinder's foot pressed against his thigh under the table â€” steady warmth that hadn't faded with the dawn.

They talked. Actually talked. About grief. About presence. About why Fursen was "actually here" unlike most clients who pretended it meant nothing.

"You carry something," Scarlet said. "I don't know what. But you're not hiding from it â€” you're just... taking a breath."

Fursen didn't answer. He didn't need to.

The Parting

"Diamond teeth and claws." Scarlet's voice was warm as they said goodbye. "I'm keeping you."

She leaned close, whispered in his ear.

"If you survive whatever you're doing out there... come back. I mean it. Most clients, I forget their faces by morning. I won't forget yours."

Cinder gave him something more tangible. A scale. Copper, palm-sized, shed naturally. Still warm.

"For luck," she said. "And for remembering."

Madame Veshra Coil â€” the woman who ran the Refuge â€” spoke to him at the bar as he left.

"You treated my girls well. They speak highly of you â€” and they don't say that about most."

Veshra's smile carried warmth and warning in equal measure. "You're welcome back. Anytime. No payment required â€” just company and stories."

She paused.

"A Leonin. I thought your people were gone... I'm glad to see I was wrong."

Fursen left the Silken Refuge with a copper scale in his pocket and an open invitation to return.

Some things couldn't be bought with gold. Some things had to be earned.

Part 5 â€” Revelations

Seraphine's Trail

Sol found Velvet Thorn in the common room that evening.

"I'm looking for someone," he said. "A woman named Seraphine Vale. She might have passed through recently."

Velvet's expression shifted â€” recognition, assessment, the calculation of what information to share and what to withhold.

"Seraphine Vale. Yes. She was here." A pause. "Twelve days ago."

"Do you know where she went?"

"She visited the Docent's Archive. Spent a full day there. When she came back..." Velvet's voice trailed off. "She looked like she'd seen a ghost. Pale. Shaken. Whatever she found in those records, it broke something in her."

"And then?"

"She left. Heading south. Toward the Bastion of Fireblood." Velvet's eyes met Sol's empty sockets. "I don't know if she's still alive. But if she crossed that border... Kaedris knows everything that enters her domain."

Sol thanked her. Filed the information away. Seraphine Vale â€” the broken inquisitor who carried Mira's sword â€” had come here seeking answers and found something worse.

They would need to visit the Docent themselves. But first, there was one more conversation to have.

Velara's History

That night, Sol retreated to his room and called to the amulet.

"Velara. I need you to tell me about Kaedris. About the Bastion. About what you stole and why."

The amulet pulsed. Velara's voice emerged not as sound, but as impression â€” images and emotions transmitted directly into Sol's consciousness.

...she was human once... a poet... she felt things so deeply the world couldn't contain them...

Images flickered: A woman. Young. Beautiful in the way fire is beautiful. Writing verses that made people weep, laugh, rage, fall in love. Feeling everything so intensely that ordinary life was torture.

...when the Usurpation came... she took the Maker's heart... claimed it for herself...

The images shifted: The murder of Aedwynn. Thirteen mortals dividing divine flesh. And one woman â€” the poet, the lover â€” cutting the heart from the Maker's chest with her own hands. Not for power. For feeling. For the ability to make the whole world feel as she did.

...the bastion isn't a place... it's literally her heart... what she carved from Aedwynn became her domain...

More images: A realm of endless passion. Love and hate. Joy and despair. Ecstasy and agony. Everything felt to the extreme, always, forever. The people who lived there burned with emotion until they were consumed by it.

...she found a way to spread it... passion-seeds... fragments of concentrated feeling harvested from the heart...

The black stone Jonas had found. The thing that had made Fursen's eyes water when he touched it.

...one seed can ignite a city... make everyone feel everything at maximum intensity until they tear each other apart or collapse from the overwhelming sensation...

Sol felt cold spreading through his bones.

...a hundred seeds could burn the world... and she was breeding them... growing them... preparing for something she called the Conflagration...

"The stone we found. The black one. That's a passion-seed?"

...not just any seed... that's the original... the first one she cut from Aedwynn's heart... without it, the others are just echoes... with it, she can finish what she started five hundred years ago...

"And you stole it."

...i loved her once... and she loved me... as much as something like her can love...

Velara's voice carried grief that transcended centuries.

...but i saw what she was becoming... what she wanted to become... so i ran... took the seed... hired the morrow company to take me as far as possible...

"What happened to the caravan?"

...she sent something to retrieve what was stolen... a shape in the heat shimmer... a woman made of fire... she found us in the bone field...

Images of screaming. Burning. People dying from the inside out, consumed by passion that wasn't their own.

...i was already dead when she arrived... the soul anchor saved my consciousness... trapped me here for five hundred years...

"And now we've found you. And the seed."

...and if you take it to the bastion... she'll feel it the moment it crosses the border... she'll unmake me... she'll unmake you... she'll unmake everything...

Sol sat in silence for a long moment.

They carried a fragment of a murdered god's heart. A weapon that could burn the world. A soul trapped for five centuries. And somewhere to the south, a Sovereign waited for the return of what had been stolen.

They wouldn't take her to the Bastion. They would go to the Docent. Find out what to do with the seed.

The amulet pulsed with gratitude â€” warm, desperate, hopeful.

Inside, Velara Ashyn wept tears she no longer had.

Session Conclusion

The Weight of What We Carry

They gathered in Sol's room that night â€” three survivors of Veinspire, three travelers who had crossed the Gap and the Bone Field and found something they didn't understand.

On the table between them: the passion-seed. Black. Spherical. Drinking in the lamplight without giving anything back.

A fragment of Aedwynn's heart. Carved by Kaedris during the Usurpation. One seed could ignite a city. A hundred could burn the world. They had been carrying it for two weeks without knowing what it was.

Velara had stolen it five hundred years ago to prevent something called the Conflagration. Kaedris had been looking for it ever since. And Seraphine Vale â€” the broken inquisitor who carried Oathkeeper, who had buried Kael â€” had come to Crownfall twelve days ago, visited the Archive, and left looking like she'd seen a ghost. Headed south. Into Kaedris's domain.

She might already be dead.

Tomorrow, they would visit the Docent. Figure out what to do with the seed. Decide what came next.

The lamp guttered. The shadows lengthened. And somewhere in the darkness, gods old and new turned their attention toward Crownfall.

Toward three survivors who carried too many secrets.

Toward the road that lay ahead.

Thematic Elements

The Weight of Pursuit:

From Veinspire's walls to the Bone Field, the party has been hunted. Ardian's gaze. The Hollow Crawler's patient stalking. Vor'Kael's attention settling on them like the weight of an empty sky. They are prey now, whether they want to be or not.

What We Carry:

Ten thousand names. A passion-seed. A murdered god's memory. A soul trapped for five centuries. Each member of the party carries something that doesn't belong to them â€” burdens that were given, stolen, or inherited from the dead.

Sanctuary and Its Price:

Crownfall offers safety. No Sovereign's power reaches here. But safety isn't free â€” it comes with questions asked and unanswered, with information traded like currency, with the knowledge that eventually, sanctuary ends.

Memory as Currency:

Fursen paid for diamond teeth with the Names. Thresh asked to be remembered. Velara has been waiting five hundred years for someone to find her. In a world built from murdered divinity, memory might be the only thing that truly lasts.

What the Party Doesn't Know

1. Vor'Kael's Response: The Hollow Empress is not patient. She is already preparing something â€” not another scout, but something worse. Something that will make the Crawler look like a warning shot.

2. The Passion-Seed's Proximity: Kaedris hasn't felt the seed yet â€” Crownfall is outside her domain, and the Unclaimed territories don't carry her awareness. But if they approach the Bastion's border, even by accident, she will know immediately.

3. Seraphine's Discovery: What Seraphine found in the Docent's Archive broke her understanding of herself, her faith, and her purpose. She went east to confront something. Whether she survived that confrontation remains to be seen.

4. The Docent's Nature: The Docent is older than Crownfall. Older than the Usurpation. He was there when Aedwynn was murdered. He knows things that could reshape the party's understanding of everything â€” if they ask the right questions.

5. Ultharion's Patience: The Obsidian Shepherd is content to track Fursen through records and observation. He doesn't need to hurry. He has been hunting for two thousand years. A few more weeks mean nothing.

"Three survivors crossed the Gap with a god's heart fragment in their pockets. One carries the names of the dead. One carries the hunger of a cursed blade. One carries the memory of creation itself. They think they've found sanctuary. They haven't. Sanctuary is just another word for 'not yet.'"

items.title: Session 22: The Docent's Archive
items.content:
Session 22 â€” The Docent's Archive

Session Overview

Session Number: 22
Party Level: 10
Location: Crownfall (The Velvet Thorn, The Exchange, The Kennels, The Spillway, The Threshold, The Silken Refuge, The Docent's Archive)
Party Members: Sol Raven, Jonas, Fursen
Deaths This Session: None
Theme: Preparation, secrets, healing, betrayal of trust

Part One â€” Morning at the Velvet Thorn

Day 16 â€” The Questions Begin

Grey light filtered through the windows of the Velvet Thorn. The smell of bacon and bread drifted up from the common room. Crownfall woke slowly around them â€” merchants setting up stalls, guards changing shifts on the district walls, the low murmur of a city that belonged to no god.

The common room was quiet at this hour. A few early risers nursing cups of something hot. Velvet herself stood behind the bar, polishing glasses with the efficiency of long habit.

Fursen approached her first.

"We need to find the Docent's Archive," he said. "Can you give us directions?"

Velvet looked up, silver-white hair catching the morning light. She set down her glass.

"North side of the Coin, near the old Coinhall. Can't miss it â€” looks like it should've fallen down fifty years ago. Stone building, no sign. Doors are always open during daylight."

She studied Fursen for a moment with those assessing eyes.

"Word of advice. The Docent doesn't do small talk. State your business, be respectful, don't touch anything without asking. He's... particular."

The Docent

Fursen pressed further. "What do you know about him? Have you met him before?"

Velvet paused. Set down the glass.

"Met him? Twice. Both times I needed something only he could provide."

She leaned against the bar, arms folded.

"What do I know? Same as everyone who's been in this city long enough. He was here before I was born. Before my mother was born, probably. The Archive needed a keeper, and one day there he was. No one knows where he came from. No one asks anymore."

Her voice dropped slightly â€” not secretive, just thoughtful.

"He doesn't age. Doesn't eat, far as anyone can tell. Doesn't leave the building. Just... reads. Catalogues. Remembers everything."

She picked up the glass again, turned it in her hands.

"The Houses respect his neutrality because it's useful. But I think they're also a little afraid of him. Three hundred years of secrets in that building, and he knows where every one of them is shelved."

A dry almost-smile.

"He's not unkind. Just... not interested in people. He's interested in what they know. If you have something worth knowing, he'll talk to you all day. If you don't..."

She shrugged.

"He'll still help. But it'll cost you. Information for information. That's how he trades."

The Burned Hand

Fursen's eyes dropped to Velvet's hands. One of them â€” the left â€” was blackened from fingertips to wrist. The skin tight, the texture of old leather left too long in the sun. It didn't look burned exactly. It looked scorched. From the inside out.

"Your hand," he said. "It's black. Why? Is it from birth?"

Velvet's hands stilled on the glass.

For a moment, she didn't answer. Then she raised the blackened hand, studied it as if seeing it for the first time.

"Got too close to the fire."

She said it simply. No bitterness. No elaboration.

Her eyes met Fursen's.

"Some borders aren't meant to be crossed. I learned that lesson young."

She lowered the hand, picked up her polishing cloth again.

"Thirty-one years ago. Hasn't spread. Hasn't healed. Just... is."

The conversation was clearly over. She returned to her glass, her movements unhurried, her face composed.

But something in the set of her shoulders suggested the question touched something she doesn't often think about.

The Hollow

Jonas stepped forward.

"Do you know what happens to be at the Hollow?"

Velvet frowned slightly. The expression of someone used to knowing things.

"The Hollow?"

She shook her head.

"Can't say I have. The deep Unclaimed has a hundred places with a hundred names â€” most of them change depending on who you ask."

She set the glass on the rack behind her.

"Where'd you hear about it?"

Jonas didn't answer. The folio from The Dealer sat heavy in his pack â€” three days southeast, something worse than what guards it.

Some questions were better left for other sources.

Part Two â€” The Party Splits

The morning stretched ahead. They had business to attend to before visiting the Archive.

Jonas and Sol headed for the Exchange to sell their gems. Fursen made for the Kennels â€” he had questions for Thresh.

Jonas & Sol â€” Marek's Stall

The Exchange sprawled across several blocks near Coinhall Plaza â€” a maze of stalls, tents, and semi-permanent shops where anything could be bought or sold.

Marek's stall wasn't hard to find. A simple wooden counter beneath a canvas awning, display cases showing cut gems arranged by type and quality. Behind the counter sat a dwarf with a grey beard that reached his belt, a jeweler's loupe hanging from a chain around his neck.

He didn't smile when they approached. Didn't frown either. Just looked at them with the flat assessment of someone who's been cheated before and learned to spot it coming.

"Buying or selling?"

His voice was like gravel in a bucket.

"Selling," Sol said. "We've come to show you some valuable gems we've gotten our hands on."

"Let's see what you've got."

Sol produced the gems from the party's collection â€” laying them out on the worn wooden counter.

Marek's thick fingers moved with surprising delicacy. He picked up each stone in turn, held it to the light, peered through the loupe. His face betrayed nothing.

The rubies first. Four of them, deep red. He turned each one, checking for inclusions, clarity, cut.

Then the sapphires. Three blue stones. Same process â€” methodical, unhurried.

He set down the loupe. Looked at Sol and Jonas.

"The rubies are decent. Not exceptional â€” minor inclusions, but good color. Forty gold each. Hundred sixty for the lot."

He tapped the sapphires.

"These are better. Clean cuts, good saturation. Hundred gold each. Three hundred."

He swept the diamonds aside â€” they'd already used two for Fursen's teeth.

"Eight hundred sixty gold for everything. That's a fair price â€” not generous, not a cheat."

His flat eyes moved between them.

"Selling all, some, or just wanted the appraisal?"

"All of it."

Marek nodded. No haggling. No games.

He reached beneath the counter and produced a lockbox. Counted out the coin with practiced efficiency â€” stacks of ten, neat and precise. Gold clicked against wood.

"Count it if you like. I don't short people."

He slid the stacks across the counter. Swept the gems into a velvet pouch that disappeared beneath his apron.

"Pleasure doing business."

His face still hadn't changed expression. The transaction was complete. He was already looking past them toward the next potential customer.

GOLD ACQUIRED: 860gp

Sol â€” The Hall of Mending

Jonas headed back toward the Velvet Thorn with the gold. Sol had other business.

He produced a key from somewhere and moved to a cabinet behind the counter â€” one Jonas hadn't noticed before. The wood was darker, older. The lock clicked with a sound like a sigh.

"Let me show you what I keep for serious buyers."

He laid items out on the counter, one by one. Rings, bracers, cloaks, blades. Jonas's eyes settled on one.

Ring of Alertness
Ring, Uncommon (Requires Attunement)
While wearing this ring, you can't be surprised while conscious, and you have advantage on initiative rolls.
"Four hundred gold."

Jonas pointed to the ring.

"The Ring of Alertness."

"The ring. Good choice."

The Dealer plucked it from the counter, held it up to the dim light.

"Can't be surprised. Always ready. For a man with your enemies, that might be the difference between waking up and not."

He extended his palm. Jonas counted out four hundred gold. The coins disappeared into a lockbox beneath the counter.

The Dealer slid the ring across.

"Wear it in good health. Or at least, in continued survival."

Jonas thanked him and left.

ITEM ACQUIRED: Ring of Alertness
Ring, Uncommon (Requires Attunement)
While wearing this ring, you can't be surprised while conscious, and you have advantage on initiative rolls.
GOLD SPENT: 400gp

Part Five â€” Day 17

Morning â€” Jonas's Room

Jonas woke to pain.

Not the dull ache of old wounds or the stiffness of sleeping in armor. This was sharp. Urgent. A pulse of cold fire radiating from his hip where the Bleeding Blade rested against the nightstand.

Hungry.

The word rose unbidden in his mind. Not a voice â€” just knowing. The blade hadn't fed since yesterday. It was reminding him.

The Ring of Alertness hummed faintly on his finger. No threats. Just the sword's appetite.

Grey morning light filtered through the window. The chair still wedged under the door. The room undisturbed.

But the blade wanted. And it would take from him if he didn't give it something else.

THE BLEEDING BLADE â€” Requires feeding today or Jonas takes 2d10 necrotic damage at dusk.

Morning â€” The Silken Refuge

Fursen woke to warmth.

Flame was still curled against him â€” her head tucked beneath his chin, her tail wrapped loosely around his calf. The purring had stopped, replaced by the soft rhythm of her breathing.

Morning light slanted through the curtains, catching the gold in her fur, the delicate cuffs on her ears.

She stirred as he moved. Those amber eyes opened slowly, blinked once, focused on his face.

"You stayed."

Not surprise. Just... acknowledgment. Like she was confirming something to herself.

She stretched â€” a long, feline motion that pressed her body against his â€” then sat up.

"Go. Do whatever dangerous thing you're doing today."

A pause. Her hand found his jaw, turned his face toward her.

"Come back alive."

Fursen â€” Madame Veshra Coil

Madame Veshra Coil was in the common room, speaking quietly with Old Nara behind the bar. She looked up as Fursen descended the stairs.

He crossed to her. Placed gold on the bar â€” ten stacks of ten, glinting in the morning light.

"Pay them well. They've earned it."

Veshra looked at the gold. Then at him.

For a moment, her expression was unreadable. Then something shifted â€” respect, perhaps. Or recognition of a kindred spirit.

"I told you. Your gold's no good here."

She didn't touch the coins.

"But..."

She slid the gold back toward him. Took fifty. Left fifty.

"Half goes to them. The other half, you keep. You'll need it for whatever comes next."

She met his eyes. That iron gaze, tempered by something warmer.

"Flame spoke well of you this morning. So did Scarlet and Cinder before. That means something in this house."

She pocketed the fifty gold.

"They'll get their share. And they'll know who it came from."

A pause.

"Go do what you need to do, Leonin. The Refuge will be here when you're done."

GOLD SPENT: 50gp (Veshra returned the other 50)

The Walk to the Archive â€” The Betrayal

The three of them converged near the Velvet Thorn. Morning light. The smell of bread from nearby stalls. Crownfall waking around them.

Fursen fell into step beside his companions. As they walked, he talked. Easy. Casual.

"Flame of Passion. That's her name â€” she chose it herself. Tabaxi, tawny fur, golden eyes..."

He described the night. The room with its amber silk. The way she moved like water. How she purred against his chest afterward and asked him to stay.

His hand reached out as he talked â€” a companionable gesture, one hand on Sol's shoulder, one on Jonas's. Near the neck. Casual. The kind of touch that says we're in this together.

His right hand â€” the one on Jonas â€” pressed briefly against bare skin above the collar.

The salve was warm. Odorless. It absorbed quickly.

Jonas's shoulder tensed. Something prickled at the edge of his awareness â€” instinct, maybe, or just the lingering distrust that never fully healed after Lastwell.

He shoved Fursen's hand away. Hard.

"Get off me."

The words came out flat. Not angry â€” just done.

Fursen stumbled back a half-step, hands raised. Placating.

"Easy, brother. Just walking."

But it didn't matter.

The salve was already absorbed. Those few seconds of contact â€” while Fursen talked about Flame's golden eyes, while Jonas was half-listening â€” were enough. The Moonbind sank into skin before Jonas even thought to react.

Jonas rubbed at his neck. Frowned. There's nothing there. No residue. No sensation.

Just Fursen being too familiar. As usual.

He kept walking. Didn't look back.

Fursen fell back half a step. Wiped his palm against his loincloth.

Done.

MOONBIND SALVE â€” APPLIED
- Target: Jonas
- Duration: 24 hours
- Effect: Emotional dampening. Dulled temper. May feel drowsy toward the end of the duration.
- Jonas is unaware.

The Docent's Archive

The Archive rose ahead of them. Crumbling stone. Open doors. The smell of old secrets.

They entered.

Vela Thorne sat at her usual table near the entrance. She looked up as they entered â€” hope flickering across her face, then fading when she saw it was them, not Seraphine.

"He's been waiting for you. Said you'd come this morning."

She gestured toward the deep stacks.

"He's... different today. I don't know how to explain it. Just... be careful what you ask for."

The Docent emerged from the shadows between shelves. He looked the same â€” dust-colored robes, ink-stained fingers, eyes that have read too many things.

But there was something in his bearing. A weight.

In his hands: the amulet. The passion-seed, wrapped in cloth.

"Thou hast returned."

He set both items on a reading table between them.

"I have answers. Some thou wilt wish to hear. Others..."

He looked at each of them in turn.

"Others will make thy path harder, not easier."

He folded his hands.

"Where wouldst thou have me begin?"

Thematic Elements

Trust and Betrayal: Fursen made a choice to drug his companion without consent. He believes he's helping â€” Jonas's temper has caused problems, cost them gold, drawn attention. But the Moonbind Salve represents a violation of trust. If Jonas discovers what was done to him, the fragile reconciliation since Lastwell may shatter completely.

The Price of Healing: Sol's Possibility infection is cured â€” but the cure came with a cost. He traded a piece of the world's lost beauty to Sister Varen, gave away something precious and irreplaceable. And the door remains open. The voices are quiet, not gone.

Sanctuary's Secrets: Crownfall is older than anyone knew. Founded by refugees two thousand years ago, protected by a barrier that blinds divine sight. Sister Varen was there at the beginning. The Docent was there before the beginning. This city holds more secrets than its citizens realize.

The Weight of Weapons: The Pulsehammer is wrong â€” time folded back on itself, touched by too many Sovereigns. The Dealer refused to buy it, refused to even have it in his shop. Some things are too dangerous to sell. Some things can only be buried or carried until they destroy you.

Questions Raised

  • What will Jonas do when the salve wears off?
  • Will he discover what Fursen did?
  • What answers does the Docent have about the passion-seed?
  • What happened to the Leonin who escaped Imhuran's purge?
  • How will Jonas feed the Bleeding Blade today?
  • What did Seraphine find in the Archive that sent her east?

"Three survivors walked into an archive carrying secrets.
One carried a cured infection and an open door.
One carried a drugged bloodstream and didn't know it.
One carried the guilt of what he'd done to help.
They came for answers.
They weren't ready for what answers cost."

â€” Whispered in the spaces between trust and betrayal

items.title: Session 23: The Hollow
items.content:
Session 23 â€” The Hollow

Session Overview

Day 17-19 | Location: Crownfall â†’ The Unclaimed â†’ The Hollow | Party: Sol Raven, Jonas, Fursen

Theme: Trust, confession, failure, loss

Part One â€” Leaving Crownfall

The Docent's Warning

The Docent stood before them, dust-colored robes hanging from shoulders that had borne the weight of three centuries of secrets. He had spent the night researching the passion-seed.

"The seed thou carriest is not merely a fragment. 'Tis the original. The first cutting from Aedwynn's Left Heart, harvested before Kaedris shaped the rest into her throne."

One seed could ignite a city â€” make every soul feel so strongly they combust from within. A hundred seeds could burn kingdoms. With the original template, Kaedris could burn the world.

Velara's Promise

Velara Ashyn stirred in the soul anchor amulet. She agreed to guide the purification of the passion-seed â€” stripping away what Kaedris had added, returning it to what it was before the corruption. But she needed a place where the Maker's touch still lingered.

"When the seed is clean, I want to rest. Five hundred years, Sol. I am so tired."

Part Two â€” Night Ambush

The Moonbind Salve

During first watch, Fursen's attention wandered â€” thoughts of Flame of Passion, the weight of ten thousand names. He missed the signs.

Jonas took second watch. The Moonbind Salve's drowsy side effects pulled at him, his eyelids heavy, his thoughts slow. He fought it, but the fog wouldn't lift.

Cindermaw Attack

Three shapes at the edge of the firelight. Bodies like embers wrapped in shadow â€” cracked black skin with molten orange pulsing beneath. Cindermaws. They attacked before Jonas could raise the alarm.

The fight was brutal. Fire and fang and the hiss of steam. When the creatures died, they burst â€” magma spraying across the campsite. The party survived, but the salve's drowsiness had nearly cost them everything.

Part Three â€” The Confession

Day 18 â€” The Truth

Fursen told Jonas everything. The Moonbind Salve. Senna's shop in the Spillway. The moment on the walk to the Archive â€” hand on Jonas's neck, the compound absorbing before Jonas even knew to pull away.

He told him why. The temper. The gold lost to outbursts. The fear that one day Jonas's rage would get them killed.

He asked for forgiveness.

Forgiveness

Jonas accepted the apology. His voice was level â€” not the forced calm of the salve, but something harder. Earned.

He told Fursen not to try such things again. Then he held out his hand.

Fursen placed the clay pot in his palm. The Moonbind Salve â€” six doses remaining.

Jonas pocketed it without another word. They kept walking.

Part Four â€” The Hollow

Day 19 â€” The Coast

Grey cliffs. Grey water. Grey sky pressing down on both. A dark opening in the cliff face â€” roughly fifteen feet high, twenty feet wide. Bones lay scattered near the entrance.

When the waves struck just right, the cave exhaled â€” a deep, resonant boom like the voice of something vast and empty.

The Hollow. Oathbreaker's End. The smith's final work.

The Gallery

Inside: carvings covering the walls. The story of a smith who worked Kaedris's forges. Who made weapons of atrocity. Who fled. Who died trying to forge something to undo his sins.

The final carving: a man alone in a cave. A hammer raised. An anvil waiting. And scratched beneath in frantic letters: "HAVE TO FINISH"

The Allips

The temperature dropped. Two shapes coalesced from the darkness â€” formless silhouettes whispering fragments of guilt.

"...she burned them from the inside..."
"...I made the tools..."
"...couldn't stay... couldn't watch..."

Allips â€” remnants of those who died with terrible secrets. The party destroyed them, but the whispers lingered.

The Workshop Echo

A figure at the center of a chamber â€” translucent, shimmering. The smith, working in silence. His hammer fell on metal that refused to take form. When he noticed them, he reached out â€” not threatening, pleading.

"...not finished... have to finish... she'll use them..."

Then he was gone. Jonas found spectral residue where the ghost had stood â€” crystallized memory, worth 200gp to the right buyer.

Part Five â€” The Smoldering Forge

The Sealed Door

A massive stone door carved with Bastion symbols. Kaedris's sigils flared white-hot as Jonas set his shoulder against it.

Athletics Check: Natural 20.

The door split down the center. The sigils faded to nothing. The way was open.

The Smoldering Remnant

He rose from the forge itself. Not climbing â€” forming. A figure of cracked black iron with molten orange bleeding through the fissures. Eyes like forge-coals. He flickered between states: SMOLDERING â€” burning, furious, relentless. HOLLOW â€” frozen, sorrowful, desperate.

In his hand: a spectral hammer. Behind him: the anvil. And on the anvil â€” Oathbreaker's End.

"...can't let you take it... not finished... NEVER FINISHED..."

The Battle

They fought. The Remnant was relentless â€” Forge Breath filling the chamber with fire, Quench turning the water to scalding steam. His hammer fell again and again.

And then â€” Jonas went down.

The Fall

The hammer caught him square. SMOLDERING state. Full force. The first blow staggered him. The second dropped him to his knees. The thirdâ€”

Jonas's body hit the water. The Bleeding Blade slipped from his fingers.

The Remnant stood over him, hollow now. "...another one... always another one..."

Session Conclusion

The Retreat

Fursen and Sol ran. Back through the antechamber. Up the stairs. Out into grey light and salt wind.

Two survivors where three had entered.

Jonas was still inside. His body. His blade. The Ring of Alertness. The Pulsehammer. Vor'Kael's true name. The Moonbind Salve. All of it â€” still in the Hollow, with the thing that killed him.

Oathbreaker's End remained on the anvil. Unfinished. Unclaimed.

ðŸ’€ Jonas â€” Dead

Their last exchange was one of reconciliation, not resentment. Fursen had confessed. Jonas had chosen to forgive. In the Ashen Realms, that meant something.

Items Lost

  • The Bleeding Blade â€” Legendary cursed longsword, now ownerless
  • Ring of Alertness â€” Can't be surprised
  • Pulsehammer â€” Time-touched weapon
  • Vor'Kael's True Name â€” Ultimate leverage, now in the Hollow
  • Moonbind Salve (6 doses)
  • Spectral Residue â€” ~200gp value

Unfinished Business

  • Oathbreaker's End still on anvil, guarded by Remnant
  • Jonas's body in forge chamber with all gear
  • Vor'Kael's true name â€” dangerous if found
  • The Bleeding Blade â€” cursed weapon, ownerless, hungry
  • Passion-seed purification â€” no place of the Maker's touch found yet
items.raw: Session 23 â€” The Hollow. Day 17-19. Party left Crownfall for The Hollow. Cindermaw ambush on night one. Fursen confessed to drugging Jonas with Moonbind Salve; Jonas forgave him. Explored The Hollow dungeon. Fought Allips. Encountered the Smoldering Remnant boss. Jonas killed by the Remnant. Fursen and Sol fled. Jonas's body remains in the forge with The Bleeding Blade, Ring of Alertness, Pulsehammer, and Vor'Kael's true name.
